content.text: 11.6	Expenses and Costs.
content.caption: Expenses and Costs.

content.text: 11.6.1	Leasing Costs, Security Deposits and Prepaid Rents.  Leasing Costs shall be allocated as provided in Section 7.3, and security deposits and prepaid rents shall be credited as set forth in Section 7.4.
content.caption: Leasing Costs, Security Deposits and Prepaid Rents.

section_hierarchy.caption: Leasing Costs, Security Deposits and Prepaid Rents.

content.text: 11.6.2	Seller Closing Costs.  Seller shall pay: (a) 50% of the Escrow Agent’s escrow fee; (b) the premium for the standard coverage portion of the premium for the Title Policy and any related sales tax; (c) the cost of recording the Deed; (d) those commissions, if any, payable by Seller pursuant to Section 1.15; and (e) any additional costs and charges customarily charged to sellers in accordance with common escrow practices in the state and county in which the Property is located.
content.caption: Seller Closing Costs.

content.text: 11.6.3	Buyer Closing Costs.  Buyer shall pay: (a) 50% of the Escrow Agent’s escrow fee; (b) the premium for the extended coverage portion of the premium for the Title Policy and the costs of any endorsements Buyer may require and any related sales tax; (c) those commissions, if any, payable by Buyer pursuant to Section 1.15; and (d) any additional costs and charges customarily charged to purchasers in accordance with common escrow practices in the state and county in which the Property is located.  In addition to the foregoing, Buyer shall be solely responsible for any costs incurred in connection with Buyer’s Due Diligence investigations of the Property, including Inspections and Surveys.
content.caption: Buyer Closing Costs.

content.text: 11.6.4	Other Expenses and Legal Costs.  Except as provided above, each party hereto shall pay its own expenses incurred in connection with this Agreement and the transactions contemplated hereby, including in the case of Buyer, all third-party engineering and environmental review costs incurred by or on behalf of Buyer, its inspection costs and Due Diligence costs.  Each party shall pay for the costs of their respective counsel in connection with Closing and this transaction.
content.caption: Other Expenses and Legal Costs.

content.text: 11.7	Prorations.
content.caption: Prorations.

content.text: 11.7.1	Proration Items.  Seller and Buyer agree to adjust, as of 11:59 pm ***INSERT LOCAL TIME*** on the day immediately preceding the Closing Date, all revenue and expenses relating to the Property (“Proration Items”), including  the following:  (a) real estate taxes and assessments (including any adjustments to real estate taxes and assessments and refunds of any payments thereof that are made following the Closing but relate to periods of time prior to Closing, which obligation will survive the Closing); (b) expenses already incurred by Seller that relate to services to be provided to the Property after the Closing Date and all fees and charges under the Assumed Contracts; and (c) all rentals and other income derived from the Property (including operating costs and other tenant reimbursements).  Seller will be charged and credited for the amounts of all of the Proration Items relating to the period up to and including 11:59 pm ***INSERT LOCAL TIME*** on the day immediately preceding the Closing Date, and Buyer will be charged and credited for all of the Proration Items relating to the period on and after the Closing Date.
content.caption: Proration Items.

content.text: 11.7.2	Method of Proration.  For purposes of calculating prorations, Buyer shall be deemed to hold title to the Property and be entitled to the income therefrom and responsible for the expenses thereof for the entire day upon which the Closing occurs.  All such prorations shall be made on the basis of the actual number of days of the month that shall have elapsed as of the day of the Closing and based upon the actual number of days in the month and a 365 day year.
content.caption: Method of Proration.

content.text: 11.7.3	Items Not Prorated.  Seller and Buyer agree that: (a) none of the insurance policies relating to the Property will be assigned to Buyer and Buyer shall be responsible for arranging for its own insurance as of the Closing Date; (b) utilities, including telephone, electricity, water and gas, shall be read on the Closing Date, and Buyer shall be responsible for all the necessary actions needed to arrange for meters to be read and utilities to be changed to the name of Buyer on the Closing Date, including the posting of any required deposits; provided, however, that Seller shall be entitled to a credit at the Closing for any utility deposits which it or its predecessors have made prior to the Closing Date, to the extent the same are transferred to Buyer.  Seller shall be entitled to recover and retain from the providers of such utilities any refunds or overpayments to the extent applicable to the period prior to the Closing Date, and any utility deposits for which it does not receive a credit hereunder.  If accounts are not set up in Buyer’s name on the Closing Date, all charges for such utilities shall be prorated outside of escrow within 60 days after the Closing Date.
content.caption: Items Not Prorated.

content.text: 11.8	Closing Statement.  The estimated Closing costs, allocations and prorations shall be set forth on a preliminary closing statement to be prepared by the Escrow Agent and submitted to the parties for their reasonable approval at least 5 Business Days prior to the Closing Date.  The parties shall then use reasonable, diligent and good faith efforts to agree upon the final closing statement that is consistent with the terms of this Agreement at least 2 Business Days prior to the Closing Date (“Closing Statement”). If, despite using reasonable, diligent and good faith efforts, the parties are unable to reach agreement on the Closing Statement at least 2 Business Days prior to the Closing Date, either party by written notice to the other party may elect to extend the Closing Date to such date that is 2 Business Days after the date on which the parties reach agreement upon the Closing Statement.
content.caption: Closing Statement.

content.text: 11.9	Reconciliation.  Any item which cannot be finally allocated or prorated because of the unavailability of information shall be tentatively prorated on the basis of the best data then available and adjusted when the information is available.  Such allocations or prorations shall be initially performed by Seller and Buyer pursuant to the Closing Statement, but shall be subject to adjustment in cash after the Closing outside of escrow as and when complete and accurate information becomes available, if such information is not available at the Closing.  If the allocations and prorations made under the Closing Statement shall prove to be incorrect or incomplete for any reason, then either party shall be entitled to an adjustment to correct the same; provided, however, that any adjustment shall be made, if at all, within 90 days after the Closing Date, and if a party fails to request an adjustment to the Closing Statement by a written notice delivered to the other party within the applicable period set forth above (such notice to specify in reasonable detail the items within the Closing Statement that such party desires to adjust and the reasons for such adjustment), then the allocations and prorations set forth in the Closing Statement shall be binding and conclusive against such party.  Until final reconciliation under this Section, Buyer and its representatives and auditors shall be afforded reasonable access during normal business hours to Seller’s books and records with respect to the Property to confirm the accuracy of the Closing Statement.
content.caption: Reconciliation.

content.text: 11.10	Escrow Agent.  Escrow Agent executes this Agreement solely to evidence its agreement to hold escrowed funds in accordance with the terms and conditions of this Agreement.  The following provisions shall control with respect to the rights, duties and liabilities of Escrow Agent.  Escrow Agent acts hereunder as a depository only and is not responsible or liable in any manner whatsoever for the (a) sufficiency, correctness, genuineness or validity of any written instrument, notice or evidence of a party’s receipt of any instruction or notice which is received by Escrow Agent, or (b) identity or authority of any person executing such instruction notice or evidence.  Escrow Agent shall have no responsibility hereunder except for the performance by it in good faith of the acts to be performed by it hereunder, and Escrow Agent shall have no liability except for its own willful misconduct or gross negligence.  If a dispute arises between the parties with respect to the disposition of the Earnest Money Deposit or any other amounts held in escrow, Escrow Agent shall be entitled, at its own discretion, to deliver such amount to an appropriate court of law pending resolution of the dispute.  Escrow Agent shall invest the amount in escrow in accounts which are federally insured, which invest solely in government securities, or which are reasonably satisfactory to Seller and Buyer, and shall be applied in accordance with the terms of this Agreement.
content.caption: Escrow Agent.

content.text: 11.11	Escrow Instructions. Upon execution of this Agreement, the parties shall deposit an executed counterpart of this Agreement with the Escrow Agent, and this Agreement shall serve as escrow instructions to the Escrow Agent for consummation of the purchase and sale contemplated hereby.  Seller and Buyer agree to execute such reasonable additional and supplementary escrow instructions as may be appropriate to enable the Escrow Agent to comply with the terms of this Agreement; provided, however, that if there is any conflict between the provisions of this Agreement and any such supplementary escrow instructions, the terms of this Agreement shall control.
content.caption: Escrow Instructions.

content.text: 11.12	Designation of Reporting Person.  To assure compliance with the requirements of Section 6045(e) of the Code, the parties hereto agree as follows:
content.caption: Designation of Reporting Person.

content.text: 11.12.1	Reporting.  Provided that Escrow Agent executes a counterpart of this Agreement to evidence Escrow Agent’s agreement to assume all responsibilities for information reporting required under Section 6045(e) of the Code, Seller and Buyer shall designate the Escrow Agent as the person responsible for all information reporting under Section 6045(e) of the Code (“Reporting Person”).  If Escrow Agent refuses to execute a counterpart of this Agreement pursuant to which it agrees to be the Reporting Person, Seller and Buyer shall agree to appoint another third party as the Reporting Person.
content.caption: Reporting.

content.text: 11.12.2	Reporting Requirements.  Seller and Buyer shall each (a) provide to the Reporting Person all information and certifications regarding such party, as reasonably requested by the Reporting Person or otherwise required to be provided by a party to the transaction described herein under Section 6045 of the Code; (b)  provide to the Reporting Person such party’s taxpayer identification number and a statement (on Internal Revenue Service Form W-9 or an acceptable substitute form, or on any other form the applicable current or future Code sections and regulations might require and/or any form requested by the Reporting Person), signed under penalty of perjury, stating that the taxpayer identification number supplied by such party to the Reporting Person is correct; and (c) retain this Agreement for not less than 4 years from the end of the calendar year in which the Closing occurred, and to produce it to the Internal Revenue Service upon a valid request therefor.
content.caption: Reporting Requirements.

content.text: 12.	CAsualty and Condemnation
content.caption: CAsualty and Condemnation

content.text: 12.1	Minor Loss/Condemnation. Buyer shall be bound to purchase the Property for the full Purchase Price as required by the terms hereof, without regard to the occurrence or effect of any damage to the Property or condemnation of any portion of the Property, provided that: (a) the insured cost to repair any such damage or destruction, or the diminution in the value of the remaining Property as a result of a partial condemnation, equals $500,000 or less, (b) any such condemnation does not impair access to the Property, and (c) upon the Closing, there shall be a credit against the Purchase Price due hereunder equal to the amount of any insurance proceeds or condemnation awards collected by Seller prior to Closing as a result of any such damage or destruction or condemnation, plus the amount of any insurance deductible not recoverable under the Leases, less any sums expended by Seller toward the restoration or repair of the Property, including barricades and other temporary repairs required for safety purposes, or in collecting such insurance proceeds or condemnation awards.  If the proceeds or awards have not been collected as of the Closing, then no credit shall be given but such proceeds or awards shall be assigned to Buyer, except to the extent needed to reimburse Seller for sums expended prior to the Closing to repair or restore the Property or to collect any such proceeds or awards.
content.caption: Minor Loss/Condemnation.

content.text: 12.2	Major Loss/Condemnation. If the amount of the damage or destruction or condemnation as specified above exceeds $500,000 or such damage or destruction is not covered by insurance maintained by Seller or any condemnation impairs access to the Property, then Buyer may at its option, to be exercised by written notice to Seller within 10 Business Days after Seller’s notice to Buyer of the occurrence of the damage or destruction or the commencement of condemnation proceedings, terminate this Agreement or proceed with the purchase and sale transaction in accordance with the terms of this Agreement.  If Buyer does not elect to terminate this Agreement within said 10 Business Day period, Buyer shall be deemed to have elected to proceed with the purchase in accordance with this Agreement and to have waived its right to terminate.  If Buyer elects to terminate this Agreement within such 10 Business Day period, the Earnest Money Deposit shall be returned to Buyer and neither party shall have any further rights or obligations hereunder except for those obligations expressly stated to survive termination.  If Buyer elects to proceed with the purchase, Seller shall not be obligated to repair any damage or destruction and upon the Closing, there shall be a credit against the Purchase Price due hereunder equal to the amount of any uninsured loss, insurance proceeds or condemnation awards collected by Seller before Closing as a result of any such damage or destruction or condemnation, plus the amount of any insurance deductible not recoverable under the Leases, less any sums expended by Seller toward the restoration or repair of the Property, including barricades and other temporary repairs required for safety purposes, or in collecting such insurance proceeds or condemnation awards.  If the proceeds or awards have not been collected as of the Closing, then such proceeds or awards shall be assigned to Buyer, except to the extent needed to reimburse Seller for sums expended prior to the Closing to repair or restore the Property, including barricades and other temporary repairs required for safety purposes, or to collect any such proceeds or awards.
content.caption: Major Loss/Condemnation.

content.text: 13.	DEFAULT AND REMEDIES
content.caption: DEFAULT AND REMEDIES

content.text: 13.1	Seller Default.  If the sale of the Property is not consummated due to a default by Seller which is not cured within 5 Business Days after notice from Buyer (with the Closing Date extended as may be necessary to accommodate such cure period), then Buyer shall be entitled, as its sole remedy, to either (a) enforce specific performance of this Agreement and to recover from Seller any reasonable out-of-pocket costs incurred by Buyer in connection with such enforcement action, plus to the extent the default or breach by Seller was intentional or willful, recover any and all damages arising out of such intentional or willful default, or (b) terminate this Agreement and receive back the Earnest Money Deposit  and to recover from Seller an amount to compensate Buyer for costs incurred in connection with this Agreement, including Due Diligence costs, costs, losses and damages incurred to obtain financing, costs incurred pursuing joint ventures, costs of foregoing other business opportunities, and attorneys’ fees in an amount up to the Earnest Money Deposit (“Seller Breakage Fee”). THE PARTIES HAVE AGREED THAT BUYER’S DAMAGES IF BUYER ELECTS NOT TO PROCEED WITH CLOSING DUE TO AN UNCURED SELLER DEFAULT WOULD BE EXTREMELY DIFFICULT OR IMPRACTICABLE TO DETERMINE.  AFTER NEGOTIATION, THE PARTIES HAVE AGREED THAT, CONSIDERING ALL THE CIRCUMSTANCES EXISTING ON THE EFFECTIVE DATE OF THIS AGREEMENT, THE AMOUNT OF THE SELLER BREAKAGE FEE IS A REASONABLE ESTIMATE OF THE DAMAGES THAT BUYER WOULD INCUR IN SUCH EVENT, AND CONDITIONED UPON BUYER’S RECEIPT OF THE EARNEST MONEY DEPOSIT AND THE SELLER BREAKAGE FEE, BUYER SHALL BE DEEMED TO HAVE WAIVED ITS RIGHT TO RECOVER DAMAGES OR SEEK SPECIFIC PERFORMANCE AGAINST SELLER.  EACH PARTY CONFIRMS THE ACCURACY OF THE STATEMENTS MADE ABOVE AND THE FACT THAT EACH PARTY WAS REPRESENTED BY COUNSEL WHO EXPLAINED, AT THE TIME THIS AGREEMENT WAS MADE, THE CONSEQUENCES OF THIS LIQUIDATED DAMAGES PROVISION.  The foregoing in no way limits Buyer’s rights and remedies if Buyer first discovers after Closing a breach or default by Seller under this Agreement.
content.caption: Seller Default.

content.text: 13.2	Buyer Default; Liquidated Damages.  If the sale of the Property is not consummated due to a default by Buyer which is not cured within 5 Business Days after notice from Seller (with the Closing Date extended as may be necessary to accommodate such cure period), then Seller shall be entitled, as its sole remedy, to retain the Earnest Money Deposit as liquidated damages, this Agreement shall terminate and such termination shall release Buyer from any and all liability hereunder, except for those obligations of Buyer that expressly survive termination of this Agreement.  THE PARTIES HAVE AGREED THAT SELLER’S ACTUAL DAMAGES, IN THE EVENT OF A FAILURE TO CONSUMMATE THIS SALE WHEN LEGALLY OBLIGATED TO DO SO WOULD BE EXTREMELY DIFFICULT OR IMPRACTICABLE TO DETERMINE.  AFTER NEGOTIATION, THE PARTIES HAVE AGREED THAT, CONSIDERING ALL THE CIRCUMSTANCES EXISTING ON THE EFFECTIVE DATE OF THIS AGREEMENT, THE AMOUNT OF THE EARNEST MONEY DEPOSIT IS A REASONABLE ESTIMATE OF THE DAMAGES THAT SELLER WOULD INCUR IN SUCH EVENT, AND SELLER WAIVES ITS RIGHT TO RECOVER DAMAGES OR SEEK SPECIFIC PERFORMANCE AGAINST BUYER.  EACH PARTY CONFIRMS THE ACCURACY OF THE STATEMENTS MADE ABOVE AND THE FACT THAT EACH PARTY WAS REPRESENTED BY COUNSEL WHO EXPLAINED, AT THE TIME THIS AGREEMENT WAS MADE, THE CONSEQUENCES OF THIS LIQUIDATED DAMAGES PROVISION.
content.caption: Buyer Default; Liquidated Damages.

content.text: 14.	CONFIDENTIALITY
content.caption: CONFIDENTIALITY

content.text: 14.1	Definition of Confidential Information.  As used herein, “Confidential Information” shall mean the non-public, confidential information related to (a) Seller’s operations and businesses, which may include leases, rent rolls, operating budgets, net operating income figures and capital expenditure summaries, (b) the existence or pendency of this transaction, (c) the material economic terms of this transaction, and (d) any other information or materials shared by the other party or its Affiliates and/or their agents related to this transaction, whether shared before or after the Effective Date, that either a party or its agents has expressly designated as confidential or would otherwise be reasonably considered to be confidential.  Notwithstanding the foregoing, in no event shall the following be considered Confidential Information: (w) any information that becomes publicly available without breach of this Agreement; (x) any information that can be shown by documentation to have been previously known to a party and/or its Affiliates at the time of its disclosure or delivery by the other party, its Affiliates and/or their agents; (y) any information rightfully received by a party and/or its Affiliates or from a third party who did not acquire or disclose such information by a wrongful or tortious act; and (z) any information that a party can demonstrate was independently developed by such party and/or its Affiliates without use of or reference to any Confidential Information.
content.caption: Definition of Confidential Information.

content.text: 14.2	Non-Disclosure of Confidential Information.  Each party shall treat the Confidential Information with the same degree of care and confidentiality that such party exercises in protecting and preserving its own confidential information and shall use reasonable and good faith efforts to avoid and prevent the disclosure of the Confidential Information to third parties; except that (a) each party may disclose the Confidential Information if so compelled by judicial or other governmental order, provided the disclosing party shall give the other party reasonable opportunity to seek a protective order or equivalent, or obtain written assurance from the applicable judicial or governmental entity that it will afford the Confidential Information the highest level of protection afforded under applicable law or regulation, (b) each party may disclose the Confidential Information to those third parties integral to the transactions contemplated under this Agreement such as Escrow Agent, Title Company and Tenants, where such disclosure either falls expressly or implicitly with the scope of the transactions and other actions contemplated under this Agreement, but only to the extent such disclosure is necessary or appropriate to carry out such contemplated transactions or actions, and (c) each party may disclose the Confidential Information to existing or potential investors, joint venture partners or lenders, as well as to the officers, employees, attorneys, advisors, consultants or Affiliates of Seller or Buyer, as the case may be, or of any of the foregoing parties (collectively, “Permitted Recipients”); provided that the disclosing party first makes those Permitted Recipients aware of the confidential nature of the Confidential Information and such Permitted Recipients acknowledge their responsibility to preserve the confidentiality of the Confidential Information.
content.caption: Non-Disclosure of Confidential Information.

content.text: 15.	Responsibility for Broker Commissions
content.caption: Responsibility for Broker Commissions

content.text: Each of Buyer and Seller represents and warrants to the other that it did not employ or use any broker or finder to arrange or bring about this transaction, except for Seller’s Broker and Buyer’s Broker (if any are identified in Section 1.12 or 1.13 above) and that there are no claims or rights for brokerage commissions or finder’s fees in connection with the transactions contemplated by this Agreement or arising out of actions or statements by the representing party except to the extent otherwise provided in this Section 15.  If any person brings a claim against Seller for a commission or finder’s fee based upon any contact, dealings or communication with Buyer in connection with the transactions contemplated by this Agreement for which Seller is not expressly responsible under Section 1.15, then Buyer shall defend Seller from such claim, and shall indemnify Seller and hold Seller harmless from any and all costs, damages, claims, liabilities or expenses (including reasonable attorneys’ fees and disbursements) incurred by Seller with respect to the claim.  If any person brings a claim against Buyer for a commission or finder’s fee based upon any contact, dealings or communication with Seller in connection with the transactions contemplated by this Agreement for which Buyer is not expressly responsible under Section 1.15, then Seller shall defend Buyer from such claim, and shall indemnify Buyer and hold Buyer harmless from any and all costs, damages, claims, liabilities or expenses (including reasonable attorneys’ fees and disbursements) incurred by Buyer with respect to the claim.
content.caption: Each of Buyer and Seller represents and warrants to the othe...

content.caption: All notices must be sent by (a) certified mail, return recei...

content.text: 16.2	Time.  Time is of the essence in the performance of all obligations under this Agreement.  “Business Day” means any day other than a Saturday, a Sunday, or any day that is recognized as a holiday in Washington State or in the state in which the Property is located.  Unless this Agreement expressly refers to “Business Days”, all references in this Agreement to days shall be deemed to mean calendar days.  The time periods under this Agreement shall be computed by excluding the first day and including the last day, but, if the last day falls on a calendar day that is not a Business Day, or if the computed date for Closing or any other event that requires recording of documents falls on a day on which the applicable county recording office is closed, then the time period or date in question shall extend to the next Business Day.
content.caption: Time.

content.text: 16.3	US Dollars.  All monetary amounts set forth in this Agreement are in US Dollars.
content.caption: US Dollars.

content.text: 16.4	Definition of Affiliate.  As used herein, “Affiliate” means any person or entity that directly, or indirectly through one or more intermediaries, controls, is controlled by or is under common control with a person or entity, as the case may be.  For the purposes of this definition, “control” and “controlled” mean the possession, direct or indirect, of the power to direct or cause the direction of the management and policies of a person or entity, whether through the ownership of voting securities, by contract or otherwise.  It is acknowledged and agreed that any limited liability company or partnership in which Unico Investment Group LLC either (i) directly or indirectly serves as a manager[, operating as managing member] or general partner, and/or (ii) directly or indirectly holds at least [2.5]5% of the total membership or partnership interests shall constitute an Affiliate of Buyer. [NOTE: USE BRACKETED LANGUAGE FOR CORE PLUS PARTNERS FUND TRANSACTIONS.]
content.caption: Definition of Affiliate.

content.text: 16.5	Successors and Assigns. This Agreement will be binding upon and inure to the benefit of Seller and Buyer and their respective permitted successors and assigns, and no other party will be conferred any rights by virtue of this Agreement or be entitled to enforce any of the provisions hereof.  Whenever a reference is made in this Agreement to Seller or Buyer, such reference will include the successors and permitted assigns of such party under this Agreement.
content.caption: Successors and Assigns.

content.text: 16.6	Assignment.  Buyer shall not have the right to assign this Agreement without the prior written consent of Seller, which consent may be granted or withheld in Seller’s sole and absolute discretion; provided, however, that if Buyer elects to proceed with the acquisition of the Property following the Due Diligence Period, Buyer may, without consent from Seller, partially or wholly assign this Agreement to (a) one or more Affiliates of Buyer, and (b) one or more Affiliates of Buyer and/or third parties under a tenancy in common structure, provided an Affiliate of Buyer will be the property manager of the Property under an agreement with all of the tenants in common.  Notice of any proposed assignment to Buyer’s Affiliate, which notice shall include the full legal name and signature block for the proposed assignee, must be given to Seller at least 2 Business Days before Closing.  No assignment by Buyer shall release it from any liability hereunder.
content.caption: Assignment.

content.text: 16.7	1031 Like-Kind Exchange.  Buyer may purchase the Property and Seller may sell the Property by completing one or more Internal Revenue Code Section 1031 tax-deferred exchange(s).  Each party agrees to cooperate with the other in effecting such an exchange; provided, however, the cooperating party shall not incur any additional liability or financial obligations and the Closing Date shall not be extended or accelerated as a consequence of any such exchange.
content.caption: 1031 Like-Kind Exchange.

content.text: 16.8	Governing Law; Venue.  This Agreement shall be governed by, and construed in accordance with, the laws of the state in which the Property is located, without regard to any otherwise applicable principles of conflicts of laws.  Venue for any action arising out of this Agreement shall be in the state courts in the state and county in which the Property is located, or in U.S. Federal District Court for the applicable district in which the Property is located.
content.caption: Governing Law; Venue.

content.text: 16.9	Waiver of Trial by Jury. EACH PARTY TO THIS AGREEMENT EXPRESSLY WAIVES ANY RIGHT TO TRIAL BY JURY OF ANY CLAIM, DEMAND, ACTION OR CAUSE OF ACTION (A) ARISING UNDER THIS AGREEMENT OR ANY OTHER INSTRUMENT, DOCUMENT OR AGREEMENT EXECUTED OR DELIVERED IN CONNECTION HEREWITH, OR (B) IN ANY WAY CONNECTED WITH OR RELATED OR INCIDENTAL TO THE DEALINGS OF THE PARTIES HERETO OR ANY OF THEM WITH RESPECT TO THIS AGREEMENT OR ANY OTHER INSTRUMENT, DOCUMENT OR AGREEMENT EXECUTED OR DELIVERED IN CONNECTION HEREWITH, OR THE TRANSACTIONS RELATED HERETO OR THERETO, IN EACH CASE WHETHER NOW EXISTING OR HEREAFTER ARISING, AND WHETHER SOUNDING IN CONTRACT OR TORT OR OTHERWISE.  EACH PARTY AGREES THAT ANY SUCH CLAIM, DEMAND, ACTION OR CAUSE OF ACTION SHALL BE DECIDED BY COURT TRIAL WITHOUT A JURY.  THE PARTIES AGREE THAT THE PROVISIONS CONTAINED HEREIN HAVE BEEN NEGOTIATED ON AN ARMS-LENGTH BASIS, WITH BOTH PARTIES AGREEING TO THE SAME KNOWINGLY AND BEING AFFORDED THE OPPORTUNITY TO HAVE THEIR RESPECTIVE LEGAL COUNSEL ADVISE THEM AS TO THE MATTERS CONTAINED HEREIN.
content.caption: Waiver of Trial by Jury.

content.text: 16.10	Attorneys’ Fees.  If any action is brought by any party to this Agreement to enforce or interpret its terms or provisions, the prevailing party will be entitled to reasonable attorneys’ fees and costs incurred in connection with such action prior to and at trial and on any appeal therefrom.
content.caption: Attorneys’ Fees.

content.text: 16.11	No Memorandum.  Buyer shall not record any memorandum disclosing this Agreement.
content.caption: No Memorandum.

content.text: 16.12	Limited Liability. Neither the members, managers, employees or agents of Seller, nor the shareholders, officers, directors, employees or agents of any of them, shall be liable under this Agreement and all parties hereto shall look solely to the assets of Seller for the payment of any claim or the performance of any obligation by Seller.  None of the individual members, managers, employees or agents or Buyer, nor the shareholders, officers, directors, partners, members, employees or agents of any of them, shall be liable under this Agreement.
content.caption: Limited Liability.

content.text: 16.13	No Joint Venture.  Nothing in this Agreement shall be construed to create a joint venture between Buyer and Seller.
content.caption: No Joint Venture.

content.text: 16.14	No Third Party Beneficiaries.  Nothing in this Agreement is intended to benefit any third party or create any third party beneficiary.
content.caption: No Third Party Beneficiaries.

content.text: 16.15	No Waiver.  No waiver of any of the provisions of this Agreement shall be deemed, or shall constitute, a waiver of any other provision, whether or not similar, nor shall any waiver constitute a continuing waiver, nor shall a waiver in any instance constitute a waiver in any subsequent instance.  No waiver shall be binding unless executed in writing by the party making the waiver.
content.caption: No Waiver.

content.text: 16.16	Entire Agreement.  This Agreement (including any and all exhibits and/or schedules attached hereto) and any other document to be furnished pursuant to the provisions hereof embody the entire agreement and understanding of the parties hereto as to the subject matter contained herein.  There are no restrictions, promises, representations, warranties, covenants or undertakings other than those expressly set forth or referred to in such documents.  This Agreement and such documents supersede all prior agreements and understandings among the parties and/or their affiliates with respect to the subject matter hereof (including, without limitation, any previously executed letters of intent, early access agreements and/or non-disclosure or confidentiality agreements).
content.caption: Entire Agreement.

content.text: 16.17	Severability.  Any term or provision of this Agreement that is invalid or unenforceable in any jurisdiction will, as to such jurisdiction, be ineffective to the extent of such invalidity or unenforceability without rendering invalid or unenforceable the remaining terms and provisions of this Agreement, or affecting the validity or enforceability of any of the terms or provisions of this Agreement.
content.caption: Severability.

content.text: 16.18	No Merger.  Subject to the limitations set forth in Section 5.4 and Section 14, the covenants, agreements, representations, and warranties made herein shall survive the Closing Date and shall not merge into the deed and its recordation in the official records or the delivery at Closing of any assignment of leases, general assignment, or bill of sale.
content.caption: No Merger.

content.text: 16.19	Amendment and Modification.  This Agreement may only be amended, modified or supplemented by a written agreement signed by Buyer and Seller.
content.caption: Amendment and Modification.

content.text: 16.20	Further Acts.  Each party, at the request of the other, shall execute, acknowledge or have notarized (if appropriate) and deliver in a timely manner such additional documents, and do such other additional acts, also in a timely manner, as may be reasonably required in order to accomplish the intent and purposes of this Agreement.
content.caption: Further Acts.

content.text: 16.21	Not an Offer.  Presentation of any draft of this Agreement by one party to the other shall not be deemed an offer, and this Agreement shall only become a binding and enforceable contract upon execution hereof by both parties.
content.caption: Not an Offer.

content.text: 16.22	Counterparts; Electronic Delivery.  This Agreement may be executed in two or more counterparts, each of which shall be deemed an original and all of which together shall constitute the same agreement, whether or not all parties execute each counterpart.  Signatures transmitted by email shall have the same effect as original ink signatures.
content.caption: Counterparts; Electronic Delivery.

risk_inventory.title: Uncertain Effective Date Determination
risk_inventory.description: The Effective Date is defined as when the Agreement is 'executed and delivered by the last of Buyer and Seller,' but there is no mechanism to verify or document when this occurs. This creates uncertainty about when contractual deadlines (due diligence period, deposit deadlines, closing date) begin to run. Disputes could arise about whether delivery occurred, particularly if signatures are exchanged electronically or through intermediaries.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: The date this Agreement is executed and delivered by the last of Buyer and Seller shall be the "Effective Date" hereof.
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Add requirement for written confirmation of Effective Date by both parties.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Insert after the Effective Date definition: 'The parties shall confirm the Effective Date in writing within one (1) business day of execution by the last signing party. If the parties dispute the Effective Date, the date shown on the Escrow Holder's records shall control.' Alternatively, define Effective Date as the date of Escrow Holder's receipt of the fully executed Agreement.

amplified_by.effect: Uncertain Effective Date makes deposit deadline uncertain, risking default
Due diligence period start date becomes uncertain

risk_inventory.title: Purchase Price Forward Reference
risk_inventory.description: The Purchase Price is referenced but defined elsewhere. While this is standard drafting practice, Buyer should verify that the Purchase Price definition in Section 2 is complete and includes all adjustments, prorations, and credits to which Buyer is entitled.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: for the Purchase Price (as defined below)
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Verify Purchase Price definition in Section 2 includes all adjustments.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Cross-reference Section 2 (p_16) and Section 11.6 (p_102) regarding prorations to ensure the Purchase Price definition and adjustment mechanisms are complete and favor Buyer's interests. No change needed to this clause itself.

risk_inventory.title: Exhibit A Legal Description Missing
risk_inventory.description: The Real Property is identified only by a blank street address and reference to Exhibit A. Buyer must verify that Exhibit A contains a complete and accurate metes-and-bounds or platted legal description that matches the title commitment. An incorrect or incomplete legal description could result in Buyer not acquiring all intended property or acquiring unintended parcels.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: located at ______________________________________, Washington, as more particularly described in Exhibit A attached hereto
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Verify Exhibit A matches title commitment legal description exactly.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Add the following sentence after '(the "Real Property")': 'Buyer shall have the right to require amendment of Exhibit A to conform to the legal description shown in the Commitment, and any such amendment shall not require additional consideration.' Also ensure Exhibit A is attached and matches the title commitment before execution.

mitigated_by.effect: Title commitment review should reveal description discrepancies
Buyer has opportunity to identify issues during title review

risk_inventory.title: Undefined Appurtenant Rights Scope
risk_inventory.description: The conveyance of 'all rights, easements and rights-of-way appurtenant to the beneficial use and enjoyment of the Real Property' is limited to appurtenant rights only. This may not capture easements in gross, license agreements, or other access/utility rights that benefit the Property but are not technically 'appurtenant.' Seller could retain valuable rights that Buyer expects to receive.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: All rights, easements and rights-of-way appurtenant to the beneficial use and enjoyment of the Real Property
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Expand to include easements in gross, licenses, and all access rights.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Replace the clause with: 'Appurtenances. All rights, privileges, easements (whether appurtenant or in gross), rights-of-way, licenses, permits, entitlements, development rights, air rights, water rights, mineral rights (to the extent owned by Seller), and any other rights or interests appurtenant to or benefiting the Real Property, whether or not of record (collectively, the "Appurtenances");'

mitigated_by.effect: Some rights may be captured under Intangible Property

amplified_by.effect: As-is provision may limit Buyer's recourse if important rights not conveyed

risk_inventory.title: Undefined Tenant/Leased Fixtures Exclusion
risk_inventory.description: The clause excludes 'fixtures owned by tenants or leased by Seller from third parties' from the conveyance, but there is no schedule or exhibit identifying these excluded items. Without a definitive list, Buyer cannot verify what is actually being purchased versus what will be removed or retained. Post-closing disputes could arise if Seller claims valuable fixtures were excluded when Buyer believed they were included.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: excluding any fixtures owned by tenants or leased by Seller from third parties
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Require Seller to provide a schedule of all excluded fixtures before Closing.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Insert language requiring Seller to deliver, within 5 business days of the Effective Date, a complete schedule identifying all fixtures owned by tenants and all fixtures leased by Seller from third parties, including the owner/lessor, description, and location. Add that any fixtures not listed on such schedule shall be deemed included in the sale. Include Buyer's right to object to any claimed exclusions during the Due Diligence Period.

amplified_by.effect: AS-IS clause may limit Buyer's ability to recover for missing fixtures Buyer believed were included

risk_inventory.title: Personal Property Exclusions Not Specified
risk_inventory.description: The bracketed language indicates that specific exclusions should be listed but the blank is unfilled. This creates uncertainty about what personal property is actually being conveyed. Seller could later claim valuable items were excluded, or Buyer may not receive property it expected.
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Complete the exclusion list or delete exclusion language entirely.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Either (a) delete the bracketed exclusion language in its entirety so all personal property owned by Seller is conveyed, or (b) require Seller to complete the list prior to the end of the Due Diligence Period and provide Buyer with an opportunity to approve or object. Add language stating: 'Any personal property not specifically listed as excluded shall be deemed included in the sale and conveyed to Buyer at Closing.'

amplified_by.effect: AS-IS language may preclude Buyer from claiming reliance on inclusion of unlisted items

risk_inventory.title: No Personal Property Inventory Required
risk_inventory.description: The clause conveys personal property 'owned by Seller and located on, in, or used in connection with' the Property, but there is no requirement for Seller to provide an inventory or schedule of such items. Buyer cannot verify what personal property exists or will be conveyed at Closing.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: All of the right, title and interest of Seller in and to all personal property owned by Seller and located on, in, or used in connection with, the Real Property
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Require Seller to provide a personal property inventory during due diligence.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Add the following language: 'Seller shall deliver to Buyer within five (5) business days of the Effective Date a complete inventory of all Personal Property to be conveyed hereunder, which inventory shall be subject to Buyer's review and approval during the Due Diligence Period. At Closing, Seller shall deliver a Bill of Sale covering all items on the approved inventory.'

mitigated_by.effect: Bill of Sale at closing will document what personal property is actually conveyed

risk_inventory.title: Intangibles Limited to 'Extent Transferable'
risk_inventory.description: The conveyance of intangible property is qualified by 'to the extent transferable by Seller.' This places the risk of non-transferability on Buyer without requiring Seller to make efforts to obtain necessary consents or to warrant transferability. Key permits, licenses, or contracts may not transfer, leaving Buyer without critical operational rights.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: to the extent transferable by Seller
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Add Seller obligation to use best efforts to obtain transfer consents.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Modify to read: 'All of the right, title and interest of Seller in and to all intangible personal property... Seller shall use commercially reasonable efforts to obtain all consents necessary to transfer such intangible property to Buyer. Seller shall identify any intangible property that is not transferable or requires consent for transfer within five (5) business days of the Effective Date, and shall notify Buyer of any consent that is not obtained prior to Closing. Buyer may elect to terminate this Agreement without penalty if any material consent is not obtained.'

amplified_by.effect: AS-IS clause may limit recourse if key permits do not transfer

risk_inventory.title: Seller Retains All Pre-Closing Third Party Claims
risk_inventory.description: Seller excludes from the conveyance 'any present or future claims of Seller against any third parties that relate to any period of time prior to the Closing.' This means if there are construction defects, warranty claims, or causes of action arising from pre-closing events (e.g., contractor negligence, environmental contamination caused by third parties), Buyer has no right to pursue those claims even though Buyer inherits the physical consequences. This is a significant allocation of risk to Buyer.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: but excluding any present or future claims of Seller against any third parties that relate to any period of time prior to the Closing
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Require assignment of all third-party claims to Buyer at Closing.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Delete the exclusionary language and replace with: 'Seller hereby assigns to Buyer all of Seller's right, title, and interest in and to any and all claims, causes of action, warranties, and guaranties against third parties relating to the Property, including without limitation claims for construction defects, design defects, environmental contamination, and breach of warranty, whether arising before or after Closing. Seller shall execute such further instruments as Buyer may reasonably request to effectuate such assignment.'

amplified_by.effect: Combined with AS-IS language, Buyer absorbs property defects with no recourse against responsible third parties
Release further limits Buyer's ability to recover for pre-closing issues

risk_inventory.title: Service Contracts Undefined and Unscheduled
risk_inventory.description: The clause includes 'equipment leases, utility contracts, maintenance contracts, and all other similar agreements' as Service Contracts being conveyed, but there is no schedule identifying these contracts. Buyer cannot evaluate the terms, obligations, or termination rights of these agreements during due diligence. Buyer may inherit unfavorable long-term contracts.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: all equipment leases, utility contracts, maintenance contracts, and all other similar agreements (collectively, the "Service Contracts")
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Require delivery of all Service Contracts and a schedule during due diligence.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Add language requiring: 'Seller shall deliver to Buyer within five (5) business days of the Effective Date complete copies of all Service Contracts together with a schedule listing each Service Contract, the parties thereto, the term, any renewal provisions, termination rights, and monthly/annual cost. Buyer's approval of the Service Contracts shall be a condition to Buyer's obligations under Section 5. Any Service Contract not disclosed to Buyer shall not be assumed by Buyer and Seller shall indemnify Buyer for any obligations thereunder.'

mitigated_by.effect: Seller cannot enter into new material Service Contracts without Buyer consent

risk_inventory.title: Lease Definition Includes 'Other Agreements to Occupy'
risk_inventory.description: The definition of 'Leases' includes not only formal leases but also 'other agreements to occupy the Real Property.' This broad language could include license agreements, month-to-month arrangements, or informal occupancy rights that may not be documented. Buyer should confirm all occupancy arrangements are disclosed.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: all leases and other agreements to occupy the Real Property and/or the Improvements, or any portion thereof
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Require rent roll to include all occupancy agreements, not just formal leases.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Add to the due diligence delivery requirements: 'Seller shall deliver a complete schedule of all Leases and other occupancy agreements, including any license agreements, month-to-month tenancies, and informal occupancy arrangements, whether or not reduced to writing. Seller represents that no person or entity has any right to occupy any portion of the Property except as set forth on such schedule.'

mitigated_by.effect: Rent roll representation provides some protection if accurate

risk_inventory.title: Seller Retains Non-Exclusive Claim Rights Post-Closing
risk_inventory.description: Seller reserves 'on a non-exclusive basis with Buyer' the right to assert claims under warranties, guaranties, and agreements related to design, construction, or performance of the Property. This creates potential conflicts: Seller may pursue claims that Buyer would prefer to settle, or Seller may settle claims Buyer needs to pursue. The 'non-exclusive' nature creates coordination issues and potential claim-splitting problems.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: Seller reserves and retains the right, on a non-exclusive basis with Buyer, to assert all claims, defenses, counter claims, and cross claims of Seller against any third parties under any warranties, guaranties, and agreements related to design, construction or performance of the Property
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Delete Seller's retained rights or limit to claims for pre-closing damages only.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Delete this reservation language or modify to read: 'Seller assigns to Buyer all claims, defenses, counterclaims, and cross claims against any third parties under any warranties, guaranties, and agreements related to design, construction, or performance of the Property. Notwithstanding the foregoing, Seller shall retain the right to pursue claims solely for damages suffered by Seller prior to Closing, provided Seller shall not settle any such claims without Buyer's prior written consent if such settlement would impair Buyer's rights or remedies. Buyer and Seller shall cooperate in the prosecution of any claims and shall not take any action that would prejudice the other party's rights.'

amplified_by.effect: Combined with exclusion in 1E, this creates uncertainty about which party can pursue which claims

risk_inventory.title: Initial Deposit Non-Refundable Upon Receipt
risk_inventory.description: The clause states the Initial Deposit 'will become non-refundable upon Escrow Holder's receipt except in case of Seller's default.' This means Buyer loses the deposit immediately upon delivery, even before conducting any due diligence. If Buyer discovers material issues during the due diligence period (see p_31), Buyer would lose the entire Initial Deposit upon termination. This is highly unusual and buyer-unfavorable; standard practice is for deposits to become non-refundable only AFTER the due diligence period expires without termination.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: The Initial Deposit will become non-refundable upon Escrow Holder's receipt except in case of Seller's default hereunder.
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Deposit should remain refundable through end of Due Diligence Period.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Delete the sentence 'The Initial Deposit will become non-refundable upon Escrow Holder's receipt except in case of Seller's default hereunder.' and replace with: 'The Initial Deposit shall be refundable to Buyer if Buyer delivers a Termination Notice pursuant to Section 5(c) prior to the expiration of the Due Diligence Period. Upon expiration of the Due Diligence Period without Buyer's delivery of a Termination Notice, the Initial Deposit shall become non-refundable except in the case of (i) Seller's default hereunder, (ii) failure of any condition precedent set forth in Section 5.4, or (iii) as otherwise expressly provided in this Agreement.'

amplified_by.effect: Liquidated damages provision allows Seller to retain entire Deposit as sole remedy, compounding the early non-refundability risk
Only applies to termination for reasons 'other than Buyer's default,' potentially excluding due diligence termination

risk_inventory.title: Immediate Payment of Deposit to Seller
risk_inventory.description: The bracketed alternative provision states 'Upon receipt, Escrow Holder shall promptly pay the Initial Deposit to Seller.' If this alternative is selected, Buyer loses escrow protection entirely. The deposit would be in Seller's hands rather than held by a neutral Escrow Holder, making recovery difficult even in cases of Seller default. This creates significant counterparty credit risk and eliminates the protective function of escrow.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: [Upon receipt, Escrow Holder shall promptly pay the Initial Deposit to Seller.]
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Delete this bracketed alternative; deposit must remain in escrow until Closing.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Delete the bracketed provision '[Upon receipt, Escrow Holder shall promptly pay the Initial Deposit to Seller.]' entirely. If Seller insists on release of deposit funds, add protective language: 'Notwithstanding the foregoing, the Initial Deposit shall be held by Escrow Holder in accordance with the terms of this Agreement and shall not be released to Seller until Closing, except as expressly provided herein.'

amplified_by.effect: If deposit is paid to Seller and Seller defaults, Buyer's remedy to recover deposit depends on Seller's willingness/ability to return funds

risk_inventory.title: Narrow Exception for Deposit Refund
risk_inventory.description: The deposit is non-refundable 'except in case of Seller's default hereunder.' This language is too narrow. It does not expressly preserve Buyer's right to recover the deposit upon (i) failure of Buyer's conditions precedent under Section 5.4, (ii) casualty or condemnation under Section 14, (iii) title defects Seller cannot cure, or (iv) other express termination rights in the Agreement. Buyer should not lose its deposit when termination is permitted under the Agreement for reasons other than Seller's default.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: except in case of Seller's default hereunder
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Expand refund exceptions to include all permitted termination events.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Replace 'except in case of Seller's default hereunder' with 'except in case of (i) Seller's default hereunder, (ii) Buyer's termination of this Agreement pursuant to Section 5(c) prior to expiration of the Due Diligence Period, (iii) failure of any condition precedent set forth in Section 5.4, (iv) termination pursuant to Section 4 due to title defects that Seller does not cure, (v) termination pursuant to Section 14 following casualty or condemnation, or (vi) any other express termination right granted to Buyer under this Agreement.'

mitigated_by.effect: Section 6 provides some protection for deposit return upon termination, but scope is unclear

risk_inventory.title: One Business Day Deadline for Additional Deposit
risk_inventory.description: Buyer has only one (1) business day to deliver the Additional Deposit after approval or expiration of due diligence. This extremely short window creates significant operational risk. Wire transfer delays, banking holidays, or administrative errors could result in missed deadline. If the Additional Deposit is not timely delivered, Buyer could be in default, potentially forfeiting the Initial Deposit.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: Within one (1) business day after the earlier of Seller's receipt of the Approval Notice, or the expiration of the Due Diligence Period
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Extend Additional Deposit deadline to three (3) business days.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Replace 'Within one (1) business day' with 'Within three (3) business days'. Also consider adding: 'Buyer's failure to timely deliver the Additional Deposit shall not constitute a default hereunder provided such deposit is delivered within two (2) business days following written notice from Seller of such failure.'

amplified_by.effect: Late deposit could trigger default and forfeiture of Initial Deposit as liquidated damages

risk_inventory.title: Additional Deposit Immediately Non-Refundable
risk_inventory.description: The Additional Deposit is stated to be 'nonrefundable, except in case of Seller's default hereunder, and as otherwise expressly provided in this Agreement.' While this includes the qualifier 'as otherwise expressly provided,' the baseline non-refundability creates risk if conditions precedent fail or other termination events occur that are not clearly covered by express Agreement provisions. This compounds with the Initial Deposit issue to put the entire Deposit at risk.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: The Additional Deposit is nonrefundable, except in case of Seller's default hereunder, and as otherwise expressly provided in this Agreement.
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Clarify all circumstances where Additional Deposit is refundable.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Replace the sentence with: 'The Additional Deposit shall be nonrefundable, except in case of (i) Seller's default hereunder, (ii) failure of any condition precedent set forth in Section 5.4, (iii) termination pursuant to Section 4 due to title defects that Seller does not cure, (iv) termination pursuant to Section 14 following casualty or condemnation, or (v) any other express termination right granted to Buyer under this Agreement that entitles Buyer to return of the Deposit.'

mitigated_by.effect: Section 6 provides some framework for deposit return, adding marginal protection

amplified_by.effect: Entire Deposit including Additional Deposit serves as liquidated damages

risk_inventory.title: Immediate Payment of Additional Deposit to Seller
risk_inventory.description: Similar to the Initial Deposit, a bracketed alternative states 'Upon receipt, Escrow Holder shall promptly pay the Additional Deposit to Seller.' If this alternative is selected along with the similar provision for the Initial Deposit, the entire Deposit would be in Seller's hands, eliminating all escrow protection for Buyer. Recovery would require legal action against Seller.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: [Upon receipt, Escrow Holder shall promptly pay the Additional Deposit to Seller.]
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Delete this bracketed alternative; deposit must remain in escrow.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Delete the bracketed provision '[Upon receipt, Escrow Holder shall promptly pay the Additional Deposit to Seller.]' entirely. The deposit should remain in escrow as stated in the first bracketed alternative.

amplified_by.effect: Buyer's ability to recover deposit upon Seller default would be impaired if funds are already with Seller

risk_inventory.title: Deemed Approval Through Inaction on Due Diligence
risk_inventory.description: The Additional Deposit becomes due upon 'expiration of the Due Diligence Period without Buyer's delivery of a Termination Notice.' This creates a deemed approval mechanism where Buyer's failure to act (deliver Termination Notice) triggers non-refundable deposit obligations. If Buyer's team misses the deadline or miscommunicates, Buyer is locked into the transaction without affirmative approval.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: the expiration of the Due Diligence Period without Buyer's delivery of a Termination Notice
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Consider requiring affirmative Approval Notice, not just absence of termination.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Consider revising to require affirmative approval: Replace 'Within one (1) business day after the earlier of Seller's receipt of the Approval Notice, or the expiration of the Due Diligence Period without Buyer's delivery of a Termination Notice' with 'Within three (3) business days after Seller's receipt of the Approval Notice pursuant to Section 5(c)'. Then add: 'If Buyer fails to deliver either an Approval Notice or a Termination Notice prior to the expiration of the Due Diligence Period, Seller may deliver written notice to Buyer demanding that Buyer make an election within two (2) business days, failing which this Agreement shall terminate and the Deposit shall be returned to Buyer.'

amplified_by.effect: Deemed approval locks in non-refundability of Initial Deposit already at risk

risk_inventory.title: Bracketed Interest Credit Language
risk_inventory.description: The bracketed language '[plus accrued interest thereon]' suggests uncertainty about whether interest on the Deposit will be credited to Buyer at Closing. The first bracketed alternative in p_18 states interest is 'held for the account of Buyer,' but this p_20 bracket creates ambiguity. If interest is substantial and the deal closes, Buyer should ensure interest credits against Purchase Price.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: [plus accrued interest thereon]
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Remove brackets and confirm interest credits to Buyer at Closing.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Remove the brackets to make the language definitive: Replace '[plus accrued interest thereon]' with 'plus all accrued interest thereon'. Ensure consistency with p_18's bracketed alternative that states interest is 'held for the account of Buyer.'

mitigated_by.effect: First bracketed alternative in p_18 provides that interest is held for Buyer's account

risk_inventory.title: Blank Purchase Price Allocation
risk_inventory.description: The allocation amount for Personal Property is left blank ($____________). This creates ambiguity that could result in disputes over the allocation, which has significant tax implications. If Seller fills in an unfavorable allocation or disputes arise later, Buyer may face unexpected tax consequences. Personal property is typically depreciated over shorter periods than real property, so Buyer generally benefits from a higher personal property allocation.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: The sum of $____________ of the Purchase Price shall be allocated to the Personal Property
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Insert specific dollar amount and confirm allocation methodology benefits Buyer's tax position.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Replace the blank '$____________' with a specific negotiated dollar amount. Consider adding language that (1) specifies the methodology for the allocation (e.g., based on fair market value appraisal), (2) requires mutual agreement on the allocation prior to Closing, (3) obligates both parties to report the allocation consistently on their respective tax returns (IRS Form 8594), and (4) provides that Buyer's reasonable allocation shall control absent Seller's timely objection.

risk_inventory.title: No Tax Reporting Consistency Requirement
risk_inventory.description: The allocation provision lacks any requirement that both parties report the allocation consistently for tax purposes. Without such language, Seller could report a different allocation to the IRS, potentially triggering an audit or dispute with tax authorities.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: The sum of $____________ of the Purchase Price shall be allocated to the Personal Property, and the balance shall be allocated to the Real Property, the Appurtenances and the Improvements.
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Add requirement for consistent tax reporting of allocation by both parties.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Add the following sentence at the end of the paragraph: 'Seller and Buyer agree to report this allocation consistently on all applicable tax returns, including IRS Form 8594, and neither party shall take a position on any tax return or in any tax proceeding inconsistent with this allocation unless required to do so by applicable law.'

risk_inventory.title: Seven-Day Delivery Window May Be Insufficient
risk_inventory.description: Seller has seven days after mutual execution to deliver survey and title documents. However, there is no remedy specified if Seller fails to deliver within this timeframe. Buyer's Title Review Period runs from the Effective Date (per Section 4B), not from receipt of documents, meaning Buyer could lose review time if Seller delays delivery. This creates a timing mismatch that disadvantages Buyer.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: within seven (7) days after mutual execution of this Agreement
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Tie Title Review Period to receipt of documents, not Effective Date.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Modify Section 4B to provide that the Title Review Period runs from the later of (i) the Effective Date, or (ii) Buyer's receipt of all Title Documents. Alternatively, add language here stating: 'Seller's failure to deliver the items required by this Section 4.1 within the time period specified shall automatically extend the Title Review Period and Due Diligence Period by one day for each day of delay beyond the seven (7) day period.'

risk_inventory.title: No Consequence for Late Delivery
risk_inventory.description: The clause obligates Seller to deliver documents within seven days but provides no consequence or remedy if Seller fails to comply. Buyer has no explicit right to extend review periods, terminate, or seek other relief for late delivery.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: Seller shall deliver the following items to Buyer within seven (7) days after mutual execution of this Agreement
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Add automatic extension of review periods or termination right for late delivery.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Add the following at the end of Section 4A: 'In the event Seller fails to deliver any of the items required under this Section 4.1 within the time period specified, the Title Review Period and Due Diligence Period shall each be automatically extended by one (1) day for each day of such delay. If Seller fails to deliver all required items within fourteen (14) days after mutual execution, Buyer may terminate this Agreement by written notice to Seller and receive a full refund of the Deposit.'

risk_inventory.title: Survey Delivery Conditioned on Seller's Possession
risk_inventory.description: Seller's obligation to deliver a survey is qualified by 'if any' and 'in the possession of Seller.' This allows Seller to claim no survey exists or that it is not in their possession, leaving Buyer without baseline survey information. Buyer bears the full cost and time burden of obtaining a new survey.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: The most recent survey of the Property, if any ("Existing Survey") in the possession of Seller
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Require Seller to deliver any survey it has or can reasonably obtain.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Revise to: 'The most recent survey of the Property in Seller's possession or control, or which Seller can obtain from its lender, title company, or property manager without unreasonable cost or effort (the "Existing Survey"). Seller represents that, to Seller's Actual Knowledge, [there is no existing survey / the Existing Survey attached hereto is the most recent survey of the Property].'

risk_inventory.title: Buyer Bears Full Survey Cost
risk_inventory.description: Buyer is required to pay for any updated or new ALTA survey at Buyer's expense. While this is market-standard, in a Buyer-favorable negotiation, Seller could be required to share this cost or provide a credit.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: at Buyer's expense
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Consider negotiating Seller contribution to survey costs.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: If Buyer desires to shift or share survey costs, revise to: 'at Buyer's expense; provided, however, that Seller shall reimburse Buyer for up to $[AMOUNT] of the cost of the Updated Survey at Closing, which amount shall be credited against the Purchase Price.' Alternatively, in stronger Buyer markets: 'at Seller's expense.'

risk_inventory.title: Title Company Name Left Blank
risk_inventory.description: The title company name is left blank, which could lead to disputes over which title company will be used. Buyer should ensure a reputable title company acceptable to Buyer is specified.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: issued by _______________ Title Insurance Company
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Insert name of Buyer-approved title company before execution.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Insert the name of a specific title company acceptable to Buyer. Consider adding: 'or such other title company as Buyer may designate in writing to Seller prior to the Effective Date.'

risk_inventory.title: Silence Constitutes Approval of Title Defects
risk_inventory.description: If Buyer fails to deliver Title Objections within the ten-day Title Review Period, all exceptions and title conditions are deemed approved. This is a significant trap for Buyer—missing the deadline results in waiver of all title objections, even material defects. The period runs from the Effective Date, not from receipt of Title Documents, compounding the risk if Seller delays delivery.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: Buyer's failure to timely notify Seller of its approval of all or certain of the Title Documents and the Title Objections, if any, within the Title Review Period shall constitute approval of all exceptions and of the condition of title to the Property.
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Remove deemed approval or require Seller to provide reminder notice before deadline.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Revise to: 'Buyer's failure to timely notify Seller of Title Objections within the Title Review Period shall constitute approval only of those specific exceptions that are Permitted Exceptions as defined herein. Notwithstanding the foregoing, Buyer shall not be deemed to have approved (i) any monetary liens or encumbrances (other than non-delinquent taxes), (ii) any matters that would materially interfere with Buyer's intended use of the Property, or (iii) any exceptions first appearing on a supplemental title report after the Effective Date.' Alternatively, add: 'Seller shall provide written notice to Buyer at least three (3) business days prior to the expiration of the Title Review Period.'

risk_inventory.title: Title Review Period Runs from Effective Date, Not Receipt
risk_inventory.description: The Title Review Period is ten days from the Effective Date, but Seller has seven days after mutual execution to deliver Title Documents (Section 4A). This means Buyer could have as few as three days to review Title Documents if Seller delivers on the last day. This is grossly inadequate for proper title review.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: Buyer shall have ten (10) days from the Effective Date (the "Title Review Period")
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Change Title Review Period to run from receipt of complete Title Documents.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Revise to: 'Buyer shall have ten (10) days from the later of (i) the Effective Date, or (ii) Buyer's receipt of all Title Documents required under Section 4.1 (the "Title Review Period").' This ensures Buyer has the full review period regardless of when Seller delivers documents.

risk_inventory.title: Seller Has Absolute Discretion to Refuse Title Cure
risk_inventory.description: Seller may elect not to cure any Title Objection in its sole discretion. Even for material defects that render title unmarketable, Seller can simply refuse to cure, leaving Buyer with only the option to waive or terminate. This gives Seller significant leverage and allows Seller to refuse to address even readily curable defects.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: (ii) notice that Seller elects not to remove or cure such Title Objection
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Require Seller to cure monetary liens and certain material defects.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Add the following: 'Notwithstanding the foregoing, Seller shall be obligated to remove or cure at or prior to Closing, at Seller's sole cost and expense: (i) all monetary liens and encumbrances against the Property (other than non-delinquent real property taxes and assessments), including without limitation any deeds of trust, mortgages, mechanics' liens, judgment liens, and tax liens; (ii) any exceptions created by Seller after the Effective Date without Buyer's consent; and (iii) any exceptions that Seller has expressly agreed in writing to remove or cure. Such obligations shall not be subject to any cap or limitation.'

risk_inventory.title: Buyer's Only Remedy is Termination or Waiver
risk_inventory.description: If Seller refuses to cure Title Objections, Buyer's only options are to waive the objection or terminate the Agreement. Buyer has no right to a purchase price reduction, credit at closing, or other remedy for uncured title defects.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: Buyer may either (i) waive such Title Objection and proceed with the Closing, or (ii) terminate this Agreement by written notice to Seller.
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Add option for purchase price reduction or credit for uncured title defects.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Revise to: 'Buyer may either (i) waive such Title Objection and proceed with the Closing, (ii) terminate this Agreement by written notice to Seller and receive a full refund of the Deposit, or (iii) proceed with the Closing and receive a credit against the Purchase Price in an amount reasonably determined by Buyer to compensate Buyer for the uncured Title Objection, provided such credit shall not exceed the estimated cost to cure such Title Objection.'

risk_inventory.title: Termination Right Limited to Due Diligence Period
risk_inventory.description: If Seller refuses to cure Title Objections, Buyer's termination right is limited to 'any time prior to the end of the Due Diligence Period.' If the Due Diligence Period ends before Seller responds to Title Objections, or shortly thereafter, Buyer may lose its termination right. This creates a timing trap.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: at any time prior to the end of the Due Diligence Period Buyer may either (i) waive such Title Objection and proceed with the Closing, or (ii) terminate this Agreement
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Extend termination right to reasonable period after Seller's response.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Revise to: 'then within five (5) business days after Seller's notice (or failure to respond), but in no event later than the Closing Date, Buyer may either (i) waive such Title Objection and proceed with the Closing, or (ii) terminate this Agreement by written notice to Seller and receive a full refund of the Deposit.'

risk_inventory.title: Five-Day Review Too Short for Supplements
risk_inventory.description: Buyer has only five (5) days to review and disapprove title exceptions in supplemental reports. Given that supplements may arrive close to closing and could contain significant new encumbrances (mechanics' liens, judgment liens, new easements), this compressed timeframe may be insufficient for proper legal review, especially if Buyer's counsel is unavailable or if the exception requires investigation. Missing this deadline results in automatic deemed approval of potentially harmful exceptions.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: Buyer shall have five (5) days following the receipt of a supplemental report to notify Seller in writing of its disapproval
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Extend supplemental review period to 10 business days.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Replace 'five (5) days' with 'ten (10) business days' to provide Buyer adequate time to review, investigate, and respond to new title exceptions that may appear in supplemental reports close to closing.

amplified_by.effect: Title review cannot extend closing, compressing available time even further

risk_inventory.title: Automatic Deemed Approval of Exceptions
risk_inventory.description: If Buyer fails to timely communicate disapproval of a supplemental exception, it automatically becomes a Permitted Exception. This 'silence equals consent' provision shifts risk to Buyer and could result in Buyer taking title subject to objectionable encumbrances (such as easements, liens, or restrictions) simply due to an administrative oversight or delayed mail delivery.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: if Buyer's disapproval of any supplemental report exception is not so communicated to Seller, the exception shall be considered a Permitted Exception
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Require affirmative written approval for new exceptions.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Delete the automatic deemed approval language and replace with: 'Any exception contained in a supplemental report shall not be deemed a Permitted Exception unless Buyer provides express written approval thereof.' This shifts the default to protect Buyer from unapproved encumbrances.

amplified_by.effect: AS-IS provision may limit Buyer's post-closing remedies for title defects

risk_inventory.title: Title Review Cannot Extend Closing
risk_inventory.description: The express prohibition that 'in no event shall title review extend the Closing Date' creates significant risk for Buyer. If a critical title defect appears in a supplemental report received close to closing, Buyer may be forced to either (a) accept a defective title, (b) waive material objections, or (c) potentially be in default for refusing to close. This is particularly dangerous if Seller causes new exceptions to appear (through liens, new agreements, etc.) near closing.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: in no event shall title review extend the Closing Date
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Add automatic closing extension for late supplements.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Delete '(ii) in no event shall title review extend the Closing Date' and replace with: '(ii) if any supplemental report is received by Buyer less than ten (10) business days prior to the scheduled Closing Date, the Closing Date shall be automatically extended to provide Buyer ten (10) business days from receipt of such supplemental report to complete its review and for Seller to cure any disapproved items.'

amplified_by.effect: Buyer could lose deposit if deemed in default for refusing to close over title issues

risk_inventory.title: Special Warranty Deed Limits Title Protection
risk_inventory.description: Seller is conveying title by special warranty deed rather than general warranty deed. A special warranty deed only warrants against defects arising during Seller's ownership period, not against defects from prior owners. This leaves Buyer exposed to claims arising from title defects that originated before Seller acquired the property, with recourse only against the title insurance policy rather than Seller directly.
