risk_inventory.problematic_text: Seller shall convey to Buyer fee simple title to the Real Property and Improvements by special warranty deed
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Request general warranty deed or enhanced title coverage.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Replace 'special warranty deed' with 'general warranty deed' to provide Buyer with comprehensive title warranties covering defects from all prior ownership periods. Alternatively, if Seller refuses, add language requiring Seller to assign to Buyer any title warranties Seller received from its predecessor in title.

mitigated_by.effect: Title insurance provides alternative protection against covered defects

risk_inventory.title: Permitted Exceptions Definition Circular
risk_inventory.description: The definition of 'Permitted Exceptions' is somewhat circular and relies heavily on deemed approvals from the title review process. Combined with the automatic deemed approval provisions in Section 4B, this could result in Buyer taking title subject to exceptions that were never actually reviewed or consciously approved, merely not timely objected to.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: subject to those title exceptions permitted herein, or as may be approved by Buyer in writing (the "Permitted Exceptions")
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Define Permitted Exceptions with specific enumerated items.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Add a new defined term or exhibit that specifically enumerates the categories of Permitted Exceptions (e.g., real property taxes not yet due, utility easements of record, zoning ordinances) rather than relying on the approval/deemed approval process. Add: 'Permitted Exceptions shall mean only: (a) the specific exceptions listed on Exhibit __ attached hereto, (b) non-delinquent real property taxes and assessments, (c) matters created by or with the written consent of Buyer, and (d) items expressly approved in writing by Buyer during the title review period.'

amplified_by.effect: Automatic deemed approval expands what becomes a Permitted Exception

risk_inventory.title: Endorsements Must Be Agreed During DD Period
risk_inventory.description: The requirement that endorsements be 'requested by Buyer and agreed to by Title Company during the Due Diligence Period' could prevent Buyer from obtaining necessary endorsements discovered after due diligence expires. If title issues are revealed post-due diligence (e.g., through a supplemental report), Buyer may not be able to require additional endorsements to address newly discovered risks.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: together with such endorsements thereto as may be requested by Buyer and agreed to by Title Company during the Due Diligence Period
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Allow endorsement requests through closing date.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Replace 'during the Due Diligence Period' with 'at any time prior to Closing' to preserve Buyer's ability to request additional endorsements as new title matters are discovered through supplemental reports or other means. Add: 'Buyer shall have the right to request additional endorsements at any time prior to Closing, and Seller shall cooperate with such requests at no additional cost to Seller.'

amplified_by.effect: Combined with no closing extension, limits Buyer's ability to address late-discovered title issues

risk_inventory.title: Title Insurance Limited to Purchase Price
risk_inventory.description: Title insurance coverage is limited to the Purchase Price amount. If Buyer is making significant improvements or the property appreciates substantially, this coverage may become inadequate. Additionally, Purchase Price may not reflect true market value if Buyer negotiated a favorable deal.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: insuring Buyer in the amount of the Purchase Price
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Consider requesting coverage at appraised or intended use value.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Add language permitting increased coverage: 'insuring Buyer in an amount equal to the greater of (a) the Purchase Price, or (b) such higher amount as Buyer may elect (with Buyer paying any additional premium for coverage exceeding the Purchase Price).'

risk_inventory.title: Due Diligence Deadline Left Blank
risk_inventory.description: The due diligence period end date is left blank ('on or before 5 p.m. Pacific time on ____________________'). This is a critical term that, if not properly completed, creates ambiguity about when Buyer's inspection rights terminate and when the deposit may become non-refundable. This could lead to disputes about whether Buyer timely exercised termination rights.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: on or before 5 p.m. Pacific time on ____________________
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Insert specific date; ensure adequate time for inspections.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: ALERT: This blank MUST be completed before execution. Recommend inserting a specific calendar date that provides Buyer at least 30-45 days from the Effective Date for comprehensive due diligence including environmental assessments, property condition reports, lease audits, and financial review. Consider adding: 'which date shall be no earlier than forty-five (45) days following the Effective Date.'

amplified_by.effect: Missing deadline could affect when Additional Deposit becomes due/at risk
Ambiguity affects deposit refund rights

risk_inventory.title: Three Business Days for Document Delivery May Be Insufficient
risk_inventory.description: Seller has only three (3) business days to deliver Due Diligence Documents. While this short timeframe benefits Buyer by getting materials quickly, if Seller fails to timely deliver, there is no automatic extension of the Due Diligence Period. Buyer could be forced to conduct inspections with incomplete information, yet still face the same deadline.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: Within three (3) business days of the Effective Date, Seller shall deliver to Buyer the documents identified on attached Schedule 1
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Add DD period extension if documents delivered late.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Add the following sentence after the existing text: 'In the event Seller fails to deliver all Due Diligence Documents within such three (3) business day period, the Due Diligence Period shall be automatically extended by one (1) day for each day of delay in Seller's delivery, and Buyer may elect to terminate this Agreement upon written notice to Seller if such documents are not delivered within ten (10) business days of the Effective Date.'

mitigated_by.effect: Buyer's sole discretion approval right provides termination flexibility

risk_inventory.title: Broad Sole Discretion Termination Right
risk_inventory.description: This is a FAVORABLE provision for Buyer. Buyer has 'sole and absolute discretion' to approve or disapprove all matters pertaining to the property's condition. This provides Buyer maximum flexibility to terminate during due diligence for any reason or no reason, making the deposit refundable during this period. Ensure this right is preserved.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: subject to written satisfaction, approval or waiver by Buyer, in its sole and absolute discretion
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Preserve this favorable provision; ensure no other terms limit it.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: NO CHANGES NEEDED - This is favorable language for Buyer. However, verify that no other provisions in the Agreement (particularly Section 5C or Section 6) contain language that could be interpreted to limit this sole discretion right or impose objective standards on Buyer's approval decision.

risk_inventory.title: Waiver of Reliance on Due Diligence Materials
risk_inventory.description: This provision disclaims any representation or warranty by Seller regarding the accuracy or completeness of due diligence documents. Buyer is essentially agreeing to conduct its entire investigation based on materials that may be incomplete, inaccurate, or misleading, with no recourse against Seller for deficiencies in those materials. This significantly increases Buyer's risk of making an uninformed purchase decision and eliminates any claim Buyer might have if the materials provided are materially inaccurate.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: Seller is furnishing copies of the Due Diligence Documents for informational purposes only and without representation or warranty as to the accuracy or completeness of such materials
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Add Seller warranty that materials are complete and accurate to Seller's knowledge.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Revise to add a knowledge-qualified representation: 'Seller is furnishing copies of the Due Diligence Documents for informational purposes; provided, however, that Seller represents and warrants that, to Seller's Actual Knowledge, (i) the Due Diligence Documents provided to Buyer constitute all material documents in Seller's possession or control relating to the Property, and (ii) Seller has not intentionally withheld any material documents or information from Buyer, except as expressly provided in Section 7 hereof.'

risk_inventory.title: Narrow Carve-Out for Section 7 Representations Only
risk_inventory.description: The exception 'except as expressly provided in Section 7 hereof' limits Buyer's recourse to only those specific representations made in Section 7. If Seller provides materially misleading due diligence materials that are not covered by Section 7 representations, Buyer has no claim. This creates a gap between the information relied upon and the representations protecting that reliance.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: except as expressly provided in Section 7 hereof
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Expand carve-out to include fraud and intentional misrepresentation.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Modify the carve-out to read: 'except as expressly provided in Section 7 hereof, and except that the foregoing shall not limit Buyer's remedies in the event of Seller's fraud, intentional misrepresentation, or intentional concealment of material information.'

risk_inventory.title: Nonintrusive Inspection Limitation May Impair Due Diligence
risk_inventory.description: The restriction to 'nonintrusive inspections, tests and studies' may prevent Buyer from conducting Phase II environmental testing, soil borings, or other invasive testing necessary to fully assess the Property's condition. This limitation could leave Buyer unable to discover material defects or environmental contamination before closing.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: nonintrusive inspections, tests and studies
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Add right to conduct intrusive testing with Seller's consent, not unreasonably withheld.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Revise to read: 'nonintrusive inspections, tests and studies as Buyer may elect of the physical condition of the Property; provided, however, that Buyer may conduct intrusive inspections, tests, and studies (including, without limitation, Phase II environmental assessments, soil borings, and geotechnical testing) upon not less than five (5) business days' prior written notice to Seller and subject to Seller's prior written consent, which consent shall not be unreasonably withheld, conditioned, or delayed.'

risk_inventory.title: Seller Accompaniment May Chill Thorough Inspection
risk_inventory.description: Seller's unilateral right to accompany Buyer during all inspections may inhibit frank discussions between Buyer and its consultants, particularly regarding environmental or structural concerns. While facially neutral, this could chill thorough inspection and documentation of Property defects.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: Seller or Seller's designee may accompany Buyer and/or its agents or contractors when exercising Buyer's right of entry
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Clarify Seller accompaniment shall not interfere with Buyer's inspection activities.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Add at end of sentence: 'Seller or Seller's designee may accompany Buyer and/or its agents or contractors when exercising Buyer's right of entry under this Section 5.2; provided, however, that Seller's presence shall not interfere with or delay Buyer's inspections, and Seller shall make reasonable efforts to accommodate Buyer's inspection schedule.'

risk_inventory.title: Blank Advance Notice Period Creates Uncertainty
risk_inventory.description: The advance notice requirement contains a blank ('____________ (___) business days') that must be negotiated and filled in. An overly long notice period could impair Buyer's ability to efficiently conduct due diligence within the Due Diligence Period, particularly for follow-up inspections.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: at least ____________ (___) business days in advance of such entry
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Negotiate for 24-48 hours advance notice, not longer.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Fill in the blank with a short, reasonable period: 'at least one (1) business day in advance of such entry' or at most 'two (2) business days in advance of such entry.' Resist any period longer than 48 hours as it may impair efficient due diligence.

risk_inventory.title: Buyer Bears All Inspection Costs
risk_inventory.description: While standard in commercial transactions, this provision places the entire financial burden of due diligence on Buyer. There is no provision for Seller to bear costs of re-inspection if Seller fails to provide access or if Property conditions change between inspections.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: Buyer shall pay for all inspections, tests and studies ordered by Buyer
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Consider adding Seller cost responsibility if re-inspection needed due to Seller's acts.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Add the following sentence: 'Notwithstanding the foregoing, if Buyer is required to conduct any re-inspection of the Property due to Seller's failure to provide timely access, changes to the Property made by Seller after an initial inspection, or inaccuracy in information previously provided by Seller, the reasonable costs of such re-inspection shall be borne by Seller.'

risk_inventory.title: Undefined 'Reasonable Advance Notice' Standard
risk_inventory.description: The requirement for 'reasonable advance notice' is undefined and subjective, potentially allowing Seller to claim insufficient notice and deny access. This conflicts with the specific notice period mentioned in Section 5B and creates ambiguity as to which standard governs.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: Buyer shall give Seller reasonable advance notice of such entry
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Replace 'reasonable' with specific time period matching Section 5B.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Revise to read: 'Buyer shall give Seller advance notice of such entry in accordance with Section 5.2 above' to eliminate any ambiguity between this provision and the specific notice period required in the lead-in paragraph of Section 5B.

risk_inventory.title: Minimize Interference Standard is Subjective
risk_inventory.description: The requirement to 'minimize interference with Seller's business on, and Seller's tenants' occupancy of, the Property' is inherently subjective and could be used by Seller to obstruct legitimate inspection activities. What constitutes 'minimized' interference is not defined and could be disputed.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: so as to minimize interference with Seller's business on, and Seller's tenants' occupancy of, the Property
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Define specific prohibited activities rather than vague 'minimize interference' standard.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Revise to read: 'so as not to unreasonably interfere with Seller's business on, and Seller's tenants' occupancy of, the Property; provided, however, that Seller acknowledges that some reasonable level of interference is inherent in property inspections and Seller shall not withhold or condition access based on minimal or temporary interference.'

risk_inventory.title: Broad Uncapped Indemnity for Entry and Testing
risk_inventory.description: Buyer provides an unlimited indemnity for 'all costs, expenses, damages, liabilities, liens or claims' arising from entry onto the Property. This indemnity is uncapped, survives closing or termination, and could expose Buyer to substantial liability even for minor inspection-related incidents. The breadth of 'directly related to any entry' is potentially very wide.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: Buyer shall indemnify and hold Seller harmless from and against all costs, expenses, damages, liabilities, liens or claims, including, without limitation, attorneys' fees and court costs, directly related to any entry on the Property
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Add cap on indemnity and limit to Buyer's negligence or willful misconduct.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Revise to read: 'Buyer shall indemnify and hold Seller harmless from and against all reasonable, third-party costs, expenses, damages, liabilities, liens or claims, including, without limitation, reasonable attorneys' fees and court costs, to the extent directly caused by the negligence or willful misconduct of Buyer or its agents, employees or contractors in connection with any entry on the Property by Buyer, its agents, employees or contractors in the course of performing inspections, tests and/or inquiries provided for under this Agreement; provided, however, that Buyer's aggregate liability under this indemnity shall not exceed [INSERT CAP - e.g., $500,000 or the amount of the Deposit]...'

risk_inventory.title: Indemnity Survives Indefinitely
risk_inventory.description: The indemnity obligation survives closing or termination without any time limitation. This creates perpetual exposure for Buyer related to pre-closing inspection activities, potentially for years after the transaction closes or terminates.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: The foregoing indemnity shall survive the Closing Date or earlier termination of this Agreement.
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Add survival period cap (e.g., 12-24 months post-closing).
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Revise to read: 'The foregoing indemnity shall survive the Closing Date or earlier termination of this Agreement for a period of twelve (12) months [or up to twenty-four (24) months if Seller insists], after which Buyer shall have no further liability under this Section 5.2(iii).'

risk_inventory.title: Broad Restoration Obligation Without Standard
risk_inventory.description: Buyer must 'promptly repair any damage' and 'restore the Property to its prior condition.' The standard of 'prior condition' is vague and could be disputed. Additionally, there is no qualification for ordinary wear and tear from inspections or reasonable tolerance for minor cosmetic impacts inherent in property testing.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: Buyer shall also promptly repair any damage done to any portion of the Property in connection with the exercise of its rights under this Section 5.2, and restore the Property to its prior condition
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Qualify restoration obligation for material damage only, not de minimis impacts.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Revise to read: 'Buyer shall also promptly repair any material damage done to any portion of the Property in connection with the exercise of its rights under this Section 5.2, and restore the Property to substantially its prior condition; provided, however, that Buyer shall not be responsible for normal wear and tear or minor cosmetic impacts reasonably incident to property inspections.'

risk_inventory.title: Pre-Existing Conditions Carve-Out May Be Narrowly Construed
risk_inventory.description: While the carve-out for pre-existing conditions is favorable to Buyer, the parenthetical excludes only 'non-negligent aggravation' of pre-existing conditions. If Buyer's testing is deemed to have negligently aggravated a pre-existing condition (even if the condition was unknown and would have required testing to discover), Buyer could be liable. The distinction between discovery and aggravation may be difficult to prove.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: but not including any claims resulting from the discovery or disclosure of pre-existing physical or environmental conditions or the non-negligent aggravation of pre-existing physical or environmental conditions
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Broaden carve-out to include reasonable aggravation during standard testing protocols.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Revise the parenthetical to read: '(but not including any claims resulting from (a) the discovery or disclosure of pre-existing physical or environmental conditions, (b) the aggravation of pre-existing physical or environmental conditions except to the extent caused by Buyer's gross negligence or willful misconduct, or (c) any claims by Seller or any third party relating to conditions that existed prior to Buyer's entry, regardless of whether such conditions were aggravated by Buyer's inspection activities conducted in accordance with industry-standard testing protocols on, in, under or about the Property).'

risk_inventory.title: Seller Discretion Over Insurance Requirements
risk_inventory.description: While the clause establishes a minimum $2,000,000 CGL requirement, additional insurance requirements are subject to Seller's 'reasonably satisfactory' approval. This subjective standard could allow Seller to demand excessive or unusual coverage, potentially delaying or complicating Buyer's due diligence access. There is no cap on what Seller can request beyond the stated minimum, and no mechanism for resolving disputes over reasonableness.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: with insurance limits and coverage reasonably satisfactory to Seller
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Define specific insurance requirements rather than leaving to Seller's discretion.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Replace the subjective 'reasonably satisfactory to Seller' language with objective insurance requirements. Suggest replacing with: 'with the following insurance coverage: (a) commercial general liability insurance with limits of at least $2,000,000 per occurrence and $4,000,000 aggregate; (b) workers' compensation insurance as required by law; and (c) automobile liability insurance with limits of at least $1,000,000 combined single limit, if applicable.' Alternatively, add language stating: 'provided that Seller's requirements shall not exceed customary insurance requirements for similar property inspections in the market where the Property is located.'

risk_inventory.title: Insurance Requirement May Delay Property Access
risk_inventory.description: Buyer must provide insurance certificates before entry, which is standard but could create timing issues if Buyer needs to quickly arrange inspections during a limited due diligence period. Combined with the subjective 'reasonably satisfactory' standard, this could effectively shorten the Due Diligence Period.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: Before Buyer or any of its consultants or agents enter onto the Property to exercise rights under this Section 5, Buyer shall provide Seller with a certificate of insurance
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Ensure due diligence period tolling if Seller delays approval of insurance.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Add a protective provision such as: 'Seller shall respond to Buyer's submitted certificate of insurance within two (2) business days of receipt. If Seller fails to respond within such period, the insurance shall be deemed acceptable. If Seller reasonably objects to the insurance, Buyer shall have two (2) business days to provide revised coverage. The Due Diligence Period shall be extended day-for-day for any delays caused by Seller's failure to timely respond or unreasonable objections to insurance coverage that complies with the minimum requirements set forth herein.'

risk_inventory.title: Unlimited Survival of Inspection Obligations
risk_inventory.description: This provision causes Buyer's indemnification obligations and other onerous terms from Section 5.2 (including repair obligations, indemnification for liens and claims, insurance requirements) to survive termination without any time limitation. This creates perpetual exposure for Buyer even if the deal terminates during due diligence. Buyer could face claims years after walking away from the transaction for alleged damage during inspections.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: The terms of this Section 5.2 shall survive termination of this Agreement.
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Add a specific survival period cap (e.g., 12-18 months post-termination).
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Modify the survival provision to include a reasonable time limitation: 'The terms of this Section 5.2 shall survive termination of this Agreement for a period of twelve (12) months following such termination, provided that any claim for indemnification hereunder must be made by Seller in writing within such twelve (12) month period setting forth in reasonable detail the nature and amount of the claim.' This limits Buyer's exposure to a reasonable period for discovery of any inspection-related damage while preventing perpetual liability.

risk_inventory.title: Silence Deemed Approval with Deposit at Risk
risk_inventory.description: If Buyer fails to deliver a Termination Notice by the end of the Due Diligence Period, Buyer is automatically deemed to have provided an Approval Notice, which causes the Deposit to become nonrefundable. This creates significant risk: if Buyer's team misses the deadline (even due to circumstances beyond control like illness, emergency, or communication failures), Buyer loses the ability to terminate and places the Deposit at risk. This is a 'trap' provision that could result in substantial financial exposure.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: If Buyer fails to deliver the Termination Notice to Seller on or before the expiration of the Due Diligence Period, Buyer shall be deemed to have timely provided an Approval Notice.
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Require affirmative Approval Notice; silence should result in termination.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Reverse the default so that failure to act results in termination rather than deemed approval: 'If Buyer fails to deliver an Approval Notice to Seller on or before the expiration of the Due Diligence Period, Buyer shall be deemed to have elected to terminate this Agreement pursuant to this Section 5.3, and the Deposit shall be returned to Buyer.' Alternatively, if Seller requires the deemed approval structure, add protective language: 'Notwithstanding the foregoing, Buyer shall have the right to deliver a Termination Notice within three (3) business days following the expiration of the Due Diligence Period if Buyer can demonstrate that circumstances beyond Buyer's reasonable control prevented timely delivery of the Termination Notice.'

risk_inventory.title: Mandatory Turnover of Due Diligence Reports
risk_inventory.description: Upon termination for any reason other than Seller's default, Buyer must deliver copies of all third-party reports to Seller upon request. This gives Seller free access to potentially valuable studies, reports, and test results that Buyer paid for. These materials may identify defects Seller can remedy before remarketing the property, or may be used against Buyer in any disputes. There is no reciprocal obligation for Seller to compensate Buyer for these materials.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: On termination of this Agreement for any reason other than Seller's default, upon Seller's written request, Buyer shall deliver to Seller copies of all third party reports, studies and test results regarding the Property procured or obtained by Buyer.
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Negotiate reimbursement for report costs or make delivery optional.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Modify to make document delivery conditional on reimbursement: 'On termination of this Agreement for any reason other than Seller's default, upon Seller's written request and provided that Seller reimburses Buyer for Buyer's actual out-of-pocket costs incurred in obtaining such materials, Buyer shall deliver to Seller copies of all third party reports, studies and test results regarding the Property procured or obtained by Buyer. Any such reports shall be delivered without representation or warranty of any kind by Buyer, and Buyer shall have no liability arising from Seller's use of or reliance upon such reports.' Alternatively, add: 'Buyer may redact from such reports any proprietary information, attorney-client privileged communications, or Buyer-specific financial analyses.'

risk_inventory.title: Vague Timing for Notice Delivery
risk_inventory.description: The clause requires Buyer to 'promptly' notify Seller of both termination and approval decisions, but does not define what 'promptly' means. While the hard deadline is the end of the Due Diligence Period, the 'promptly' language could be used by Seller to argue Buyer breached by not delivering notice earlier, potentially affecting Buyer's rights or creating disputes about whether proper notice was given.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: then Buyer shall promptly notify Seller of such determination in writing
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Remove 'promptly' requirement or define specific timeframe.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Clarify the timing by replacing 'promptly' with specific language: 'then Buyer shall notify Seller of such determination in writing at any time on or before the expiration of the Due Diligence Period' or 'then Buyer may, at any time on or before 5:00 p.m. Pacific Time on the last day of the Due Diligence Period, notify Seller of such determination in writing.' This removes ambiguity about whether Buyer's notice was sufficiently timely.

risk_inventory.title: Conditions Subject to Waiver Framework
risk_inventory.description: This provision establishes that Buyer's closing conditions are subject to 'satisfaction or waiver by Buyer.' While this preserves Buyer's flexibility to waive conditions, it also means Buyer cannot refuse to close by claiming a condition failed if Buyer could have waived it. This framework should be reviewed in conjunction with Section 5.6 (waiver provisions) to understand the full scope of Buyer's discretion and any limitations.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: subject to the satisfaction or waiver by Buyer of the following conditions
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Ensure waiver provisions don't limit Buyer's right to enforce conditions.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Cross-reference with Section 5.6 (p_49) to ensure consistency. Consider adding clarifying language: 'Buyer's right to waive any condition shall be in Buyer's sole discretion, and Buyer's election not to waive a failed condition shall not constitute a default by Buyer under this Agreement.' This protects Buyer from arguments that it should have waived a condition rather than terminating.

risk_inventory.title: Closing Condition Tied to Section 11.3 Deliveries
risk_inventory.description: This condition requires Seller to deliver items listed in Section 11.3, but the language 'as provided in this Agreement' could be interpreted to mean that if Section 11.3 provides any flexibility on timing or manner of delivery, Seller has satisfied this condition even with delayed or incomplete delivery. The condition should be absolute rather than qualified by 'as provided in this Agreement.'
risk_inventory.problematic_text: as provided in this Agreement
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Strengthen condition to require complete delivery before Closing.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Revise to make the condition more protective: 'Seller shall have delivered all items described in Section 11.3 hereof to Escrow Holder (or directly to Buyer where specified) at least one (1) business day prior to the Closing Date, in form and substance reasonably satisfactory to Buyer.' This ensures Buyer has adequate time to review deliverables and establishes a clear standard for compliance.

risk_inventory.title: Irrevocable Commitment Standard Undefined
risk_inventory.description: The condition requires the Title Company to be 'irrevocably committed' to issue the Title Policy, but this standard is ambiguous. Title companies typically issue commitments with standard exceptions and requirements. It's unclear what constitutes an 'irrevocable' commitment versus a standard commitment, and whether any conditions or requirements in the commitment would defeat this standard. This ambiguity could lead to disputes about whether this condition has been satisfied or give Seller an argument that the condition is not met even when a standard commitment is available.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: irrevocably committed to issue the Title Policy
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Define what constitutes 'irrevocably committed' or use standard 'prepared to issue' language.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Revise the clause to provide a clearer standard. Replace 'irrevocably committed to issue' with 'prepared and unconditionally committed to issue, subject only to payment of the applicable premium and satisfaction of standard closing requirements.' Alternatively, add a definition clarifying that 'irrevocably committed' means the Title Company has issued a commitment without conditions other than (i) delivery of closing documents in the form required by this Agreement, (ii) payment of the title premium, and (iii) recording of the Deed.

risk_inventory.title: Condition Depends on Section 4 Requirements
risk_inventory.description: This condition precedent incorporates the requirements of Section 4 by reference. Buyer should ensure that Section 4 adequately addresses the form of Title Policy required, including extended coverage, deletion of standard exceptions (survey, mechanics' liens, parties in possession), and any required endorsements. If Section 4 requirements are insufficient, this condition precedent may be satisfied with a Title Policy that doesn't fully protect Buyer.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: pursuant to Section 4 hereof
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Verify Section 4 specifies all required title policy coverage and endorsements.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Review Section 4 (paragraphs p_26 through p_29) to confirm the Title Policy requirements are adequate for Buyer's protection. Consider adding specific requirements to this condition if Section 4 is lacking, such as: 'Title Company shall be irrevocably committed to issue the Title Policy pursuant to Section 4 hereof, including without limitation deletion of the standard printed exceptions for (a) parties in possession, (b) mechanics' liens, (c) matters that would be disclosed by a current and accurate survey, and (d) taxes and assessments not yet due and payable, and with such endorsements as Buyer may reasonably require.'

risk_inventory.title: Material Qualifier Weakens Rep Bring-Down
risk_inventory.description: The condition requires representations to be true only 'in all material respects,' which significantly weakens Buyer's protection. This means Seller's representations could be inaccurate in ways that don't meet the 'material' threshold, yet Buyer would still be required to close. Combined with the existing 'Seller's Actual Knowledge' qualifiers on many representations in Section 7A, this creates a double-layered shield for Seller. Immaterial misrepresentations could still cause Buyer financial harm post-closing without triggering the condition precedent.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: in all material respects
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Delete 'in all material respects' or negotiate a specific dollar threshold for materiality.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Remove the 'in all material respects' qualifier to strengthen the bring-down condition. The revised language should read: 'Each representation and warranty made by Seller in this Agreement shall be true, accurate and complete as of the Closing Date.' Alternatively, if Seller insists on a materiality qualifier, negotiate for a defined threshold: 'Each representation and warranty made by Seller in this Agreement shall be true, accurate and complete as of the Closing Date, except for inaccuracies that, individually or in the aggregate, would not reasonably be expected to result in losses to Buyer exceeding $[X].' The threshold should be coordinated with any indemnification basket in the Agreement.

risk_inventory.title: No Mechanism to Verify Reps at Closing
risk_inventory.description: While this condition requires representations to be true at Closing, the Agreement does not appear to require Seller to deliver a bring-down certificate confirming the continued accuracy of representations as of Closing. Without a closing deliverable confirming representation accuracy, Buyer has limited ability to verify compliance with this condition precedent and may have difficulty establishing a breach if issues arise post-closing.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: as of the Closing Date
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Require Seller to deliver a bring-down certificate at Closing confirming rep accuracy.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Add to Seller's closing deliverables in Section 11.3 (p_81) a requirement for a bring-down certificate. Insert the following as a new subsection: '(xii) A certificate executed by Seller confirming that each representation and warranty made by Seller in this Agreement is true, accurate and complete as of the Closing Date (or if any representation or warranty is not true, accurate and complete, specifying the nature and extent of such inaccuracy).' Also consider adding to this condition: 'and Seller shall have delivered the certificate required by Section 11.3(xii) confirming same.'

risk_inventory.title: Minimum Tenant Estoppels Not Defined
risk_inventory.description: The condition references 'Minimum Tenant Estoppels' but this term does not appear to be defined in the document map. Without a clear definition specifying which tenants must provide estoppels (e.g., by square footage threshold, rent amount, or specific named tenants), Buyer has uncertain protection. Seller could argue that estoppels from minor tenants satisfy this condition even if major tenants refuse or provide adverse estoppels. This is a critical gap for multi-tenant properties where estoppels from anchor or major tenants are essential.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: Minimum Tenant Estoppels
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Define 'Minimum Tenant Estoppels' to specify required tenants by name, percentage, or threshold.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Add a definition for 'Minimum Tenant Estoppels' either in this section or in a definitions section. Suggested language: '"Minimum Tenant Estoppels" means estoppel certificates from (a) tenants occupying at least [75]% of the leased square footage of the Property, and (b) each tenant leasing more than [10,000] square feet at the Property, which estoppels shall be dated no earlier than [30] days prior to the Closing Date.' Alternatively, if specific anchor tenants are critical: '"Minimum Tenant Estoppels" means estoppel certificates from (a) [list specific tenant names], and (b) tenants occupying at least [X]% of the remaining leased square footage.' Consider also adding a provision addressing what happens if estoppels reveal adverse information.

risk_inventory.title: Substantially In Form Standard May Allow Deviations
risk_inventory.description: The 'substantially in the form' language allows estoppels to deviate from Exhibit H. Tenants frequently modify requested estoppel forms, sometimes inserting claims, qualifications, or adverse information. If deviations are permitted as long as estoppels are 'substantially' in the required form, Buyer may be required to accept estoppels containing adverse information or lacking key confirmations. There is no standard for what deviations are acceptable.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: substantially in the form of Exhibit H
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Add language requiring estoppels not reveal adverse matters or materially deviate from Exhibit H.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Strengthen the estoppel requirement by adding qualifications. Revise to: 'Seller shall have delivered the Minimum Tenant Estoppels, each substantially in the form of Exhibit H attached hereto (with such modifications as are customarily required by tenants, but without any material modifications adverse to Buyer), and which estoppels shall not (a) disclose any default by landlord under any Lease, (b) disclose any offset, defense, or claim against landlord, (c) disclose any prepayment of rent for more than one month, (d) reflect any terms materially inconsistent with the Lease delivered to Buyer, or (e) contain any other information that would reasonably be expected to have a material adverse effect on the Property or Buyer's ownership thereof.'

risk_inventory.title: Estoppel Condition is Bracketed/Optional
risk_inventory.description: The entire estoppel condition precedent is in brackets, indicating it is optional or subject to negotiation. Buyer should ensure this provision is included in the final Agreement, particularly for multi-tenant properties where estoppel verification is critical to confirming lease terms, rental obligations, security deposits, and the absence of landlord defaults.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: [Seller shall have delivered the Minimum Tenant Estoppels
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Remove brackets to make estoppel delivery a firm condition precedent.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Remove the brackets from this provision to make the estoppel delivery requirement a firm condition precedent to Buyer's obligation to close. The provision should read without brackets: 'Seller shall have delivered the Minimum Tenant Estoppels, each substantially in the form of Exhibit H attached hereto.' Also ensure Section 8D (p_71) regarding Seller's covenant to obtain estoppels is also not bracketed and coordinates with this condition.

risk_inventory.title: Seller Conditions May Create Closing Uncertainty
risk_inventory.description: This provision establishes Seller's conditions precedent to closing. While some conditions favoring Seller are standard, Buyer should carefully review Sections 5E(i) through 5E(iii) to ensure they don't create opportunities for Seller to avoid closing on pretextual grounds. The 'all other conditions to Seller's obligations' reference also incorporates unstated conditions that may be scattered throughout the Agreement, creating uncertainty about what Seller can use to refuse closing.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: In addition to all other conditions to Seller's obligations in this Agreement
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Identify and list all Seller conditions in one place to avoid hidden closing obstacles.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Consider revising to limit Seller's conditions precedent to those expressly stated in Section 5E. The provision could be modified to: 'Seller and Buyer agree that Seller's obligation to proceed with the Closing is subject solely to the satisfaction or waiver by Seller of the following conditions at or prior to the Closing:' This eliminates the catch-all reference to 'all other conditions' that may be embedded elsewhere in the Agreement. Alternatively, add: 'For the avoidance of doubt, the conditions set forth in this Section 5E constitute the exclusive conditions precedent to Seller's obligation to close, and no other provision of this Agreement shall be construed as creating additional conditions precedent to Seller's obligations.'

risk_inventory.title: Seller May Waive Its Own Conditions
risk_inventory.description: The provision allows Seller to waive its conditions precedent at Seller's discretion. While this is standard, Buyer should confirm that Seller cannot use the failure of its own waivable conditions as a basis for termination or to claim Buyer default. The interplay between this provision and Section 5F (p_49) regarding waiver of conditions should be reviewed.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: satisfaction or waiver by Seller
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Confirm Seller cannot terminate based on its own unsatisfied but waivable conditions.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Add clarifying language to ensure Seller cannot use its own conditions as a pretext to avoid closing: 'Seller and Buyer agree that Seller's obligation to proceed with the Closing is subject to the satisfaction or waiver by Seller of the following conditions at or prior to the Closing; provided, however, that if any such condition is not satisfied and Seller elects not to waive such condition, Seller's sole remedy shall be to terminate this Agreement in accordance with Section 6, and Seller shall not be entitled to claim Buyer is in default or pursue any remedies against Buyer as a result of such non-satisfaction.'

risk_inventory.title: No Deadline Specified for Closing Payment Deposit
risk_inventory.description: While this condition requires Buyer to deposit the Closing Payment into escrow, it does not specify a deadline other than before Closing. Section 3C (p_20) should specify the timing, but if it merely says 'at Closing,' there could be a gap where Seller claims the condition is not satisfied because funds weren't deposited sufficiently in advance. This creates potential for Seller to claim Buyer default on timing grounds.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: Buyer shall have deposited the Closing Payment into escrow
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Specify that Closing Payment must be deposited by a time certain before scheduled Closing.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Coordinate this provision with Section 3C (p_20) to ensure timing is clear and reasonable. Consider revising to: 'Buyer shall have deposited the Closing Payment into escrow no later than 12:00 p.m. Pacific Time on the business day immediately preceding the Closing Date (or such later time as may be required by Escrow Holder to process the wire transfer for same-day Closing).' This provides a clear deadline while allowing for same-day closing mechanics if wire transfers can be processed in time.

risk_inventory.title: Delivery Obligations Undefined Here
risk_inventory.description: This clause conditions Seller's obligation to close on Buyer's delivery of items described in Section 11.4. Without reviewing Section 11.4 directly in this clause, Buyer cannot immediately assess the full scope of its delivery obligations, which could include documents or items that are difficult or time-consuming to obtain. If Buyer fails to deliver any required item, Seller could refuse to close without liability.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: those items described in Section 11.4 hereof
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Review Section 11.4 deliverables; ensure all are within Buyer's control.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Review Section 11.4 (referenced in para p_93 through p_100) to identify all Buyer delivery obligations. Consider whether any items require third-party cooperation or could cause closing delay. If any items are outside Buyer's direct control, negotiate to add qualifiers such as 'to the extent reasonably obtainable' or specify that failure to deliver due to third-party non-cooperation shall not constitute a failure of condition.

risk_inventory.title: Bring-Down May Block Closing
risk_inventory.description: This provision requires that Buyer's representations and warranties be true as of Closing. While standard, this creates a bring-down condition that could allow Seller to refuse to close if any of Buyer's representations become inaccurate—even due to circumstances beyond Buyer's control. The 'material respects' qualifier provides some protection, but Buyer should ensure its representations are limited and accurate.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: Each representation and warranty made by Buyer in this Agreement shall be true, accurate and complete in all material respects of as of the Closing Date
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Review Buyer's reps in Section 7B; ensure they are narrow and accurate.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Cross-reference Section 7B (para p_62 through p_64) to review the scope of Buyer's representations and warranties. Ensure representations are limited to matters within Buyer's knowledge and control. Consider whether any representations could become inaccurate between signing and closing. If representations are broad, negotiate to add knowledge qualifiers or limit to matters 'as of the Effective Date' rather than bringing down to Closing.

risk_inventory.title: Typographical Error in Text
risk_inventory.description: The phrase 'in all material respects of as of the Closing Date' contains a typographical error ('of as of' should be 'as of'). While likely a scrivener's error, ambiguous language could potentially be exploited in a dispute.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: in all material respects of as of the Closing Date
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Correct to 'in all material respects as of the Closing Date'.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Correct the typographical error by changing 'in all material respects of as of the Closing Date' to 'in all material respects as of the Closing Date'. This is a minor scrivener's error but should be corrected to avoid any ambiguity.

risk_inventory.title: Termination Right May Be Waived Inadvertently
risk_inventory.description: While the clause clarifies that conditions in Sections 5.1-5.4 are for Buyer's exclusive benefit, the termination right requires 'written notice' without specifying a deadline or cure period. This could create uncertainty about when the right lapses. Additionally, a party proceeding toward closing despite knowledge of an unsatisfied condition might be deemed to have waived the condition.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: this Agreement may be terminated by the party benefiting from such condition by written notice to the other party
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Add deadline for termination notice; clarify waiver standards.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Consider adding language that specifies: (1) a deadline by which the termination notice must be delivered (e.g., 'prior to the Closing Date'), (2) that proceeding to closing with knowledge of an unsatisfied condition shall not constitute a waiver unless explicitly waived in writing, and (3) that the terminating party shall not be required to provide any cure period to the other party. Suggested addition: 'Such termination right must be exercised prior to the Closing Date and shall not be deemed waived by any action short of an express written waiver.'

risk_inventory.title: Section Reference Appears Incomplete
risk_inventory.description: The clause references 'Sections 5.1 through 5.4' but the document structure shows these are Sections 5A through 5D. Additionally, there is no space between '5.4' and 'are' in the text ('5.4are'), suggesting a formatting or typographical issue. This could create ambiguity about which conditions are for Buyer's benefit.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: Sections 5.1 through 5.4are
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Correct section references to match document numbering convention.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Review the actual section numbering convention used in the Agreement. If sections are labeled 5A, 5B, 5C, 5D rather than 5.1, 5.2, 5.3, 5.4, correct the cross-references accordingly. Also add the missing space: 'Sections 5.1 through 5.4 are' or 'Sections 5A through 5D are' as appropriate. Verify that all conditions intended for Buyer's benefit are captured in the reference.

risk_inventory.title: Deposit Treatment Unclear on Termination
risk_inventory.description: This termination provision addresses return of documents and sharing of escrow cancellation fees, but critically does not address the return of Buyer's Deposit upon termination. The clause explicitly excludes 'Section 13' scenarios (which addresses defaults), but does not affirmatively state that Buyer's Deposit is returned in non-default termination scenarios. This omission could be exploited by Seller to argue the Deposit is not automatically returned.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: If this Agreement is terminated for any reason other than as described in Section 13
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Add explicit language requiring return of Deposit upon non-default termination.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Add explicit language addressing Deposit disposition upon termination. Suggested revision: 'If this Agreement is terminated for any reason other than as described in Section 13: (a) all documents deposited with the Escrow Holder by Buyer shall be returned to Buyer, all documents deposited with Escrow Holder by Seller shall be returned to Seller, and all documents delivered to Buyer by Seller shall be returned to Seller; (a-1) the Deposit shall be returned to Buyer; (b) no Broker's Fee shall be payable to Broker; and (c) the parties shall equally share any cancellation fee of the Escrow Holder.' Cross-reference Section 13 (p_116) to ensure no conflict with liquidated damages provisions.

risk_inventory.title: Buyer Must Return Due Diligence Documents
risk_inventory.description: Upon termination, Buyer must return 'all documents delivered to Buyer by Seller.' This could include voluminous due diligence materials that Buyer may have copied, analyzed, or relied upon in making decisions about other properties. The obligation to return (rather than destroy) could be burdensome and the scope is unclear regarding copies.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: all documents delivered to Buyer by Seller shall be returned to Seller
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Clarify whether destruction is permitted; address copies and digital files.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Consider revising to: 'all documents delivered to Buyer by Seller shall, at Seller's election, be either returned to Seller or destroyed by Buyer (with written certification of destruction provided to Seller upon request).' Also clarify treatment of copies: 'Buyer shall return or destroy all copies of such documents, whether in physical or electronic form, except that Buyer may retain one copy in its legal files solely for purposes of establishing compliance with this Agreement.'

risk_inventory.title: Shared Cancellation Fee Even If Seller Caused Termination
risk_inventory.description: The clause requires parties to 'equally share any cancellation fee of the Escrow Holder' regardless of which party caused the termination. This means Buyer pays half the cancellation fee even if Seller breached a representation or failed to satisfy a condition, as long as the termination is not under Section 13 (default).
risk_inventory.problematic_text: the parties shall equally share any cancellation fee of the Escrow Holder
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Allocate cancellation fee to party causing termination.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Revise cost allocation to reflect fault: 'the cancellation fee of the Escrow Holder shall be paid by the party whose action or inaction caused the termination, or if neither party is at fault (e.g., failure of financing contingency or mutual agreement to terminate), the parties shall equally share any cancellation fee of the Escrow Holder.'

risk_inventory.title: Representations Limited by Knowledge Qualifiers
risk_inventory.description: This introductory clause to Seller's representations does not itself contain risk, but the substantive representations that follow (Sections 7A(i) through 7A(vi)) are heavily qualified by 'Seller's Actual Knowledge' standards. Buyer should be aware that the following representations may be significantly limited and should review the definition of 'Seller's Actual Knowledge' carefully.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: Seller represents and warrants to Buyer as follows
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Review knowledge qualifiers and consider expanding scope of unqualified reps.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: This is an introductory clause. The substantive risks are in the following subsections (p_53 through p_61). Key concerns to flag for negotiation: (1) Definition of 'Seller's Actual Knowledge' in p_59 limits knowledge to specific individuals without duty of inquiry; (2) Most representations are qualified by knowledge, reducing their protective value; (3) p_60 limits remedies for pre-closing discovered breaches; (4) p_61 eliminates liability for representations that become untrue due to permitted actions. Recommend negotiating for broader unqualified representations or expanding the knowledge definition to include constructive knowledge or a duty of reasonable inquiry.

risk_inventory.title: Unqualified Organization Representation
risk_inventory.description: Unlike other Seller representations that are qualified by 'Seller's Actual Knowledge,' this representation regarding Seller's organization, authorization, and non-violation of contracts/judicial orders is made without any knowledge qualifier. While organization reps are typically unqualified, the inclusion of the broad statement that documents 'do not, and at the time of Closing, will not, violate any provisions of any contract or judicial order' could expose Buyer to risk if Seller unknowingly violates an obscure contractual restriction. If this representation proves false, Buyer may have a claim, but the survival period and any caps on liability will limit Buyer's remedies.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: do not, and at the time of Closing, will not, violate any provisions of any contract or judicial order to which Seller is a party or to which Seller is subject
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Consider adding 'to Seller's Actual Knowledge' to the non-violation portion.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Revise the representation to add a knowledge qualifier to the non-violation covenant. Suggested language: 'and, to Seller's Actual Knowledge, do not, and at the time of Closing, will not, violate any provisions of any contract or judicial order to which Seller is a party or to which Seller is subject.' Alternatively, consider whether Buyer actually wants this qualified or prefers the stronger unqualified rep with potential recourse.

risk_inventory.title: No Good Standing Representation
risk_inventory.description: The representation states Seller is 'duly organized and validly existing' but does not include the customary 'in good standing' language. While Seller may be validly existing, it could be administratively dissolved or not in good standing in its state of formation, which could affect its authority to convey property or result in tax liens. This is particularly important if the Property is in a different state than Seller's state of formation.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: duly organized and validly existing under the laws of the State of
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Add 'and in good standing' after 'validly existing.'
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Revise the representation to include good standing confirmation. Suggested language: 'Seller is a ___________ duly organized, validly existing and in good standing under the laws of the State of ___________.' Also consider adding a requirement that Seller be qualified to do business in the state where the Property is located if different from Seller's state of formation.

risk_inventory.title: Rent Roll Accuracy Limited to Seller's Knowledge
risk_inventory.description: The rent roll representation is qualified by 'Seller's Actual Knowledge' and further limited to 'material respects.' Combined with the narrow definition of 'Seller's Actual Knowledge' in Section 7A(vi) (which typically limits knowledge to specific individuals without duty of inquiry), this provides Buyer with very limited protection if the rent roll contains inaccuracies that Seller's designated representative did not personally know about. Rent roll accuracy is fundamental to the economic deal.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: To Seller's Actual Knowledge, the rent roll identified in the Due Diligence Documents (the "Rent Roll") is true and correct in all material respects
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Request unqualified rent roll rep or add Seller's duty to investigate.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Strengthen this representation by either: (1) removing the knowledge qualifier entirely so it reads 'The Rent Roll is true and correct in all material respects as of the Effective Date'; (2) adding a duty of inquiry to the knowledge definition in Section 7A(vi); or (3) requiring Seller to certify the rent roll at Closing with an updated representation. Also consider removing 'in all material respects' to provide full accuracy protection, or at minimum define what constitutes 'material.'

risk_inventory.title: Rent Roll Not Dated or Updated at Closing
risk_inventory.description: The representation references 'the rent roll identified in the Due Diligence Documents' but does not specify a date for the rent roll or require an updated rent roll at Closing. Between the Effective Date and Closing, lease terms may change, tenants may default, or new leases may be signed. Without a bring-down requirement or updated rent roll certification, Buyer could acquire property with materially different rental income than represented.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: the rent roll identified in the Due Diligence Documents (the "Rent Roll")
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Require updated certified rent roll at Closing.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Add language requiring an updated rent roll at Closing: 'To Seller's Actual Knowledge, the rent roll identified in the Due Diligence Documents (the "Rent Roll") is true and correct in all material respects as of the Effective Date, and Seller shall deliver to Buyer at Closing an updated Rent Roll certified by Seller to be true and correct in all material respects as of the Closing Date.' Cross-reference Section 11.3 for Seller's closing deliveries to ensure this is captured as a required delivery.

risk_inventory.title: Violation Representation Limited to Effective Date
risk_inventory.description: The representation regarding governmental notices of violations is explicitly limited to 'as of the Effective Date.' This means Seller makes no representation about violations existing or notices received between the Effective Date and Closing. While Seller agrees to forward notices received after the Effective Date, there is no representation that no violations exist at Closing, leaving Buyer exposed to acquiring property with undisclosed code violations or compliance issues that arose after contract signing.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: as of the Effective Date, Seller has received no notice from any governmental authority
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Extend violation representation through Closing with bring-down.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Revise to extend the representation through Closing: 'To Seller's Actual Knowledge, as of the Effective Date and continuing through the Closing Date, Seller has received no notice from any governmental authority with jurisdiction over the Property of any current violation by the Property of any laws, ordinances or regulations applicable to the Property, and Seller is in compliance with any such past notices of past violations.' Ensure Section 5.4(iii) bring-down covers this representation.

risk_inventory.title: Limited to Notices Received by Seller
risk_inventory.description: The representation is limited to notices 'Seller has received' from governmental authorities. This does not cover: (1) violations that exist but for which no notice has been issued; (2) notices sent to the Property address rather than Seller's address; (3) notices sent to a property manager or other agent; or (4) violations discoverable through public records. Buyer could acquire property with existing violations that simply haven't resulted in formal notice to Seller.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: Seller has received no notice from any governmental authority
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Broaden to include violations generally, not just noticed violations.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Strengthen the representation to cover actual violations: 'To Seller's Actual Knowledge, (a) the Property is in compliance with all applicable laws, ordinances, and regulations, (b) as of the Effective Date, Seller has received no notice from any governmental authority with jurisdiction over the Property of any violation by the Property of any laws, ordinances or regulations applicable to the Property, and (c) Seller is in compliance with any past notices of violations. Seller shall immediately provide Buyer with a copy of any such notices received after the Effective Date.'

risk_inventory.title: Notice Forwarding Without Termination Right
risk_inventory.description: While Seller agrees to 'immediately provide Buyer with a copy of any such notices received after the Effective Date,' the clause does not give Buyer any remedies if a material violation notice is received. There is no right to terminate, no price adjustment mechanism, and no obligation for Seller to cure. Buyer could be stuck acquiring property with newly-discovered material code violations with no recourse other than proceeding to Closing or potentially claiming a breach of the bring-down condition.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: Seller shall immediately provide Buyer with a copy of any such notices received after the Effective Date
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Add termination right or cure obligation for material violations.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Add remedies for post-Effective Date violation notices: 'Seller shall immediately provide Buyer with a copy of any such notices received after the Effective Date. If any such notice discloses a violation that would cost in excess of $_____ to cure, Buyer may elect to either (a) terminate this Agreement and receive a return of the Deposit, or (b) proceed to Closing with a credit against the Purchase Price equal to the estimated cost of cure. If Buyer elects option (a), Seller shall have the right, but not the obligation, to cure such violation within ____ days, in which event the Closing Date shall be extended accordingly.'

risk_inventory.title: Litigation Rep Covers All Seller Litigation Not Property
risk_inventory.description: The representation states there is no litigation 'pending or threatened against Seller' rather than being limited to litigation affecting the Property. This is actually overbroad and could inadvertently cause a breach if Seller has unrelated litigation. However, from Buyer's perspective, the opposite problem exists: this representation could be interpreted narrowly to NOT cover litigation against the Property itself if Seller is not named as a defendant (e.g., suits by third parties over title, boundary disputes, etc.). A well-drafted litigation rep should cover both Seller and the Property.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: there is no litigation pending or threatened against Seller
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Revise to cover litigation against both Seller and the Property.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Revise for appropriate scope: 'To Seller's Actual Knowledge, there is no litigation, arbitration, or administrative proceeding pending or threatened (a) against Seller that would materially adversely affect Seller's ability to perform its obligations under this Agreement or (b) against or affecting the Property or any portion thereof.' This covers Buyer's legitimate concerns while narrowing Seller's exposure for unrelated corporate litigation.

risk_inventory.title: No Disclosure Schedule for Litigation
risk_inventory.description: Unlike the hazardous materials representation in Section 7A(vi) which references 'Exhibit H' for exceptions, the litigation representation contains no carve-out for disclosed matters. If there is any pending or threatened litigation, Seller cannot make this representation truthfully without a disclosure schedule. Additionally, if litigation arises between signing and Closing, there is no mechanism for supplemental disclosure without breaching the bring-down condition.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: there is no litigation pending or threatened against Seller
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Add 'except as disclosed on Exhibit ___' and require Seller disclosure.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Add disclosure mechanism: 'To Seller's Actual Knowledge, except as set forth on Exhibit ___ attached hereto, there is no litigation, arbitration, or administrative proceeding pending or threatened against Seller or affecting the Property.' Also reference Section 7A(vi) procedure for updating disclosures between signing and Closing.

risk_inventory.title: Condemnation Rep Limited to Seller's Actual Knowledge
risk_inventory.description: Condemnation and eminent domain proceedings are matters of public record and published notice. Qualifying this representation by 'Seller's Actual Knowledge' allows Seller to avoid liability even if condemnation proceedings are publicly pending but Seller's designated representative did not personally know about them. Condemnation can dramatically affect property value, and Buyer should have stronger protection.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: To Seller's Actual Knowledge, no condemnation or eminent domain proceedings are pending or threatened against the Property
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Remove knowledge qualifier or add Seller duty to investigate public records.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Either remove the knowledge qualifier entirely: 'No condemnation or eminent domain proceedings are pending or threatened against the Property, and Seller has received no notice of any contemplated condemnation or eminent domain proceedings.' Alternatively, add a duty of inquiry: 'To Seller's Actual Knowledge (after reasonable inquiry of the applicable governmental authorities), no condemnation or eminent domain proceedings are pending or threatened against the Property.' Also add post-signing notice requirement similar to Section 7A(iii).

risk_inventory.title: No Post-Signing Condemnation Notice Obligation
risk_inventory.description: Unlike Section 7A(iii) regarding violation notices which requires Seller to 'immediately provide Buyer with a copy of any such notices received after the Effective Date,' the condemnation representation contains no similar obligation. If Seller learns of threatened condemnation between signing and Closing, there is no express duty to notify Buyer. While Section 14 addresses destruction/condemnation occurring before Closing, it is triggered by the event itself, not notice of threatened proceedings.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: no condemnation or eminent domain proceedings are pending or threatened against the Property
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Add post-signing notice obligation for condemnation threats.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Add notice and remedy provisions: 'To Seller's Actual Knowledge, no condemnation or eminent domain proceedings are pending or threatened against the Property. Seller shall immediately notify Buyer in writing if Seller receives any notice or otherwise becomes aware of any condemnation or eminent domain proceedings that are pending, threatened, or contemplated against all or any portion of the Property after the Effective Date. Upon receipt of such notice, the provisions of Section 14 shall apply.'

risk_inventory.title: Inconsistent Knowledge Qualifier Standard
risk_inventory.description: This paragraph uses 'to the best of Seller's knowledge' while other sections use 'to Seller's Actual Knowledge.' The phrase 'best of knowledge' could imply a duty to investigate, but this inconsistency creates ambiguity about the applicable standard and could lead to disputes about what Seller was required to know.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: To the best of Seller's knowledge
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Conform all knowledge qualifiers to use the defined term 'Seller's Actual Knowledge' consistently.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Replace all instances of 'To the best of Seller's knowledge' in this paragraph with 'To Seller's Actual Knowledge' to ensure consistency with the defined term in Section 7A(vi) (p_59) and avoid any argument that a different standard applies to these representations.

risk_inventory.title: Uncapped Exhibit H Disclosure Carve-Out
risk_inventory.description: The representation regarding tenant concessions is subject to exceptions disclosed on Exhibit H. Buyer should carefully review Exhibit H to ensure it does not contain sweeping exceptions that gut this representation. The carve-out allows Seller to disclose any tenant concessions or allowances without liability.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: except as set forth on Exhibit H hereto
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Review Exhibit H carefully and negotiate to limit scope of permitted disclosures.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Buyer's counsel should immediately review Exhibit H to determine what concessions and allowances are being disclosed. Consider adding language that Exhibit H shall not be amended after the Effective Date without Buyer's consent, or that material additions to Exhibit H after Due Diligence shall give Buyer a termination right.

risk_inventory.title: Representation Limited to Existing Leases Only
risk_inventory.description: The representations are limited to 'leases in existence as of the Effective Date,' which could exclude new leases entered into between Effective Date and Closing. Buyer may be exposed to undisclosed concessions or commissions on leases executed after the Effective Date.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: any lease in existence as of the Effective Date
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Expand representation to cover all leases through Closing Date.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Modify the representation to read 'any lease in existence as of the Effective Date or entered into prior to Closing in accordance with this Agreement' to ensure Buyer receives the same protections for any new leases Seller may execute during the contract period pursuant to Section 8.

risk_inventory.title: Materiality Qualifier on Lease Copies
risk_inventory.description: The representation that lease copies are 'true, correct and complete in all material respects' allows Seller to have immaterial inaccuracies in the leases provided. While standard, this could allow Seller to omit side letters or amendments that individually appear immaterial but collectively affect lease economics.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: true, correct and complete in all material respects
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Consider removing 'in all material respects' for more complete lease disclosure.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Consider removing 'in all material respects' so the representation reads 'true, correct and complete' without qualification. Alternatively, add a representation that all amendments, side letters, and modifications to the leases have been provided to Buyer.

risk_inventory.title: No Duty to Investigate for Knowledge
risk_inventory.description: The definition of 'Seller's Actual Knowledge' is limited to a single named individual's actual knowledge 'without such person undertaking any investigation.' This extremely narrow standard means Seller has no obligation to make any inquiry, and the knowledge of all other Seller personnel, property managers, or agents is excluded. This could allow Seller to claim ignorance of material issues.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: without such person undertaking any investigation
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Add duty of reasonable inquiry and expand knowledge parties to include property manager.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Revise to read: 'the actual knowledge of [named individual] and [property manager], after reasonable inquiry of such persons' direct reports and review of the Property files.' This imposes a minimal investigation duty and includes the property manager who typically has day-to-day knowledge of Property operations, tenant issues, and physical condition.

risk_inventory.title: Representations Auto-Modified by Due Diligence Materials
risk_inventory.description: This provision automatically deems Seller's representations modified to conform to any inconsistent information in the Due Diligence Materials. This is extremely Seller-favorable because it shifts the burden to Buyer to identify all inconsistencies, effectively negating representations if contrary information is buried anywhere in the due diligence documents.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: such representations and warranties shall be deemed modified to the extent necessary to eliminate such inconsistency and to conform such representations and warranties to such Due Diligence Materials
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Delete auto-modification clause or limit to express written disclosures on a schedule.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Delete this sentence entirely. If Seller insists on some protection, replace with: 'In the event of any inconsistency between the representations and warranties and information expressly disclosed in a schedule attached to this Agreement, the disclosure on such schedule shall control.' This limits the modification to scheduled disclosures rather than anything buried in a document room.

risk_inventory.title: Buyer Covenant Not to Sue Knowledge Individuals
risk_inventory.description: Buyer covenants not to bring any action against the named knowledge individuals personally. While it is reasonable to protect employees from personal liability, this language is broad ('any action of any kind') and could be read to prevent Buyer from even deposing these individuals in litigation against Seller.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: Buyer covenants that it will bring no action of any kind against any such individuals related to or arising out of the representations and warranties
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Clarify that covenant only bars claims for personal liability, not discovery.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Revise to read: 'Buyer covenants that it will bring no action seeking personal monetary liability against any such individuals related to or arising out of the representations and warranties set forth in Section 7.1 of this Agreement, provided that this covenant shall not limit Buyer's right to seek discovery from such individuals in any action against Seller.'

risk_inventory.title: Broad Pre-Closing Waiver of Representation Claims
risk_inventory.description: If Buyer closes with knowledge of a breach, Buyer waives all remedies including rescission. This is a significant risk because 'knowledge' is broadly defined to include anything in the 'Property Information' that is inconsistent with a representation—meaning Buyer could be deemed to know of issues buried in documents it may not have fully reviewed.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: Buyer hereby expressly waives, relinquishes and releases any right or remedy available to it at law, in equity or under this Agreement to make a claim against Seller for damages that Buyer may incur, or to rescind this Agreement
