risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Delete waiver or limit to matters expressly disclosed in writing by Seller.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Revise this provision to read: 'In the event the Closing occurs and Buyer had actual knowledge (as opposed to constructive or deemed knowledge) that a representation or warranty was materially untrue based on express written disclosure by Seller specifically identifying the representation affected, Buyer shall be deemed to have waived its claim with respect to such specifically disclosed matter only.' This limits the waiver to matters Seller expressly brings to Buyer's attention.

risk_inventory.title: Deemed Knowledge from Property Information
risk_inventory.description: Buyer is 'deemed to have known' of representation breaches if any 'Property Information' contains inconsistent information. This constructive knowledge standard is extremely broad and could trap Buyer if adverse information is buried in voluminous due diligence materials that Buyer did not specifically review.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: Buyer shall be 'deemed to have known' that a representation or warranty was untrue, inaccurate or incorrect at the time of the Closing if any Property Information furnished or made available to or otherwise obtained by Buyer contains express information which is inconsistent with such representation or warranty
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Delete deemed knowledge provision or limit to information in specifically identified documents.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Delete this sentence. Alternatively, revise to: 'Buyer shall be deemed to have known that a representation or warranty was untrue if Seller delivers to Buyer, prior to Closing, a written notice specifically identifying the representation or warranty and the inconsistent facts.' This requires Seller to affirmatively bring issues to Buyer's attention rather than relying on buried disclosures.

risk_inventory.title: $50,000 Aggregate Deductible on Claims
risk_inventory.description: Buyer cannot make claims for representation breaches unless aggregate damages exceed $50,000. While baskets are market, this provision operates as a true deductible (Buyer cannot recover the first $50,000) rather than a threshold (where once exceeded, Buyer recovers from dollar one). The aggregate nature means multiple smaller issues could individually fall below the threshold.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: Buyer's damages as a result of such representations or warranties being untrue, inaccurate or incorrect are, in the aggregate, less than $50,000
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Negotiate for threshold (not deductible) or lower amount; clarify multiple claims aggregate.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Revise to read: '(2) Buyer's damages as a result of such representations or warranties being untrue, inaccurate or incorrect are, in the aggregate, less than $25,000; provided that once Buyer's aggregate damages exceed $25,000, Buyer may recover all damages from dollar one.' This converts the deductible to a threshold and reduces the amount.

risk_inventory.title: Blank Aggregate Liability Cap
risk_inventory.description: The aggregate liability cap is left blank ($_________). This is a critical negotiating point that must be resolved. If the cap is set too low relative to the purchase price, Buyer's remedies for material breaches could be severely limited. Typical caps range from 1-3% of purchase price for non-fundamental representations.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: shall not exceed $___________, in the aggregate
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Negotiate cap at minimum 3-5% of Purchase Price; exclude fraud and intentional misconduct.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Fill in the blank with an appropriate percentage of the Purchase Price (suggest 3-5% minimum). Add exclusions: 'provided that this limitation shall not apply to (a) claims arising from Seller's fraud or intentional misconduct, (b) breaches of Seller's covenants under Section 8, (c) Seller's indemnification obligations under Section 5.2, or (d) claims covered by the Deed warranties.' This ensures the cap does not protect Seller from egregious conduct.

risk_inventory.title: Liability Cap Applies to Both Parties
risk_inventory.description: The cap applies to 'either party,' meaning Buyer's liability to Seller is also capped. While this appears balanced, Buyer's primary exposure is losing the deposit (which is already addressed in Section 13.1), so a mutual cap may give Seller more protection than Buyer. The cap should be asymmetric if Seller's potential liability exposure is greater.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: the aggregate liability of either party arising pursuant to or in connection with the representations, warranties, covenants and other obligations
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Consider asymmetric caps given different risk profiles of each party.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Consider whether the cap should be asymmetric. Buyer's primary exposure for breach is the liquidated damages provision in Section 13.1 (deposit forfeiture). The cap may be more important for limiting Seller's exposure. If retained as mutual, ensure the cap amount is appropriate for both parties' exposure profiles.

risk_inventory.title: Cap Covers All Obligations Including Covenants
risk_inventory.description: The liability cap applies not just to representations and warranties but to 'covenants and other obligations (whether express or implied).' This could limit Buyer's recovery for breach of Seller's operating covenants, failure to deliver documents, or other contractual obligations beyond just rep breaches.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: representations, warranties, covenants and other obligations (whether express or implied)
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Limit cap to representations and warranties only; exclude covenants.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Revise to read: 'the aggregate liability of Seller arising pursuant to or in connection with the representations and warranties of Seller in Section 7.1 of this Agreement shall not exceed $[X].' This limits the cap to representation claims and excludes covenant breaches, indemnification obligations, and other contractual duties.

risk_inventory.title: Introductory Language Only - No Substantive Content
risk_inventory.description: This paragraph is merely introductory language for Buyer's representations and warranties. The actual representations follow in subsequent paragraphs. No risks in this specific paragraph, but Buyer should ensure its representations are appropriately qualified and not broader than necessary.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: Buyer hereby represents and warrants that:
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Review subsequent Buyer representations for appropriate qualifications.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Review paragraphs p_63 and p_64 for Buyer's substantive representations to ensure they are appropriately limited in scope and qualified where necessary. Buyer's representations should be symmetrical with Seller's where appropriate.

risk_inventory.title: Buyer Rep Broader Than Seller's Equivalent
risk_inventory.description: Buyer's organizational representation includes 'in good standing' and 'full right, power and authority,' which is broader than Seller's equivalent representation in Section 7A(i) (p_53). This asymmetry means Buyer bears a higher standard of warranty than Seller for equivalent organizational matters. Additionally, Buyer's representation is unqualified while many of Seller's representations are limited by 'Seller's Actual Knowledge.'
risk_inventory.problematic_text: duly organized, validly existing and in good standing under the laws of the State of __________, with full right, power and authority
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Request parallel language for Seller's organizational rep or soften Buyer's language.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Either (a) modify Buyer's representation to match the Seller's organizational representation in p_53 by removing 'in good standing' if not included there, or (b) alternatively, propose reciprocal language requiring Seller to also represent 'good standing' and 'full right, power and authority' in p_53. The goal is symmetry between the parties' organizational warranties.

risk_inventory.title: Unqualified No-Violation Rep Creates Risk
risk_inventory.description: Buyer represents that execution 'do not, and at the time of Closing will not, violate any provisions of any contract or judicial order.' This is an absolute, unqualified representation with no materiality qualifier. Minor technical violations of any contract could theoretically constitute a breach. Compare this to Seller's representations which are heavily qualified by 'Seller's Actual Knowledge.'
risk_inventory.problematic_text: do not, and at the time of Closing will not, violate any provisions of any contract or judicial order to which Buyer is a party or to which Buyer is subject
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Add materiality qualifier: 'do not materially violate' or knowledge qualifier.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Revise the representation to read: 'do not, and at the time of Closing will not, to Buyer's knowledge, violate in any material respect any provisions of any contract or judicial order to which Buyer is a party or to which Buyer is subject.' This adds both a knowledge qualifier (consistent with how Seller's reps are qualified) and a materiality threshold to prevent technical foot-faults from constituting a breach.

risk_inventory.title: 6-Month Survival Period Too Short for Buyer
risk_inventory.description: The six-month survival period for representations and warranties is extremely short and favors Seller. Many breaches of Seller's representations (particularly regarding the rent roll, litigation, environmental matters, or lease compliance) may not be discoverable until well after six months of ownership. Industry standard for commercial real estate is typically 12-18 months. This short period significantly limits Buyer's ability to seek recourse for Seller misrepresentations.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: shall survive for a period of six (6) months from the Closing Date
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Negotiate for 12-18 month survival period, minimum 12 months.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Revise the survival period from 'six (6) months' to 'twelve (12) months' or 'eighteen (18) months.' Additionally, consider adding a carve-out for fraud, intentional misrepresentation, or willful misconduct which should survive indefinitely or for the applicable statute of limitations period. Proposed language: 'shall survive for a period of eighteen (18) months from the Closing Date; provided, however, that claims based on fraud, intentional misrepresentation, or willful misconduct shall survive until the expiration of the applicable statute of limitations.'

risk_inventory.title: Auto-Termination of Claims Not in Litigation
risk_inventory.description: The provision automatically terminates 'any cause of action resulting from a breach thereof not then in litigation' at the end of the Survival Period. This requires Buyer to actually file litigation (not merely give notice of a claim or begin negotiations) to preserve claims. This is more restrictive than provisions allowing claims to survive if written notice is given within the survival period.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: any cause of action resulting from a breach thereof not then in litigation
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Change to allow survival if written notice of claim given within period.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Revise the termination language to read: 'at which time such representations and warranties (and any cause of action resulting from a breach thereof as to which Buyer has not given written notice to Seller specifying in reasonable detail the nature of such breach) shall terminate.' This allows Buyer to preserve claims by giving written notice rather than requiring actual litigation to be commenced within the survival period.

risk_inventory.title: Termination as Sole Remedy for Seller's Changed Reps
risk_inventory.description: If Seller discovers that a representation has become incorrect after the Due Diligence Period, Buyer's 'sole remedy' is termination. This means Buyer cannot pursue damages even if Seller's misrepresentation was negligent or caused Buyer to incur significant costs. This effectively allows Seller to disclose problems at the last minute and escape liability by allowing Buyer to terminate, putting all risk of wasted due diligence costs, financing costs, and opportunity costs on Buyer.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: Buyer's termination of this Agreement shall be Buyer's sole remedy against Seller in the circumstances described in this paragraph
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Preserve right to damages for misrepresentation, add expense reimbursement at minimum.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Delete 'shall be Buyer's sole remedy against Seller in the circumstances described in this paragraph' and replace with: 'shall not preclude Buyer from seeking recovery of Buyer's actual out-of-pocket costs and expenses incurred in connection with this transaction, including but not limited to due diligence costs, legal fees, financing costs, and inspection expenses, subject to a cap of $_______. Nothing herein shall limit Buyer's remedies for fraud or intentional misrepresentation.' Alternatively, add reimbursement of Buyer's transaction expenses upon termination under this provision.

risk_inventory.title: Compressed Decision Timeline on Changed Reps
risk_inventory.description: If Seller notifies of a changed representation late in the process, Buyer has only 10 days (or until Closing if less than 10 days remain) to evaluate and decide whether to terminate. Seller then has 5 days to elect to cure. This compressed timeline may not allow Buyer sufficient time to assess the impact of material new information, particularly if it involves complex issues like environmental contamination, title defects, or tenant disputes.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: Buyer may elect within ten (10) days after receipt of such notice (or, if such notice is received less than ten days prior to the Closing Date, Buyer may elect on or before the Closing Date)
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Require minimum 15 days for Buyer evaluation, automatic Closing extension if needed.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Revise to provide: 'Buyer may elect within fifteen (15) days after receipt of such notice to provide written notice to Seller of Buyer's intent to terminate this Agreement; provided that if such notice is received less than fifteen (15) days prior to the scheduled Closing Date, the Closing Date shall be automatically extended to provide Buyer the full fifteen (15) day evaluation period.' This ensures Buyer always has adequate time to assess material changes.

risk_inventory.title: Seller Cure Right Delays Closing Without Cost
risk_inventory.description: If Buyer elects to terminate due to a changed representation, Seller can elect to cure, making Seller's cure a 'condition precedent to Buyer's obligations.' However, there is no deadline for Seller's cure, no requirement that Seller bear the costs of delay, and no compensation to Buyer if Seller's cure attempts fail. Buyer could be held in limbo while Seller attempts to cure, incurring carrying costs and losing other opportunities.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: Seller may within five (5) days after receipt of such termination notice (or, if such termination notice is received less than five days prior to the Closing Date, on or before the Closing Date) notify Buyer of Seller's intent to cure the condition causing such misrepresentation prior to Closing, in which event Seller's cure of such condition shall be a condition precedent to Buyer's obligations hereunder
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Add cure deadline, Buyer expense reimbursement if cure fails, right to terminate if cure exceeds 30 days.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Revise to add: 'Seller's cure period shall not exceed thirty (30) days from Seller's notice of intent to cure, and the Closing Date shall be extended accordingly. If Seller fails to cure the condition within such thirty (30) day period, Buyer may terminate this Agreement and receive a return of the Deposit together with reimbursement of Buyer's actual out-of-pocket transaction costs incurred after the original Closing Date, up to a maximum of $_______. Seller shall provide Buyer with weekly written updates on cure progress.'

risk_inventory.title: Covenant Period Has No Post-Termination Tail
risk_inventory.description: Seller's covenants apply 'between the Effective Date and the Closing or earlier termination of this Agreement.' If the Agreement terminates (for any reason), Seller's covenants immediately cease. This is standard, but if there are any surviving obligations or wind-down activities, Buyer would have no contractual protection for Seller's conduct during any interim period before termination is fully effectuated.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: Between the Effective Date and the Closing or earlier termination of this Agreement
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Confirm survival provisions adequately cover any post-termination exposure.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: This is informational. Review the survival provisions (p_65, p_38) to ensure any breaches of Seller's covenants that occurred prior to termination remain actionable. Consider adding: 'provided that any breach of the covenants set forth herein occurring prior to such termination shall survive termination for the Survival Period set forth in Section 7(c).'

risk_inventory.title: Deemed Approval After 5 Days
risk_inventory.description: Buyer's consent to new leases, lease modifications, or lease terminations is 'conclusively deemed granted' if Buyer does not object within 5 days of Seller's request. This is an extremely short window for Buyer to review potentially complex lease documents, evaluate tenant creditworthiness, and assess the impact on property value. If Buyer is traveling, distracted by other matters, or experiences any delay in receiving the notice, Buyer could inadvertently approve a lease that materially affects the Property's value or operations.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: Buyer's consent shall conclusively be deemed granted if Buyer does not object to a proposed new lease, lease modification or lease termination within five (5) days after Seller has provided Buyer with a written request for approval
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Extend deemed approval period to 10-15 business days.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Replace 'five (5) days' with 'ten (10) business days' and add language requiring that Seller's request must include complete copies of all relevant lease documents and a summary of material terms. Consider adding: 'Failure to provide complete documentation shall toll the approval period until such documentation is provided.'

amplified_by.effect: Buyer becomes responsible for all leasing commissions and TI costs for approved leases

risk_inventory.title: Buyer Assumes All Leasing Costs Post-Approval
risk_inventory.description: If Buyer approves (or is deemed to approve) any new lease or lease modification, Buyer becomes 'responsible for all leasing commissions, tenant improvements and other costs payable by the Landlord thereunder' from Closing. This could represent significant unexpected costs, especially if combined with the 5-day deemed approval provision. There is no cap on these costs, no requirement that Seller disclose estimated costs when seeking approval, and no distinction between costs arising before vs. after Closing.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: If any new lease or Lease modification is entered into with Buyer's approval as set forth above, then from and after Closing Buyer shall be responsible for all leasing commissions, tenant improvements and other costs payable by the Landlord thereunder.
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Require cost disclosure; cap Buyer's exposure; allocate pre-Closing costs to Seller.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Modify to: 'If any new lease or Lease modification is entered into with Buyer's prior written approval (which approval shall not be deemed granted), Buyer shall be responsible for leasing commissions, tenant improvements and other landlord costs thereunder that accrue or become due after Closing. Seller shall remain responsible for all such costs that accrue or become due prior to Closing. Seller's request for approval shall include a detailed estimate of all anticipated leasing commissions, tenant improvement costs, and other landlord obligations under the proposed lease or modification.'

amplified_by.effect: Deemed approval after 5 days could trigger cost assumption without informed consent

risk_inventory.title: Vague 'Same Manner' Operating Standard
risk_inventory.description: During the Due Diligence Period, Seller must maintain and operate the Property 'in the same manner in which Seller is currently operating.' This standard is subjective and difficult to enforce. It does not require Seller to maintain the Property in good condition, comply with all laws, or meet any objective standard—only to continue whatever practices Seller was employing, which could be substandard.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: Seller shall continue to maintain, operate, and lease the Property in the same manner in which Seller is currently operating, maintaining and leasing the Property
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Add objective standards: 'in good condition' and 'in compliance with applicable laws.'
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Revise to: 'Seller shall continue to maintain, operate, and lease the Property (i) in the same manner in which Seller is currently operating, maintaining and leasing the Property, (ii) in good condition and repair, ordinary wear and tear excepted, (iii) in compliance with all applicable laws, and (iv) in accordance with the terms of all Leases and Service Contracts.'

risk_inventory.title: No Lease Consent Rights During Due Diligence
risk_inventory.description: The consent requirement for new leases, modifications, or terminations only applies 'After the Due Diligence Period expires.' During the Due Diligence Period itself, Seller appears free to enter into new leases or modify/terminate existing leases without Buyer's consent, as long as it's consistent with Seller's current manner of leasing. This could allow Seller to lock in unfavorable long-term leases before Buyer has completed its review.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: After the Due Diligence Period expires, Seller shall not modify or terminate any lease, or enter into any new lease, without the prior written consent of Buyer
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Require Buyer consent for material leasing activity from Effective Date.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Revise to: 'From and after the Effective Date, Seller shall not modify or terminate any lease, or enter into any new lease, without the prior written consent of Buyer, which consent shall not be unreasonably withheld, conditioned or delayed; provided that during the Due Diligence Period, Buyer may withhold consent in its sole and absolute discretion.'

mitigated_by.effect: Buyer can terminate during DD period if it discovers unfavorable leasing

risk_inventory.title: Broad Exception for 'Reasonably Necessary' Contracts
risk_inventory.description: While Seller generally needs Buyer's consent to enter into, modify, or terminate Service Contracts, there is a broad exception for contracts 'deemed reasonably necessary by Seller which are cancelable on thirty (30) days' notice without penalty.' The determination of what is 'reasonably necessary' is made by Seller, not an objective standard, and Seller could enter into unfavorable contracts under this exception that burden Buyer post-Closing.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: except those deemed reasonably necessary by Seller which are cancelable on thirty (30) days' notice without penalty
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Require notice to Buyer of all new contracts; limit exception to emergency situations.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Revise to: 'except those that are (i) necessary to address an emergency threatening imminent harm to persons or material damage to the Property, (ii) cancelable on thirty (30) days' notice without penalty or premium, and (iii) on market terms. Seller shall provide Buyer with written notice of any such contract within two (2) business days of execution, together with a copy thereof.'

mitigated_by.effect: Contracts under this exception must be cancelable on 30 days notice

risk_inventory.title: Seller Not Obligated to Terminate Contracts Creating Cost
risk_inventory.description: Seller is not obligated to terminate any Service Contract that Buyer does not want to assume 'if such termination will create any additional cost or liability for Seller.' This could leave Buyer saddled with unwanted, long-term, or above-market service contracts if termination would cost Seller anything. There is no provision for Buyer to offer to pay the termination cost or for the parties to share such costs.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: Seller shall not be obligated to terminate any Service Contract if such termination will create any additional cost or liability for Seller
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Allow Buyer to pay termination costs to exit unwanted contracts.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Add: 'Notwithstanding the foregoing, if Buyer elects not to assume any Service Contract and termination thereof would create additional cost or liability, Buyer may elect to pay such termination cost or liability (not to exceed $_____), in which case Seller shall terminate such Service Contract effective as of the Closing Date. If Buyer does not so elect and Seller does not terminate such Service Contract, Buyer shall have the right to terminate this Agreement and receive a refund of the Deposit if the aggregate annual cost of non-terminable Service Contracts that Buyer has elected not to assume exceeds $_____.'

amplified_by.effect: AS-IS provision may limit Buyer's recourse for assuming unfavorable contracts

risk_inventory.title: Insurance Maintenance Limited to 'Currently in Force'
risk_inventory.description: Seller's obligation is only to 'maintain all casualty and liability insurance currently in force.' There is no requirement that current insurance is adequate, that it meets any particular coverage levels, or that it complies with lender requirements. If current coverage is deficient, Seller has no obligation to cure that deficiency.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: Seller shall maintain all casualty and liability insurance currently in force with respect to the Property
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Require insurance meeting specified minimums and lender requirements.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Revise to: 'Seller shall maintain all casualty and liability insurance currently in force with respect to the Property, but in no event less than (i) property/casualty insurance in an amount not less than the full replacement cost of the Improvements, (ii) commercial general liability insurance with limits of not less than $_____ per occurrence and $_____ aggregate, and (iii) such other insurance as may be required by any lender holding a lien on the Property or by any Lease. Seller shall provide Buyer with certificates of insurance upon request.'

amplified_by.effect: Inadequate insurance could leave Buyer exposed if casualty occurs before Closing

risk_inventory.title: Only 'Commercially Reasonable Efforts' for Estoppels
risk_inventory.description: Seller's obligation to obtain tenant estoppels is limited to 'commercially reasonable efforts.' This is a lower standard than 'best efforts' and provides Seller significant latitude. If Seller fails to obtain the Minimum Tenant Estoppels, Buyer's only remedy is termination—there is no right to specific performance or damages, and no obligation for Seller to use stronger efforts.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: Seller shall use commercially reasonable efforts to obtain an estoppel statement from each tenant
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Require 'best efforts' or define specific actions Seller must take.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Revise to: 'Seller shall use best efforts to obtain an estoppel statement from each tenant, substantially in the form of Exhibit G ("Tenant Estoppels"). Such efforts shall include, without limitation, (i) delivering estoppel requests to all tenants within five (5) business days after the Effective Date, (ii) following up with tenants who have not responded within ten (10) days, and (iii) if requested by Buyer, providing rent concessions or other reasonable incentives to tenants to encourage timely response.'

mitigated_by.effect: Buyer can terminate if Minimum Tenant Estoppels not obtained

risk_inventory.title: Seller's Certificate Substitutes for Missing Estoppels
risk_inventory.description: If Seller obtains the Minimum Tenant Estoppels but cannot obtain estoppels from remaining tenants, Buyer must accept a 'Seller's Lease Certificate' certifying (only 'to Seller's knowledge') the matters in the estoppel form. This certificate is far less valuable than a tenant estoppel because: (1) it's qualified by Seller's knowledge, (2) Seller may have limited liability for inaccuracies (see survival and liability provisions), and (3) it doesn't bind the tenant.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: Buyer shall accept a certificate of Seller ("Seller's Lease Certificate") certifying, to Seller's knowledge, those matters included in the attached form of Tenant Estoppel regarding the lease(s) with such tenant(s)
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Limit use of Seller's Certificate; require indemnity for inaccuracies; extend survival.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Add after the existing text: 'Seller's Lease Certificate shall not be subject to any knowledge qualification and Seller shall indemnify and hold Buyer harmless from any loss, cost, damage or expense arising from any inaccuracy in any Seller's Lease Certificate, which indemnification obligation shall survive Closing for a period of [eighteen (18) months / the Survival Period]. Notwithstanding the foregoing, Buyer shall not be required to accept a Seller's Lease Certificate with respect to any tenant occupying more than _____ rentable square feet or any tenant whose Lease has a remaining term (including renewal options) of more than _____ years.'

amplified_by.effect: Narrow knowledge definition limits utility of Seller's Certificate
Limited survival period may expire before lease issues materialize

risk_inventory.title: Subordination Agreements Conditioned on Lease Terms
risk_inventory.description: Seller's obligation to cooperate in obtaining subordination agreements (SNDAs) is heavily conditioned: only if the tenant's lease permits such a request. Additionally, Seller has 'no obligation to obtain and deliver' any subordination agreements—only to 'cooperate.' This may leave Buyer unable to satisfy lender requirements for subordination agreements.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: Seller agrees to cooperate with Buyer to obtain subordination agreements from tenants on the Property and deliver same to Buyer; provided said tenants' leases permit the landlord to request a subordination agreement from the Tenant and provided, further, Seller shall have no obligation to obtain and deliver any such subordination agreements to Buyer
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Require Seller to use commercially reasonable efforts to obtain SNDAs.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Revise to: 'Seller shall use commercially reasonable efforts to obtain subordination, non-disturbance and attornment agreements ("SNDAs") from tenants in a form reasonably required by Buyer's lender. If Seller is unable to obtain an SNDA from any tenant whose lease does not permit landlord to require same, Seller shall (i) notify Buyer in writing and (ii) use commercially reasonable efforts to negotiate with such tenant for execution of an SNDA.'

risk_inventory.title: Comprehensive AS-IS Waiver Including Environmental
risk_inventory.description: This extremely broad AS-IS provision disclaims virtually all warranties and representations except those expressly stated in Section 7. Of particular concern, it disclaims representations regarding: (x) presence or absence of hazardous materials, (ix) compliance with environmental laws, (vii) compliance with all laws, and (xi) accuracy of due diligence materials. This shifts substantial risk to Buyer, particularly environmental risk which can result in significant remediation costs and liability.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: (IX) COMPLIANCE WITH ANY ENVIRONMENTAL PROTECTION, POLLUTION OR LAND USE LAWS, RULES, REGULATIONS, ORDERS OR REQUIREMENTS; (X) THE PRESENCE OR ABSENCE OF HAZARDOUS MATERIALS AT, ON, UNDER, OR ADJACENT TO THE PROPERTY
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Carve out environmental matters from AS-IS; add environmental rep to Section 7.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Add to the AS-IS provision: 'Notwithstanding the foregoing, the disclaimers set forth in this Section 9 shall not apply to (i) any claims arising from Seller's fraud or intentional misrepresentation, (ii) any claims arising from Seller's breach of the representations and warranties set forth in Section 7, or (iii) [environmental conditions that existed prior to the Effective Date to the extent Seller had actual knowledge thereof and failed to disclose same to Buyer].' Additionally, consider adding an environmental representation to Section 7: 'To Seller's Actual Knowledge, except as disclosed in the environmental reports included in the Due Diligence Documents, there are no Hazardous Materials located on, under or about the Property in violation of applicable Environmental Laws.'

mitigated_by.effect: Section 7 representations are carved out from AS-IS

amplified_by.effect: Section 10 Release compounds this waiver with an affirmative release
Short survival period limits time to discover and assert claims

risk_inventory.title: Waiver of Reliance on Due Diligence Materials
risk_inventory.description: Buyer expressly agrees it is 'relying solely on its own investigation' and not on 'any information provided or to be provided by Seller.' This waiver extends to the accuracy and completeness of due diligence materials, meaning Buyer may have no recourse even if Seller provided materially inaccurate information (outside of Section 7 reps). This significantly undermines the value of the due diligence process.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: BUYER IS, EXCEPT FOR SELLER'S REPRESENTATIONS AND WARRANTIES CONTAINED IN SECTION 7 HEREIN, RELYING SOLELY ON ITS OWN INVESTIGATION OF THE PROPERTY AND REVIEW OF SUCH INFORMATION AND DOCUMENTATION, AND NOT ON ANY INFORMATION PROVIDED OR TO BE PROVIDED BY SELLER
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Add exception for materially misleading information provided by Seller.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Add: 'Notwithstanding the foregoing, Buyer may rely upon information provided by Seller to the extent such information is materially false or misleading and Seller had actual knowledge that such information was materially false or misleading at the time it was provided. This provision shall not limit any claim for fraud.'

mitigated_by.effect: Representations in Section 7 are carved out

amplified_by.effect: Section 5.2 also disclaims reliance on DD Documents

risk_inventory.title: Release of Third-Party Information Sources
risk_inventory.description: Buyer agrees to 'fully and irrevocably release all such sources of information and preparers of information' retained by Seller from any claims. This could include environmental consultants, property condition assessors, and others whose reports may contain errors. Buyer would be precluded from pursuing claims against these parties even if their reports were negligently prepared.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: BUYER AGREES TO FULLY AND IRREVOCABLY RELEASE ALL SUCH SOURCES OF INFORMATION AND PREPARERS OF INFORMATION AND DOCUMENTATION AFFECTING THE PROPERTY WHICH WERE RETAINED BY SELLER FROM ANY AND ALL CLAIMS
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Delete third-party release or limit to parties with no direct contractual relationship.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Revise to: 'Buyer agrees not to pursue claims against third-party sources of information retained by Seller for matters disclosed in reports provided to Buyer during the Due Diligence Period, except to the extent such third parties had a direct contractual relationship with Buyer or provided reliance letters to Buyer. This release shall not apply to claims for fraud, gross negligence, or willful misconduct.'

mitigated_by.effect: Carve-out exists for claims based on direct relationship with preparers

risk_inventory.title: No Seller Obligation to Repair
risk_inventory.description: The AS-IS provision expressly states that 'SELLER HAS NO OBLIGATIONS TO MAKE REPAIRS, REPLACEMENTS OR IMPROVEMENTS.' Combined with the covenant in Section 8(a) that only requires Seller to maintain the Property 'in the same manner' as currently, this creates a gap where Property condition could deteriorate without remedy to Buyer.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: SELLER HAS NO OBLIGATIONS TO MAKE REPAIRS, REPLACEMENTS OR IMPROVEMENTS EXCEPT AS MAY OTHERWISE BE EXPRESSLY STATED HEREIN
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Require material repairs needed for Closing; add condition precedent for Property condition.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Add to Section 8 or as a condition precedent: 'Notwithstanding Section 9, Seller shall make all repairs necessary to (i) maintain the Property in substantially the same condition as of the Effective Date, ordinary wear and tear excepted, (ii) comply with all applicable laws and codes, and (iii) comply with the terms of all Leases. If at Closing the Property is not in substantially the same condition as of the Effective Date (ordinary wear and tear excepted), Buyer may elect to (a) proceed to Closing with a credit against the Purchase Price equal to the estimated cost of such repairs, or (b) terminate this Agreement and receive a refund of the Deposit.'

amplified_by.effect: Vague operating covenant doesn't require repairs

risk_inventory.title: Sweeping release of all claims
risk_inventory.description: This release is extraordinarily broad, requiring Buyer to release Seller from 'any and all losses, liabilities, damages, claims, demands, causes of action, costs and expenses, whether known or unknown' arising from or connected with the Property. This includes structural conditions, environmental issues, and title matters. The 'whether known or unknown' language is particularly dangerous as it waives claims Buyer may not discover until after closing, potentially including latent defects, undisclosed environmental contamination, or other significant issues that due diligence may not uncover.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: shall forever release Seller, its members and principals, and its officers, directors, agents and employees, and its and their respective successors, of and from any and all losses, liabilities, damages, claims, demands, causes of action, costs and expenses, whether known or unknown, arising out of or in any way connected with the Property
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Narrow release to exclude fraud, intentional misconduct, and known but undisclosed defects.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Revise the release to carve out: (a) claims arising from fraud or intentional misrepresentation by Seller; (b) claims arising from Seller's willful misconduct or gross negligence; (c) matters actually known to Seller but not disclosed to Buyer; (d) third-party claims arising from Seller's acts or omissions prior to Closing; and (e) indemnification obligations under Section 7.1 representations. Add language stating 'This release shall not apply to any matter that Seller had actual knowledge of prior to Closing and failed to disclose to Buyer in writing.'

mitigated_by.effect: Partially preserves claims under Section 7.1 representations and post-closing obligations

amplified_by.effect: Combined with AS-IS clause, eliminates virtually all Buyer recourse
Short survival period on reps further limits window to discover and pursue excepted claims

risk_inventory.title: Broad environmental claims release
risk_inventory.description: Buyer releases Seller from 'any environmental claims and causes of action existing now or hereafter created or enacted.' This waives current and future environmental claims under laws that may not yet exist. While there is an exception for hazardous substances 'caused by Seller,' the burden of proving Seller caused the contamination will fall on Buyer, which is extremely difficult after closing when chain of custody is broken and Seller controls no records.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: Buyer will thereby forever release Seller of and from any environmental claims and causes of action existing now or hereafter created or enacted, whether at common law or by federal, state, county, or municipal law or ordinance, except for any reimbursement or contribution claims which Buyer may have against Seller under any state or federal laws regarding the release of any hazardous substances on the Property caused by Seller
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Preserve environmental claims for pre-closing contamination and require Seller's cooperation in third-party claims.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Revise the environmental release to: (a) preserve Buyer's claims for contamination that existed prior to Closing, regardless of who caused it; (b) preserve claims for contamination caused by Seller, its tenants, or any party under Seller's control during Seller's ownership period; (c) require Seller to cooperate with Buyer in any third-party environmental claims at Seller's expense to the extent related to Seller's ownership period; (d) require Seller to retain environmental records for a period of [5-10] years post-Closing and make them available to Buyer; and (e) add an indemnification from Seller for pre-closing environmental violations.

mitigated_by.effect: Environmental representation (if included) may provide limited recourse subject to survival period

amplified_by.effect: AS-IS provision combined with release leaves Buyer with minimal environmental protection

risk_inventory.title: Covenant not to sue is absolute
risk_inventory.description: The covenant that Buyer 'agrees never to commence, aid in any way, or prosecute against Seller... any action or other proceeding' is extremely broad and could be interpreted to prevent Buyer from even participating as a witness in litigation involving Seller and the Property, or from joining necessary parties in third-party claims. The 'aid in any way' language could hamper Buyer's ability to pursue legitimate claims against third parties where Seller's testimony or cooperation is needed.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: Buyer agrees never to commence, aid in any way, or prosecute against Seller, its officers, directors, agents and employees and its and their respective successors, any action or other proceeding based upon any losses, liabilities, damages, claims, demands, causes of action, costs and expenses, covered in this paragraph
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Limit covenant to direct claims, preserve rights for contribution and third-party actions.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Revise the covenant not to sue to: (a) apply only to direct claims by Buyer against Seller, not to claims where Seller is a necessary party or witness; (b) expressly preserve Buyer's right to seek contribution or indemnification from Seller in connection with third-party claims; (c) carve out claims excepted from the release in Section 10; and (d) add language that 'Nothing in this covenant shall prevent Buyer from defending itself in any action or proceeding, including by naming Seller as a necessary or indispensable party.'

risk_inventory.title: Limited survival exception for reps
risk_inventory.description: While this carve-out preserves claims under Section 7.1 representations, it is limited 'to the extent same survive Closing as provided therein.' This ties directly to Section 7.3 (p_65) which likely contains a short survival period, potentially as little as 6-12 months. Combined with the narrow 'to Seller's Actual Knowledge' qualifiers on most representations, this exception provides less protection than it appears.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: any representations and warranties made specifically by Seller in Section 7.1 above to the extent same survive Closing as provided therein
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Extend representation survival period and add specific indemnification obligations.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Strengthen this carve-out by: (a) removing the qualifier 'to the extent same survive Closing as provided therein' and instead specifying a minimum survival period of [18-24 months] directly in this section; (b) adding language that 'The survival period for representations relating to environmental matters, title, and authority shall be [3-5 years]'; (c) adding an express indemnification obligation: 'Seller shall indemnify Buyer for any breach of the foregoing representations and warranties'; and (d) specifying that the survival period shall be tolled during any period when Buyer is prevented from discovering a breach.

amplified_by.effect: Short survival period in Section 7.3 significantly limits the practical value of this carve-out
Narrow knowledge qualifier on reps reduces likelihood of successful breach claim

risk_inventory.title: Vague 'other obligations' carve-out
risk_inventory.description: The carve-out for 'any other obligations of Seller identified herein which are to be performed after Closing' is vague and may be subject to dispute. It does not specify which obligations survive, potentially leading to litigation over whether specific Seller obligations (such as proration true-ups, estoppel delivery, or cooperation with 1031 exchanges) are covered.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: any other obligations of Seller identified herein which are to be performed after Closing
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Enumerate specific post-closing obligations that survive the release.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Replace the vague reference with a specific enumeration: 'The following obligations of Seller shall survive Closing and are excepted from the foregoing release: (i) proration adjustments under Section 11.6; (ii) reconciliation obligations under Section 11.8 and 11.9; (iii) cooperation with Buyer's 1031 exchange under Section 17; (iv) any indemnification obligations under this Agreement; (v) Seller's obligation to deliver documents in Seller's possession relating to the Property; and (vi) any express survival provisions elsewhere in this Agreement.'

risk_inventory.title: Closing date left blank
risk_inventory.description: The Closing Date is left blank ('on or before ______________________'). An undefined closing date creates significant uncertainty and could result in disputes over when performance is due, when time-is-of-the-essence provisions trigger, and when default occurs. This is a critical term that should never be left undefined in an executed agreement.
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Insert specific Closing Date tied to a date certain or formula based on Effective Date.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Insert a specific closing date or a formula: 'on or before the date that is [forty-five (45)] days after the expiration of the Due Diligence Period, or such earlier date as Buyer and Seller may mutually agree in writing (the "Closing Date")'. Alternatively, insert a specific date if known. Ensure the closing date provides adequate time after due diligence expiration for Buyer to arrange financing, complete title review, and satisfy closing conditions.

amplified_by.effect: If time-is-of-the-essence, undefined date creates immediate default risk

risk_inventory.title: Extension fee is non-refundable except for Seller default
risk_inventory.description: The Extension Fee is described as 'nonrefundable, except in case of Seller's default.' This means if Buyer pays an Extension Fee but closing fails to occur for reasons other than Seller's default (e.g., title issues, failure of a condition, mutual termination, casualty), Buyer loses the Extension Fee. This is a one-sided risk allocation that could result in significant forfeiture.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: The Extension Fee shall be nonrefundable, except in case of Seller's default.
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Make Extension Fee refundable if closing fails through no fault of Buyer.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Revise to: 'The Extension Fee shall be nonrefundable, except (i) in case of Seller's default, (ii) if Closing fails to occur due to a failure of any condition precedent to Buyer's obligation to close set forth in Section 5.4 (other than conditions within Buyer's control), (iii) if this Agreement is terminated due to a casualty or condemnation under Section 13, or (iv) if the parties mutually agree to terminate this Agreement. In any such case, Seller shall promptly return the Extension Fee to Buyer.'

risk_inventory.title: Extension terms left blank
risk_inventory.description: Multiple critical extension terms are left blank: the extension period length ('_____________ day extension periods'), notice period ('at least __________ business days prior'), and Extension Fee amount ('$_______________'). These blanks create uncertainty about Buyer's extension rights and costs, which are valuable protections if Buyer needs additional time to close.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: two _____________ day extension periods, by giving written notice to Seller of its intention to extend the Closing Date, which notice shall be given at least __________ business days prior to the then-current closing date (as it may have been previously extended), in which notice shall be accompanied by payment to Seller in the amount of $_______________ (each an "Extension Fee")
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Fill in extension terms: suggest 15-day extensions, 5-day notice, and reasonable fee.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Insert reasonable terms: 'two fifteen (15) day extension periods, by giving written notice to Seller of its intention to extend the Closing Date, which notice shall be given at least five (5) business days prior to the then-current closing date (as it may have been previously extended), in which notice shall be accompanied by payment to Seller in the amount of $[insert amount representing approximately 0.1-0.25% of Purchase Price] (each an "Extension Fee")'. Ensure the extension period is sufficient to address potential delays and the fee is proportionate to the transaction size.

risk_inventory.title: Only partial credit for second extension fee
risk_inventory.description: While the first Extension Fee is fully credited to the Purchase Price, only 'one-half (1/2) of the Extension Fee' for the second extension is credited. This means Buyer effectively loses half of the second extension fee even if closing occurs, creating an additional cost for exercising this contractual right.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: one-half (1/2) of the Extension Fee paid by Buyer, if any, for the second extension shall be applicable to the Purchase Price
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Negotiate for full credit of both extension fees toward Purchase Price.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Revise to: 'The Extension Fee, if any, paid by Buyer with respect to any extension period shall be applicable to the Purchase Price.' This ensures Buyer receives full credit for extension fees if closing occurs, making the extension fee function purely as consideration for additional time rather than as a penalty.

risk_inventory.title: Strict Time-of-Essence Closing Obligation
risk_inventory.description: The requirement that all documents be executed and delivered 'on or before the Closing Date' creates a strict time obligation without express grace periods or cure rights. If Buyer encounters any delays in funding or document preparation, even minor ones, this could be characterized as a breach triggering default remedies under Section 13A (liquidated damages/deposit forfeiture).
risk_inventory.problematic_text: shall be paid, and all documents necessary for the consummation of the purchase and sale transaction contemplated hereby shall be executed and delivered on or before the Closing Date
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Add reasonable cure period for non-material closing delays.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Modify the clause to add a reasonable cure period for Buyer: After 'on or before the Closing Date,' insert: ', provided, however, that in the event Buyer fails to deliver all required funds or documents on the Closing Date due to circumstances beyond Buyer's reasonable control (excluding lack of funds), Buyer shall have two (2) business days to cure such failure without such failure constituting a default hereunder.'

risk_inventory.title: Possession Subject to Tenant Rights
risk_inventory.description: Buyer receives possession 'subject to the rights of tenants in possession under Leases' without any representation that such tenants are in compliance with their leases or that no tenants are in holdover status. This could result in Buyer taking possession with problematic tenancies, including tenants who should have vacated, tenants in default, or tenants with unexpired rights that impair Buyer's intended use.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: subject to the rights of tenants in possession under Leases
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Add representation that tenants are in compliance and not in holdover.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Modify the clause to clarify the condition of tenant possession. After 'under Leases' add: ', it being agreed that Seller represents that as of the Closing Date (i) no tenant is in material default under its Lease, (ii) no tenant is in holdover status, and (iii) all tenants in possession are parties to written Leases delivered to Buyer during the Due Diligence Period. Seller shall indemnify Buyer against any claims by or relating to any occupant of the Property whose occupancy is not pursuant to a Lease disclosed to Buyer.'

risk_inventory.title: Undefined Alternate Delivery Timeframes
risk_inventory.description: The parenthetical 'or within such timeframe as may be more specifically provided below' creates ambiguity about when certain deliverables are actually due. While this provides flexibility, it could allow Seller to argue that certain documents need not be delivered at Closing, potentially leaving Buyer without critical documents needed to verify the transaction.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: (or within such timeframe as may be more specifically provided below)
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Clarify which items may be delivered post-Closing and set deadlines.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: For clarity, modify the parenthetical to read: '(or if a different timeframe is expressly specified for a particular item below, within such specified timeframe, but in no event later than five (5) business days after the Closing Date)'. This ensures all items have a backstop deadline even if the specific provisions are ambiguous.

risk_inventory.title: No Specification of Deed Form or Warranty Type
risk_inventory.description: The clause requires delivery of 'The Deed' without specifying the form of deed (special warranty, general warranty, quitclaim, etc.) or referencing an exhibit. While Section 4C references 'Special Warranty Deed' and there is an exhibit, this delivery provision does not cross-reference those requirements, creating potential ambiguity about what form of deed satisfies Seller's obligation.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: The Deed conveying to Buyer the Real Property, Appurtenances and Improvements
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Specify deed must be Special Warranty Deed per Exhibit B.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Replace 'The Deed' with 'A Special Warranty Deed in the form attached hereto as Exhibit B,' to ensure consistency with Section 4C and remove any ambiguity about the type of deed and warranties Seller is providing.

risk_inventory.title: Deed Deliverable Lacks Express Recordability Requirement
risk_inventory.description: While a Real Estate Excise Tax Affidavit is required (suggesting recordation is contemplated), there is no express requirement that the Deed be in recordable form, properly acknowledged/notarized, and otherwise satisfy recording requirements. If the deed has technical defects preventing recording, Buyer may not discover this until after Closing.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: The Deed conveying to Buyer the Real Property, Appurtenances and Improvements, together with a Real Estate Excise Tax Affidavit
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Add requirement that Deed must be in recordable form.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Modify the clause to read: 'A Special Warranty Deed in the form attached hereto as Exhibit B, duly executed and acknowledged by Seller in recordable form, conveying to Buyer the Real Property, Appurtenances and Improvements, together with a fully completed Real Estate Excise Tax Affidavit in form acceptable for recording in the county where the Property is located'.

risk_inventory.title: Bill of Sale Without Warranty Language Specified
risk_inventory.description: The Bill of Sale is referenced as being 'in the form of Exhibit C' but the actual exhibit would need to be reviewed to confirm it includes appropriate warranties of title and freedom from liens on the personal property. Buyer should confirm Exhibit C contains adequate protections.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: The Bill of Sale duly executed by Seller, in the form of Exhibit C attached hereto
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Verify Exhibit C Bill of Sale includes title warranty.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Add clarifying language to ensure adequate warranties: 'The Bill of Sale duly executed by Seller, in the form of Exhibit C attached hereto, warranting Seller's good and marketable title to the Personal Property, free and clear of all liens, claims, and encumbrances'. Alternatively, confirm Exhibit C contains such language and add reference: 'including the warranties set forth therein'.

risk_inventory.title: Lease Assignment Lacks Tenant Consent Requirement
risk_inventory.description: The Assignment and Assumption of Leases is to be delivered by Seller, but there is no requirement that Seller obtain any consents from tenants that may be required under their Leases for assignment of the landlord's interest. Some commercial leases require landlord to obtain tenant consent or provide notice before assigning the lease. Failure to comply could give tenants termination rights or other claims.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: Two (2) counterparts of the Assignment and Assumption of Leases duly executed by Seller, assigning and conveying to Buyer the Seller's interest in, to and under the Leases
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Add Seller covenant to obtain required tenant consents pre-Closing.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Add to the delivery requirement: 'together with evidence of any tenant consents required under the Leases for assignment of the landlord's interest, or a certificate from Seller that no such consents are required under any Lease.' Additionally, consider adding to Section 8 a Seller covenant to use commercially reasonable efforts to obtain any required tenant consents prior to Closing.

risk_inventory.title: No Rent Roll or Arrears Schedule at Closing
risk_inventory.description: While Seller must assign the Leases, there is no requirement in the Closing deliverables for an updated rent roll or schedule of tenant arrears/delinquencies as of the Closing Date. The representation in Section 7A(ii) regarding the rent roll only speaks to accuracy 'as of the Effective Date.' Buyer could close without current information on which tenants are paying and which are delinquent.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: assigning and conveying to Buyer the Seller's interest in, to and under the Leases, in the form of Exhibit D attached hereto
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Require updated rent roll and delinquency schedule at Closing.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Add a new delivery item to Section 11.3: '(xii) A current rent roll certified by Seller as true and correct as of the Closing Date, including a schedule of all tenant delinquencies, prepaid rents, and security deposits held by Seller, together with any changes to the information reflected on the rent roll provided during the Due Diligence Period.'

risk_inventory.title: Lease Delivery Limited to Seller's Possession
risk_inventory.description: The delivery obligation is limited to Leases and Lease Documents 'in Seller's possession or control.' This qualifier allows Seller to avoid delivering documents it may have lost, misplaced, or that are held by third parties (property managers, prior counsel, etc.). Buyer could close without complete lease files, making it difficult to enforce lease terms, verify tenant obligations, or identify estoppel issues post-closing.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: in Seller's possession or control
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Require Seller to use best efforts to obtain all lease documents before Closing.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Modify the delivery requirement to impose a broader obligation on Seller. Replace 'in Seller's possession or control' with 'in Seller's possession or control, and Seller shall use commercially reasonable efforts to obtain any Leases or Lease Documents not in Seller's possession or control prior to Closing.' Additionally, add a representation that the delivered lease files are complete to Seller's Actual Knowledge.

risk_inventory.title: No Deadline for Outside-Escrow Delivery
risk_inventory.description: The parenthetical '(to be delivered outside of Escrow)' creates ambiguity about when these documents must be delivered. Unlike items delivered into escrow which have a clear closing deadline, documents delivered outside escrow could theoretically be delivered after closing, leaving Buyer without critical lease documentation at the time of ownership transfer.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: (to be delivered outside of Escrow)
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Specify delivery deadline for documents delivered outside escrow.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Add timing clarity by replacing '(to be delivered outside of Escrow)' with '(to be delivered to Buyer outside of Escrow no later than one (1) business day prior to Closing)' to ensure Buyer has adequate time to review lease files before taking title.

risk_inventory.title: Assignment Limited to Buyer-Continued Contracts
risk_inventory.description: The assignment covers only 'Service Contracts to be continued by Buyer after the Closing.' This language implies Buyer has selected which contracts to continue, but the mechanism and timing for that selection is in Section 8B, which gives Seller discretion over modifications. If there is any dispute about which contracts are 'to be continued,' Buyer could be left without clear assignment of beneficial contracts or inadvertently assume unfavorable ones.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: Service Contracts to be continued by Buyer after the Closing
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Cross-reference the specific schedule of assumed contracts.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Add clarity by modifying to read: 'the Service Contracts identified on Exhibit __ as contracts to be assumed by Buyer after the Closing (the "Assumed Contracts")' and ensure there is a corresponding exhibit that will be finalized and attached prior to expiration of the Due Diligence Period, subject to Buyer's approval. This creates a definitive list of assumed contracts.

risk_inventory.title: Service Contract Delivery Limited to Possession
risk_inventory.description: Similar to the lease delivery issue, delivery of Service Contracts is limited to those 'in the possession or control of Seller.' This allows Seller to avoid delivering contracts held by property managers, vendors, or other third parties. Buyer may not have complete documentation of ongoing service obligations being assumed.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: in the possession or control of Seller
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Require Seller to obtain all service contracts from property managers.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Strengthen the delivery obligation by adding: 'Seller shall use commercially reasonable efforts to obtain from its property manager and any other third parties all Service Contracts relating to the Property and not currently in Seller's possession.' Also add a Seller representation that all material Service Contracts have been delivered to Buyer.

risk_inventory.title: Copies Acceptable in Lieu of Originals
risk_inventory.description: The provision allows for 'Originals or copies' of Service Contracts. While copies are often acceptable, originals are preferable for enforceability purposes and to verify authenticity. Without originals, Buyer may face challenges if contract disputes arise with vendors.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: Originals or copies
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Require originals where available; copies only if originals unavailable.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Modify to read: 'Originals of all Service Contracts (or, if originals are not in Seller's possession or control, copies thereof certified by Seller as true and complete)'. This ensures Buyer receives the best available documentation and Seller certifies copy accuracy.

risk_inventory.title: FIRPTA Affidavit Form at Escrow Holder Discretion
risk_inventory.description: The FIRPTA affidavit must be 'in the form reasonably required by the Escrow Holder.' While 'reasonably' provides some protection, this gives Escrow Holder discretion over the form, which could create last-minute issues if Escrow Holder requires non-standard language that Seller resists. The parties lose control over the specific content of this closing document.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: in the form reasonably required by the Escrow Holder
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Attach the required FIRPTA affidavit form as an exhibit.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Replace 'in the form reasonably required by the Escrow Holder' with 'in the form attached hereto as Exhibit __, or such other form as may be reasonably required by the Escrow Holder or Title Company.' Then attach a standard FIRPTA affidavit as the referenced exhibit. This provides certainty while allowing flexibility for escrow requirements.

risk_inventory.title: Unlimited Documentation Requirements
risk_inventory.description: This provision requires Seller to deliver 'Such entity formation documents, authorizations, certificates of trust, and other documentation' as Escrow Holder or Title Company 'may require.' This is an open-ended obligation with no limitations, potentially allowing last-minute demands for extensive documentation that could delay closing or create disputes. Buyer's closing is indirectly affected if Seller balks at unreasonable requests.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: and other documentation with respect to Seller as Escrow Holder may require
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Add 'reasonably' qualifier to documentation requirements.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Modify the provision to add reasonableness standards: 'Such entity formation documents, authorizations, certificates of trust, and other documentation with respect to Seller as Escrow Holder or the Title Company may reasonably require in order to cause the Closing to occur and issue the Title Policy; provided, however, that such documentation requirements shall be consistent with customary commercial real estate closing requirements in the jurisdiction where the Property is located.'

risk_inventory.title: Title Company Controls Documentation Scope
risk_inventory.description: The Title Company's requirements for issuing the Title Policy drive documentation obligations. If the Title Company has unusual or onerous documentation requirements, Seller must comply, which could create closing delays. Conversely, if Seller cannot satisfy the Title Company, Buyer's condition precedent (receiving the Title Policy) may fail through no fault of either party.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: as the Title Company may require in order issue the Title Policy
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Confirm Title Company requirements during due diligence.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Add a sentence at the end: 'Seller agrees to cooperate with Buyer to identify any such documentation requirements of the Title Company during the Due Diligence Period. If the Title Company's requirements cannot be satisfied through commercially reasonable efforts, the parties shall cooperate in good faith to identify an alternative title insurer acceptable to Buyer.'

risk_inventory.title: Closing Statement Requires Only Seller Approval
risk_inventory.description: The closing statement is required to be 'approved in writing by Seller' but there is no corresponding requirement for Buyer approval. This creates an asymmetry where Seller controls the final closing statement without Buyer having a contractual right to review and approve prorations, credits, and adjustments. If the closing statement contains errors or unfavorable calculations, Buyer has no explicit contractual protection to require corrections before closing.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: approved in writing by Seller
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Add requirement for Buyer's written approval of closing statement.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Revise the clause to require mutual approval of the closing statement by adding 'and Buyer' after 'Seller'. The revised text should read: 'A closing statement prepared in writing by Escrow Holder and approved in writing by Seller and Buyer;' This ensures both parties must approve the final accounting before closing proceeds.

risk_inventory.title: Unlimited Additional Document Obligation on Seller
risk_inventory.description: While this clause obligates Seller to deliver additional documents 'reasonably required' to close, the phrasing is open-ended and could be interpreted narrowly by Seller. The phrase 'or otherwise to close the Escrow' is broad but may not capture all documents Buyer needs for post-closing operations (such as complete tenant files, vendor information, building systems documentation, etc.). This catch-all provision could be strengthened to ensure Buyer receives all operational documents necessary for property management.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: reasonably required by Escrow Holder or otherwise to close the Escrow
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Expand to include documents reasonably required by Buyer for property operations.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Revise the clause to explicitly include Buyer's reasonable requests and post-closing operational needs. Replace 'reasonably required by Escrow Holder or otherwise to close the Escrow' with 'reasonably required by Escrow Holder, Buyer, or the Title Company to close the Escrow and to enable Buyer to assume ownership and operation of the Property'. This ensures Buyer can request necessary operational documents as part of closing deliveries.

risk_inventory.title: Delivery Timing Framework Mirrors Seller Section
risk_inventory.description: This introductory clause for Buyer deliveries appropriately mirrors the structure of Seller's delivery obligations (Section 11.3). However, Buyer should ensure that all specific timeframes referenced in sub-sections are reasonable and achievable. The parenthetical 'or within such timeframe as may be more specifically provided below' creates flexibility but Buyer should verify no compressed timelines exist in the specific delivery requirements.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: On or before the Closing Date (or within such timeframe as may be more specifically provided below)
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Review all sub-section timeframes to confirm they are achievable.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: No change required to this clause. However, during review, confirm that any specific timeframes referenced in Sections 11.4(i) through 11.4(vii) (or however many sub-sections exist) provide Buyer adequate time to prepare and deliver all required documents. If any compressed timeframes are identified, flag for negotiation.

risk_inventory.title: Lease Assignment Execution Requirement
risk_inventory.description: This clause requires Buyer to execute the Assignment and Assumption of Leases, which is standard. However, Buyer should review the form attached as Exhibit D carefully, as execution of this document will bind Buyer to assume all landlord obligations under the Leases from the Conveyance Date forward. The form should be reviewed in conjunction with representations about lease status (Section 7.1(ii)) and any tenant estoppel requirements (Section 5.4(iv)).
risk_inventory.problematic_text: Assignment and Assumption of Leases duly executed by Buyer
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Verify Exhibit D form includes appropriate landlord liability cutoff date.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Review Exhibit D (Assignment and Assumption of Leases form) to confirm: (1) Buyer's assumption of obligations is limited to obligations arising or accruing from and after the Conveyance Date; (2) Seller retains liability for pre-closing landlord defaults or obligations; (3) the indemnification provisions in the Assignment form are mutual and appropriately balanced. Cross-reference with p_301 (Assignor indemnification of Assignee) and p_303 (Assignee assumption) to ensure consistency.

risk_inventory.title: Open-Ended Closing Document Requirement
risk_inventory.description: This clause creates an unlimited obligation for Buyer to deliver 'any other documents' that are 'reasonably required by Escrow Holder or otherwise to close the Escrow.' The phrase 'or otherwise' is dangerously vague and could be interpreted to require Buyer to execute documents beyond those contemplated in the Agreement. This open-ended language could be used by Seller or Escrow Holder to demand additional documents, guarantees, or instruments at closing that Buyer never agreed to provide, potentially as a condition to closing.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: Any other documents, instruments, records, correspondence or agreements called for hereunder which have not previously been delivered, or which are reasonably required by Escrow Holder or otherwise to close the Escrow and consummate the purchase of the Property in accordance with the terms hereof.
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Add 'reasonably' qualifier and limit to documents consistent with Agreement terms.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Revise to read: 'Such other documents and instruments as are expressly required under this Agreement and which have not previously been delivered, or which are reasonably required by Escrow Holder to effectuate the transfer of title in accordance with this Agreement; provided, however, that Buyer shall not be required to deliver any document that would (i) materially expand Buyer's obligations beyond those set forth in this Agreement, (ii) create any new representations, warranties, or indemnities, or (iii) impose any liability on Buyer not expressly contemplated herein.'

amplified_by.effect: If Buyer refuses to provide demanded documents, Seller could claim Buyer default and retain deposit as liquidated damages

risk_inventory.title: Uncertain 'Customary' Closing Costs Allocation
risk_inventory.description: The clause allocates recording fees and 'all other costs' based on what is 'customary for the county' without defining what those customs are or providing a fallback if customs are disputed. This creates uncertainty about Buyer's financial obligations and could lead to disputes at closing. The phrase 'all other costs and charges of the escrow' is also vague and could include unexpected fees.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: Recording fees and all other costs and charges of the escrow for the sale shall be paid in the manner customary for the county in which the Property is located or, if there is no custom, shall be split equally between Buyer and Seller.
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Specify exact closing cost allocation or cap Buyer's share of unspecified costs.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Replace with specific allocation: 'Recording fees for the Deed shall be paid by Buyer. Recording fees for releases of existing liens and encumbrances shall be paid by Seller. All other customary closing costs shall be split equally between Buyer and Seller, provided that in no event shall Buyer be responsible for any single closing cost item exceeding $[amount] or aggregate unspecified closing costs exceeding $[amount] without Buyer's prior written consent. The parties agree that the following costs are included in 'customary closing costs': [list specific items].'

risk_inventory.title: Buyer Bears All Extended Coverage and Endorsement Costs
risk_inventory.description: While standard for commercial transactions, Buyer is responsible for all incremental costs of extended title coverage and any endorsements. Depending on the complexity of title and lender requirements, these costs could be substantial. The clause provides no cap or estimate of these costs.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: Buyer shall pay the incremental premium to obtain "extended" coverage and the cost of any endorsements to the Title Policy requested by Buyer or its lender
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Consider negotiating Seller contribution to endorsements required to cure title issues.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Add language: 'Notwithstanding the foregoing, Seller shall pay the cost of any endorsements required to insure over or cure any title exceptions that Seller is obligated to remove pursuant to Section 4 of this Agreement, including but not limited to gap coverage, any endorsements necessitated by matters first appearing on title after the Effective Date, and any endorsements required to insure over matters created by Seller's actions or omissions.'

mitigated_by.effect: Seller's obligation to convey clear title may require Seller to address issues that would otherwise require costly endorsements

risk_inventory.title: Buyer Bears Risk of Uncollected Rents
risk_inventory.description: The proration is based on 'rents actually collected' as of Closing, meaning if tenants are delinquent, Buyer receives no credit for unpaid rent even though Buyer will own the property going forward. Combined with the delinquent rent provisions in p_103, Buyer may have difficulty collecting arrears that Seller allowed to accumulate, while Seller has no incentive to aggressively pursue collections pre-closing.
