risk_inventory.problematic_text: Rents actually collected, property taxes and assessments for the then current year shall be prorated at the Closing effective as of the Closing Date.
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Request credit for accrued but uncollected rent above a threshold, or holdback.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Revise to add protection: 'Rents actually collected shall be prorated at the Closing effective as of the Closing Date. In addition, if any tenant is more than thirty (30) days delinquent in rent payments as of the Closing Date, Buyer shall receive a credit against the Purchase Price equal to fifty percent (50%) of such delinquent amounts (the "Delinquency Credit"). If Buyer subsequently collects any portion of such delinquent amounts, Buyer shall remit to Seller the portion of collections attributable to the pre-Closing period, up to the amount of the Delinquency Credit, after first applying such collections to current rent obligations. Alternatively, Seller may elect to retain such delinquent amounts in escrow pending collection, to be disbursed in accordance with Section 11.7.'

mitigated_by.effect: Buyer retains right to collect delinquent rents post-closing with allocation to Seller

amplified_by.effect: As-is clause may limit Buyer's recourse if delinquencies result from property condition issues

risk_inventory.title: Indefinite Tax Adjustment Obligation
risk_inventory.description: The clause requires tax adjustments after closing when final tax amounts become known, but provides no time limit for when such adjustments must be claimed or made. This creates an open-ended obligation that could extend well beyond closing, and lacks specificity on mechanics of payment. There is also no materiality threshold—any difference, no matter how small, triggers an adjustment.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: If the Closing occurs before the tax rate is fixed for the then current year, the apportionment of the taxes shall be upon the basis of the tax rate for the preceding year applied to the latest assessed valuation but any difference in ad valorem taxes for the year of sale actually paid by Buyer shall be adjusted between the parties upon receipt of written evidence of the payment thereof.
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Add deadline for tax adjustment claims and minimum threshold for adjustments.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Revise to add limitations: 'If the Closing occurs before the tax rate is fixed for the then current year, the apportionment of taxes shall be based on the tax rate for the preceding year applied to the latest assessed valuation. Upon receipt of the actual tax bill for the year of Closing, the parties shall re-prorate taxes based on the actual amounts; provided, however, that (i) any claim for adjustment must be made in writing within ninety (90) days after the party seeking adjustment receives the final tax bill, (ii) no adjustment shall be required if the aggregate difference is less than $1,000, and (iii) payment of any adjustment shall be made within thirty (30) days of written demand accompanied by reasonable supporting documentation. This obligation shall survive Closing for a period of eighteen (18) months.'

risk_inventory.title: Security Deposit Credit Based on Seller Disclosure
risk_inventory.description: Buyer receives credit for security deposits based on what was 'paid to Seller' and 'disclosed on the Rent Roll,' but Buyer has limited ability to verify actual deposit amounts held. If Seller's records are inaccurate or deposits have been improperly applied, Buyer may not receive full credit and could face tenant claims for deposits Buyer never received.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: Buyer shall be entitled to a credit against the Purchase Price for the total sum of all refundable security deposits paid to Seller by tenants under any Leases affecting the Property, except for deposits which have been credited or refunded to tenants as disclosed on the Rent Roll, or are expressly nonrefundable to tenants pursuant to their Leases.
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Require Seller representation on deposit accuracy and indemnity for undisclosed deposits.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Add protective language: 'Seller represents and warrants that the security deposit amounts shown on the Rent Roll attached as Exhibit [_] are true, correct, and complete in all material respects, and that no security deposits have been applied, credited, or refunded except as expressly noted thereon. Seller shall indemnify and hold Buyer harmless from any claims by tenants for security deposits in excess of the amounts credited to Buyer at Closing, which indemnity shall survive Closing for a period of [eighteen (18) months / the applicable statute of limitations]. At Buyer's request, Seller shall provide bank statements or other documentation evidencing the security deposits held as of a date within ten (10) days of Closing.'

mitigated_by.effect: Seller's representation on rent roll accuracy provides some recourse, though subject to knowledge qualifier and survival limits

amplified_by.effect: Short survival period for representations limits time to discover deposit discrepancies
As-is clause may be argued to limit Buyer's recourse for deposit issues

risk_inventory.title: Delinquent Rent Priority Disfavors Buyer
risk_inventory.description: The waterfall for applying delinquent rent collections prioritizes current rent owed to Buyer first, but then pays collection costs second and Seller's pre-closing delinquencies third. This means Buyer must actively pursue collections, incur costs, and only then can Seller recover its past-due amounts. However, if a tenant pays only partial amounts, Buyer's current rent is covered but Buyer bears the ongoing collection burden with no compensation for administrative efforts beyond 'reasonable outside collection costs.' More importantly, the order could be restructured to better protect Buyer by ensuring Buyer receives all post-closing rent before any application to Seller's delinquencies.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: shall be applied in the following order of priority, with respect to the applicable lease: (i) first, to any rent then due to Buyer for the month in which the Closing occurs or any subsequent month(s) for which rent is then delinquent; (ii) second, to pay reasonable outside collection costs incurred by the party collecting such rent; and (iii) third, to Seller to the extent of any rents delinquent as of the Closing Date
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Add buyer compensation for collection efforts beyond outside costs
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Revise the payment waterfall to: (1) add a provision requiring Buyer to be compensated for internal administrative costs of collection (e.g., $250 per delinquent account pursued), not just 'outside collection costs'; (2) clarify that 'reasonable outside collection costs' includes attorney fees if collection requires legal action; and (3) consider adding a time limit (e.g., 90 days post-closing) after which Buyer has no obligation to pursue delinquent rents on Seller's behalf and may retain all collections as compensation for ongoing tenant relationship management.

amplified_by.effect: If rents are prorated as of Closing, Seller gets credit for unpaid rent that may never be collected

risk_inventory.title: Seller Retains Post-Closing Collection Rights
risk_inventory.description: Seller reserves the right to collect delinquent rents directly from tenants after Closing. While Seller cannot terminate leases or evict tenants, Seller's collection efforts could interfere with Buyer's tenant relationships, create confusion about payment obligations, and potentially harass tenants that Buyer wishes to retain. There is no requirement for Seller to coordinate with Buyer or limit collection methods.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: Seller reserves the right after Closing to collect delinquent rents from tenants for periods prior to the Closing Date, provided that Seller shall have no right to terminate the lease of any such tenant or to evict any such tenant from the Property after the Closing Date
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Require Seller to coordinate collection efforts with Buyer
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Add the following limitations on Seller's post-closing collection rights: (1) Seller must provide Buyer with written notice at least 10 business days before initiating any collection action against a tenant; (2) Seller may not engage collection agencies, file lawsuits, or report tenants to credit bureaus without Buyer's prior written consent; (3) Seller's collection efforts must cease upon written request from Buyer if Buyer determines such efforts are adversely affecting the tenant relationship or Property operations; (4) Seller's collection rights terminate 180 days after Closing, after which all rights to delinquent rent are assigned to Buyer; and (5) Seller shall indemnify Buyer for any damages caused by Seller's post-closing collection activities.

mitigated_by.effect: Seller cannot terminate leases or evict tenants, limiting most aggressive collection tactics

risk_inventory.title: Vague Estimation Process for Pass-Through Credits
risk_inventory.description: When the excess Operating Expense Pass-throughs cannot be determined at Closing, Buyer receives a credit 'based upon an estimate' with no specified methodology, standards, or dispute resolution mechanism. This creates uncertainty about how the estimate will be calculated, who prepares it, and what happens if the parties disagree on the estimate amount.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: if the excess cannot be determined at Closing, Buyer shall receive a credit based upon an estimate, and the parties shall make an adjusting payment between them when the correct amount can be determined
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Specify estimation methodology and who controls calculation
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Replace the vague estimation language with: 'if the excess cannot be determined at Closing, Buyer shall receive a credit equal to the greater of (a) 105% of Seller's reasonable good-faith estimate of the excess, supported by documentation of the calculation methodology, or (b) the average monthly Operating Expense Pass-through collections for the six months preceding Closing multiplied by the number of months in the applicable reconciliation period. The estimate shall be prepared by Seller and delivered to Buyer at least five (5) business days before Closing for Buyer's review. Any adjusting payment shall be made within thirty (30) days after the correct amount is determined, with interest at the rate of [Prime + 2%] on any underpayment from Closing Date to payment date.'

mitigated_by.effect: Section 1I provides a 60-day reconciliation process that will eventually determine correct amounts

risk_inventory.title: Buyer Bears Tenant Repayment Obligation
risk_inventory.description: Buyer is made responsible for crediting or repaying excess Operating Expense Pass-throughs to tenants, but there is no express indemnification from Seller if the amounts credited to Buyer at Closing prove insufficient to cover actual tenant repayment obligations. If Seller's estimates are low, Buyer could be out-of-pocket.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: In either event, Buyer shall be responsible for crediting or repaying those amounts to the appropriate tenants
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Add Seller indemnification for any shortfall in credits
risk_inventory.model_instructions: After the sentence ending with 'to the appropriate tenants,' add: 'Seller shall indemnify and hold Buyer harmless from any liability to tenants for Operating Expense Pass-through overpayments attributable to Seller's period of ownership to the extent such liability exceeds the credit received by Buyer at Closing. Such indemnification obligation shall survive Closing for a period of eighteen (18) months.'

mitigated_by.effect: Post-closing reconciliation process should capture any shortfalls

risk_inventory.title: Seller Controls Reconciliation Calculation Timing
risk_inventory.description: Seller has 60 days post-closing to prepare the final Operating Expense Pass-through calculation. This gives Seller significant time to prepare figures in its favor while Buyer must rely on Seller's records and calculation methodology. Additionally, there is no deadline for when the final adjusting payment must be made after Buyer's review period, potentially leaving disputes unresolved indefinitely.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: Within 60 days after closing, Seller shall prepare and present to Buyer a final calculation of Operating Expense Pass-throughs for Seller's period of ownership
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Shorten Seller's calculation period and add payment deadline
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Revise the timing provisions as follows: (1) reduce Seller's calculation period from 60 days to 45 days; (2) add after Buyer's 60-day review period: 'Any disputes regarding the calculations shall be submitted to an independent certified public accountant mutually selected by the parties (or, if the parties cannot agree, selected by the American Arbitration Association) within 30 days after the expiration of Buyer's review period, whose determination shall be final and binding. The cost of such accountant shall be borne by the party whose position is further from the accountant's determination.'; (3) add: 'Any adjusting payment due from either party shall be paid within fifteen (15) days after final determination of the correct amounts, with interest at [Prime + 2%] per annum from Closing Date on any amount owed by Seller.'

mitigated_by.effect: Buyer has 60 days to review Seller's calculations

risk_inventory.title: Buyer Bears Under-Collection Recovery Risk
risk_inventory.description: If Seller under-collected Operating Expense Pass-throughs, the adjustment between the parties occurs only 'after year-end billing to and receipt from said tenants.' This means Buyer must first successfully collect the under-collected amounts from tenants before receiving reimbursement from Seller. If tenants dispute or refuse to pay, Buyer bears the collection risk and may never recover funds owed to Seller's period of ownership.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: If Seller under-collected payments of Operating Expense Pass-throughs for any tenant's share of such expenses, an adjustment will be made between the parties after year-end billing to and receipt from said tenants
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Require Seller to bear under-collection risk for its ownership period
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Replace the under-collection provision with: 'If Seller under-collected payments of Operating Expense Pass-throughs for any tenant's share of such expenses during Seller's period of ownership, Seller shall be entitled to reimbursement from Buyer only to the extent Buyer actually collects such amounts from the applicable tenants within twelve (12) months after year-end billing. Buyer shall use commercially reasonable efforts to collect such amounts but shall have no obligation to initiate litigation or incur legal fees to collect under-payments attributable to Seller's ownership period. Buyer shall provide Seller with monthly reports on collection status. Any amounts not collected within the twelve-month period shall be deemed uncollectible and Seller shall have no further claim thereto.'

amplified_by.effect: Similar collection risk exists for delinquent rents, compounding Buyer's exposure

risk_inventory.title: Buyer Protected from Undisclosed Pre-Closing Expenses
risk_inventory.description: This provision helpfully states that no expense related to ownership or operation 'shall be charged to or paid or assumed by Buyer...other than those obligations expressly assumed by Buyer.' This is actually FAVORABLE to Buyer and provides important protection. However, it should be cross-referenced with Seller's representations to ensure consistency and should survive closing.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: No other expense related to the ownership or operation of the Property shall be charged to or paid or assumed by Buyer, whether allocable to any period before or after the Closing, other than those obligations expressly assumed by Buyer
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Confirm this protection survives closing and add indemnification
risk_inventory.model_instructions: After the existing sentence, add: 'The foregoing protection shall survive Closing and Seller shall indemnify, defend, and hold Buyer harmless from any claims, costs, expenses, or liabilities arising from expenses or obligations of ownership or operation of the Property allocable to any period prior to Closing that are not expressly assumed by Buyer hereunder. This indemnification obligation shall survive Closing for a period of [eighteen (18) months/two (2) years].' Also add a cross-reference: 'This provision is in addition to, and not in limitation of, Seller's representations and warranties under Section 7 hereof.'

risk_inventory.title: Broad Buyer Indemnification for Seller's TI Obligations
risk_inventory.description: Buyer is required to indemnify and hold Seller harmless from 'all claims, losses, liabilities and expenses (including attorneys' fees and costs)' related to the In Process TI Work, but only 'to the extent of the funds escrowed.' This creates ambiguity—if a claim exceeds the escrowed funds, is Buyer's indemnification capped at the escrow amount or is Buyer fully exposed? The phrase 'to the extent of' is unclear. Additionally, the indemnification covers work that Seller contracted for and may have been improperly scoped or defectively begun.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: To the extent of the funds escrowed for such purpose, Buyer shall defend, indemnify and hold Seller harmless from all claims, losses, liabilities and expenses (including attorneys' fees and costs) incurred by or asserted against Seller and related to the In Process TI Work
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Cap indemnification at escrowed funds and exclude Seller's negligence
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Revise the indemnification provision to read: 'Buyer's obligation to indemnify Seller shall be strictly limited to the funds actually held in escrow for In Process TI Work and shall not exceed such amount under any circumstances. Buyer shall have no indemnification obligation for (i) claims arising from Seller's negligence, willful misconduct, or breach of contract with contractors or tenants prior to Closing, (ii) defects in the design, specifications, or work product completed prior to Closing, (iii) disputes with contractors regarding work performed or amounts invoiced prior to Closing, or (iv) any claims by tenants arising from Seller's failure to timely commence or properly perform tenant improvement obligations. Seller shall remain primarily liable for all claims arising from the foregoing and shall indemnify Buyer for the same.'

mitigated_by.effect: The 'to the extent of' language suggests some limitation on exposure

amplified_by.effect: The AS-IS provision could be argued to extend to TI work conditions

risk_inventory.title: Vague Standard for TI Work Cost Agreement
risk_inventory.description: The amount to be escrowed for In Process TI Work is determined by costs 'as reasonably agreed by Buyer and Seller during the Due Diligence Period.' There is no mechanism for resolving disputes if the parties cannot agree, no requirement for contractor bids or third-party estimates, and no contingency for cost overruns. If costs exceed the escrow amount, Buyer must fund the shortfall and seek reimbursement from Seller.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: such costs as reasonably agreed by Buyer and Seller during the Due Diligence Period shall be withheld from the Purchase Price at Closing
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Require contractor estimates and contingency; add dispute mechanism
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Replace the cost determination language with: 'Seller shall provide Buyer, no later than ten (10) days before the expiration of the Due Diligence Period, with (a) a detailed scope of all In Process TI Work, (b) copies of all contracts and change orders related thereto, (c) a certified statement from Seller's contractor(s) of the estimated cost to complete, and (d) evidence of all amounts paid to date. The amount to be escrowed shall equal 115% of the contractor's certified estimate of remaining costs (to provide a contingency for unforeseen costs). If the parties cannot agree on the escrow amount, the matter shall be determined by an independent construction consultant selected by the Title Company, whose determination shall be binding. If actual costs exceed the escrowed amount, Seller shall reimburse Buyer for such excess within ten (10) days of demand, and Seller's obligation shall be secured by [a holdback from proceeds/a letter of credit/personal guaranty].'

amplified_by.effect: Short due diligence period may not allow adequate time to assess TI work costs

risk_inventory.title: Buyer Only 'Consults' on TI Work Completion
risk_inventory.description: Buyer is required only to 'consult with Seller's contractors and project managers regarding the completion of such work.' This suggests Seller's contractors remain in control of the work despite Buyer owning the Property. Buyer should have full authority to direct the work, hire replacement contractors if necessary, and make decisions about completion.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: Buyer shall consult with Seller's contractors and project managers regarding the completion of such work
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Give Buyer full control over TI work completion post-closing
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Replace 'Buyer shall consult with Seller's contractors and project managers regarding the completion of such work' with: 'Effective upon Closing, Buyer shall have full authority and control over the completion of the In Process TI Work, including the right to (i) direct Seller's contractors in the performance of the work, (ii) approve or reject work product, (iii) negotiate and approve change orders, (iv) terminate Seller's contractors for cause and engage replacement contractors, and (v) make all decisions regarding the scope, timing, and quality of the work. Seller shall cooperate with Buyer and, upon request, shall assign to Buyer all of Seller's rights under contracts with contractors and project managers related to the In Process TI Work.'

risk_inventory.title: Escrow Funds Released Without Verification
risk_inventory.description: The provision states that escrow funds 'shall be released to Buyer without any requirement for the consent of Seller and shall be used by Buyer to pay the landlord's share of such tenant improvements.' While this gives Buyer flexibility, it could create disputes if Seller believes funds are being misapplied. The lack of documentation requirements could also create issues with the escrow holder.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: Any funds held in the escrow shall be released to Buyer without any requirement for the consent of Seller and shall be used by Buyer to pay the landlord's share of such tenant improvements and allowances
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Add disbursement procedures while maintaining Buyer control
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Revise to read: 'Funds held in escrow shall be released to Buyer upon Buyer's written request to Escrow Holder, which request shall include a certification that the funds will be used for In Process TI Work. Seller's consent shall not be required for any such release. Buyer agrees to maintain records of all expenditures from escrow funds and shall provide Seller with a summary accounting within thirty (30) days after completion of all In Process TI Work or full disbursement of escrowed funds, whichever occurs first. Such accounting obligation shall not limit or delay Buyer's right to receive disbursements.'

risk_inventory.title: Escrow Closing Conditions Incomplete
risk_inventory.description: The conditions for Escrow Holder to close include only (i) recording the Deed, and (ii) Seller receiving payment when Title Company is ready to deliver the Title Policy. This section does not expressly incorporate Buyer's conditions precedent from Section 5D, which include delivery of Seller's closing documents, truth of representations, and estoppel delivery. If Escrow Holder closes without all Buyer conditions being satisfied, Buyer may have closed without contractual protections.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: when and only when each of the following conditions have been satisfied
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Add express reference to Buyer's conditions precedent in Section 5D
risk_inventory.model_instructions: After subsection (ii), add the following conditions: '(iii) all conditions precedent to Buyer's obligation to close set forth in Section 5.4 have been satisfied or waived by Buyer in writing; (iv) Escrow Holder has received written confirmation from Buyer that Buyer is prepared to close; and (v) Seller has deposited all items required under Section 11.3 into escrow.' Also add: 'Notwithstanding anything to the contrary herein, Escrow Holder shall not close the Escrow or record any documents without the express written authorization of both Buyer and Seller (or their respective counsel), which authorization may be provided by email.'

mitigated_by.effect: Section 5D sets forth additional conditions that should prevent closing

amplified_by.effect: Conditions may be deemed waived if Buyer proceeds to close

risk_inventory.title: Deed Recording Sequence Risk
risk_inventory.description: The provision contemplates that Escrow Holder will close by 'causing the Deed to be recorded' and 'delivering the Closing Payment... to Seller.' Standard practice requires confirmation of collected funds before recording. The clause should clarify that recording occurs only after funds have been verified as collected/cleared.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: close the Escrow on the Closing Date by (i) causing the Deed to be recorded in the Recorder's Office of the county in which the Property is located, and (ii) delivering the Closing Payment and the Deposit to Seller
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Clarify that deed records only after funds are verified collected
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Revise the opening of Section 12.1 to read: 'Escrow Holder shall close the Escrow on the Closing Date by (i) first, confirming that the Closing Payment has been received in collected funds by Escrow Holder, (ii) then, causing the Deed to be recorded in the Recorder's Office of the county in which the Property is located, and (iii) upon confirmation of recording, delivering the Closing Payment and the Deposit to Seller and delivering the other funds and documents as provided in this Agreement...'

risk_inventory.title: Undefined Document Delivery Standard
risk_inventory.description: The condition that 'all funds and documents have been delivered' lacks specificity about which documents are required and what constitutes proper delivery. This vagueness could allow Seller to argue Buyer has not satisfied a condition when minor or disputed items remain outstanding, potentially delaying or preventing closing. There is no mechanism to resolve disputes about whether delivery has occurred.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: All funds and documents have been delivered to Escrow Holder
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Cross-reference specific document lists from Sections 11.3 and 11.4.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Revise to read: 'All funds required under Section 3 and all documents required under Sections 11.3 (Seller's Deliveries) and 11.4 (Buyer's Deliveries) have been delivered to Escrow Holder in the form required by this Agreement.' This creates clear, verifiable standards tied to specific contract sections rather than a vague 'all documents' requirement.

risk_inventory.title: Title Company Readiness Subjective Standard
risk_inventory.description: The condition that Title Company be 'prepared to deliver' the Title Policy introduces subjectivity. There is no standard for what 'prepared' means—the Title Company could delay indefinitely by claiming it is not yet 'prepared' without breaching any obligation. This could delay closing or give Seller leverage to claim Buyer's conditions are unsatisfied if Buyer has any responsibility for title matters.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: Title Company is prepared to deliver the Title Policy
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Require Title Company to irrevocably commit or issue the policy.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Revise to read: 'Title Company has irrevocably committed to issue, or has issued, the Title Policy in accordance with Section 4.4, subject only to the recording of the Deed and payment of the applicable premium.' This creates an objective, verifiable standard and aligns with Section 5.4(ii) which already uses 'irrevocably committed' language for Buyer's conditions precedent.

risk_inventory.title: Interest Allocation Before Closing Favors Buyer
risk_inventory.description: This provision allocates pre-closing interest on deposited funds to Buyer, which is favorable. However, the clause lacks specificity on what happens to interest if the transaction terminates—particularly important if Buyer terminates during due diligence and is entitled to deposit return. The provision should clarify that interest follows the deposit in all termination scenarios.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: Interest accruing to such account prior to the Closing shall be for the account of Buyer
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Clarify interest follows deposit upon any termination and return.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Add clarifying language: 'Interest accruing to such account prior to the Closing shall be for the account of Buyer. In the event this Agreement is terminated and the Deposit is returned to Buyer pursuant to Section 6 or otherwise, all accrued interest shall be returned to Buyer along with the Deposit.' This ensures Buyer receives the full benefit of its funds during any holding period.

risk_inventory.title: Seller May Redirect Closing Funds
risk_inventory.description: The phrase 'or as Seller may otherwise direct' allows Seller to redirect the entire purchase price to third parties without Buyer's consent or verification. While common in commercial transactions, this creates risk that funds could be diverted to parties with adverse claims, creating title or lien issues for Buyer post-closing. Buyer has no ability to object or verify the propriety of such directions.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: to Seller, or as Seller may otherwise direct
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Require Buyer approval for non-standard disbursement instructions.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Revise to read: 'Escrow Holder shall disburse the Closing Payment and the Deposit to Seller in accordance with wiring instructions provided by Seller pursuant to Section 12.2(b); provided, however, that if Seller directs disbursement to any party other than Seller, such direction must be provided in writing at least three (3) business days prior to Closing, and Buyer shall have the right to object to any such disbursement direction that Buyer reasonably believes may create an adverse claim against the Property.' This protects Buyer from potential fraud or improper diversions.

risk_inventory.title: No Timeline for Deed Delivery to Buyer
risk_inventory.description: While this provision requires the recorded Deed to be delivered to Buyer, there is no timeline specified. Buyer could close and fund without receiving evidence of title transfer for an extended period. The provision also does not address what happens if recording is rejected or delayed by the county recorder's office.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: Escrow Holder shall cause the recorded Deed to be delivered to Buyer
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Add delivery timeline and procedure for recording failures.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Revise to read: 'Escrow Holder shall cause the Deed to be recorded in the Official Records of [County] County promptly following Closing, and shall deliver to Buyer a conformed copy of the recorded Deed within five (5) business days after recording. In the event the Deed is rejected for recording, Escrow Holder shall immediately notify both parties and the parties shall cooperate to cure any defect; provided that Seller shall be responsible for curing any defect arising from Seller's execution or the form of the Deed.' This creates accountability and a process for addressing recording issues.

risk_inventory.title: Ambiguous Entitlement Standard for Escrow Items
risk_inventory.description: The phrase 'entitled thereto or benefited thereby' provides no objective standard for determining which party receives disputed items from escrow. In the event of a dispute between Buyer and Seller regarding entitlement to documents, deposits, or other escrowed items, this vague language gives the Escrow Holder discretion that could harm Buyer's interests. There is no mechanism for resolving disputes or protecting Buyer's claim to items it may be entitled to receive.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: to the party entitled thereto or benefited thereby
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Add dispute resolution mechanism and objective criteria for determining entitlement.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Revise to add clarity: 'Escrow Holder shall deliver all other items deposited into Escrow to the party entitled thereto pursuant to the express terms of this Agreement. In the event of a dispute between Buyer and Seller regarding entitlement to any escrowed item, Escrow Holder shall hold such item pending (a) joint written instructions from both parties, or (b) a final, non-appealable court order directing disbursement.'

risk_inventory.title: Broad Carve-Outs Undermine Liquidated Damages Protection
risk_inventory.description: While the liquidated damages provision limits Seller's remedy to retention of the Deposit, the final sentence carves out Buyer's 'indemnification or repair and restoration obligations under this Agreement' and attorney's fees under Section 15. These carve-outs could expose Buyer to significant additional liability beyond the Deposit. The indemnification obligations in Section 5B(iii) are broadly worded and could result in substantial claims. This undermines the certainty that a liquidated damages provision is meant to provide.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: THE FOREGOING LIMITATION OF REMEDY SHALL NOT APPLY TO BUYER'S INDEMNIFICATION OR REPAIR AND RESTORATION OBLIGATIONS UNDER THIS AGREEMENT, OR BUYER'S COVENANT UNDER SECTION 15 BELOW REGARDING PAYMENT OF ATTORNEYS' FEES.
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Cap indemnification exposure or clarify that carve-outs only apply post-closing.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Revise carve-out language to limit Buyer's exposure: 'THE FOREGOING LIMITATION OF REMEDY SHALL NOT APPLY TO (I) BUYER'S INDEMNIFICATION OBLIGATIONS UNDER SECTION 5.2 OF THIS AGREEMENT, PROVIDED THAT SUCH OBLIGATIONS SHALL BE LIMITED TO ACTUAL THIRD-PARTY CLAIMS ARISING FROM BUYER'S PHYSICAL ENTRY ONTO THE PROPERTY PRIOR TO TERMINATION AND SHALL NOT EXCEED [INSERT CAP] IN THE AGGREGATE, (II) BUYER'S REPAIR AND RESTORATION OBLIGATIONS UNDER SECTION 5.2 FOR PHYSICAL DAMAGE ACTUALLY CAUSED BY BUYER'S INSPECTIONS, OR (III) BUYER'S COVENANT UNDER SECTION 15 BELOW REGARDING PAYMENT OF ATTORNEYS' FEES IN ANY ENFORCEMENT ACTION COMMENCED BY SELLER AFTER BUYER'S DEFAULT.'

risk_inventory.title: Broad Definition of Buyer Default
risk_inventory.description: The provision is triggered by 'a DEFAULT UNDER THIS AGREEMENT BY BUYER' without defining what constitutes a default. Minor technical breaches, delays in delivering non-material items, or other foot-faults could potentially be characterized as defaults, resulting in forfeiture of the Deposit. There is no notice requirement, no cure period, and no materiality qualifier before the Deposit is forfeited.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: IF CLOSING FAILS TO OCCUR AS THE RESULT OF A DEFAULT UNDER THIS AGREEMENT BY BUYER
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Define 'default' and add notice/cure period before forfeiture.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Revise the trigger language: 'IF CLOSING FAILS TO OCCUR AS THE RESULT OF A MATERIAL DEFAULT BY BUYER IN THE PERFORMANCE OF BUYER'S EXPRESS OBLIGATIONS TO CLOSE UNDER THIS AGREEMENT (INCLUDING BUYER'S FAILURE TO DEPOSIT THE CLOSING PAYMENT OR DELIVER CLOSING DOCUMENTS), WHICH DEFAULT CONTINUES FOR FIVE (5) BUSINESS DAYS AFTER WRITTEN NOTICE FROM SELLER SPECIFYING SUCH DEFAULT'. This limits forfeiture to material defaults directly related to closing obligations and provides a brief cure opportunity.

risk_inventory.title: Escrow Holder Instructed to Release Without Dispute Resolution
risk_inventory.description: The instruction to Escrow Holder to deliver the Deposit to Seller upon Buyer's default lacks any mechanism for Buyer to contest the characterization of default. In practice, Seller could claim default where the facts are disputed, and Escrow Holder may release funds based solely on Seller's assertion. This creates risk of improper forfeiture without recourse.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: THE ESCROW HOLDER IS HEREBY INSTRUCTED BY SELLER AND BUYER TO DELIVER THE DEPOSIT TO SELLER IN SUCH EVENT
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Require joint written instructions or demand letter before release.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Revise escrow instructions: 'IN SUCH EVENT, SELLER SHALL DELIVER TO ESCROW HOLDER AND BUYER A WRITTEN NOTICE SPECIFYING THE NATURE OF BUYER'S DEFAULT. IF BUYER FAILS TO OBJECT IN WRITING WITHIN TEN (10) BUSINESS DAYS OF RECEIPT OF SUCH NOTICE, ESCROW HOLDER IS HEREBY INSTRUCTED TO DELIVER THE DEPOSIT TO SELLER. IF BUYER TIMELY OBJECTS, ESCROW HOLDER SHALL CONTINUE TO HOLD THE DEPOSIT PENDING JOINT WRITTEN INSTRUCTIONS OR A FINAL COURT ORDER.'

risk_inventory.title: Buyer Waives Specific Performance and All Damage Claims
risk_inventory.description: This provision requires Buyer to waive specific performance and 'any other damage claims' against a defaulting Seller. This is highly unfavorable to Buyer because: (1) in a rising market, the Property may be worth substantially more than Buyer's out-of-pocket costs, and Buyer loses that appreciation; (2) Buyer cannot compel Seller to close even if Seller simply gets a better offer; (3) the $50,000 cap on expense reimbursement may not cover Buyer's actual costs for legal fees, due diligence, financing costs, and other expenses in complex transactions.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: Buyer expressly waives its right to specific performance, and any other damage claims.
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Delete waiver of specific performance or add carve-out for willful breach.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Delete the sentence 'Buyer expressly waives its right to specific performance, and any other damage claims.' and replace with: 'Notwithstanding the foregoing, in the event of Seller's willful default or Seller's conveyance of the Property to a third party in breach of this Agreement, Buyer shall be entitled to pursue specific performance of Seller's obligations hereunder in addition to the remedies set forth above.' This preserves Buyer's right to the bargained-for property in cases of bad faith by Seller.

risk_inventory.title: Expense Reimbursement Capped at $50,000
risk_inventory.description: Buyer's recovery for Seller's default is limited to return of the Deposit plus actual out-of-pocket costs capped at $50,000. In a commercial real estate transaction, Buyer's due diligence costs alone (environmental reports, surveys, appraisals, legal fees, engineering studies, lender costs) often exceed this amount. If Seller defaults close to closing, Buyer may have incurred substantially greater expenses that cannot be recovered.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: Buyer's actual out-of-pocket third party costs and expenses in connection with this transaction in no event to exceed Fifty Hundred Thousand Dollars ($50,000)
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Increase cap to at least $150,000-$250,000 or remove cap entirely.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Replace '$50,000' with a higher cap appropriate to the transaction size, such as '$250,000' or '1% of the Purchase Price, whichever is greater'. Alternatively, revise to: 'together with all of Buyer's actual out-of-pocket third party costs and expenses in connection with this transaction, including without limitation due diligence costs, lender fees, legal fees, and consultant fees, which shall be documented by reasonable evidence of payment.'

risk_inventory.title: Asymmetric Default Remedies Favor Seller
risk_inventory.description: The remedy structure is significantly asymmetric: Buyer forfeits its entire Deposit upon default (p_116), while Seller's maximum exposure for default is return of Deposit plus $50,000. This creates moral hazard where Seller has minimal downside risk from default but Buyer faces full forfeiture. This asymmetry incentivizes Seller to default if it receives a better offer or market conditions change.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: Buyer's sole remedy shall be to terminate this Agreement and receive the Deposit [(plus accrued interest)], together with an additional sum from Seller equal to Buyer's actual out-of-pocket third party costs and expenses in connection with this transaction in no event to exceed Fifty Hundred Thousand Dollars ($50,000)
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Negotiate for liquidated damages from Seller equal to Deposit amount.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Revise to create symmetry: 'then, upon notice by Buyer to Seller and Escrow Holder to that effect, at Buyer's election, Buyer may either (a) pursue specific performance of Seller's obligations to convey the Property, or (b) terminate this Agreement and receive the Deposit (plus accrued interest), together with liquidated damages from Seller in an amount equal to the Deposit, plus reimbursement of Buyer's actual out-of-pocket third party costs and expenses in connection with this transaction.' This creates equivalent exposure for both parties.

risk_inventory.title: Buyer's Remedy Conditioned on All Seller Conditions Being Satisfied
risk_inventory.description: Buyer's remedies for Seller's default are only available 'if all other conditions to Seller's obligations to consummate the sale of the Property to be satisfied as of the date of such default or failure of condition have been satisfied.' This means if any Seller condition precedent (e.g., Buyer's closing conditions under Section 5E) is unsatisfied, Seller could avoid liability for its default. Seller could engineer a condition failure to escape default liability.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: if all other conditions to Seller's obligations to consummate the sale of the Property to be satisfied as of the date of such default or failure of condition have been satisfied at the time of such default or failure
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Revise to exclude conditions frustrated by Seller's own breach.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Revise the conditional language: 'and if all other conditions to Seller's obligations to consummate the sale of the Property required to be satisfied as of the date of such default have been satisfied at the time of such default (other than conditions the non-satisfaction of which was caused by or results from Seller's default)'. This prevents Seller from using its own breach to manufacture an excuse from liability.

risk_inventory.title: Material Damage Threshold Left Blank
risk_inventory.description: The materiality threshold for damage that triggers Buyer's termination right is left blank ('$_________'). Without a defined threshold, there will be disputes about whether damage is 'material' and whether Buyer has the right to terminate. This creates significant uncertainty in a casualty scenario.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: For purposes hereof, damage is material if the reasonable estimated cost of repair exceeds $_________.
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Insert specific dollar threshold (e.g., $100,000 or 5% of Purchase Price).
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Insert an appropriate materiality threshold. Suggested language: 'For purposes hereof, damage is material if the reasonable estimated cost of repair exceeds the lesser of (i) $100,000 or (ii) five percent (5%) of the Purchase Price.' The dual test protects Buyer in both high and low-value transactions.

risk_inventory.title: Only 10 Days to Elect Termination After Casualty
risk_inventory.description: Buyer has only 10 days from receipt of Seller's notice to elect termination after a casualty or condemnation. This may be insufficient time to: (1) assess the true extent of damage; (2) obtain contractor estimates; (3) consult with lenders about impacts on financing; (4) evaluate whether insurance proceeds will be adequate. If Buyer fails to elect within 10 days, the right is waived.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: If Buyer does not elect to terminate this Agreement within 10 days of receipt of written notice from Seller of the damage or taking
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Extend election period to 20-30 days after receipt of damage assessment.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Revise to provide adequate time: 'If Buyer does not elect to terminate this Agreement within twenty (20) business days of receipt of written notice from Seller of the damage or taking (which notice shall include a reasonably detailed description of the damage, Seller's estimate of repair costs, and information regarding applicable insurance coverage)'. This gives Buyer adequate time with better information.

risk_inventory.title: No Purchase Price Reduction for Non-Material Damage
risk_inventory.description: If damage is not 'material' (below the threshold), Buyer must close at the full Purchase Price and can only receive an assignment of insurance proceeds. However, insurance proceeds may not fully cover repair costs due to deductibles, coverage gaps, or depreciation. Buyer bears the risk of any shortfall between actual repair costs and insurance recovery.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: nor shall the Purchase Price be reduced
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Add Purchase Price credit for uninsured damage.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Revise to protect Buyer: 'nor shall the Purchase Price be reduced except that Buyer shall receive a credit against the Purchase Price equal to the amount of any applicable deductible under Seller's casualty insurance policy plus the amount by which actual repair costs (as reasonably estimated by a contractor selected by Buyer and approved by Seller, such approval not to be unreasonably withheld) exceed available insurance proceeds.'

risk_inventory.title: Buyer's Election Period Triggered Only by Seller's Notice
risk_inventory.description: Buyer's 10-day election period runs from 'receipt of written notice from Seller' of the damage. This gives Seller control over when the clock starts. Seller could delay notice to pressure Buyer toward closing, or provide notice at an inconvenient time. There is no requirement that Seller provide prompt notice or that Buyer have independent discovery rights.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: within 10 days of receipt of written notice from Seller of the damage or taking
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Require prompt notice from Seller and allow Buyer's own discovery to trigger rights.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Add notice obligation and alternative trigger: 'Seller shall provide written notice to Buyer of any casualty or condemnation within two (2) business days of Seller's knowledge thereof. If Buyer does not elect to terminate this Agreement within twenty (20) business days of the earlier of (x) receipt of written notice from Seller of the damage or taking, or (y) Buyer's actual knowledge of such damage or taking'. This prevents Seller from manipulating timing.

risk_inventory.title: No definition of 'prevailing party'
risk_inventory.description: The clause awards attorneys' fees to the 'prevailing party' but does not define what constitutes prevailing. In mixed-outcome litigation where each party wins some claims and loses others, courts may struggle to determine the prevailing party, or may find no prevailing party exists, leaving Buyer unable to recover fees even after substantially winning. This ambiguity could result in protracted satellite litigation over fee entitlement.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: who is the prevailing party in any legal proceeding
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Add definition of 'prevailing party' including partial success scenarios.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Insert a definition clarifying that 'prevailing party' means the party who achieves the primary relief sought or who obtains a net favorable judgment on the principal claims in controversy, and that the court shall have discretion to apportion fees in mixed-outcome cases where neither party clearly prevails.

amplified_by.effect: If Buyer must litigate to recover deposit after improper Seller termination claim, fee recovery uncertainty compounds financial exposure

risk_inventory.title: Fee recovery limited to signatories only
risk_inventory.description: The fee-shifting provision applies only to 'signatories' of the Agreement. If Buyer needs to bring or defend claims against Seller's principals, guarantors, affiliates, or agents who are not signatories, this provision would not apply, potentially leaving Buyer without fee recovery even if successful in related litigation.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: Any signatory to this Agreement who is the prevailing party in any legal proceeding against any other signatory
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Expand to include affiliates, principals, and agents of signatories.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Revise to read: 'Any signatory to this Agreement, or any affiliate, principal, agent, or successor thereof, who is the prevailing party in any legal proceeding against any other signatory or its affiliates, principals, agents, or successors brought in connection with this Agreement or the transaction contemplated hereby...'

risk_inventory.title: No deemed delivery for refused notices
risk_inventory.description: While the provision addresses 'refusal to accept delivery,' it does not clearly specify when a refused notice is deemed effective. The clause states notice is 'deemed to have been given upon the date of actual receipt or delivery (or refusal to accept delivery)' but requires 'written or electronic confirmation of such delivery or refusal.' If Seller refuses delivery and the courier cannot obtain confirmation of refusal, Buyer may be unable to prove effective notice, potentially causing missed deadlines for due diligence objections, termination, or other critical time-sensitive matters.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: as evidenced by the notifying party's receipt of written or electronic confirmation of such delivery or refusal
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Add deemed delivery provision for refusal or evasion of delivery.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Add the following sentence after the existing text: 'Notwithstanding the foregoing, if a party refuses delivery or evades attempts at delivery, notice shall be deemed effective on the date of such refusal or, in the case of evasion, on the third business day after the first attempted delivery, provided the notifying party can demonstrate reasonable evidence of such refusal or attempted delivery.'

amplified_by.effect: Short 10-day title review period makes notice delivery failures particularly damaging
Due diligence termination rights depend on timely notice

risk_inventory.title: No provision for certified mail delivery
risk_inventory.description: The notice provision permits only personal delivery, overnight courier, or electronic transmission. Certified mail with return receipt requested is a common and legally reliable method of delivery that provides clear evidence of receipt, but is not permitted here. While not critical, this limits Buyer's delivery options and backup methods.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: (i) personally delivered, (ii) sent by Federal Express or similar nationally recognized overnight courier service, or (iii) electronically transmitted
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Add certified/registered mail as permitted notice method.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Revise the enumerated list to add: '(iv) sent by United States certified or registered mail, return receipt requested, postage prepaid, in which case notice shall be deemed given three (3) business days after deposit in the mail.'

risk_inventory.title: Incomplete notice addresses in document
risk_inventory.description: The provision references 'the addresses of the parties shall be as follows' but the actual addresses are not fully visible in this section. Buyer should verify that complete and accurate addresses for Seller and all required copy recipients are included in the executed agreement, including any address changes that may have occurred since drafting.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: For the purposes of notice, the addresses of the parties shall be as follows:
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Verify all party addresses are complete and accurate before execution.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Ensure the notice section includes complete street addresses, city, state, zip code, and email addresses for both Buyer and Seller, as well as for their respective counsel and any other required copy recipients. Consider adding a provision that notice to counsel alone is insufficient to constitute notice to a party.

risk_inventory.title: Incomplete copy recipient information
risk_inventory.description: The copy provision only shows a law firm name without complete contact information. If this is intended as required copy to Buyer's or Seller's counsel, incomplete information could result in failed delivery and arguments that notice was ineffective.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: Copies to:	Fikso Kretschmer Smith Dixon Ormseth P.S.
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Include complete address, email, and specify whether copy is required.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Complete the copy recipient information to include full street address, city, state, zip code, attention line, email address, and telephone/fax numbers. Also clarify whether delivery of copies to counsel is required for effective notice or merely courtesy, by adding: 'Copies to counsel are for convenience only and failure to deliver copies shall not affect the validity of notice to the party.'

risk_inventory.title: Broad integration clause excludes all prior negotiations
risk_inventory.description: This integration clause is absolute and provides that the Agreement 'contains the complete agreement' and 'cannot be varied except by the written agreement of the parties.' Combined with the statement that 'there are no oral agreements, understandings, representations or warranties that are not expressly set forth herein,' this effectively eliminates any claim Buyer might have based on pre-contractual representations made by Seller or its brokers during negotiations. If Seller made material representations about the Property during negotiations that induced Buyer to enter the agreement, Buyer has waived reliance on those representations.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: The parties agree that there are no oral agreements, understandings, representations or warranties that are not expressly set forth herein.
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Negotiate carve-out for fraudulent or intentional misrepresentations.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Add the following at the end of the integration clause: 'Notwithstanding the foregoing, nothing in this Section shall be deemed to limit any claim by Buyer based on fraud, intentional misrepresentation, or the willful concealment of material information by Seller or its agents.' Alternatively, ensure all material representations made during negotiations are incorporated into Section 7A as express warranties.

mitigated_by.effect: Express representations in Section 7A provide some protection, but are narrowly drafted with knowledge qualifiers

amplified_by.effect: AS-IS clause combined with integration clause creates comprehensive waiver of reliance on any non-written statements
Release provision further limits claims Buyer can bring

risk_inventory.title: No specification of modification requirements
risk_inventory.description: The clause states the Agreement 'cannot be varied except by the written agreement of the parties' but does not specify whether modifications must be signed by authorized representatives, whether email constitutes sufficient 'writing,' or whether specific formalities are required. This could create disputes about whether informal written communications constitute binding modifications.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: cannot be varied except by the written agreement of the parties
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Specify that modifications require signed written amendment by authorized representatives.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Revise to read: 'cannot be varied except by a written amendment signed by authorized representatives of both parties. No course of dealing, course of performance, or informal written communication (including email) shall be deemed to modify, amend, or waive any provision hereof unless expressly stated in a signed writing.'

risk_inventory.title: Successors and Assigns Limited by Agreement
risk_inventory.description: The phrase 'where permitted by this Agreement' effectively subordinates the binding effect on successors and assigns to the restrictions found elsewhere in the Agreement (specifically Section 9/p_154). This means the Agreement's benefits may not automatically flow to Buyer's assignees if Seller's consent is required and withheld. While this is standard protective language, combined with the assignment restrictions in Section 9, it limits Buyer's flexibility in structuring its acquisition through related entities or bringing in co-investors post-signing.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: where permitted by this Agreement
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Ensure assignment rights in Section 9 are adequate for Buyer's transaction structure.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Review Section 9 (p_154) assignment provisions in conjunction with this clause. Consider whether additional permitted assignees should be included in Section 9, such as (i) any entity formed for the purpose of acquiring the Property, (ii) institutional investors or co-investors, or (iii) any qualified intermediary for 1031 exchange purposes. If Buyer anticipates bringing in equity partners or restructuring the acquisition vehicle, negotiate broader assignment rights in Section 9 to ensure this binding effect clause does not inadvertently limit Buyer's flexibility.

amplified_by.effect: Assignment restrictions require Seller consent for most transfers, limiting who can benefit from this binding effect clause

risk_inventory.title: Buyer Assignment Requires Seller Consent
risk_inventory.description: Buyer cannot assign its interest under the Agreement without Seller's prior written consent, which is not qualified by any 'not to be unreasonably withheld' standard. This gives Seller absolute discretion to block any assignment outside of the affiliate exception, potentially trapping Buyer in the transaction even if legitimate business reasons exist for an assignment (such as bringing in an institutional co-investor, syndicating the deal, or assigning to a joint venture). This could prevent Buyer from effectuating common transaction structures.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: Buyer may not assign its interest under this Agreement without Seller's prior written consent
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Add 'which consent shall not be unreasonably withheld, conditioned or delayed.'
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Modify the assignment consent requirement to add 'which consent shall not be unreasonably withheld, conditioned, or delayed.' Additionally, consider expanding the list of permitted assignees beyond just controlled affiliates to include: (i) any entity in which Buyer or its principals hold a controlling interest, (ii) any qualified intermediary or exchange accommodation titleholder in connection with a 1031 exchange, (iii) any institutional investor or fund managed by Buyer's sponsor, and (iv) any joint venture in which Buyer or its affiliate is a managing member or general partner. Also consider adding a provision that Buyer shall not be released from liability for any assignee that is not creditworthy to Seller's reasonable satisfaction, which may make Seller more willing to accept broader assignment rights.

mitigated_by.effect: Buyer can assign to controlled affiliates without consent, which covers some restructuring scenarios

amplified_by.effect: If Buyer cannot assign and cannot close, deposit may be at risk as liquidated damages

risk_inventory.title: Control Definition May Exclude Common Structures
risk_inventory.description: The definition of 'control' requires 'ownership of a majority of the beneficial interest' AND 'managerial control.' This conjunctive standard may exclude legitimate acquisition structures where Buyer has managerial control but not majority economic interest (common in joint ventures with institutional capital partners), or where a sponsor controls the entity through contractual rights rather than majority ownership. Many real estate investment structures involve passive majority investors with a sponsor maintaining control through management rights.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: "control" and similar terms mean ownership of a majority of the beneficial interest in, and managerial control over the assignee entity
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Broaden 'control' to include managerial control alone, regardless of economic ownership.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Revise the definition of 'control' to be more flexible and reflective of common real estate ownership structures. Replace the current definition with: '"control" and similar terms mean (i) ownership of a majority of the beneficial interest in the assignee entity, or (ii) managerial control over the assignee entity (including but not limited to control exercised by the managing member of a limited liability company, the general partner of a limited partnership, or pursuant to contractual management rights), regardless of the percentage of beneficial ownership held.' This revision uses 'or' instead of 'and' and recognizes that managerial control can exist without majority economic ownership.

amplified_by.effect: If Buyer's intended structure doesn't meet the narrow 'control' definition, Seller consent is required

risk_inventory.title: Buyer Remains Liable After Permitted Assignment
risk_inventory.description: The assignment provision is silent on whether Buyer is released from its obligations after a permitted assignment to an affiliate. While this is common in PSAs and may be acceptable, Buyer should be aware that even after assigning to a controlled entity, the original Buyer may remain liable for the assignee's performance obligations. This could expose the original signing entity to liability even after it has divested its interest.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: Buyer may assign this Agreement to any entity which controls, is controlled by, or is under common control with Buyer, upon prior written notice to Seller
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Consider adding that Buyer is released upon assignment to a creditworthy assignee.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Consider adding the following language at the end of the assignment provision: 'Upon any permitted assignment hereunder (whether to an affiliate or otherwise with Seller's consent), the original Buyer shall be released from all obligations hereunder arising from and after the date of such assignment, provided that the assignee assumes in writing all of Buyer's obligations under this Agreement.' Alternatively, if Seller is unlikely to agree to a full release, consider adding: 'provided that the original Buyer shall remain liable for the performance of the assignee only with respect to the obligation to close and pay the Purchase Price, and shall have no liability for any post-Closing obligations assumed by such assignee.'

risk_inventory.title: No Affirmative Obligation to Facilitate 1031 Exchange
risk_inventory.description: While the provision states parties 'will cooperate,' it is heavily qualified by limitations that neither party shall incur additional cost, advance excess monies, or cause delays. This essentially converts the cooperation obligation into a passive, no-cost accommodation rather than an affirmative duty to facilitate. If Buyer's 1031 exchange requires any accommodation that could be characterized as causing 'delays' or involving any indirect cost, Seller could refuse to cooperate.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: neither party shall incur additional cost or expense on the other party's behalf, and shall not be required to advance or deposit monies in excess of amounts required by this Agreement for purchase of the subject Property, and such exchange shall not cause any delays in the time periods or Closing Date specified in this Agreement
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Clarify that reasonable accommodations not materially delaying Closing are required.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Revise the 1031 exchange provision to provide more meaningful cooperation while protecting against material prejudice. Consider: 'Seller and/or Buyer may wish to effect an IRC Section 1031 tax-deferred exchange, and each party agrees to cooperate reasonably in facilitating such exchange, including executing such documents and taking such actions as may be reasonably required to effectuate such exchange; provided, however, (i) the cooperating party shall not be required to incur any material out-of-pocket cost or expense (unless reimbursed by the exchanging party), (ii) the cooperating party shall not be required to take title to any property other than as contemplated by this Agreement, (iii) the exchanging party shall indemnify and hold harmless the cooperating party from any liability arising from such exchange, and (iv) the Closing Date shall not be extended by more than five (5) business days to accommodate such exchange without the other party's consent.'

amplified_by.effect: Strict closing date requirements may make it impossible to accommodate 1031 exchange timing needs

risk_inventory.title: No Extension of Closing for Exchange Purposes
risk_inventory.description: The provision explicitly prohibits any delays to 'time periods or Closing Date' to accommodate a 1031 exchange. This is particularly problematic because 1031 exchanges often require precise timing coordination with qualified intermediaries, identification of replacement property, and other logistical matters. If Buyer's exchange fails due to this rigid timing, Buyer could lose significant tax deferral benefits. Even a short extension of a few days could be critical for exchange completion.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: such exchange shall not cause any delays in the time periods or Closing Date specified in this Agreement
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Negotiate ability to extend Closing by 3-5 business days for exchange coordination.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Modify the no-delay provision to permit limited flexibility for exchange purposes: 'such exchange shall not cause any delays in the time periods or Closing Date specified in this Agreement; provided, however, that the exchanging party may, upon written notice delivered at least five (5) business days prior to the scheduled Closing Date, extend the Closing Date by up to five (5) business days solely to coordinate the logistics of such exchange, and provided further that such extension shall only be permitted once and shall not extend the Closing Date beyond [insert outside date].' This gives Buyer a narrow but meaningful accommodation for exchange timing while limiting Seller's exposure to extended uncertainty.

risk_inventory.title: Fixed Venue May Be Inconvenient for Buyer
risk_inventory.description: Venue is fixed in a specific Washington county (to be filled in). Depending on Buyer's location and the Property's location, this may or may not be convenient. Buyer should confirm this is an appropriate venue and that the specified county has jurisdiction over the Property and the parties. If Buyer is an out-of-state entity, litigating disputes in Washington state court may be inconvenient and costly.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: Venue for any dispute under this Agreement shall be in _________ County, Washington
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Confirm venue is appropriate; consider permitting federal court as alternative.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Review the venue provision for appropriateness given Buyer's business location and the Property location. Consider the following modifications: (i) ensure the blank is filled with the county where the Property is located, which is typically most convenient for property-related disputes; (ii) consider adding 'or in the United States District Court for the Western/Eastern District of Washington' to provide federal court as an alternative venue for diversity jurisdiction cases; (iii) if Buyer prefers arbitration, consider adding: 'Notwithstanding the foregoing, any party may elect to submit any dispute to binding arbitration in accordance with the Commercial Arbitration Rules of the American Arbitration Association, which arbitration shall be conducted in [City], Washington.' Also confirm that Washington choice of law is appropriate for this transaction.

risk_inventory.title: No Reformation or Modification Provision
risk_inventory.description: The severability clause only provides for provisions to be treated 'as if' they were never contained in the Agreement. It does not include a reformation provision that would allow a court to modify an unenforceable provision to make it enforceable to the maximum extent permitted by law. Additionally, there is no savings clause addressing what happens if a severed provision was material to the parties' bargain, potentially leaving the remainder of the agreement unbalanced.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: this Agreement shall be construed as if such invalid, illegal, or unenforceable provision had never been contained herein
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Add reformation language to modify rather than delete unenforceable provisions.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Consider enhancing the severability provision with reformation and savings language: 'In case any one or more of the provisions contained in this Agreement shall for any reason be held to be invalid, illegal, or unenforceable in any respect, such invalidity, illegality, or unenforceability shall not affect any other provision hereof, and such provision shall be reformed and construed so that it will be valid, legal, and enforceable to the maximum extent permitted by applicable law. If such provision cannot be so reformed, this Agreement shall be construed as if such invalid, illegal, or unenforceable provision had never been contained herein; provided, however, that if the removal of such provision would materially and adversely alter the economic bargain of this Agreement, the parties shall negotiate in good faith to amend this Agreement to restore the parties to their original intended positions as closely as possible.'

risk_inventory.title: Exhibits Incorporated Without Verification
risk_inventory.description: This clause incorporates all exhibits by reference without any provision requiring Buyer to verify that all referenced exhibits are actually attached, complete, and accurate. If an exhibit is missing, incomplete, or contains unfavorable terms, Buyer would still be bound by whatever was purportedly 'attached.' This creates risk that Seller could later claim certain terms were part of an exhibit that Buyer did not review. The clause also provides no mechanism for addressing conflicts between the main agreement and exhibits.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: All exhibits attached hereto are incorporated herein by this reference.
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Add language requiring all exhibits to be listed and attached at execution.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Revise to read: 'All exhibits attached hereto and listed on Schedule [X] are incorporated herein by this reference. Buyer acknowledges receipt of all such exhibits prior to execution. In the event of any conflict between the terms of this Agreement and any exhibit, the terms of this Agreement shall control unless the exhibit expressly states otherwise.'

amplified_by.effect: The integration clause prevents Buyer from arguing exhibits were not properly disclosed

risk_inventory.title: Extension Limited to Certain Deadlines
risk_inventory.description: While this provision extends performance dates that fall on non-business days, it only applies to dates for 'performance of any act.' This may not clearly extend notice deadlines, option exercise periods, or approval periods that expire (rather than require affirmative acts). A deadline expiring on a Saturday could trap Buyer if the clause is narrowly construed. Additionally, this provision may not extend deadlines triggered by elapsed time periods (e.g., '10 days after receipt') if the calculation results in a weekend.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: If the date for performance of any act under this Agreement falls on a Saturday, Sunday or federal holiday
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Clarify that all deadlines, including expiration dates, are extended.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Revise to read: 'If the date for performance of any act, the expiration of any period, or any deadline under this Agreement falls on a Saturday, Sunday or federal holiday, such date shall automatically be extended to the first succeeding business day. For purposes of calculating any time period measured in days, Saturdays, Sundays, and federal holidays shall be included in the calculation, but if the resulting date falls on a Saturday, Sunday, or federal holiday, performance shall be due on the next business day.'

risk_inventory.title: Seller May Continue Marketing During Due Diligence
risk_inventory.description: This clause expressly permits Seller to continue marketing the Property and negotiating with other potential buyers until expiration of the Due Diligence Period and satisfaction of all Buyer conditions. This is highly unusual and seller-favorable. Buyer is exposed to being used as a stalking horse while Seller shops for better offers. Buyer invests time and money in due diligence with no assurance Seller will not accept a competing offer. This undermines Buyer's exclusivity despite having a signed PSA and deposit at risk.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: Seller shall have the right to continue to market the Property and/or to negotiate with other potential Buyers of the Property until the expiration of the Due Diligence Period and the satisfaction or waiver in writing of all conditions to the obligations of Buyer under this Agreement
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Delete Seller's right to market or require exclusivity upon deposit.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Delete the sentence beginning 'Buyer understands and agrees that Seller shall have the right to continue to market the Property...' in its entirety. Alternatively, if Seller insists on some protection, replace with: 'Upon Buyer's delivery of the Initial Deposit, Seller agrees not to market the Property, solicit offers, or negotiate with any third party for the sale of the Property during the pendency of this Agreement.'

amplified_by.effect: The longer the due diligence period, the longer Buyer is exposed to being shopped
If Buyer terminates after being shopped, Buyer loses deposit

risk_inventory.title: Integration Clause Disclaims All Prior Representations
risk_inventory.description: The integration clause states there are no 'oral contracts, representations, conditions, or warranties, express or implied, in addition to this Agreement.' This disclaims any representations made by Seller or Seller's broker during negotiations that are not expressly included in the Agreement. If Seller or its agents made material statements about the Property during marketing (income projections, tenant quality, condition issues, etc.), Buyer cannot rely on them unless written into the PSA. This significantly limits Buyer's fraud and misrepresentation claims.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: there being no oral contracts, representations, conditions, or warranties, express or implied, in addition to this Agreement
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Add carve-out for fraud and intentional misrepresentation.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Add the following at the end of the first sentence: '; provided, however, that nothing in this Section shall limit Buyer's remedies for fraud or intentional misrepresentation by Seller or its agents, regardless of whether such representations are contained in this Agreement.'

amplified_by.effect: The AS-IS clause combined with integration makes it nearly impossible to pursue claims based on pre-contract statements

risk_inventory.title: No Prejudice to Buyer's Waiver Rights
risk_inventory.description: While this clause is facially mutual, it confirms that Buyer's failure to enforce a Seller breach does not waive future enforcement. However, the clause could be strengthened to clarify that Buyer's acceptance of partial performance or delayed performance does not waive strict compliance going forward, particularly for closing conditions and delivery obligations.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: No waiver of any default by Buyer or Seller hereunder shall be implied from any omission by the other party to take any action on account of such default if such default persists or is repeated
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Add language preserving Buyer's right to insist on strict compliance.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Add the following sentence at the end: 'Buyer's acceptance of any partial or delayed performance by Seller, or Buyer's failure to object to any non-conforming tender, shall not waive Buyer's right to require strict compliance with all terms of this Agreement with respect to any future performance.'

risk_inventory.title: Mutual Confidentiality May Limit Buyer's Flexibility
risk_inventory.description: The confidentiality provision requires both parties to keep Agreement terms confidential and prohibits public announcements without consent. While this is mutual, it may hamper Buyer's ability to: (1) discuss the transaction with potential joint venture partners or equity sources not yet identified; (2) make required disclosures if Buyer is a public company or REIT; (3) discuss the transaction with potential replacement tenants or property managers during due diligence; (4) comply with legal or regulatory disclosure requirements.
