The exception for 'lenders, partners, consultants and professional advisors' may be too narrow.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: Seller and Buyer agree to keep the terms of this Agreement confidential and not make any public announcements or disclosures with respect to the subject matter hereof without the prior written consent of the other party
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Expand permitted disclosure list and add carve-out for required disclosures.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Revise to read: 'Seller and Buyer agree to keep the terms of this Agreement confidential and not make any public announcements or disclosures with respect to the subject matter hereof without the prior written consent of the other party (which consent shall not be unreasonably withheld, conditioned, or delayed); provided that each party may disclose the terms of this Agreement (a) to its lenders, potential lenders, investors, potential investors, partners, potential partners, attorneys, accountants, consultants, property managers, brokers, and professional advisors as necessary or convenient for the completion of this transaction or the financing or syndication thereof; (b) as required by applicable law, regulation, court order, or securities filing requirements; and (c) in connection with any dispute arising out of this Agreement.'

risk_inventory.title: No Remedy Specified for Confidentiality Breach
risk_inventory.description: The confidentiality provision does not specify remedies for breach. Without specifying that injunctive relief is available and that the non-breaching party need not prove irreparable harm, Buyer may have difficulty enforcing this provision if Seller makes unauthorized disclosures that harm Buyer's negotiating position with tenants or damage the transaction.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: Seller and Buyer agree to keep the terms of this Agreement confidential
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Add provision for injunctive relief without need to prove irreparable harm.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Add the following at the end of the section: 'Each party acknowledges that a breach of this Section 18 may cause irreparable harm to the other party for which monetary damages would be inadequate, and the non-breaching party shall be entitled to seek injunctive relief, specific performance, and other equitable remedies without the necessity of proving actual damages or posting a bond.'

risk_inventory.title: Unlimited Further Instruments Obligation
risk_inventory.description: This provision creates an open-ended obligation for Buyer to execute additional documents 'as often as' requested by Seller, with no limitation on the scope, timing, or number of such requests. While subject to a 'reasonable opinion' standard, this is determined by the requesting party (Seller), not objectively. This could require Buyer to execute documents post-closing that were not contemplated at closing, potentially expanding Buyer's obligations or affecting title/rights in unanticipated ways.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: whenever and as often as it shall be requested so to do by the other, cause to be executed, acknowledged or delivered any and all such further instruments and documents as may be necessary or proper, in the reasonable opinion of the requesting party
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Add time limit and scope restrictions on further instruments requests.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Modify the provision to: (1) add a time limitation (e.g., 'for a period of six (6) months following Closing'); (2) clarify that such instruments shall not impose any additional material obligations, liabilities, or costs on the non-requesting party beyond those contemplated by this Agreement; (3) change 'reasonable opinion of the requesting party' to 'mutual reasonable agreement of the parties' or 'objectively necessary'; and (4) add that the non-requesting party shall not be required to execute any instrument that would expand its representations, warranties, or indemnification obligations.

risk_inventory.title: No Cost Allocation for Further Instruments
risk_inventory.description: The provision does not address which party bears the costs associated with preparing, executing, acknowledging, or delivering further instruments. Buyer could be required to incur significant legal and administrative costs to comply with Seller's post-closing requests.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: cause to be executed, acknowledged or delivered any and all such further instruments and documents
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Require requesting party to bear all costs of further instruments.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Add the following language at the end of the provision: 'The requesting party shall bear all reasonable costs and expenses, including attorneys' fees, incurred by the non-requesting party in connection with the preparation, review, execution, acknowledgment, and delivery of any such further instruments and documents.'

risk_inventory.title: Uncapped Broker Indemnification Survives Closing
risk_inventory.description: Buyer provides an unlimited, uncapped indemnification to Seller for any broker claims arising through Buyer. This indemnity expressly survives Closing with no time limitation, unlike the limited survival period for Seller's representations (Section 7.3 provides only 9 months). The indemnity includes 'any and all claims, liabilities, costs and expenses' with no cap, creating potentially unlimited exposure for Buyer if a broker makes a claim, even years after closing.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: each agrees to and does hereby indemnify and hold the other harmless against the payment of any commission to any person or entity claiming by, through or under Seller or Buyer, as applicable.  This indemnification shall extend to any and all claims, liabilities, costs and expenses (including reasonable attorneys' fees and litigation costs) arising as a result of such claims and shall survive the Closing
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Add cap and survival period consistent with rep survival at Section 7.3.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Modify the indemnification provision to: (1) add a cap on Buyer's indemnification obligation (e.g., 'not to exceed the Purchase Price' or a specific dollar amount); (2) add a survival period consistent with other representations and warranties (e.g., 'This indemnification shall survive the Closing for a period of nine (9) months'); and (3) add a notice and opportunity to defend provision requiring prompt notice of any claim and allowing the indemnifying party to control the defense.

risk_inventory.title: Express Unlimited Survival for Broker Section
risk_inventory.description: The final sentence states this Section 'shall expressly survive any Closing or any termination of this Agreement' with no time limitation. This creates asymmetric treatment compared to Seller's representations which survive only 9 months (Section 7.3). Buyer's broker indemnity exposure could continue indefinitely while Seller's representation exposure expires quickly.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: This Section 31 shall expressly survive any Closing or any termination of this Agreement.
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Limit survival to 9 months consistent with Section 7.3.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Replace 'This Section 31 shall expressly survive any Closing or any termination of this Agreement.' with 'This Section shall survive the Closing or any termination of this Agreement for a period of nine (9) months, consistent with the survival period for representations and warranties set forth in Section 7.3.'

risk_inventory.title: Incorrect Section Cross-Reference
risk_inventory.description: The survival provision references 'Section 31' but this appears to be Section 21 based on the document structure. This drafting error could create ambiguity about which section's survival is being addressed, potentially affecting enforceability or interpretation.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: This Section 31 shall expressly survive
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Correct section reference from '31' to '21'.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Change 'This Section 31' to 'This Section 21' or simply 'This Section' to avoid any numbering confusion and ensure the survival provision clearly applies to the broker indemnification obligations.

risk_inventory.title: Waiver of Statutory Disclosure Rights
risk_inventory.description: Buyer is waiving its statutory right under Washington law (RCW Ch. 64.06) to receive the Seller Disclosure Statement. While the Environmental section is carved out, Buyer loses the right to receive disclosures about structural issues, systems, title matters, and other material conditions that could affect the Property. This waiver eliminates a statutory protection designed to ensure buyers receive material information about property conditions.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: BUYER HEREBY WAIVES ITS RIGHT TO RECEIVE THE SELLER DISCLOSURE STATEMENT REFERRED TO THEREIN.  THIS WAIVER DOES NOT EXTEND TO THE SECTION OF THE DISCLOSURE STATEMENT ENTITLED "ENVIRONMENTAL".
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Consider requiring full Seller Disclosure Statement, not just Environmental section.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Consider deleting this waiver provision entirely and requiring Seller to provide the complete Seller Disclosure Statement pursuant to RCW Ch. 64.06. If the waiver must remain, add the following carve-out language: 'This waiver does not extend to the sections entitled "Environmental," "Structural," "Systems and Fixtures," "Title," and "Homeowners' Association/Common Interest." Additionally, nothing in this waiver shall limit Seller's liability for fraud, intentional misrepresentation, or knowing concealment of material defects.'

risk_inventory.title: Incomplete Waiver Clause - Text Cut Off
risk_inventory.description: This provision appears to be incomplete, with the text cutting off mid-sentence at 'Buyer waive'. This could create ambiguity about what exactly Buyer is waiving and render the provision unenforceable or subject to interpretation disputes. The incomplete language could be construed against Seller (as drafter) or could leave Buyer's rights unclear.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: and by executing this Agreement, Buyer waive
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Complete the provision or delete incomplete language entirely.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: This provision must be completed to clarify what Buyer is waiving. If this is intended to waive the right to receive the balance of the Seller Disclosure Statement, the complete language should read: 'and by executing this Agreement, Buyer waives its right to receive the balance of the completed Seller Disclosure Statement, other than the Environmental section.' However, Buyer should consider whether this waiver is advisable and may wish to delete this waiver language entirely and require the full Seller Disclosure Statement.

risk_inventory.title: Environmental Disclosure Timing Uses Undefined Term
risk_inventory.description: The provision requires Seller to provide the Environmental section 'during the Review Period,' but the Agreement uses 'Due Diligence Period' as the defined term (Section 5.1). 'Review Period' is not defined, creating ambiguity about when the Environmental disclosure must be delivered and when Buyer's approval period runs. This could affect Buyer's ability to terminate if environmental issues are disclosed late.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: during the Review Period
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Change 'Review Period' to 'Due Diligence Period' for consistency.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Replace 'Review Period' with 'Due Diligence Period' to match the defined term used throughout the Agreement (see Section 5.1). Additionally, consider adding specific timing language such as 'within five (5) business days following the Effective Date' to ensure Buyer has adequate time to review environmental disclosures during the Due Diligence Period.

risk_inventory.title: Waiver of Seller Disclosure Statement
risk_inventory.description: Buyer is waiving its right to receive the complete Seller Disclosure Statement, which under Washington law (RCW 64.06) typically provides important information about the property's condition, known defects, and environmental issues. This waiver limits Buyer's ability to obtain information that Seller may be legally required to disclose and could expose Buyer to unknown property conditions.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: its right to receive the balance of the completed Seller Disclosure Statement
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Consider requiring full Seller Disclosure Statement or limiting waiver scope.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Revise to either: (1) delete this waiver and require Seller to provide the complete Seller Disclosure Statement, or (2) add language stating 'Notwithstanding this waiver, Buyer reserves all rights to pursue claims based on Seller's fraud, intentional misrepresentation, or knowing concealment of material defects.' Also consider adding: 'Buyer's waiver of the right to receive the Seller Disclosure Statement shall not affect Buyer's rights under Section 7 (Seller's Representations and Warranties) or any other provision of this Agreement.'

risk_inventory.title: No Right to Updated Disclosures
risk_inventory.description: Buyer waives any right to receive updated or revised Seller Disclosure Statements even if Seller becomes aware of new material information about the property condition after the initial disclosure. This means Seller could learn of significant defects or environmental issues before closing but have no obligation to inform Buyer, leaving Buyer exposed to undisclosed problems.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: Buyer further agrees that any information discovered by Buyer concerning the Property shall not obligate Seller to prepare and deliver to Buyer a revised or updated Seller Disclosure Statement. Buyer hereby waives any right to receive an updated or revised Seller Disclosure Statement, regardless of the source of any new information.
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Require Seller to disclose newly discovered material defects before closing.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Revise to add: 'Notwithstanding the foregoing, Seller shall promptly notify Buyer in writing of any material defect, environmental condition, or other matter that would materially adversely affect the Property or its value that Seller becomes aware of after the Effective Date and prior to Closing. Such disclosure obligation shall not be deemed a Seller Disclosure Statement under RCW 64.06 but shall be a covenant of this Agreement, breach of which shall entitle Buyer to terminate this Agreement and receive a return of the Deposit, or to proceed to Closing and pursue claims against Seller for breach.'

risk_inventory.title: Broad Waiver of Reliance on Seller Info
risk_inventory.description: Buyer agrees to acquire the property solely based on its own inspections and 'not on any information provided in any Seller Disclosure Statement or... any information otherwise provided or to be provided by Seller.' This extremely broad language could be interpreted to bar claims for Seller's misrepresentations or fraudulent statements made outside of the formal representations and warranties, significantly limiting Buyer's remedies if Seller provides false information during due diligence.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: will acquire the Property solely on the basis of and in reliance upon such examinations and not on any information provided in any Seller Disclosure Statement or, except as set forth in this Agreement or the Closing documents, any information otherwise provided or to be provided by Seller or by anyone acting or claiming to act by, through or under or on Seller's behalf
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Carve out fraud and intentional misrepresentation from reliance waiver.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Revise to read: 'will acquire the Property solely on the basis of and in reliance upon such examinations and the representations and warranties expressly set forth in this Agreement and the Closing documents; provided, however, that nothing in this Section shall limit or waive Buyer's rights or remedies arising from (a) Seller's fraud, intentional misrepresentation, or knowing concealment of material facts, (b) Seller's breach of any representation, warranty, or covenant expressly set forth in this Agreement, or (c) any indemnification obligations of Seller under this Agreement.'

risk_inventory.title: Buyer Warrants Sophistication
risk_inventory.description: Buyer warrants it is a 'sophisticated Buyer' familiar with real estate ownership and development. This warranty could be used by Seller to argue that Buyer should have discovered defects through its inspections or that Buyer cannot claim reliance on any Seller statements because a sophisticated party would have verified independently. This strengthens Seller's defenses against Buyer claims.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: Buyer further warrants that it is a sophisticated Buyer who is familiar with the ownership and development of real estate projects similar to the Property
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Delete or limit scope of sophistication warranty.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Delete 'Buyer further warrants that it is a sophisticated Buyer who is familiar with the ownership and development of real estate projects similar to the Property and' OR revise to acknowledge Buyer's sophistication without creating a warranty: 'Buyer acknowledges that it has experience with commercial real estate transactions; provided, however, that such acknowledgment shall not affect Buyer's rights under this Agreement or limit Seller's obligations hereunder.'

risk_inventory.title: Waiver of Statutory Rescission Rights
risk_inventory.description: Buyer waives 'TO THE FULLEST EXTENT PERMISSIBLE BY LAW' its right to rescind the Agreement under RCW 64.06, Washington's seller disclosure statute. This eliminates a statutory protection that would otherwise allow Buyer to rescind if Seller fails to provide required disclosures or provides materially inaccurate disclosures. The prospective nature of this waiver (applying to future updated disclosures) is particularly concerning.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: BUYER HEREBY WAIVES, TO THE FULLEST EXTENT PERMISSIBLE BY LAW, THE RIGHT TO RESCIND THIS AGREEMENT PURSUANT TO ANY PROVISION OF RCW 64.06, AS AMENDED BY CHAPTER 64, LAWS OF 2010
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Preserve rescission rights for fraud or knowing misrepresentation.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Revise to add carve-outs: 'BUYER HEREBY WAIVES, TO THE FULLEST EXTENT PERMISSIBLE BY LAW, THE RIGHT TO RESCIND THIS AGREEMENT PURSUANT TO ANY PROVISION OF RCW 64.06, AS AMENDED BY CHAPTER 64, LAWS OF 2010; PROVIDED, HOWEVER, THAT THIS WAIVER SHALL NOT APPLY TO (A) ANY FRAUDULENT, INTENTIONALLY FALSE, OR KNOWINGLY MISLEADING STATEMENTS OR OMISSIONS IN ANY SELLER DISCLOSURE STATEMENT, (B) SELLER'S KNOWING CONCEALMENT OF MATERIAL DEFECTS, OR (C) ENVIRONMENTAL CONDITIONS NOT DISCLOSED IN THE ENVIRONMENTAL SECTION OF THE SELLER DISCLOSURE STATEMENT REQUIRED TO BE DELIVERED PURSUANT TO SECTION 32.'

risk_inventory.title: Disclosure Statement Provides No Rights
risk_inventory.description: The provision states that any Seller Disclosure Statement 'SHALL GIVE BUYER NO RIGHTS WITH RESPECT TO SELLER OR UNDER THIS AGREEMENT.' This could be interpreted to mean that even intentionally false statements in the Seller Disclosure Statement cannot support a claim against Seller, which is an extremely Seller-favorable position that may not be enforceable as to fraud but creates significant litigation risk.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: IT IS THE INTENT OF BUYER THAT ANY SELLER DISCLOSURE STATEMENT PROVIDED BY SELLER WILL NOT BE RELIED UPON BY BUYER, AND SHALL GIVE BUYER NO RIGHTS WITH RESPECT TO SELLER OR UNDER THIS AGREEMENT
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Add carve-out preserving claims for fraud or intentional misstatement.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Revise to read: 'IT IS THE INTENT OF BUYER THAT ANY SELLER DISCLOSURE STATEMENT PROVIDED BY SELLER WILL NOT BE RELIED UPON BY BUYER FOR PURPOSES OF ANY NEGLIGENT MISREPRESENTATION CLAIM, AND SHALL GIVE BUYER NO RIGHTS WITH RESPECT TO SELLER OR UNDER THIS AGREEMENT EXCEPT THAT BUYER EXPRESSLY RESERVES ALL CLAIMS AND REMEDIES ARISING FROM SELLER'S FRAUD, INTENTIONAL MISREPRESENTATION, OR KNOWING OMISSION OF MATERIAL INFORMATION IN ANY SELLER DISCLOSURE STATEMENT.'

risk_inventory.title: Disclosure Waiver Survives Closing
risk_inventory.description: The waiver provisions survive closing, meaning Buyer cannot assert any claims based on the Seller Disclosure Statement even after discovering post-closing defects that were required to be but were not disclosed. Combined with the AS-IS provision and other waivers, this significantly limits Buyer's post-closing remedies.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: THE PROVISIONS OF THIS SECTION 32 SHALL SURVIVE THE CLOSING
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Ensure fraud and intentional misrepresentation claims survive.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Revise to read: 'THE PROVISIONS OF THIS SECTION 32 SHALL SURVIVE THE CLOSING; PROVIDED, HOWEVER, THAT BUYER'S CLAIMS FOR SELLER'S FRAUD, INTENTIONAL MISREPRESENTATION, OR KNOWING CONCEALMENT OF MATERIAL FACTS SHALL ALSO SURVIVE CLOSING AND SHALL NOT BE LIMITED OR WAIVED BY THIS SECTION 32.'

risk_inventory.title: Property Description Blank
risk_inventory.description: The legal description of the property has blank fields (County and the actual metes and bounds or lot description). While this is clearly a form to be completed, Buyer should ensure the legal description is accurate and complete before signing, and that it matches the title commitment and survey.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: All that certain real property situated in ____________________ County, Washington, as more particularly described as follows:
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Verify legal description matches title commitment and survey before signing.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Prior to execution, complete the blank with the correct county name and ensure the complete legal description following this introductory language matches: (1) the legal description in the Title Commitment to be provided under Section 4.1(ii), (2) the survey description, and (3) any property description referenced in the Leases. Consider adding: 'The legal description shall be subject to confirmation by the Title Company and may be revised by mutual agreement of the parties to correct any errors or to conform to the legal description shown on the Survey.'

risk_inventory.title: Special Warranty Deed Limits Title Protection
risk_inventory.description: The deed form is a Special Warranty Deed rather than a General Warranty Deed. This means Seller only warrants title against defects arising during Seller's period of ownership ('by, through or under' Seller), not against title defects that predate Seller's acquisition. Buyer bears the risk of any title defects originating from prior owners, which could include undiscovered liens, encumbrances, adverse claims, or boundary disputes that existed before Seller took title.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: grants, bargains, and conveys
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Negotiate for General Warranty Deed or enhanced title insurance.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Replace the Special Warranty Deed form with a General Warranty Deed that includes full covenants of seisin, right to convey, against encumbrances, quiet enjoyment, and general warranty. Alternatively, if Seller insists on Special Warranty Deed, negotiate for: (1) enhanced owner's title insurance with extended coverage, (2) Seller's indemnification for known title defects, and (3) representations regarding Seller's knowledge of any title matters arising prior to Seller's ownership.

mitigated_by.effect: Title insurance may cover some defects not warranted by Seller, reducing but not eliminating exposure

amplified_by.effect: AS-IS provision could be argued to limit Buyer's recourse for undisclosed title issues
Express exclusion of implied covenants further narrows Buyer's warranty protection

risk_inventory.title: Personal Property and Intangibles Not Conveyed in Deed
risk_inventory.description: The deed only conveys real property, buildings, improvements, and lessor's interest in leases. It does not convey personal property, service contracts, permits, licenses, warranties, or other intangible property that are part of the purchase under the PSA. Buyer must rely on separate conveyance documents (Bill of Sale, Assignment of Contracts) which could create gaps if those documents are not properly executed or delivered.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: all of its right, title and interest in that certain real property, together with buildings and improvements now or hereafter situated thereon and the lessor's or landlord's interest in all space leases
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Confirm all conveyance documents are closing deliveries under PSA.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Verify that the PSA Section 11.3 closing deliveries include all required conveyance documents for the full scope of the Property as defined in Section 1, including: (1) the Deed for real property and improvements, (2) Bill of Sale for personal property, (3) Assignment of Leases, (4) Assignment of Contracts and Intangibles. Add a closing condition requiring delivery of all such documents as a condition to Buyer's obligation to close.

mitigated_by.effect: PSA requires separate documents for personal property and contract assignments at closing

risk_inventory.title: Conveyance Subject to Undefined Exhibit B Exceptions
risk_inventory.description: The deed is expressly subject to matters listed in an Exhibit B that is not provided for review. These 'Permitted Exceptions' could include significant encumbrances, easements, restrictions, or other matters that materially affect Buyer's use and enjoyment of the Property. Without reviewing Exhibit B, Buyer cannot assess what limitations will burden the Property post-closing.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: expressly subject to the matters set forth in Exhibit B attached hereto
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Require Exhibit B to match only Buyer-approved Permitted Exceptions.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Add language to the PSA requiring that Exhibit B to the Deed shall consist only of the 'Permitted Exceptions' as defined and approved by Buyer under Section 4 (Title Review). Include a closing condition that Buyer shall have the right to review and approve the final form of Exhibit B prior to closing, and that any matter not previously approved as a Permitted Exception shall not be included. Consider adding: 'Exhibit B shall contain only those title exceptions expressly approved or deemed approved by Buyer pursuant to Section 4B of the Purchase Agreement.'

mitigated_by.effect: Buyer has approval rights over title matters during due diligence, which should define what becomes Permitted Exceptions

amplified_by.effect: AS-IS provision could limit Buyer's post-closing remedies for burdensome exceptions

risk_inventory.title: Express Exclusion of Implied Title Covenants
risk_inventory.description: This provision expressly excludes all covenants that would otherwise arise by statute or implication, limiting Buyer's warranty protection to only those covenants expressly stated in the deed. Under Washington law, a General Warranty Deed would typically include implied covenants of seisin, right to convey, freedom from encumbrances, quiet enjoyment, and general warranty. This language strips away those protections.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: does by these presents expressly limit the covenants of the deed to those herein expressed, and excludes all covenants arising or to arise by statutory or other implication
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Delete exclusion or negotiate for express inclusion of standard covenants.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Delete the clause excluding implied covenants, or alternatively modify the deed to expressly include the standard covenants of title: (1) covenant of seisin (Grantor owns the Property), (2) covenant of right to convey, (3) covenant against encumbrances (except Permitted Exceptions), (4) covenant of quiet enjoyment, and (5) covenant of general warranty. If Seller refuses, ensure title insurance provides equivalent protection and consider a separate indemnification agreement for title defects.

mitigated_by.effect: Title insurance provides some protection against title defects regardless of deed covenants

amplified_by.effect: Combined with special warranty limitation, Buyer has minimal contractual title protection

risk_inventory.title: Warranty Limited to Claims Through Grantor Only
risk_inventory.description: The warranty defense obligation is limited to claims 'by, through or under said Grantor and not otherwise.' This means Seller has no obligation to defend Buyer against title claims arising from parties other than those claiming through Seller's chain of title during Seller's ownership. Pre-existing title defects, third-party adverse claims, or boundary disputes from adjacent owners are not covered.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: against all persons whomsoever lawfully claiming or to claim by, through or under said Grantor and not otherwise
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Negotiate broader warranty or require enhanced title insurance endorsements.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Modify the warranty language to provide broader protection. Replace 'by, through or under said Grantor and not otherwise' with 'by, through or under said Grantor or any predecessor in title.' Alternatively, delete 'and not otherwise' to preserve some ambiguity in Buyer's favor. If Seller refuses deed modification, require extended coverage title insurance with endorsements for survey matters, access, zoning, and any other identified risks not covered by the limited warranty.

mitigated_by.effect: Title insurance may cover third-party claims not warranted by Seller

risk_inventory.title: Bill of Sale Contains No Warranties on Personal Property
risk_inventory.description: The Bill of Sale form transfers personal property without any express warranties regarding title, condition, or fitness for purpose. Combined with the AS-IS provisions in the PSA, Buyer receives personal property without any assurance that Seller owns it free and clear, that it is in working condition, or that it is fit for its intended use.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: does hereby sell, transfer and convey to
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Add warranty of title and condition to Bill of Sale.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Modify the Bill of Sale to include: (1) Warranty of title - 'Seller warrants that it is the lawful owner of the Personal Property, that the Personal Property is free and clear of all liens, claims, and encumbrances, and that Seller has the right to sell and transfer the same'; (2) Consider adding a warranty that the Personal Property is in the same condition as existed during Buyer's due diligence inspection. Reference should be made to any representations in the PSA regarding personal property that survive closing.

mitigated_by.effect: Bill of Sale Exhibit F contains a representation that Seller is lawful owner

amplified_by.effect: AS-IS provision disclaims warranties on personal property condition

risk_inventory.title: Personal Property Limited to Schedule I Items
risk_inventory.description: The Bill of Sale references 'Schedule I' for the list of personal property items, but this schedule is not provided for review. If Schedule I is incomplete or does not match Buyer's understanding of what personal property is included in the sale, Buyer may not receive all items expected. The phrase 'including, without limitation' provides some protection but the scheduled items define the core conveyance.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: including, without limitation, those items described in Schedule I attached hereto
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Verify Schedule I matches PSA inventory; add catch-all language.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Ensure Schedule I to the Bill of Sale is prepared and reviewed by Buyer prior to closing. Add language that Schedule I shall include all personal property identified in the Due Diligence Documents or observed during Buyer's property inspections. Consider adding: 'Schedule I shall include, but not be limited to, all furniture, fixtures, equipment, supplies, and other tangible personal property located on or in the Property as of the Effective Date of the Purchase Agreement that is owned by Seller and used in connection with the operation of the Property.'

mitigated_by.effect: The phrase 'including, without limitation' suggests Schedule I is not exhaustive

risk_inventory.title: Bill of Sale Incorporates PSA Terms by Reference
risk_inventory.description: The Bill of Sale incorporates terms of the Purchase Agreement by reference. While this can be protective by preserving PSA rights, it also means any limitations, disclaimers, or AS-IS provisions in the PSA apply to the personal property conveyance. Buyer should understand that the PSA's AS-IS language and survival limitations will govern post-closing claims related to personal property.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: The terms of the Purchase Agreement with respect to this Bill of Sale and the property conveyed in this Bill of Sale are incorporated herein by reference
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Clarify which PSA terms survive and apply to personal property claims.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Review the PSA to identify which provisions apply to personal property and confirm they provide adequate protection. Consider adding clarifying language specifying that Seller's representations regarding ownership of personal property (if any) survive closing for the same period as other representations under Section 7C. Confirm that the incorporation by reference does not inadvertently waive claims for breach of personal property representations.

amplified_by.effect: AS-IS provision incorporated by reference disclaims condition warranties
Limited survival period constrains time for personal property claims

risk_inventory.title: Unqualified Personal Property Warranty
risk_inventory.description: Seller provides an absolute representation and warranty that personal property is 'free and clear of all liens, encumbrances, conditional sales contracts, security interests and claims' without any knowledge qualifier. This is broader than the knowledge-qualified representations in Section 7A of the main agreement, creating potential inconsistency. While this benefits Buyer, the lack of a schedule identifying the specific personal property covered makes enforcement difficult and could lead to disputes about scope.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: Seller hereby represents and warrants to Buyer that Seller is the lawful owner of such personal property, and that such personal property is free and clear of all liens, encumbrances, conditional sales contracts, security interests and claims
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Ensure personal property is specifically identified on attached schedule.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Add a cross-reference to identify the covered personal property: 'Seller hereby represents and warrants to Buyer that Seller is the lawful owner of the personal property described in the attached Schedule [X] (the "Personal Property"), and that such Personal Property is free and clear of all liens, encumbrances, conditional sales contracts, security interests and claims.' Also consider whether this representation should survive closing consistent with Section 7C survival provisions.

mitigated_by.effect: If this representation is subject to the same survival period in Section 7C, claims must be brought within that limited window

amplified_by.effect: The AS-IS provision may create tension with this warranty if personal property issues arise post-closing

risk_inventory.title: Personal Property Not Specifically Identified
risk_inventory.description: The Bill of Sale references 'such personal property' without a clear definition or attached schedule identifying what personal property is actually being conveyed. This creates significant risk that Buyer may not receive all personal property expected, or disputes may arise about what was included in the sale. The reference to p_284 shows only a placeholder bracket suggesting a schedule should be attached but may not be.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: such personal property
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Require detailed schedule of all personal property to be attached before closing.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Replace 'such personal property' with a defined term that references an attached schedule: 'the Personal Property described in Schedule A attached hereto and incorporated herein by reference (the "Personal Property")'. Ensure that this schedule is cross-referenced with the personal property definition in Section 1D of the PSA (p_12) to ensure consistency and completeness. As a closing condition, Buyer should verify Schedule A is complete and accurate.

amplified_by.effect: If personal property is not properly identified, the AS-IS disclaimer may prevent Buyer from claiming additional items post-closing

risk_inventory.title: Missing Personal Property Schedule
risk_inventory.description: This appears to be a placeholder for a schedule that should list the personal property included in the sale, but contains only bracketed text indicating it needs to be completed. If this schedule is not properly filled out before closing, Buyer will have no clear record of what personal property was conveyed, making enforcement of the warranty in p_267 extremely difficult and potentially allowing Seller to remove valuable FF&E.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: [Personal Property of Personal Property Included in the Sale]
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Require completed inventory schedule with values before closing.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: This bracketed placeholder must be replaced with a comprehensive schedule listing all personal property included in the sale. Add the following as a closing condition in Section 5D or 11C: 'Seller shall deliver to Buyer at least five (5) business days prior to Closing a complete and accurate schedule of all Personal Property to be conveyed at Closing (the "Personal Property Schedule"), which shall include a description of each item and its approximate value. Buyer shall have the right to inspect and verify such Personal Property prior to Closing.' The schedule should cross-reference the personal property description in Section 1D.

amplified_by.effect: If personal property schedule is not a required Seller delivery, there is no mechanism to ensure it is provided

risk_inventory.title: Blank Assignment Form Fields
risk_inventory.description: The Assignment and Assumption of Leases contains blank fields for date, party names, and entity types that must be completed before execution. While this is standard for a form document, Buyer should ensure all blanks are properly completed consistent with the PSA before execution at Closing.
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Verify all blanks completed correctly and consistently with PSA at closing.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: As part of closing review procedures, ensure: (1) the date matches the Closing Date; (2) Assignor name and entity type exactly matches Seller as defined in PSA; (3) Assignee name and entity type exactly matches Buyer (or permitted assignee if Buyer has assigned rights under Section 15 or 20); (4) all entity designations are accurate per formation documents. Consider adding a closing checklist item to verify consistency across all closing documents.

mitigated_by.effect: Section 11C requires proper execution of assignment documents as a Seller delivery

risk_inventory.title: Lease Schedule Must Be Complete and Accurate
risk_inventory.description: The assignment covers only leases 'described in Schedule I attached hereto.' If Schedule I is incomplete or inaccurate, Buyer may not receive assignment of all leases, potentially leaving some tenant relationships unassigned and creating title/ownership issues. Buyer should verify Schedule I matches the rent roll and all leases disclosed during due diligence.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: which leases are described in Schedule I attached hereto (the "Leases")
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Cross-check Schedule I against rent roll and all disclosed leases before closing.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Add a verification requirement: As a closing condition, Buyer shall confirm that Schedule I to the Assignment and Assumption of Leases includes all leases and occupancy agreements affecting the Property as disclosed in the Due Diligence Documents, the rent roll delivered pursuant to Section 7A(ii), and any new leases entered into in accordance with Section 8B. Any discrepancy shall be resolved prior to Closing. Consider adding Seller representation that Schedule I is complete and accurate as of Closing.

mitigated_by.effect: Seller's representation regarding the rent roll provides some protection if leases are omitted

amplified_by.effect: The knowledge qualifier on Seller's representations may limit Buyer's recourse for undisclosed leases

risk_inventory.title: PSA Terms Incorporated by Reference
risk_inventory.description: The assignment incorporates the PSA terms by reference, which is appropriate for ensuring consistency. However, Buyer should be aware that any limitations, caps, or disclaimers in the PSA will also apply to claims arising under this assignment unless specifically stated otherwise.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: The terms of the Agreement with respect to this Assignment are incorporated herein by reference.
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Confirm PSA terms (especially limitations) apply appropriately to assignment.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Review this incorporation clause to ensure it does not inadvertently import limitations that should not apply to the assignment. Consider clarifying which specific PSA terms are incorporated, particularly: (1) indemnification provisions from Section 10; (2) survival periods from Section 7C; (3) liability limitations from Section 13. If Buyer negotiates different or better terms in the assignment (such as the indemnification in p_301), ensure those terms are not overridden by this incorporation clause by adding: 'In the event of any conflict between this Assignment and the Agreement, the terms of this Assignment shall control with respect to the assignment and assumption of the Leases.'

amplified_by.effect: The limited survival period in the PSA may apply to claims under this assignment

risk_inventory.title: Vague Assignment Terms Reference
risk_inventory.description: The clause references assignment 'on the terms and conditions set forth below' without specifying those terms within this paragraph. While the subsequent paragraphs do contain terms, this introductory language creates potential ambiguity about what exactly constitutes the full scope of the assignment terms, and whether any oral or extrinsic terms could be argued to apply.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: on the terms and conditions set forth below
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Ensure all material assignment terms are expressly stated in the document.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Consider adding a clause stating that 'Such terms and conditions are set forth exclusively in Sections [X] through [Y] below, and no other terms shall apply to this assignment.' This ensures completeness and prevents arguments about implied or unstated terms.

risk_inventory.title: Conveyance Date Determination Ambiguity
risk_inventory.description: The assignment is effective 'as of the date on which the Property is conveyed to Assignee pursuant to the Agreement.' If there is any dispute about when conveyance actually occurred (e.g., recording date vs. delivery of deed vs. closing), Buyer/Assignee could face a gap in coverage or unclear allocation of pre/post-closing liabilities. The definition relies on an external event without specifying the precise moment of effectiveness.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: As of the date on which the Property is conveyed to Assignee pursuant to the Agreement (the "Conveyance Date")
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Define Conveyance Date as the date of recording of the Deed.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Replace the definition with more precise language: 'As of the date on which the Deed is recorded in the official records of [County] County (the "Conveyance Date")' or alternatively 'As of the Closing Date as defined in the Agreement (the "Conveyance Date")'. This eliminates ambiguity about when the assignment becomes effective and when liability shifts.

risk_inventory.title: Favorable Pre-Closing Indemnity From Seller
risk_inventory.description: This provision provides Buyer/Assignee with indemnification from Seller/Assignor for all Claims originating prior to the Conveyance Date and arising out of Assignor's obligations under the Leases. This is favorable to Buyer, but Buyer should verify this indemnity survives closing and is not limited by caps, baskets, or survival periods in the main Agreement that could undermine its value.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: Assignor hereby agrees to indemnify Assignee against and hold Assignee harmless from any and all liabilities, losses, claims, damages, costs or expenses, including, without limitation, reasonable attorneys' fees and costs (collectively, the "Claims"), originating prior to the Conveyance Date and arising out of the Assignor's obligations under the Leases
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Confirm this indemnity survives closing and is not subject to caps/baskets.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Add explicit survival language: 'This indemnification obligation shall survive the Conveyance Date and the Closing for a period of [24/36] months.' Also consider adding: 'Notwithstanding any limitation on liability, survival period, basket, or cap contained in the Agreement, this indemnification obligation shall not be subject to any such limitations.' Cross-reference the main Agreement's liability provisions (Section 7C survival, any indemnity caps) to ensure this assignment-level indemnity is not inadvertently limited.

risk_inventory.title: No Express Survival Period for Seller Indemnity
risk_inventory.description: The indemnification from Assignor to Assignee for pre-closing Lease obligations does not include an express survival period. Without clear survival language, there may be arguments that this indemnity terminates upon closing or is subject to a short limitations period, leaving Buyer unprotected for latent claims that surface after closing.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: Assignor hereby agrees to indemnify Assignee against and hold Assignee harmless
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Add explicit survival period of at least 24 months post-closing.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Insert the following at the end of the paragraph: 'The obligations of Assignor under this Section shall survive the Conveyance Date and Closing for a period of twenty-four (24) months, and shall not merge with any instrument delivered at Closing.' This protects Buyer's ability to pursue claims that arise from pre-closing matters but are discovered post-closing.

risk_inventory.title: Unlimited Assumption of Seller's Lease Obligations
risk_inventory.description: Buyer/Assignee assumes 'all of Assignor's obligations under the Leases' without limitation. This broad assumption could include: (1) unfunded tenant improvement obligations, (2) free rent obligations, (3) lease buyout provisions, (4) landlord repair/maintenance backlogs, (5) potential lease violations by Seller that Buyer inherits. The assumption is uncapped and unlimited, exposing Buyer to potentially significant unknown liabilities.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: Assignee hereby assumes all of Assignor's obligations under the Leases
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Limit assumption to obligations arising post-closing only.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Revise to read: 'Assignee hereby assumes all of Assignor's obligations under the Leases that first arise or accrue on or after the Conveyance Date, excluding (i) any obligation of Assignor arising from Assignor's breach or default occurring prior to the Conveyance Date, (ii) any unfunded tenant improvement allowances or free rent obligations relating to periods prior to the Conveyance Date, and (iii) any obligation arising from Assignor's failure to perform landlord obligations prior to the Conveyance Date.' This carve-out ensures Buyer only assumes truly forward-looking obligations.

risk_inventory.title: Buyer Provides Uncapped Indemnity to Seller
risk_inventory.description: Buyer/Assignee agrees to indemnify Seller/Assignor against 'any and all Claims' arising from Assignee's obligations under the Leases post-closing. This indemnity has no cap, no basket, and no temporal limitation. Combined with the broad assumption of 'all' obligations, Buyer's exposure is unlimited and could include claims that actually originated from Seller's pre-closing conduct but are characterized as relating to Assignee's obligations.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: agrees to indemnify Assignor against and hold Assignor harmless from any and all Claims originating on or subsequent to the Conveyance Date and arising out of the Assignee's obligations under the Leases
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Add a cap on Buyer's indemnity equal to the Purchase Price or insurance limits.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Add the following limitation: 'Notwithstanding the foregoing, Assignee's aggregate liability under this indemnification shall not exceed [the Purchase Price / $X / the limits of Assignee's commercial general liability insurance], and shall exclude any Claims to the extent arising from (i) Assignor's breach of any representation or warranty in the Agreement, (ii) Assignor's pre-Conveyance Date defaults under the Leases, or (iii) Assignor's negligence or willful misconduct.' This caps exposure and clarifies that Seller cannot shift its own misconduct to Buyer via this indemnity.

risk_inventory.title: Origination Date Creates Gap Risk
risk_inventory.description: The indemnity structure uses 'originating' prior to or 'on or subsequent to' the Conveyance Date as the dividing line. Claims that 'originate' before closing but 'arise' after closing (or vice versa) create allocation disputes. For example, a tenant improvement obligation that originated pre-closing but becomes due post-closing could fall into a grey area. The distinction between 'originating' and 'arising' is not clearly defined.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: originating on or subsequent to the Conveyance Date and arising out of the Assignee's obligations
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Clarify that Seller indemnifies for all matters relating to pre-closing periods.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Revise both p_301 and p_303 to use clearer temporal language. In p_301, change to: 'Claims arising out of or relating to (i) any act, omission, or condition occurring or existing prior to the Conveyance Date, or (ii) Assignor's performance or non-performance of obligations under the Leases for periods prior to the Conveyance Date.' In p_303, change to: 'Claims arising out of or relating to Assignee's performance or non-performance of obligations under the Leases for periods on or after the Conveyance Date, but excluding any Claim to the extent attributable to Assignor's acts, omissions, or defaults prior to the Conveyance Date.'

risk_inventory.title: Losing Party Pays Attorney Fees
risk_inventory.description: The prevailing party fee-shifting provision creates significant litigation cost exposure for Buyer. If Buyer brings a claim under this Assignment and does not prevail, Buyer must pay Seller's attorneys' fees and costs without limitation. This could chill Buyer's willingness to enforce legitimate claims and creates asymmetric risk if Seller has greater litigation resources.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: the losing party shall pay the prevailing party's costs and expenses of such dispute, including, without limitation, reasonable attorneys' fees and costs
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Consider removing or making fee-shifting mutual only above a threshold.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Consider revising to: 'In any dispute arising under this Assignment, each party shall bear its own attorneys' fees and costs, unless a court determines that a party's position was frivolous or taken in bad faith, in which case the court may award reasonable attorneys' fees to the other party.' Alternatively, add a materiality threshold: 'provided that this fee-shifting provision shall only apply to disputes involving claims in excess of $[50,000].' This reduces the chilling effect on legitimate smaller claims while still deterring frivolous litigation.

risk_inventory.title: No Definition of Prevailing Party
risk_inventory.description: The clause does not define what constitutes a 'prevailing party,' which can be ambiguous in cases where each party wins on some issues or where the plaintiff recovers less than a settlement offer. Without a clear definition, there could be additional litigation over who actually prevailed.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: the losing party shall pay the prevailing party's costs
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Define 'prevailing party' to reduce post-dispute litigation.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Add the following definition: 'For purposes of this Section, the "prevailing party" shall mean the party who obtains a judgment or award substantially in its favor on the principal claims at issue, or if the dispute is settled, the party in whose favor the settlement is predominantly rendered. A party who recovers money damages shall be considered the prevailing party unless such recovery is less than [the opposing party's last written settlement offer / 50% of the amount claimed].'

risk_inventory.title: Unrestricted Assignability of Lease Assignment
risk_inventory.description: This provision allows the Assignment of Leases to be binding on 'successors and assigns' without any restriction on Seller/Assignor's ability to assign. While this benefits Buyer by allowing future transferability, it also means Seller could potentially assign its indemnification obligations under p_301 to a less creditworthy entity before closing or during the survival period, potentially leaving Buyer without recourse for pre-closing landlord obligations.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: This Assignment shall be binding on and inure to the benefit of the parties hereto and their respective successors and assigns
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Add restriction on Assignor's assignment without Buyer consent
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Modify the provision to read: 'This Assignment shall be binding on and inure to the benefit of the parties hereto and their respective successors and assigns; provided, however, that Assignor may not assign its obligations hereunder (including without limitation its indemnification obligations under Section [reference to indemnity section]) without the prior written consent of Assignee, which consent may be withheld in Assignee's sole discretion.' This ensures Buyer retains recourse against a creditworthy indemnitor.

risk_inventory.title: Blank Date and Party Information
risk_inventory.description: The Assignment of Contracts contains blank fields for the date and party identification. While this is standard for a form document attached as an exhibit, Buyer should ensure these blanks are properly completed at closing to match the actual closing date and correct legal entity names. Incorrect or incomplete party information could affect enforceability of the assignment and related indemnification provisions.
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Confirm all blanks completed correctly at closing
risk_inventory.model_instructions: No modification to contract language required. Add a closing checklist item or instruction note: 'Buyer's counsel shall verify that all blanks in the Assignment and Assumption of Contracts and Intangibles are completed accurately at closing, including (i) the correct closing date, (ii) Seller's full legal entity name and state of formation matching the PSA, and (iii) Buyer's full legal entity name and state of formation matching the PSA.'

risk_inventory.title: Schedule I Dependency Without Verification Right
risk_inventory.description: The definition of 'Contracts' is entirely dependent on Schedule I, which is an exhibit prepared by the Seller/Assignor. Buyer has no independent verification mechanism in this assignment document to confirm Schedule I is complete and accurate. If Seller omits contracts from Schedule I, Buyer may unknowingly assume obligations under undisclosed contracts or fail to receive the benefit of favorable contracts.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: which service contracts are described in Schedule I attached hereto (the "Contracts")
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Add warranty that Schedule I is complete and accurate.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Insert the following sentence after the defined term: 'Assignor represents and warrants that Schedule I contains a complete and accurate list of all service contracts affecting the Property as of the Conveyance Date.' Additionally, cross-reference this with Section 7A representations to ensure survival of this warranty beyond closing.

amplified_by.effect: Buyer will assume all obligations under undisclosed contracts that affect the Property

risk_inventory.title: Blanket Incorporation of PSA Terms
risk_inventory.description: The broad incorporation of PSA terms by reference ('The terms of the Agreement with respect to this Assignment are incorporated herein by reference') creates potential ambiguity about which specific PSA provisions govern this Assignment. In a dispute, Seller could argue that unfavorable PSA provisions (such as liability caps, survival limitations, or dispute resolution procedures) override more favorable provisions that might otherwise apply to this Assignment.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: The terms of the Agreement with respect to this Assignment are incorporated herein by reference.
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Specify which PSA terms apply to this Assignment.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Replace the blanket incorporation clause with specific cross-references: 'The following provisions of the Agreement are incorporated herein by reference and shall govern this Assignment: [Section __ (Definitions), Section __ (Survival), Section __ (Dispute Resolution), Section __ (Governing Law)]. In the event of any conflict between this Assignment and the Agreement, the terms most favorable to Assignee shall control.'

risk_inventory.title: Seller Retains Pre-Closing Claims Against Contracts
risk_inventory.description: The carve-out 'excluding claims by Assignor, if any, arising out of matters occurring before the Conveyance Date' allows Seller to retain valuable claims (such as breach of contract claims against service providers, warranties from contractors, or rights to refunds/credits) that relate to the Property. This could leave Buyer without recourse against vendors for pre-closing defects or without the benefit of favorable contract terms.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: excluding claims by Assignor, if any, arising out of matters occurring before the Conveyance Date
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Require assignment of all claims or obtain representations about pending claims.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Delete the carve-out language entirely OR modify to read: 'Assignor hereby assigns to Assignee all of its right, title and interest in and to the Contracts and any intangible property now owned by Assignor in connection with the Property, including without limitation all claims, causes of action, warranties, and rights to credits or refunds arising under the Contracts, whether arising before or after the Conveyance Date. To the extent any such pre-Conveyance Date claims are not assignable, Assignor shall hold such claims in trust for the benefit of Assignee and shall prosecute such claims at Assignee's direction and expense, with all proceeds payable to Assignee.'

amplified_by.effect: AS-IS clause may limit Buyer's ability to seek recourse for pre-closing defects discovered post-closing

risk_inventory.title: Undefined 'Intangible Property' Scope
risk_inventory.description: The phrase 'any intangible property now owned by Assignor in connection with the Property' is vague and lacks a clear definition. This could lead to disputes about whether specific items (trade names, permits, licenses, warranties, intellectual property, domain names, telephone numbers) are included in the assignment. The lack of specificity may result in Buyer not receiving items it expected or Seller retaining valuable intangibles.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: any intangible property now owned by Assignor in connection with the Property
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Define intangible property with specific enumerated categories.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Replace 'any intangible property now owned by Assignor in connection with the Property' with: 'all intangible property owned by Assignor in connection with the Property, including without limitation: (a) all trade names, trademarks, and service marks used in connection with the Property; (b) all permits, licenses, approvals, and authorizations; (c) all warranties and guaranties from contractors, subcontractors, suppliers, and manufacturers; (d) all telephone numbers, domain names, and websites; (e) all plans, specifications, drawings, and architectural works; (f) all tenant and prospect lists, marketing materials, and promotional materials; and (g) all goodwill associated with the foregoing (collectively, the "Intangible Property")'

mitigated_by.effect: PSA Section 1E provides some definition of Intangible Property that may govern

risk_inventory.title: Indemnity Limited to Pre-Closing Matters Only
risk_inventory.description: The indemnity only covers claims 'originating prior to the Conveyance Date.' This creates a dangerous gap for claims that straddle the closing date or are discovered post-closing but relate to pre-closing conduct. For example, if a service provider was performing defective work before closing but the claim doesn't 'originate' until post-closing discovery, Buyer may have no indemnification coverage. The word 'originating' is also ambiguous—it's unclear whether this means when the underlying conduct occurred, when the claim accrues, or when a third party first asserts it.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: originating prior to the Conveyance Date
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Change 'originating' to 'arising from acts or omissions occurring' for clarity.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Replace 'originating prior to the Conveyance Date and arising out of Assignor's obligations under the Contracts' with: 'arising out of or related to: (a) any breach or default by Assignor under any Contract occurring on or prior to the Conveyance Date; (b) any act or omission of Assignor under any Contract on or prior to the Conveyance Date; (c) any obligation or liability under any Contract that accrued or relates to the period on or prior to the Conveyance Date, regardless of when such Claim is asserted or discovered; or (d) any Contract not listed on Schedule I that affects the Property.'

amplified_by.effect: Buyer assumes all post-closing obligations, creating exposure if pre-closing defaults trigger post-closing consequences

risk_inventory.title: No Survival Period for Contract Assignment Indemnity
risk_inventory.description: Unlike Section 7C of the PSA which specifies a 270-day survival period for representations and warranties, this Assignment document contains no explicit survival period for the indemnification obligation. Without a specified survival term, the indemnity could be subject to general statute of limitations arguments or could be deemed to merge into the closing, leaving Buyer without recourse for later-discovered claims.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: Assignor hereby agrees to indemnify Assignee against and hold Assignee harmless from any and all liabilities, losses, claims, damages, costs or expenses
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Add explicit survival period of at least 2-3 years for this indemnity.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Add the following sentence at the end of this paragraph: 'The indemnification obligations of Assignor under this Section shall survive the Closing and the Conveyance Date for a period of three (3) years, provided that any claim for indemnification asserted in writing within such period shall survive until final resolution thereof, regardless of such three (3) year period.'

mitigated_by.effect: PSA survival clause may be incorporated by reference via p_341, but this is ambiguous

risk_inventory.title: No Liability Cap on Contract Assignment Indemnity
risk_inventory.description: This indemnity contains no cap or basket limitation on Seller's exposure. While this is favorable to Buyer, it creates a potential inconsistency with liability limitations that may exist elsewhere in the PSA. If the PSA contains liability caps that apply 'notwithstanding anything to the contrary,' Seller may argue those caps apply to this Assignment indemnity, creating uncertainty about Buyer's actual recovery rights.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: any and all liabilities, losses, claims, damages, costs or expenses
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Confirm this indemnity is excluded from any PSA liability caps.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Add the following clarification: 'For the avoidance of doubt, the indemnification obligations under this Assignment are not subject to any basket, deductible, cap, or other limitation on liability set forth in the Agreement, and the foregoing indemnification shall be in addition to, and not in limitation of, any other remedies available to Assignee at law or in equity.'

risk_inventory.title: Buyer 'Desires' Rather Than Unconditionally Accepts
risk_inventory.description: The recital uses precatory language ('Assignee desires to accept the assignment thereof') rather than operative acceptance language. While recitals are generally not operative provisions, this weak language could be used by Seller to argue that Buyer's acceptance is somehow conditional or that Buyer has not fully accepted all assigned items.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: Assignee desires to accept the assignment thereof
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Ensure operative provisions contain clear acceptance language.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: This is a recital, so the primary fix should be ensuring that the operative provisions (particularly the assumption clause at p_351) contain unconditional acceptance language. However, for consistency, consider revising this recital to: 'Pursuant to the Agreement, Assignor desires to assign, and Assignee desires to accept and assume, Assignor's interest in the Contracts and in certain intangible personal property with respect to the Property, on the terms and conditions set forth below.'

mitigated_by.effect: The operative assumption clause provides clearer acceptance language

risk_inventory.title: Uncapped assumption of all contract obligations
risk_inventory.description: As Buyer/Assignee, this provision requires assumption of 'all' obligations under the Contracts without limitation or qualification. The scope is unlimited and could include unknown liabilities, disputes, or breaches by Seller that occurred pre-closing but manifest post-closing. There is no carve-out for pre-existing breaches, no cap on exposure, and no limitation to obligations that were disclosed or discoverable during due diligence.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: Assignee hereby assumes all of Assignor's obligations under the Contracts
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Limit assumption to disclosed contracts and post-closing performance obligations only.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Modify to read: 'Assignee hereby assumes Assignor's obligations under the Contracts listed on Exhibit ___ attached hereto, but only to the extent such obligations (a) arise from events occurring on or after the Conveyance Date, (b) do not result from any breach, default, or failure to perform by Assignor prior to the Conveyance Date, and (c) were disclosed in the Due Diligence Documents or otherwise known to Assignee prior to Closing.'

risk_inventory.title: Unlimited buyer indemnity for contract claims
risk_inventory.description: The indemnity obligation has no cap, basket, or time limitation. Buyer must indemnify Seller for 'any and all Claims' arising from assumed contract obligations, which could result in unlimited exposure. This is particularly concerning because it is not mutual—Seller's indemnity in p_349 covers pre-closing claims, but there is no cap on either party's indemnity and no survival period limiting when claims can be brought.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: agrees to indemnify Assignor against and hold Assignor harmless from any and all Claims originating on or subsequent to the Conveyance Date
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Add liability cap tied to Purchase Price and survival period for indemnity claims.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Add the following limitation after 'under the Contracts': '; provided, however, that (i) Assignee's aggregate liability under this indemnity shall not exceed $_______ [or ___% of the Purchase Price], (ii) Assignee shall have no liability for any Claim unless Assignor provides written notice of such Claim within twelve (12) months after the Conveyance Date, and (iii) Assignee shall have no liability for any individual Claim unless the damages exceed $_______ and no aggregate liability unless total Claims exceed $_______.'

risk_inventory.title: Attorneys' fees shifting creates litigation risk
risk_inventory.description: The prevailing party fee-shifting provision applies to disputes under this Assignment. While facially mutual, this creates risk for Buyer if any dispute arises over contract interpretation, particularly given the broad assumption of obligations in p_351. If Seller brings a claim under the Assignment and prevails, Buyer bears not only the underlying liability but also Seller's attorneys' fees, which could substantially increase exposure.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: the losing party shall pay the prevailing party's costs and expenses of such dispute, including, without limitation, reasonable attorneys' fees and costs
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Consider limiting fee-shifting to claims above a threshold amount.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Consider modifying to: 'the losing party shall pay the prevailing party's reasonable attorneys' fees and costs, provided that this fee-shifting provision shall only apply to disputes involving claimed damages in excess of $_______ and shall not apply to any claim that is resolved through good faith negotiation within thirty (30) days of written notice.'

risk_inventory.title: Binding on successors expands indemnity exposure
risk_inventory.description: This provision makes the Assignment binding on successors and assigns, which means Buyer's indemnity obligations under p_351 could follow any sale of the Property. If Buyer sells the Property, Buyer may remain liable under the indemnity even after disposition unless the successor expressly assumes these obligations and Seller releases Buyer.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: This Assignment shall be binding on an inure to the benefit of the parties hereto and their respective successors and assigns
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Add release mechanism upon transfer to qualified successor.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Add the following sentence: 'Notwithstanding the foregoing, in the event Assignee transfers its interest in the Property to a successor who expressly assumes Assignee's obligations under this Assignment in writing, Assignor agrees to release Assignee from its obligations hereunder, provided such successor has a net worth reasonably acceptable to Assignor or provides other reasonable credit support.'

risk_inventory.title: Execution date not specified in form
risk_inventory.description: The Assignment references 'the day and year first written above' but this is a form document attached as an exhibit. Ensure that the execution date is properly filled in at closing and corresponds to the Conveyance Date to avoid any gap in coverage or ambiguity about when obligations transfer.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: as of the day and year first written above
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Confirm execution date matches Conveyance Date at closing.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: This is a form document issue. At closing, ensure the date in the preamble of this Assignment matches the actual Closing Date/Conveyance Date. Consider modifying to: 'as of the Closing Date (as defined in the Agreement)' to ensure automatic alignment with the PSA.

risk_inventory.title: No Duty to Investigate Rent Roll
risk_inventory.description: The Seller's representation regarding the Rent Roll is qualified by 'to its actual knowledge, without investigating.' This 'without investigating' language explicitly relieves Seller of any duty to verify the accuracy of the Rent Roll information before making the representation. This means Seller could provide materially inaccurate rent roll information and claim they had no duty to check it, leaving Buyer without recourse for reliance on incorrect information that could significantly impact property valuation and investment returns.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: to its actual knowledge, without investigating
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Remove 'without investigating' or require Seller to make reasonable inquiry.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Delete the phrase 'without investigating' from the representation. Alternatively, replace the knowledge qualifier with 'to Seller's actual knowledge after reasonable inquiry' or 'to Seller's knowledge' with a definition in the Agreement that includes a duty of reasonable investigation. At minimum, require that Seller has reviewed the Rent Roll with the property manager before certifying its accuracy.

risk_inventory.title: Rent Roll Date Not Tied to Closing
risk_inventory.description: The Rent Roll representation is made 'as of' a blank date that appears to be filled in at signing, not at Closing. This creates a gap where the Rent Roll could become materially inaccurate between the date of the representation and the actual Closing Date, yet Seller would have no obligation to update or re-certify the information. Tenant defaults, lease terminations, or rent modifications occurring after the representation date but before Closing would not be covered.
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Require Seller to re-certify Rent Roll accuracy as of Closing Date.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Modify the representation to require accuracy both as of the Effective Date and as of the Closing Date. Add language such as: 'The undersigned hereby represents and warrants that to its actual knowledge, the information in the attached Rent Roll is true and correct in all material respects as of the Effective Date and shall be re-certified by Seller as true and correct in all material respects as of the Closing Date.' Also add an obligation for Seller to promptly notify Buyer of any changes to the Rent Roll between signing and Closing.

risk_inventory.title: Materiality Qualifier on Rent Roll Accuracy
risk_inventory.description: The representation that the Rent Roll is accurate 'in all material respects' introduces subjectivity and allows for potentially significant inaccuracies that may not rise to the level of 'material.' There is no definition of what constitutes a material inaccuracy in the Rent Roll context. This could excuse errors in rent amounts, lease expiration dates, security deposit balances, or tenant concessions that individually might not be deemed 'material' but collectively could significantly impact the property's value or cash flow.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: true and correct in all material respects
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Define 'material' with specific dollar thresholds for Rent Roll representations.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Either (1) remove the 'in all material respects' qualifier so the representation is unqualified, or (2) add a specific definition of materiality for Rent Roll purposes, such as: 'For purposes of this representation, any inaccuracy shall be deemed material if (a) monthly rent amounts are misstated by more than $500 per lease, (b) lease expiration dates are misstated by more than 30 days, (c) security deposit amounts are misstated by more than $250, or (d) the aggregate impact of all inaccuracies exceeds $5,000.' Consider negotiating a schedule of acceptable variance thresholds.

risk_inventory.title: Reliance Statement May Limit Third-Party Claims
risk_inventory.description: The representation explicitly states it is made 'for your benefit and protection' with the understanding that 'you intend to rely upon this statement in connection with your intended purchase.' While this establishes reliance for the Buyer, it may inadvertently limit who can rely on the representation—potentially excluding Buyer's lenders, assignees, or successors who may also need to rely on the Rent Roll accuracy for financing or subsequent transactions.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: for your benefit and protection with the understanding that you intend to rely upon this statement
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Expand reliance to include Buyer's lenders, successors, and assigns.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Modify the reliance language to expressly permit reliance by additional parties: 'The undersigned makes this representation and warranty for the benefit and protection of [Buyer], its lenders, successors, and assigns, with the understanding that such parties intend to rely upon this statement in connection with the purchase of the Property and any financing related thereto.' This ensures that Buyer's lender can rely on the representation for underwriting purposes and that the representation survives any assignment of Buyer's interest.

risk_inventory.title: No Survival Period Specified for Rent Roll Rep
risk_inventory.description: This Rent Roll representation appears in a separate exhibit/certificate form and does not specify its own survival period. While the main Agreement may have a survival provision in Section 7.3, it is unclear whether this separate certification is covered by that survival period or whether it survives Closing at all. If the representation terminates at Closing, Buyer would have no post-Closing recourse for discovering Rent Roll inaccuracies.
