risk_inventory.problematic_text: The undersigned hereby represents and warrants
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Add explicit survival period or cross-reference to Agreement's survival terms.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Add a survival provision to this certificate: 'This representation and warranty shall survive the Closing for a period consistent with the survival of Seller's representations and warranties under Section 7.3 of the Purchase and Sale Agreement, or for a period of [twelve (12) months] following the Closing Date, whichever is longer.' Alternatively, add language expressly incorporating this certificate into the Agreement's survival framework: 'This representation and warranty is made pursuant to and subject to the terms and conditions of the Agreement, including the survival provisions of Section 7.3 thereof.'

risk_inventory.title: Heading Only - No Substantive Terms
risk_inventory.description: This paragraph contains only a heading 'Assignment and Assumption of Contracts and Intangible Property' without any substantive terms. This appears to be either a section header or an incomplete exhibit. The actual assignment form appears earlier in the document (see p_335-p_359). Buyer should confirm this is not a duplicate or missing exhibit and that all necessary assignment documentation is complete.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: Assignment and Assumption of Contracts and Intangible Property
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Confirm this is intentional section break or complete with substantive terms.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Review the document structure to determine if this heading is: (1) a duplicate of the exhibit at p_335 that should be deleted, (2) a placeholder for additional content that needs to be completed, or (3) an intentional section break that should include a cross-reference to the actual Assignment form. If this is meant to reference the Assignment form, add: 'See Exhibit E attached hereto and incorporated herein by reference.' Ensure the exhibit numbering and cross-references throughout the Agreement are consistent.

p_4.title: Uncertain Effective Date Determination
p_4.description: The Effective Date is defined as when the Agreement is 'executed and delivered by the last of Buyer and Seller,' but there is no mechanism to verify or document when this occurs. This creates uncertainty about when contractual deadlines (due diligence period, deposit deadlines, closing date) begin to run. Disputes could arise about whether delivery occurred, particularly if signatures are exchanged electronically or through intermediaries.
p_4.problematic_text: The date this Agreement is executed and delivered by the last of Buyer and Seller shall be the "Effective Date" hereof.
p_4.user_recommendation: Add requirement for written confirmation of Effective Date by both parties.
p_4.model_instructions: Insert after the Effective Date definition: 'The parties shall confirm the Effective Date in writing within one (1) business day of execution by the last signing party. If the parties dispute the Effective Date, the date shown on the Escrow Holder's records shall control.' Alternatively, define Effective Date as the date of Escrow Holder's receipt of the fully executed Agreement.

amplified_by.effect: Uncertain Effective Date makes deposit deadline uncertain, risking default
Due diligence period start date becomes uncertain

p_8.title: Purchase Price Forward Reference
p_8.description: The Purchase Price is referenced but defined elsewhere. While this is standard drafting practice, Buyer should verify that the Purchase Price definition in Section 2 is complete and includes all adjustments, prorations, and credits to which Buyer is entitled.
p_8.problematic_text: for the Purchase Price (as defined below)
p_8.user_recommendation: Verify Purchase Price definition in Section 2 includes all adjustments.
p_8.model_instructions: Cross-reference Section 2 (p_16) and Section 11.6 (p_102) regarding prorations to ensure the Purchase Price definition and adjustment mechanisms are complete and favor Buyer's interests. No change needed to this clause itself.

p_9.title: Exhibit A Legal Description Missing
p_9.description: The Real Property is identified only by a blank street address and reference to Exhibit A. Buyer must verify that Exhibit A contains a complete and accurate metes-and-bounds or platted legal description that matches the title commitment. An incorrect or incomplete legal description could result in Buyer not acquiring all intended property or acquiring unintended parcels.
p_9.problematic_text: located at ______________________________________, Washington, as more particularly described in Exhibit A attached hereto
p_9.user_recommendation: Verify Exhibit A matches title commitment legal description exactly.
p_9.model_instructions: Add the following sentence after '(the "Real Property")': 'Buyer shall have the right to require amendment of Exhibit A to conform to the legal description shown in the Commitment, and any such amendment shall not require additional consideration.' Also ensure Exhibit A is attached and matches the title commitment before execution.

mitigated_by.effect: Title commitment review should reveal description discrepancies
Buyer has opportunity to identify issues during title review

p_10.title: Undefined Appurtenant Rights Scope
p_10.description: The conveyance of 'all rights, easements and rights-of-way appurtenant to the beneficial use and enjoyment of the Real Property' is limited to appurtenant rights only. This may not capture easements in gross, license agreements, or other access/utility rights that benefit the Property but are not technically 'appurtenant.' Seller could retain valuable rights that Buyer expects to receive.
p_10.problematic_text: All rights, easements and rights-of-way appurtenant to the beneficial use and enjoyment of the Real Property
p_10.user_recommendation: Expand to include easements in gross, licenses, and all access rights.
p_10.model_instructions: Replace the clause with: 'Appurtenances. All rights, privileges, easements (whether appurtenant or in gross), rights-of-way, licenses, permits, entitlements, development rights, air rights, water rights, mineral rights (to the extent owned by Seller), and any other rights or interests appurtenant to or benefiting the Real Property, whether or not of record (collectively, the "Appurtenances");'

mitigated_by.effect: Some rights may be captured under Intangible Property

amplified_by.effect: As-is provision may limit Buyer's recourse if important rights not conveyed

p_11.title: Undefined Tenant/Leased Fixtures Exclusion
p_11.description: The clause excludes 'fixtures owned by tenants or leased by Seller from third parties' from the conveyance, but there is no schedule or exhibit identifying these excluded items. Without a definitive list, Buyer cannot verify what is actually being purchased versus what will be removed or retained. Post-closing disputes could arise if Seller claims valuable fixtures were excluded when Buyer believed they were included.
p_11.problematic_text: excluding any fixtures owned by tenants or leased by Seller from third parties
p_11.user_recommendation: Require Seller to provide a schedule of all excluded fixtures before Closing.
p_11.model_instructions: Insert language requiring Seller to deliver, within 5 business days of the Effective Date, a complete schedule identifying all fixtures owned by tenants and all fixtures leased by Seller from third parties, including the owner/lessor, description, and location. Add that any fixtures not listed on such schedule shall be deemed included in the sale. Include Buyer's right to object to any claimed exclusions during the Due Diligence Period.

amplified_by.effect: AS-IS clause may limit Buyer's ability to recover for missing fixtures Buyer believed were included

p_12.title: Personal Property Exclusions Not Specified
p_12.description: The bracketed language indicates that specific exclusions should be listed but the blank is unfilled. This creates uncertainty about what personal property is actually being conveyed. Seller could later claim valuable items were excluded, or Buyer may not receive property it expected.
p_12.user_recommendation: Complete the exclusion list or delete exclusion language entirely.
p_12.model_instructions: Either (a) delete the bracketed exclusion language in its entirety so all personal property owned by Seller is conveyed, or (b) require Seller to complete the list prior to the end of the Due Diligence Period and provide Buyer with an opportunity to approve or object. Add language stating: 'Any personal property not specifically listed as excluded shall be deemed included in the sale and conveyed to Buyer at Closing.'

amplified_by.effect: AS-IS language may preclude Buyer from claiming reliance on inclusion of unlisted items

p_12.title: No Personal Property Inventory Required
p_12.description: The clause conveys personal property 'owned by Seller and located on, in, or used in connection with' the Property, but there is no requirement for Seller to provide an inventory or schedule of such items. Buyer cannot verify what personal property exists or will be conveyed at Closing.
p_12.problematic_text: All of the right, title and interest of Seller in and to all personal property owned by Seller and located on, in, or used in connection with, the Real Property
p_12.user_recommendation: Require Seller to provide a personal property inventory during due diligence.
p_12.model_instructions: Add the following language: 'Seller shall deliver to Buyer within five (5) business days of the Effective Date a complete inventory of all Personal Property to be conveyed hereunder, which inventory shall be subject to Buyer's review and approval during the Due Diligence Period. At Closing, Seller shall deliver a Bill of Sale covering all items on the approved inventory.'

mitigated_by.effect: Bill of Sale at closing will document what personal property is actually conveyed

p_13.title: Intangibles Limited to 'Extent Transferable'
p_13.description: The conveyance of intangible property is qualified by 'to the extent transferable by Seller.' This places the risk of non-transferability on Buyer without requiring Seller to make efforts to obtain necessary consents or to warrant transferability. Key permits, licenses, or contracts may not transfer, leaving Buyer without critical operational rights.
p_13.problematic_text: to the extent transferable by Seller
p_13.user_recommendation: Add Seller obligation to use best efforts to obtain transfer consents.
p_13.model_instructions: Modify to read: 'All of the right, title and interest of Seller in and to all intangible personal property... Seller shall use commercially reasonable efforts to obtain all consents necessary to transfer such intangible property to Buyer. Seller shall identify any intangible property that is not transferable or requires consent for transfer within five (5) business days of the Effective Date, and shall notify Buyer of any consent that is not obtained prior to Closing. Buyer may elect to terminate this Agreement without penalty if any material consent is not obtained.'

amplified_by.effect: AS-IS clause may limit recourse if key permits do not transfer

p_13.title: Seller Retains All Pre-Closing Third Party Claims
p_13.description: Seller excludes from the conveyance 'any present or future claims of Seller against any third parties that relate to any period of time prior to the Closing.' This means if there are construction defects, warranty claims, or causes of action arising from pre-closing events (e.g., contractor negligence, environmental contamination caused by third parties), Buyer has no right to pursue those claims even though Buyer inherits the physical consequences. This is a significant allocation of risk to Buyer.
p_13.problematic_text: but excluding any present or future claims of Seller against any third parties that relate to any period of time prior to the Closing
p_13.user_recommendation: Require assignment of all third-party claims to Buyer at Closing.
p_13.model_instructions: Delete the exclusionary language and replace with: 'Seller hereby assigns to Buyer all of Seller's right, title, and interest in and to any and all claims, causes of action, warranties, and guaranties against third parties relating to the Property, including without limitation claims for construction defects, design defects, environmental contamination, and breach of warranty, whether arising before or after Closing. Seller shall execute such further instruments as Buyer may reasonably request to effectuate such assignment.'

amplified_by.effect: Combined with AS-IS language, Buyer absorbs property defects with no recourse against responsible third parties
Release further limits Buyer's ability to recover for pre-closing issues

p_13.title: Service Contracts Undefined and Unscheduled
p_13.description: The clause includes 'equipment leases, utility contracts, maintenance contracts, and all other similar agreements' as Service Contracts being conveyed, but there is no schedule identifying these contracts. Buyer cannot evaluate the terms, obligations, or termination rights of these agreements during due diligence. Buyer may inherit unfavorable long-term contracts.
p_13.problematic_text: all equipment leases, utility contracts, maintenance contracts, and all other similar agreements (collectively, the "Service Contracts")
p_13.user_recommendation: Require delivery of all Service Contracts and a schedule during due diligence.
p_13.model_instructions: Add language requiring: 'Seller shall deliver to Buyer within five (5) business days of the Effective Date complete copies of all Service Contracts together with a schedule listing each Service Contract, the parties thereto, the term, any renewal provisions, termination rights, and monthly/annual cost. Buyer's approval of the Service Contracts shall be a condition to Buyer's obligations under Section 5. Any Service Contract not disclosed to Buyer shall not be assumed by Buyer and Seller shall indemnify Buyer for any obligations thereunder.'

mitigated_by.effect: Seller cannot enter into new material Service Contracts without Buyer consent

p_14.title: Lease Definition Includes 'Other Agreements to Occupy'
p_14.description: The definition of 'Leases' includes not only formal leases but also 'other agreements to occupy the Real Property.' This broad language could include license agreements, month-to-month arrangements, or informal occupancy rights that may not be documented. Buyer should confirm all occupancy arrangements are disclosed.
p_14.problematic_text: all leases and other agreements to occupy the Real Property and/or the Improvements, or any portion thereof
p_14.user_recommendation: Require rent roll to include all occupancy agreements, not just formal leases.
p_14.model_instructions: Add to the due diligence delivery requirements: 'Seller shall deliver a complete schedule of all Leases and other occupancy agreements, including any license agreements, month-to-month tenancies, and informal occupancy arrangements, whether or not reduced to writing. Seller represents that no person or entity has any right to occupy any portion of the Property except as set forth on such schedule.'

mitigated_by.effect: Rent roll representation provides some protection if accurate

p_15.title: Seller Retains Non-Exclusive Claim Rights Post-Closing
p_15.description: Seller reserves 'on a non-exclusive basis with Buyer' the right to assert claims under warranties, guaranties, and agreements related to design, construction, or performance of the Property. This creates potential conflicts: Seller may pursue claims that Buyer would prefer to settle, or Seller may settle claims Buyer needs to pursue. The 'non-exclusive' nature creates coordination issues and potential claim-splitting problems.
p_15.problematic_text: Seller reserves and retains the right, on a non-exclusive basis with Buyer, to assert all claims, defenses, counter claims, and cross claims of Seller against any third parties under any warranties, guaranties, and agreements related to design, construction or performance of the Property
p_15.user_recommendation: Delete Seller's retained rights or limit to claims for pre-closing damages only.
p_15.model_instructions: Delete this reservation language or modify to read: 'Seller assigns to Buyer all claims, defenses, counterclaims, and cross claims against any third parties under any warranties, guaranties, and agreements related to design, construction, or performance of the Property. Notwithstanding the foregoing, Seller shall retain the right to pursue claims solely for damages suffered by Seller prior to Closing, provided Seller shall not settle any such claims without Buyer's prior written consent if such settlement would impair Buyer's rights or remedies. Buyer and Seller shall cooperate in the prosecution of any claims and shall not take any action that would prejudice the other party's rights.'

amplified_by.effect: Combined with exclusion in 1E, this creates uncertainty about which party can pursue which claims

p_18.title: Initial Deposit Non-Refundable Upon Receipt
p_18.description: The clause states the Initial Deposit 'will become non-refundable upon Escrow Holder's receipt except in case of Seller's default.' This means Buyer loses the deposit immediately upon delivery, even before conducting any due diligence. If Buyer discovers material issues during the due diligence period (see p_31), Buyer would lose the entire Initial Deposit upon termination. This is highly unusual and buyer-unfavorable; standard practice is for deposits to become non-refundable only AFTER the due diligence period expires without termination.
p_18.problematic_text: The Initial Deposit will become non-refundable upon Escrow Holder's receipt except in case of Seller's default hereunder.
p_18.user_recommendation: Deposit should remain refundable through end of Due Diligence Period.
p_18.model_instructions: Delete the sentence 'The Initial Deposit will become non-refundable upon Escrow Holder's receipt except in case of Seller's default hereunder.' and replace with: 'The Initial Deposit shall be refundable to Buyer if Buyer delivers a Termination Notice pursuant to Section 5(c) prior to the expiration of the Due Diligence Period. Upon expiration of the Due Diligence Period without Buyer's delivery of a Termination Notice, the Initial Deposit shall become non-refundable except in the case of (i) Seller's default hereunder, (ii) failure of any condition precedent set forth in Section 5.4, or (iii) as otherwise expressly provided in this Agreement.'

amplified_by.effect: Liquidated damages provision allows Seller to retain entire Deposit as sole remedy, compounding the early non-refundability risk
Only applies to termination for reasons 'other than Buyer's default,' potentially excluding due diligence termination

p_18.title: Immediate Payment of Deposit to Seller
p_18.description: The bracketed alternative provision states 'Upon receipt, Escrow Holder shall promptly pay the Initial Deposit to Seller.' If this alternative is selected, Buyer loses escrow protection entirely. The deposit would be in Seller's hands rather than held by a neutral Escrow Holder, making recovery difficult even in cases of Seller default. This creates significant counterparty credit risk and eliminates the protective function of escrow.
p_18.problematic_text: [Upon receipt, Escrow Holder shall promptly pay the Initial Deposit to Seller.]
p_18.user_recommendation: Delete this bracketed alternative; deposit must remain in escrow until Closing.
p_18.model_instructions: Delete the bracketed provision '[Upon receipt, Escrow Holder shall promptly pay the Initial Deposit to Seller.]' entirely. If Seller insists on release of deposit funds, add protective language: 'Notwithstanding the foregoing, the Initial Deposit shall be held by Escrow Holder in accordance with the terms of this Agreement and shall not be released to Seller until Closing, except as expressly provided herein.'

amplified_by.effect: If deposit is paid to Seller and Seller defaults, Buyer's remedy to recover deposit depends on Seller's willingness/ability to return funds

p_18.title: Narrow Exception for Deposit Refund
p_18.description: The deposit is non-refundable 'except in case of Seller's default hereunder.' This language is too narrow. It does not expressly preserve Buyer's right to recover the deposit upon (i) failure of Buyer's conditions precedent under Section 5.4, (ii) casualty or condemnation under Section 14, (iii) title defects Seller cannot cure, or (iv) other express termination rights in the Agreement. Buyer should not lose its deposit when termination is permitted under the Agreement for reasons other than Seller's default.
p_18.problematic_text: except in case of Seller's default hereunder
p_18.user_recommendation: Expand refund exceptions to include all permitted termination events.
p_18.model_instructions: Replace 'except in case of Seller's default hereunder' with 'except in case of (i) Seller's default hereunder, (ii) Buyer's termination of this Agreement pursuant to Section 5(c) prior to expiration of the Due Diligence Period, (iii) failure of any condition precedent set forth in Section 5.4, (iv) termination pursuant to Section 4 due to title defects that Seller does not cure, (v) termination pursuant to Section 14 following casualty or condemnation, or (vi) any other express termination right granted to Buyer under this Agreement.'

mitigated_by.effect: Section 6 provides some protection for deposit return upon termination, but scope is unclear

p_19.title: One Business Day Deadline for Additional Deposit
p_19.description: Buyer has only one (1) business day to deliver the Additional Deposit after approval or expiration of due diligence. This extremely short window creates significant operational risk. Wire transfer delays, banking holidays, or administrative errors could result in missed deadline. If the Additional Deposit is not timely delivered, Buyer could be in default, potentially forfeiting the Initial Deposit.
p_19.problematic_text: Within one (1) business day after the earlier of Seller's receipt of the Approval Notice, or the expiration of the Due Diligence Period
p_19.user_recommendation: Extend Additional Deposit deadline to three (3) business days.
p_19.model_instructions: Replace 'Within one (1) business day' with 'Within three (3) business days'. Also consider adding: 'Buyer's failure to timely deliver the Additional Deposit shall not constitute a default hereunder provided such deposit is delivered within two (2) business days following written notice from Seller of such failure.'

amplified_by.effect: Late deposit could trigger default and forfeiture of Initial Deposit as liquidated damages

p_19.title: Additional Deposit Immediately Non-Refundable
p_19.description: The Additional Deposit is stated to be 'nonrefundable, except in case of Seller's default hereunder, and as otherwise expressly provided in this Agreement.' While this includes the qualifier 'as otherwise expressly provided,' the baseline non-refundability creates risk if conditions precedent fail or other termination events occur that are not clearly covered by express Agreement provisions. This compounds with the Initial Deposit issue to put the entire Deposit at risk.
p_19.problematic_text: The Additional Deposit is nonrefundable, except in case of Seller's default hereunder, and as otherwise expressly provided in this Agreement.
p_19.user_recommendation: Clarify all circumstances where Additional Deposit is refundable.
p_19.model_instructions: Replace the sentence with: 'The Additional Deposit shall be nonrefundable, except in case of (i) Seller's default hereunder, (ii) failure of any condition precedent set forth in Section 5.4, (iii) termination pursuant to Section 4 due to title defects that Seller does not cure, (iv) termination pursuant to Section 14 following casualty or condemnation, or (v) any other express termination right granted to Buyer under this Agreement that entitles Buyer to return of the Deposit.'

mitigated_by.effect: Section 6 provides some framework for deposit return, adding marginal protection

amplified_by.effect: Entire Deposit including Additional Deposit serves as liquidated damages

p_19.title: Immediate Payment of Additional Deposit to Seller
p_19.description: Similar to the Initial Deposit, a bracketed alternative states 'Upon receipt, Escrow Holder shall promptly pay the Additional Deposit to Seller.' If this alternative is selected along with the similar provision for the Initial Deposit, the entire Deposit would be in Seller's hands, eliminating all escrow protection for Buyer. Recovery would require legal action against Seller.
p_19.problematic_text: [Upon receipt, Escrow Holder shall promptly pay the Additional Deposit to Seller.]
p_19.user_recommendation: Delete this bracketed alternative; deposit must remain in escrow.
p_19.model_instructions: Delete the bracketed provision '[Upon receipt, Escrow Holder shall promptly pay the Additional Deposit to Seller.]' entirely. The deposit should remain in escrow as stated in the first bracketed alternative.

amplified_by.effect: Buyer's ability to recover deposit upon Seller default would be impaired if funds are already with Seller

p_19.title: Deemed Approval Through Inaction on Due Diligence
p_19.description: The Additional Deposit becomes due upon 'expiration of the Due Diligence Period without Buyer's delivery of a Termination Notice.' This creates a deemed approval mechanism where Buyer's failure to act (deliver Termination Notice) triggers non-refundable deposit obligations. If Buyer's team misses the deadline or miscommunicates, Buyer is locked into the transaction without affirmative approval.
p_19.problematic_text: the expiration of the Due Diligence Period without Buyer's delivery of a Termination Notice
p_19.user_recommendation: Consider requiring affirmative Approval Notice, not just absence of termination.
p_19.model_instructions: Consider revising to require affirmative approval: Replace 'Within one (1) business day after the earlier of Seller's receipt of the Approval Notice, or the expiration of the Due Diligence Period without Buyer's delivery of a Termination Notice' with 'Within three (3) business days after Seller's receipt of the Approval Notice pursuant to Section 5(c)'. Then add: 'If Buyer fails to deliver either an Approval Notice or a Termination Notice prior to the expiration of the Due Diligence Period, Seller may deliver written notice to Buyer demanding that Buyer make an election within two (2) business days, failing which this Agreement shall terminate and the Deposit shall be returned to Buyer.'

amplified_by.effect: Deemed approval locks in non-refundability of Initial Deposit already at risk

p_20.title: Bracketed Interest Credit Language
p_20.description: The bracketed language '[plus accrued interest thereon]' suggests uncertainty about whether interest on the Deposit will be credited to Buyer at Closing. The first bracketed alternative in p_18 states interest is 'held for the account of Buyer,' but this p_20 bracket creates ambiguity. If interest is substantial and the deal closes, Buyer should ensure interest credits against Purchase Price.
p_20.user_recommendation: Remove brackets and confirm interest credits to Buyer at Closing.
p_20.model_instructions: Remove the brackets to make the language definitive: Replace '[plus accrued interest thereon]' with 'plus all accrued interest thereon'. Ensure consistency with p_18's bracketed alternative that states interest is 'held for the account of Buyer.'

mitigated_by.effect: First bracketed alternative in p_18 provides that interest is held for Buyer's account

p_21.title: Blank Purchase Price Allocation
p_21.description: The allocation amount for Personal Property is left blank ($____________). This creates ambiguity that could result in disputes over the allocation, which has significant tax implications. If Seller fills in an unfavorable allocation or disputes arise later, Buyer may face unexpected tax consequences. Personal property is typically depreciated over shorter periods than real property, so Buyer generally benefits from a higher personal property allocation.
p_21.problematic_text: The sum of $____________ of the Purchase Price shall be allocated to the Personal Property
p_21.user_recommendation: Insert specific dollar amount and confirm allocation methodology benefits Buyer's tax position.
p_21.model_instructions: Replace the blank '$____________' with a specific negotiated dollar amount. Consider adding language that (1) specifies the methodology for the allocation (e.g., based on fair market value appraisal), (2) requires mutual agreement on the allocation prior to Closing, (3) obligates both parties to report the allocation consistently on their respective tax returns (IRS Form 8594), and (4) provides that Buyer's reasonable allocation shall control absent Seller's timely objection.

p_21.title: No Tax Reporting Consistency Requirement
p_21.description: The allocation provision lacks any requirement that both parties report the allocation consistently for tax purposes. Without such language, Seller could report a different allocation to the IRS, potentially triggering an audit or dispute with tax authorities.
p_21.problematic_text: The sum of $____________ of the Purchase Price shall be allocated to the Personal Property, and the balance shall be allocated to the Real Property, the Appurtenances and the Improvements.
p_21.user_recommendation: Add requirement for consistent tax reporting of allocation by both parties.
p_21.model_instructions: Add the following sentence at the end of the paragraph: 'Seller and Buyer agree to report this allocation consistently on all applicable tax returns, including IRS Form 8594, and neither party shall take a position on any tax return or in any tax proceeding inconsistent with this allocation unless required to do so by applicable law.'

p_23.title: Seven-Day Delivery Window May Be Insufficient
p_23.description: Seller has seven days after mutual execution to deliver survey and title documents. However, there is no remedy specified if Seller fails to deliver within this timeframe. Buyer's Title Review Period runs from the Effective Date (per Section 4B), not from receipt of documents, meaning Buyer could lose review time if Seller delays delivery. This creates a timing mismatch that disadvantages Buyer.
p_23.problematic_text: within seven (7) days after mutual execution of this Agreement
p_23.user_recommendation: Tie Title Review Period to receipt of documents, not Effective Date.
p_23.model_instructions: Modify Section 4B to provide that the Title Review Period runs from the later of (i) the Effective Date, or (ii) Buyer's receipt of all Title Documents. Alternatively, add language here stating: 'Seller's failure to deliver the items required by this Section 4.1 within the time period specified shall automatically extend the Title Review Period and Due Diligence Period by one day for each day of delay beyond the seven (7) day period.'

p_23.title: No Consequence for Late Delivery
p_23.description: The clause obligates Seller to deliver documents within seven days but provides no consequence or remedy if Seller fails to comply. Buyer has no explicit right to extend review periods, terminate, or seek other relief for late delivery.
p_23.problematic_text: Seller shall deliver the following items to Buyer within seven (7) days after mutual execution of this Agreement
p_23.user_recommendation: Add automatic extension of review periods or termination right for late delivery.
p_23.model_instructions: Add the following at the end of Section 4A: 'In the event Seller fails to deliver any of the items required under this Section 4.1 within the time period specified, the Title Review Period and Due Diligence Period shall each be automatically extended by one (1) day for each day of such delay. If Seller fails to deliver all required items within fourteen (14) days after mutual execution, Buyer may terminate this Agreement by written notice to Seller and receive a full refund of the Deposit.'

p_24.title: Survey Delivery Conditioned on Seller's Possession
p_24.description: Seller's obligation to deliver a survey is qualified by 'if any' and 'in the possession of Seller.' This allows Seller to claim no survey exists or that it is not in their possession, leaving Buyer without baseline survey information. Buyer bears the full cost and time burden of obtaining a new survey.
p_24.problematic_text: The most recent survey of the Property, if any ("Existing Survey") in the possession of Seller
p_24.user_recommendation: Require Seller to deliver any survey it has or can reasonably obtain.
p_24.model_instructions: Revise to: 'The most recent survey of the Property in Seller's possession or control, or which Seller can obtain from its lender, title company, or property manager without unreasonable cost or effort (the "Existing Survey"). Seller represents that, to Seller's Actual Knowledge, [there is no existing survey / the Existing Survey attached hereto is the most recent survey of the Property].'

p_24.title: Buyer Bears Full Survey Cost
p_24.description: Buyer is required to pay for any updated or new ALTA survey at Buyer's expense. While this is market-standard, in a Buyer-favorable negotiation, Seller could be required to share this cost or provide a credit.
p_24.user_recommendation: Consider negotiating Seller contribution to survey costs.
p_24.model_instructions: If Buyer desires to shift or share survey costs, revise to: 'at Buyer's expense; provided, however, that Seller shall reimburse Buyer for up to $[AMOUNT] of the cost of the Updated Survey at Closing, which amount shall be credited against the Purchase Price.' Alternatively, in stronger Buyer markets: 'at Seller's expense.'

p_25.title: Title Company Name Left Blank
p_25.description: The title company name is left blank, which could lead to disputes over which title company will be used. Buyer should ensure a reputable title company acceptable to Buyer is specified.
p_25.user_recommendation: Insert name of Buyer-approved title company before execution.
p_25.model_instructions: Insert the name of a specific title company acceptable to Buyer. Consider adding: 'or such other title company as Buyer may designate in writing to Seller prior to the Effective Date.'

p_26.title: Silence Constitutes Approval of Title Defects
p_26.description: If Buyer fails to deliver Title Objections within the ten-day Title Review Period, all exceptions and title conditions are deemed approved. This is a significant trap for Buyer—missing the deadline results in waiver of all title objections, even material defects. The period runs from the Effective Date, not from receipt of Title Documents, compounding the risk if Seller delays delivery.
p_26.problematic_text: Buyer's failure to timely notify Seller of its approval of all or certain of the Title Documents and the Title Objections, if any, within the Title Review Period shall constitute approval of all exceptions and of the condition of title to the Property.
p_26.user_recommendation: Remove deemed approval or require Seller to provide reminder notice before deadline.
p_26.model_instructions: Revise to: 'Buyer's failure to timely notify Seller of Title Objections within the Title Review Period shall constitute approval only of those specific exceptions that are Permitted Exceptions as defined herein. Notwithstanding the foregoing, Buyer shall not be deemed to have approved (i) any monetary liens or encumbrances (other than non-delinquent taxes), (ii) any matters that would materially interfere with Buyer's intended use of the Property, or (iii) any exceptions first appearing on a supplemental title report after the Effective Date.' Alternatively, add: 'Seller shall provide written notice to Buyer at least three (3) business days prior to the expiration of the Title Review Period.'

p_26.title: Title Review Period Runs from Effective Date, Not Receipt
p_26.description: The Title Review Period is ten days from the Effective Date, but Seller has seven days after mutual execution to deliver Title Documents (Section 4A). This means Buyer could have as few as three days to review Title Documents if Seller delivers on the last day. This is grossly inadequate for proper title review.
p_26.problematic_text: Buyer shall have ten (10) days from the Effective Date (the "Title Review Period")
p_26.user_recommendation: Change Title Review Period to run from receipt of complete Title Documents.
p_26.model_instructions: Revise to: 'Buyer shall have ten (10) days from the later of (i) the Effective Date, or (ii) Buyer's receipt of all Title Documents required under Section 4.1 (the "Title Review Period").' This ensures Buyer has the full review period regardless of when Seller delivers documents.

p_26.title: Seller Has Absolute Discretion to Refuse Title Cure
p_26.description: Seller may elect not to cure any Title Objection in its sole discretion. Even for material defects that render title unmarketable, Seller can simply refuse to cure, leaving Buyer with only the option to waive or terminate. This gives Seller significant leverage and allows Seller to refuse to address even readily curable defects.
p_26.problematic_text: (ii) notice that Seller elects not to remove or cure such Title Objection
p_26.user_recommendation: Require Seller to cure monetary liens and certain material defects.
p_26.model_instructions: Add the following: 'Notwithstanding the foregoing, Seller shall be obligated to remove or cure at or prior to Closing, at Seller's sole cost and expense: (i) all monetary liens and encumbrances against the Property (other than non-delinquent real property taxes and assessments), including without limitation any deeds of trust, mortgages, mechanics' liens, judgment liens, and tax liens; (ii) any exceptions created by Seller after the Effective Date without Buyer's consent; and (iii) any exceptions that Seller has expressly agreed in writing to remove or cure. Such obligations shall not be subject to any cap or limitation.'

p_26.title: Buyer's Only Remedy is Termination or Waiver
p_26.description: If Seller refuses to cure Title Objections, Buyer's only options are to waive the objection or terminate the Agreement. Buyer has no right to a purchase price reduction, credit at closing, or other remedy for uncured title defects.
p_26.problematic_text: Buyer may either (i) waive such Title Objection and proceed with the Closing, or (ii) terminate this Agreement by written notice to Seller.
p_26.user_recommendation: Add option for purchase price reduction or credit for uncured title defects.
p_26.model_instructions: Revise to: 'Buyer may either (i) waive such Title Objection and proceed with the Closing, (ii) terminate this Agreement by written notice to Seller and receive a full refund of the Deposit, or (iii) proceed with the Closing and receive a credit against the Purchase Price in an amount reasonably determined by Buyer to compensate Buyer for the uncured Title Objection, provided such credit shall not exceed the estimated cost to cure such Title Objection.'

p_26.title: Termination Right Limited to Due Diligence Period
p_26.description: If Seller refuses to cure Title Objections, Buyer's termination right is limited to 'any time prior to the end of the Due Diligence Period.' If the Due Diligence Period ends before Seller responds to Title Objections, or shortly thereafter, Buyer may lose its termination right. This creates a timing trap.
p_26.problematic_text: at any time prior to the end of the Due Diligence Period Buyer may either (i) waive such Title Objection and proceed with the Closing, or (ii) terminate this Agreement
p_26.user_recommendation: Extend termination right to reasonable period after Seller's response.
p_26.model_instructions: Revise to: 'then within five (5) business days after Seller's notice (or failure to respond), but in no event later than the Closing Date, Buyer may either (i) waive such Title Objection and proceed with the Closing, or (ii) terminate this Agreement by written notice to Seller and receive a full refund of the Deposit.'

p_27.title: Five-Day Review Too Short for Supplements
p_27.description: Buyer has only five (5) days to review and disapprove title exceptions in supplemental reports. Given that supplements may arrive close to closing and could contain significant new encumbrances (mechanics' liens, judgment liens, new easements), this compressed timeframe may be insufficient for proper legal review, especially if Buyer's counsel is unavailable or if the exception requires investigation. Missing this deadline results in automatic deemed approval of potentially harmful exceptions.
p_27.problematic_text: Buyer shall have five (5) days following the receipt of a supplemental report to notify Seller in writing of its disapproval
p_27.user_recommendation: Extend supplemental review period to 10 business days.
p_27.model_instructions: Replace 'five (5) days' with 'ten (10) business days' to provide Buyer adequate time to review, investigate, and respond to new title exceptions that may appear in supplemental reports close to closing.

amplified_by.effect: Title review cannot extend closing, compressing available time even further

p_27.title: Automatic Deemed Approval of Exceptions
p_27.description: If Buyer fails to timely communicate disapproval of a supplemental exception, it automatically becomes a Permitted Exception. This 'silence equals consent' provision shifts risk to Buyer and could result in Buyer taking title subject to objectionable encumbrances (such as easements, liens, or restrictions) simply due to an administrative oversight or delayed mail delivery.
p_27.problematic_text: if Buyer's disapproval of any supplemental report exception is not so communicated to Seller, the exception shall be considered a Permitted Exception
p_27.user_recommendation: Require affirmative written approval for new exceptions.
p_27.model_instructions: Delete the automatic deemed approval language and replace with: 'Any exception contained in a supplemental report shall not be deemed a Permitted Exception unless Buyer provides express written approval thereof.' This shifts the default to protect Buyer from unapproved encumbrances.

amplified_by.effect: AS-IS provision may limit Buyer's post-closing remedies for title defects

p_27.title: Title Review Cannot Extend Closing
p_27.description: The express prohibition that 'in no event shall title review extend the Closing Date' creates significant risk for Buyer. If a critical title defect appears in a supplemental report received close to closing, Buyer may be forced to either (a) accept a defective title, (b) waive material objections, or (c) potentially be in default for refusing to close. This is particularly dangerous if Seller causes new exceptions to appear (through liens, new agreements, etc.) near closing.
p_27.problematic_text: in no event shall title review extend the Closing Date
p_27.user_recommendation: Add automatic closing extension for late supplements.
p_27.model_instructions: Delete '(ii) in no event shall title review extend the Closing Date' and replace with: '(ii) if any supplemental report is received by Buyer less than ten (10) business days prior to the scheduled Closing Date, the Closing Date shall be automatically extended to provide Buyer ten (10) business days from receipt of such supplemental report to complete its review and for Seller to cure any disapproved items.'

amplified_by.effect: Buyer could lose deposit if deemed in default for refusing to close over title issues

p_28.title: Special Warranty Deed Limits Title Protection
p_28.description: Seller is conveying title by special warranty deed rather than general warranty deed. A special warranty deed only warrants against defects arising during Seller's ownership period, not against defects from prior owners. This leaves Buyer exposed to claims arising from title defects that originated before Seller acquired the property, with recourse only against the title insurance policy rather than Seller directly.
p_28.problematic_text: Seller shall convey to Buyer fee simple title to the Real Property and Improvements by special warranty deed
p_28.user_recommendation: Request general warranty deed or enhanced title coverage.
p_28.model_instructions: Replace 'special warranty deed' with 'general warranty deed' to provide Buyer with comprehensive title warranties covering defects from all prior ownership periods. Alternatively, if Seller refuses, add language requiring Seller to assign to Buyer any title warranties Seller received from its predecessor in title.

mitigated_by.effect: Title insurance provides alternative protection against covered defects

p_28.title: Permitted Exceptions Definition Circular
p_28.description: The definition of 'Permitted Exceptions' is somewhat circular and relies heavily on deemed approvals from the title review process. Combined with the automatic deemed approval provisions in Section 4B, this could result in Buyer taking title subject to exceptions that were never actually reviewed or consciously approved, merely not timely objected to.
p_28.problematic_text: subject to those title exceptions permitted herein, or as may be approved by Buyer in writing (the "Permitted Exceptions")
p_28.user_recommendation: Define Permitted Exceptions with specific enumerated items.
p_28.model_instructions: Add a new defined term or exhibit that specifically enumerates the categories of Permitted Exceptions (e.g., real property taxes not yet due, utility easements of record, zoning ordinances) rather than relying on the approval/deemed approval process. Add: 'Permitted Exceptions shall mean only: (a) the specific exceptions listed on Exhibit __ attached hereto, (b) non-delinquent real property taxes and assessments, (c) matters created by or with the written consent of Buyer, and (d) items expressly approved in writing by Buyer during the title review period.'

amplified_by.effect: Automatic deemed approval expands what becomes a Permitted Exception

p_29.title: Endorsements Must Be Agreed During DD Period
p_29.description: The requirement that endorsements be 'requested by Buyer and agreed to by Title Company during the Due Diligence Period' could prevent Buyer from obtaining necessary endorsements discovered after due diligence expires. If title issues are revealed post-due diligence (e.g., through a supplemental report), Buyer may not be able to require additional endorsements to address newly discovered risks.
p_29.problematic_text: together with such endorsements thereto as may be requested by Buyer and agreed to by Title Company during the Due Diligence Period
p_29.user_recommendation: Allow endorsement requests through closing date.
p_29.model_instructions: Replace 'during the Due Diligence Period' with 'at any time prior to Closing' to preserve Buyer's ability to request additional endorsements as new title matters are discovered through supplemental reports or other means. Add: 'Buyer shall have the right to request additional endorsements at any time prior to Closing, and Seller shall cooperate with such requests at no additional cost to Seller.'

amplified_by.effect: Combined with no closing extension, limits Buyer's ability to address late-discovered title issues

p_29.title: Title Insurance Limited to Purchase Price
p_29.description: Title insurance coverage is limited to the Purchase Price amount. If Buyer is making significant improvements or the property appreciates substantially, this coverage may become inadequate. Additionally, Purchase Price may not reflect true market value if Buyer negotiated a favorable deal.
p_29.problematic_text: insuring Buyer in the amount of the Purchase Price
p_29.user_recommendation: Consider requesting coverage at appraised or intended use value.
p_29.model_instructions: Add language permitting increased coverage: 'insuring Buyer in an amount equal to the greater of (a) the Purchase Price, or (b) such higher amount as Buyer may elect (with Buyer paying any additional premium for coverage exceeding the Purchase Price).'

p_31.title: Due Diligence Deadline Left Blank
p_31.description: The due diligence period end date is left blank ('on or before 5 p.m. Pacific time on ____________________'). This is a critical term that, if not properly completed, creates ambiguity about when Buyer's inspection rights terminate and when the deposit may become non-refundable. This could lead to disputes about whether Buyer timely exercised termination rights.
p_31.problematic_text: on or before 5 p.m. Pacific time on ____________________
p_31.user_recommendation: Insert specific date; ensure adequate time for inspections.
p_31.model_instructions: ALERT: This blank MUST be completed before execution. Recommend inserting a specific calendar date that provides Buyer at least 30-45 days from the Effective Date for comprehensive due diligence including environmental assessments, property condition reports, lease audits, and financial review. Consider adding: 'which date shall be no earlier than forty-five (45) days following the Effective Date.'

amplified_by.effect: Missing deadline could affect when Additional Deposit becomes due/at risk
Ambiguity affects deposit refund rights

p_31.title: Three Business Days for Document Delivery May Be Insufficient
p_31.description: Seller has only three (3) business days to deliver Due Diligence Documents. While this short timeframe benefits Buyer by getting materials quickly, if Seller fails to timely deliver, there is no automatic extension of the Due Diligence Period. Buyer could be forced to conduct inspections with incomplete information, yet still face the same deadline.
p_31.problematic_text: Within three (3) business days of the Effective Date, Seller shall deliver to Buyer the documents identified on attached Schedule 1
p_31.user_recommendation: Add DD period extension if documents delivered late.
p_31.model_instructions: Add the following sentence after the existing text: 'In the event Seller fails to deliver all Due Diligence Documents within such three (3) business day period, the Due Diligence Period shall be automatically extended by one (1) day for each day of delay in Seller's delivery, and Buyer may elect to terminate this Agreement upon written notice to Seller if such documents are not delivered within ten (10) business days of the Effective Date.'

mitigated_by.effect: Buyer's sole discretion approval right provides termination flexibility

p_31.title: Broad Sole Discretion Termination Right
p_31.description: This is a FAVORABLE provision for Buyer. Buyer has 'sole and absolute discretion' to approve or disapprove all matters pertaining to the property's condition. This provides Buyer maximum flexibility to terminate during due diligence for any reason or no reason, making the deposit refundable during this period. Ensure this right is preserved.
p_31.problematic_text: subject to written satisfaction, approval or waiver by Buyer, in its sole and absolute discretion
p_31.user_recommendation: Preserve this favorable provision; ensure no other terms limit it.
p_31.model_instructions: NO CHANGES NEEDED - This is favorable language for Buyer. However, verify that no other provisions in the Agreement (particularly Section 5C or Section 6) contain language that could be interpreted to limit this sole discretion right or impose objective standards on Buyer's approval decision.

p_32.title: Waiver of Reliance on Due Diligence Materials
p_32.description: This provision disclaims any representation or warranty by Seller regarding the accuracy or completeness of due diligence documents. Buyer is essentially agreeing to conduct its entire investigation based on materials that may be incomplete, inaccurate, or misleading, with no recourse against Seller for deficiencies in those materials. This significantly increases Buyer's risk of making an uninformed purchase decision and eliminates any claim Buyer might have if the materials provided are materially inaccurate.
p_32.problematic_text: Seller is furnishing copies of the Due Diligence Documents for informational purposes only and without representation or warranty as to the accuracy or completeness of such materials
p_32.user_recommendation: Add Seller warranty that materials are complete and accurate to Seller's knowledge.
p_32.model_instructions: Revise to add a knowledge-qualified representation: 'Seller is furnishing copies of the Due Diligence Documents for informational purposes; provided, however, that Seller represents and warrants that, to Seller's Actual Knowledge, (i) the Due Diligence Documents provided to Buyer constitute all material documents in Seller's possession or control relating to the Property, and (ii) Seller has not intentionally withheld any material documents or information from Buyer, except as expressly provided in Section 7 hereof.'

p_32.title: Narrow Carve-Out for Section 7 Representations Only
p_32.description: The exception 'except as expressly provided in Section 7 hereof' limits Buyer's recourse to only those specific representations made in Section 7. If Seller provides materially misleading due diligence materials that are not covered by Section 7 representations, Buyer has no claim. This creates a gap between the information relied upon and the representations protecting that reliance.
p_32.problematic_text: except as expressly provided in Section 7 hereof
p_32.user_recommendation: Expand carve-out to include fraud and intentional misrepresentation.
p_32.model_instructions: Modify the carve-out to read: 'except as expressly provided in Section 7 hereof, and except that the foregoing shall not limit Buyer's remedies in the event of Seller's fraud, intentional misrepresentation, or intentional concealment of material information.'

p_33.title: Nonintrusive Inspection Limitation May Impair Due Diligence
p_33.description: The restriction to 'nonintrusive inspections, tests and studies' may prevent Buyer from conducting Phase II environmental testing, soil borings, or other invasive testing necessary to fully assess the Property's condition. This limitation could leave Buyer unable to discover material defects or environmental contamination before closing.
p_33.user_recommendation: Add right to conduct intrusive testing with Seller's consent, not unreasonably withheld.
p_33.model_instructions: Revise to read: 'nonintrusive inspections, tests and studies as Buyer may elect of the physical condition of the Property; provided, however, that Buyer may conduct intrusive inspections, tests, and studies (including, without limitation, Phase II environmental assessments, soil borings, and geotechnical testing) upon not less than five (5) business days' prior written notice to Seller and subject to Seller's prior written consent, which consent shall not be unreasonably withheld, conditioned, or delayed.'

p_33.title: Seller Accompaniment May Chill Thorough Inspection
p_33.description: Seller's unilateral right to accompany Buyer during all inspections may inhibit frank discussions between Buyer and its consultants, particularly regarding environmental or structural concerns. While facially neutral, this could chill thorough inspection and documentation of Property defects.
p_33.problematic_text: Seller or Seller's designee may accompany Buyer and/or its agents or contractors when exercising Buyer's right of entry
p_33.user_recommendation: Clarify Seller accompaniment shall not interfere with Buyer's inspection activities.
p_33.model_instructions: Add at end of sentence: 'Seller or Seller's designee may accompany Buyer and/or its agents or contractors when exercising Buyer's right of entry under this Section 5.2; provided, however, that Seller's presence shall not interfere with or delay Buyer's inspections, and Seller shall make reasonable efforts to accommodate Buyer's inspection schedule.'

p_33.title: Blank Advance Notice Period Creates Uncertainty
p_33.description: The advance notice requirement contains a blank ('____________ (___) business days') that must be negotiated and filled in. An overly long notice period could impair Buyer's ability to efficiently conduct due diligence within the Due Diligence Period, particularly for follow-up inspections.
p_33.problematic_text: at least ____________ (___) business days in advance of such entry
p_33.user_recommendation: Negotiate for 24-48 hours advance notice, not longer.
p_33.model_instructions: Fill in the blank with a short, reasonable period: 'at least one (1) business day in advance of such entry' or at most 'two (2) business days in advance of such entry.' Resist any period longer than 48 hours as it may impair efficient due diligence.

p_34.title: Buyer Bears All Inspection Costs
p_34.description: While standard in commercial transactions, this provision places the entire financial burden of due diligence on Buyer. There is no provision for Seller to bear costs of re-inspection if Seller fails to provide access or if Property conditions change between inspections.
p_34.problematic_text: Buyer shall pay for all inspections, tests and studies ordered by Buyer
p_34.user_recommendation: Consider adding Seller cost responsibility if re-inspection needed due to Seller's acts.
p_34.model_instructions: Add the following sentence: 'Notwithstanding the foregoing, if Buyer is required to conduct any re-inspection of the Property due to Seller's failure to provide timely access, changes to the Property made by Seller after an initial inspection, or inaccuracy in information previously provided by Seller, the reasonable costs of such re-inspection shall be borne by Seller.'

p_35.title: Undefined 'Reasonable Advance Notice' Standard
p_35.description: The requirement for 'reasonable advance notice' is undefined and subjective, potentially allowing Seller to claim insufficient notice and deny access. This conflicts with the specific notice period mentioned in Section 5B and creates ambiguity as to which standard governs.
p_35.problematic_text: Buyer shall give Seller reasonable advance notice of such entry
p_35.user_recommendation: Replace 'reasonable' with specific time period matching Section 5B.
p_35.model_instructions: Revise to read: 'Buyer shall give Seller advance notice of such entry in accordance with Section 5.2 above' to eliminate any ambiguity between this provision and the specific notice period required in the lead-in paragraph of Section 5B.

p_35.title: Minimize Interference Standard is Subjective
p_35.description: The requirement to 'minimize interference with Seller's business on, and Seller's tenants' occupancy of, the Property' is inherently subjective and could be used by Seller to obstruct legitimate inspection activities. What constitutes 'minimized' interference is not defined and could be disputed.
p_35.problematic_text: so as to minimize interference with Seller's business on, and Seller's tenants' occupancy of, the Property
p_35.user_recommendation: Define specific prohibited activities rather than vague 'minimize interference' standard.
p_35.model_instructions: Revise to read: 'so as not to unreasonably interfere with Seller's business on, and Seller's tenants' occupancy of, the Property; provided, however, that Seller acknowledges that some reasonable level of interference is inherent in property inspections and Seller shall not withhold or condition access based on minimal or temporary interference.'

p_36.title: Broad Uncapped Indemnity for Entry and Testing
p_36.description: Buyer provides an unlimited indemnity for 'all costs, expenses, damages, liabilities, liens or claims' arising from entry onto the Property. This indemnity is uncapped, survives closing or termination, and could expose Buyer to substantial liability even for minor inspection-related incidents. The breadth of 'directly related to any entry' is potentially very wide.
p_36.problematic_text: Buyer shall indemnify and hold Seller harmless from and against all costs, expenses, damages, liabilities, liens or claims, including, without limitation, attorneys' fees and court costs, directly related to any entry on the Property
p_36.user_recommendation: Add cap on indemnity and limit to Buyer's negligence or willful misconduct.
p_36.model_instructions: Revise to read: 'Buyer shall indemnify and hold Seller harmless from and against all reasonable, third-party costs, expenses, damages, liabilities, liens or claims, including, without limitation, reasonable attorneys' fees and court costs, to the extent directly caused by the negligence or willful misconduct of Buyer or its agents, employees or contractors in connection with any entry on the Property by Buyer, its agents, employees or contractors in the course of performing inspections, tests and/or inquiries provided for under this Agreement; provided, however, that Buyer's aggregate liability under this indemnity shall not exceed [INSERT CAP - e.g., $500,000 or the amount of the Deposit]...'

p_36.title: Indemnity Survives Indefinitely
p_36.description: The indemnity obligation survives closing or termination without any time limitation. This creates perpetual exposure for Buyer related to pre-closing inspection activities, potentially for years after the transaction closes or terminates.
p_36.problematic_text: The foregoing indemnity shall survive the Closing Date or earlier termination of this Agreement.
p_36.user_recommendation: Add survival period cap (e.g., 12-24 months post-closing).
p_36.model_instructions: Revise to read: 'The foregoing indemnity shall survive the Closing Date or earlier termination of this Agreement for a period of twelve (12) months [or up to twenty-four (24) months if Seller insists], after which Buyer shall have no further liability under this Section 5.2(iii).'

p_36.title: Broad Restoration Obligation Without Standard
p_36.description: Buyer must 'promptly repair any damage' and 'restore the Property to its prior condition.' The standard of 'prior condition' is vague and could be disputed. Additionally, there is no qualification for ordinary wear and tear from inspections or reasonable tolerance for minor cosmetic impacts inherent in property testing.
p_36.problematic_text: Buyer shall also promptly repair any damage done to any portion of the Property in connection with the exercise of its rights under this Section 5.2, and restore the Property to its prior condition
p_36.user_recommendation: Qualify restoration obligation for material damage only, not de minimis impacts.
p_36.model_instructions: Revise to read: 'Buyer shall also promptly repair any material damage done to any portion of the Property in connection with the exercise of its rights under this Section 5.2, and restore the Property to substantially its prior condition; provided, however, that Buyer shall not be responsible for normal wear and tear or minor cosmetic impacts reasonably incident to property inspections.'

p_36.title: Pre-Existing Conditions Carve-Out May Be Narrowly Construed
p_36.description: While the carve-out for pre-existing conditions is favorable to Buyer, the parenthetical excludes only 'non-negligent aggravation' of pre-existing conditions. If Buyer's testing is deemed to have negligently aggravated a pre-existing condition (even if the condition was unknown and would have required testing to discover), Buyer could be liable. The distinction between discovery and aggravation may be difficult to prove.
p_36.problematic_text: but not including any claims resulting from the discovery or disclosure of pre-existing physical or environmental conditions or the non-negligent aggravation of pre-existing physical or environmental conditions
p_36.user_recommendation: Broaden carve-out to include reasonable aggravation during standard testing protocols.
p_36.model_instructions: Revise the parenthetical to read: '(but not including any claims resulting from (a) the discovery or disclosure of pre-existing physical or environmental conditions, (b) the aggravation of pre-existing physical or environmental conditions except to the extent caused by Buyer's gross negligence or willful misconduct, or (c) any claims by Seller or any third party relating to conditions that existed prior to Buyer's entry, regardless of whether such conditions were aggravated by Buyer's inspection activities conducted in accordance with industry-standard testing protocols on, in, under or about the Property).'

p_37.title: Seller Discretion Over Insurance Requirements
p_37.description: While the clause establishes a minimum $2,000,000 CGL requirement, additional insurance requirements are subject to Seller's 'reasonably satisfactory' approval. This subjective standard could allow Seller to demand excessive or unusual coverage, potentially delaying or complicating Buyer's due diligence access. There is no cap on what Seller can request beyond the stated minimum, and no mechanism for resolving disputes over reasonableness.
p_37.problematic_text: with insurance limits and coverage reasonably satisfactory to Seller
p_37.user_recommendation: Define specific insurance requirements rather than leaving to Seller's discretion.
p_37.model_instructions: Replace the subjective 'reasonably satisfactory to Seller' language with objective insurance requirements. Suggest replacing with: 'with the following insurance coverage: (a) commercial general liability insurance with limits of at least $2,000,000 per occurrence and $4,000,000 aggregate; (b) workers' compensation insurance as required by law; and (c) automobile liability insurance with limits of at least $1,000,000 combined single limit, if applicable.' Alternatively, add language stating: 'provided that Seller's requirements shall not exceed customary insurance requirements for similar property inspections in the market where the Property is located.'

p_37.title: Insurance Requirement May Delay Property Access
p_37.description: Buyer must provide insurance certificates before entry, which is standard but could create timing issues if Buyer needs to quickly arrange inspections during a limited due diligence period. Combined with the subjective 'reasonably satisfactory' standard, this could effectively shorten the Due Diligence Period.
p_37.problematic_text: Before Buyer or any of its consultants or agents enter onto the Property to exercise rights under this Section 5, Buyer shall provide Seller with a certificate of insurance
p_37.user_recommendation: Ensure due diligence period tolling if Seller delays approval of insurance.
p_37.model_instructions: Add a protective provision such as: 'Seller shall respond to Buyer's submitted certificate of insurance within two (2) business days of receipt. If Seller fails to respond within such period, the insurance shall be deemed acceptable. If Seller reasonably objects to the insurance, Buyer shall have two (2) business days to provide revised coverage. The Due Diligence Period shall be extended day-for-day for any delays caused by Seller's failure to timely respond or unreasonable objections to insurance coverage that complies with the minimum requirements set forth herein.'

p_38.title: Unlimited Survival of Inspection Obligations
p_38.description: This provision causes Buyer's indemnification obligations and other onerous terms from Section 5.2 (including repair obligations, indemnification for liens and claims, insurance requirements) to survive termination without any time limitation. This creates perpetual exposure for Buyer even if the deal terminates during due diligence. Buyer could face claims years after walking away from the transaction for alleged damage during inspections.
p_38.problematic_text: The terms of this Section 5.2 shall survive termination of this Agreement.
p_38.user_recommendation: Add a specific survival period cap (e.g., 12-18 months post-termination).
p_38.model_instructions: Modify the survival provision to include a reasonable time limitation: 'The terms of this Section 5.2 shall survive termination of this Agreement for a period of twelve (12) months following such termination, provided that any claim for indemnification hereunder must be made by Seller in writing within such twelve (12) month period setting forth in reasonable detail the nature and amount of the claim.' This limits Buyer's exposure to a reasonable period for discovery of any inspection-related damage while preventing perpetual liability.

p_39.title: Silence Deemed Approval with Deposit at Risk
p_39.description: If Buyer fails to deliver a Termination Notice by the end of the Due Diligence Period, Buyer is automatically deemed to have provided an Approval Notice, which causes the Deposit to become nonrefundable. This creates significant risk: if Buyer's team misses the deadline (even due to circumstances beyond control like illness, emergency, or communication failures), Buyer loses the ability to terminate and places the Deposit at risk. This is a 'trap' provision that could result in substantial financial exposure.
p_39.problematic_text: If Buyer fails to deliver the Termination Notice to Seller on or before the expiration of the Due Diligence Period, Buyer shall be deemed to have timely provided an Approval Notice.
p_39.user_recommendation: Require affirmative Approval Notice; silence should result in termination.
p_39.model_instructions: Reverse the default so that failure to act results in termination rather than deemed approval: 'If Buyer fails to deliver an Approval Notice to Seller on or before the expiration of the Due Diligence Period, Buyer shall be deemed to have elected to terminate this Agreement pursuant to this Section 5.3, and the Deposit shall be returned to Buyer.' Alternatively, if Seller requires the deemed approval structure, add protective language: 'Notwithstanding the foregoing, Buyer shall have the right to deliver a Termination Notice within three (3) business days following the expiration of the Due Diligence Period if Buyer can demonstrate that circumstances beyond Buyer's reasonable control prevented timely delivery of the Termination Notice.'

p_39.title: Mandatory Turnover of Due Diligence Reports
p_39.description: Upon termination for any reason other than Seller's default, Buyer must deliver copies of all third-party reports to Seller upon request. This gives Seller free access to potentially valuable studies, reports, and test results that Buyer paid for. These materials may identify defects Seller can remedy before remarketing the property, or may be used against Buyer in any disputes. There is no reciprocal obligation for Seller to compensate Buyer for these materials.
p_39.problematic_text: On termination of this Agreement for any reason other than Seller's default, upon Seller's written request, Buyer shall deliver to Seller copies of all third party reports, studies and test results regarding the Property procured or obtained by Buyer.
p_39.user_recommendation: Negotiate reimbursement for report costs or make delivery optional.
p_39.model_instructions: Modify to make document delivery conditional on reimbursement: 'On termination of this Agreement for any reason other than Seller's default, upon Seller's written request and provided that Seller reimburses Buyer for Buyer's actual out-of-pocket costs incurred in obtaining such materials, Buyer shall deliver to Seller copies of all third party reports, studies and test results regarding the Property procured or obtained by Buyer. Any such reports shall be delivered without representation or warranty of any kind by Buyer, and Buyer shall have no liability arising from Seller's use of or reliance upon such reports.' Alternatively, add: 'Buyer may redact from such reports any proprietary information, attorney-client privileged communications, or Buyer-specific financial analyses.'

p_39.title: Vague Timing for Notice Delivery
p_39.description: The clause requires Buyer to 'promptly' notify Seller of both termination and approval decisions, but does not define what 'promptly' means. While the hard deadline is the end of the Due Diligence Period, the 'promptly' language could be used by Seller to argue Buyer breached by not delivering notice earlier, potentially affecting Buyer's rights or creating disputes about whether proper notice was given.
p_39.problematic_text: then Buyer shall promptly notify Seller of such determination in writing
p_39.user_recommendation: Remove 'promptly' requirement or define specific timeframe.
p_39.model_instructions: Clarify the timing by replacing 'promptly' with specific language: 'then Buyer shall notify Seller of such determination in writing at any time on or before the expiration of the Due Diligence Period' or 'then Buyer may, at any time on or before 5:00 p.m. Pacific Time on the last day of the Due Diligence Period, notify Seller of such determination in writing.' This removes ambiguity about whether Buyer's notice was sufficiently timely.

p_40.title: Conditions Subject to Waiver Framework
p_40.description: This provision establishes that Buyer's closing conditions are subject to 'satisfaction or waiver by Buyer.' While this preserves Buyer's flexibility to waive conditions, it also means Buyer cannot refuse to close by claiming a condition failed if Buyer could have waived it. This framework should be reviewed in conjunction with Section 5.6 (waiver provisions) to understand the full scope of Buyer's discretion and any limitations.
p_40.problematic_text: subject to the satisfaction or waiver by Buyer of the following conditions
p_40.user_recommendation: Ensure waiver provisions don't limit Buyer's right to enforce conditions.
p_40.model_instructions: Cross-reference with Section 5.6 (p_49) to ensure consistency. Consider adding clarifying language: 'Buyer's right to waive any condition shall be in Buyer's sole discretion, and Buyer's election not to waive a failed condition shall not constitute a default by Buyer under this Agreement.' This protects Buyer from arguments that it should have waived a condition rather than terminating.

p_41.title: Closing Condition Tied to Section 11.3 Deliveries
p_41.description: This condition requires Seller to deliver items listed in Section 11.3, but the language 'as provided in this Agreement' could be interpreted to mean that if Section 11.3 provides any flexibility on timing or manner of delivery, Seller has satisfied this condition even with delayed or incomplete delivery. The condition should be absolute rather than qualified by 'as provided in this Agreement.'
p_41.user_recommendation: Strengthen condition to require complete delivery before Closing.
p_41.model_instructions: Revise to make the condition more protective: 'Seller shall have delivered all items described in Section 11.3 hereof to Escrow Holder (or directly to Buyer where specified) at least one (1) business day prior to the Closing Date, in form and substance reasonably satisfactory to Buyer.' This ensures Buyer has adequate time to review deliverables and establishes a clear standard for compliance.

p_42.title: Irrevocable Commitment Standard Undefined
p_42.description: The condition requires the Title Company to be 'irrevocably committed' to issue the Title Policy, but this standard is ambiguous. Title companies typically issue commitments with standard exceptions and requirements. It's unclear what constitutes an 'irrevocable' commitment versus a standard commitment, and whether any conditions or requirements in the commitment would defeat this standard. This ambiguity could lead to disputes about whether this condition has been satisfied or give Seller an argument that the condition is not met even when a standard commitment is available.
p_42.problematic_text: irrevocably committed to issue the Title Policy
p_42.user_recommendation: Define what constitutes 'irrevocably committed' or use standard 'prepared to issue' language.
p_42.model_instructions: Revise the clause to provide a clearer standard. Replace 'irrevocably committed to issue' with 'prepared and unconditionally committed to issue, subject only to payment of the applicable premium and satisfaction of standard closing requirements.' Alternatively, add a definition clarifying that 'irrevocably committed' means the Title Company has issued a commitment without conditions other than (i) delivery of closing documents in the form required by this Agreement, (ii) payment of the title premium, and (iii) recording of the Deed.

p_42.title: Condition Depends on Section 4 Requirements
p_42.description: This condition precedent incorporates the requirements of Section 4 by reference. Buyer should ensure that Section 4 adequately addresses the form of Title Policy required, including extended coverage, deletion of standard exceptions (survey, mechanics' liens, parties in possession), and any required endorsements. If Section 4 requirements are insufficient, this condition precedent may be satisfied with a Title Policy that doesn't fully protect Buyer.
p_42.user_recommendation: Verify Section 4 specifies all required title policy coverage and endorsements.
p_42.model_instructions: Review Section 4 (paragraphs p_26 through p_29) to confirm the Title Policy requirements are adequate for Buyer's protection. Consider adding specific requirements to this condition if Section 4 is lacking, such as: 'Title Company shall be irrevocably committed to issue the Title Policy pursuant to Section 4 hereof, including without limitation deletion of the standard printed exceptions for (a) parties in possession, (b) mechanics' liens, (c) matters that would be disclosed by a current and accurate survey, and (d) taxes and assessments not yet due and payable, and with such endorsements as Buyer may reasonably require.'

p_43.title: Material Qualifier Weakens Rep Bring-Down
p_43.description: The condition requires representations to be true only 'in all material respects,' which significantly weakens Buyer's protection. This means Seller's representations could be inaccurate in ways that don't meet the 'material' threshold, yet Buyer would still be required to close. Combined with the existing 'Seller's Actual Knowledge' qualifiers on many representations in Section 7A, this creates a double-layered shield for Seller. Immaterial misrepresentations could still cause Buyer financial harm post-closing without triggering the condition precedent.
p_43.user_recommendation: Delete 'in all material respects' or negotiate a specific dollar threshold for materiality.
p_43.model_instructions: Remove the 'in all material respects' qualifier to strengthen the bring-down condition. The revised language should read: 'Each representation and warranty made by Seller in this Agreement shall be true, accurate and complete as of the Closing Date.' Alternatively, if Seller insists on a materiality qualifier, negotiate for a defined threshold: 'Each representation and warranty made by Seller in this Agreement shall be true, accurate and complete as of the Closing Date, except for inaccuracies that, individually or in the aggregate, would not reasonably be expected to result in losses to Buyer exceeding $[X].' The threshold should be coordinated with any indemnification basket in the Agreement.

p_43.title: No Mechanism to Verify Reps at Closing
