p_43.description: While this condition requires representations to be true at Closing, the Agreement does not appear to require Seller to deliver a bring-down certificate confirming the continued accuracy of representations as of Closing. Without a closing deliverable confirming representation accuracy, Buyer has limited ability to verify compliance with this condition precedent and may have difficulty establishing a breach if issues arise post-closing.
p_43.user_recommendation: Require Seller to deliver a bring-down certificate at Closing confirming rep accuracy.
p_43.model_instructions: Add to Seller's closing deliverables in Section 11.3 (p_81) a requirement for a bring-down certificate. Insert the following as a new subsection: '(xii) A certificate executed by Seller confirming that each representation and warranty made by Seller in this Agreement is true, accurate and complete as of the Closing Date (or if any representation or warranty is not true, accurate and complete, specifying the nature and extent of such inaccuracy).' Also consider adding to this condition: 'and Seller shall have delivered the certificate required by Section 11.3(xii) confirming same.'

p_44.title: Minimum Tenant Estoppels Not Defined
p_44.description: The condition references 'Minimum Tenant Estoppels' but this term does not appear to be defined in the document map. Without a clear definition specifying which tenants must provide estoppels (e.g., by square footage threshold, rent amount, or specific named tenants), Buyer has uncertain protection. Seller could argue that estoppels from minor tenants satisfy this condition even if major tenants refuse or provide adverse estoppels. This is a critical gap for multi-tenant properties where estoppels from anchor or major tenants are essential.
p_44.user_recommendation: Define 'Minimum Tenant Estoppels' to specify required tenants by name, percentage, or threshold.
p_44.model_instructions: Add a definition for 'Minimum Tenant Estoppels' either in this section or in a definitions section. Suggested language: '"Minimum Tenant Estoppels" means estoppel certificates from (a) tenants occupying at least [75]% of the leased square footage of the Property, and (b) each tenant leasing more than [10,000] square feet at the Property, which estoppels shall be dated no earlier than [30] days prior to the Closing Date.' Alternatively, if specific anchor tenants are critical: '"Minimum Tenant Estoppels" means estoppel certificates from (a) [list specific tenant names], and (b) tenants occupying at least [X]% of the remaining leased square footage.' Consider also adding a provision addressing what happens if estoppels reveal adverse information.

p_44.title: Substantially In Form Standard May Allow Deviations
p_44.description: The 'substantially in the form' language allows estoppels to deviate from Exhibit H. Tenants frequently modify requested estoppel forms, sometimes inserting claims, qualifications, or adverse information. If deviations are permitted as long as estoppels are 'substantially' in the required form, Buyer may be required to accept estoppels containing adverse information or lacking key confirmations. There is no standard for what deviations are acceptable.
p_44.problematic_text: substantially in the form of Exhibit H
p_44.user_recommendation: Add language requiring estoppels not reveal adverse matters or materially deviate from Exhibit H.
p_44.model_instructions: Strengthen the estoppel requirement by adding qualifications. Revise to: 'Seller shall have delivered the Minimum Tenant Estoppels, each substantially in the form of Exhibit H attached hereto (with such modifications as are customarily required by tenants, but without any material modifications adverse to Buyer), and which estoppels shall not (a) disclose any default by landlord under any Lease, (b) disclose any offset, defense, or claim against landlord, (c) disclose any prepayment of rent for more than one month, (d) reflect any terms materially inconsistent with the Lease delivered to Buyer, or (e) contain any other information that would reasonably be expected to have a material adverse effect on the Property or Buyer's ownership thereof.'

p_44.title: Estoppel Condition is Bracketed/Optional
p_44.description: The entire estoppel condition precedent is in brackets, indicating it is optional or subject to negotiation. Buyer should ensure this provision is included in the final Agreement, particularly for multi-tenant properties where estoppel verification is critical to confirming lease terms, rental obligations, security deposits, and the absence of landlord defaults.
p_44.problematic_text: [Seller shall have delivered the Minimum Tenant Estoppels
p_44.user_recommendation: Remove brackets to make estoppel delivery a firm condition precedent.
p_44.model_instructions: Remove the brackets from this provision to make the estoppel delivery requirement a firm condition precedent to Buyer's obligation to close. The provision should read without brackets: 'Seller shall have delivered the Minimum Tenant Estoppels, each substantially in the form of Exhibit H attached hereto.' Also ensure Section 8D (p_71) regarding Seller's covenant to obtain estoppels is also not bracketed and coordinates with this condition.

p_45.title: Seller Conditions May Create Closing Uncertainty
p_45.description: This provision establishes Seller's conditions precedent to closing. While some conditions favoring Seller are standard, Buyer should carefully review Sections 5E(i) through 5E(iii) to ensure they don't create opportunities for Seller to avoid closing on pretextual grounds. The 'all other conditions to Seller's obligations' reference also incorporates unstated conditions that may be scattered throughout the Agreement, creating uncertainty about what Seller can use to refuse closing.
p_45.problematic_text: In addition to all other conditions to Seller's obligations in this Agreement
p_45.user_recommendation: Identify and list all Seller conditions in one place to avoid hidden closing obstacles.
p_45.model_instructions: Consider revising to limit Seller's conditions precedent to those expressly stated in Section 5E. The provision could be modified to: 'Seller and Buyer agree that Seller's obligation to proceed with the Closing is subject solely to the satisfaction or waiver by Seller of the following conditions at or prior to the Closing:' This eliminates the catch-all reference to 'all other conditions' that may be embedded elsewhere in the Agreement. Alternatively, add: 'For the avoidance of doubt, the conditions set forth in this Section 5E constitute the exclusive conditions precedent to Seller's obligation to close, and no other provision of this Agreement shall be construed as creating additional conditions precedent to Seller's obligations.'

p_45.title: Seller May Waive Its Own Conditions
p_45.description: The provision allows Seller to waive its conditions precedent at Seller's discretion. While this is standard, Buyer should confirm that Seller cannot use the failure of its own waivable conditions as a basis for termination or to claim Buyer default. The interplay between this provision and Section 5F (p_49) regarding waiver of conditions should be reviewed.
p_45.user_recommendation: Confirm Seller cannot terminate based on its own unsatisfied but waivable conditions.
p_45.model_instructions: Add clarifying language to ensure Seller cannot use its own conditions as a pretext to avoid closing: 'Seller and Buyer agree that Seller's obligation to proceed with the Closing is subject to the satisfaction or waiver by Seller of the following conditions at or prior to the Closing; provided, however, that if any such condition is not satisfied and Seller elects not to waive such condition, Seller's sole remedy shall be to terminate this Agreement in accordance with Section 6, and Seller shall not be entitled to claim Buyer is in default or pursue any remedies against Buyer as a result of such non-satisfaction.'

p_46.title: No Deadline Specified for Closing Payment Deposit
p_46.description: While this condition requires Buyer to deposit the Closing Payment into escrow, it does not specify a deadline other than before Closing. Section 3C (p_20) should specify the timing, but if it merely says 'at Closing,' there could be a gap where Seller claims the condition is not satisfied because funds weren't deposited sufficiently in advance. This creates potential for Seller to claim Buyer default on timing grounds.
p_46.problematic_text: Buyer shall have deposited the Closing Payment into escrow
p_46.user_recommendation: Specify that Closing Payment must be deposited by a time certain before scheduled Closing.
p_46.model_instructions: Coordinate this provision with Section 3C (p_20) to ensure timing is clear and reasonable. Consider revising to: 'Buyer shall have deposited the Closing Payment into escrow no later than 12:00 p.m. Pacific Time on the business day immediately preceding the Closing Date (or such later time as may be required by Escrow Holder to process the wire transfer for same-day Closing).' This provides a clear deadline while allowing for same-day closing mechanics if wire transfers can be processed in time.

p_47.title: Delivery Obligations Undefined Here
p_47.description: This clause conditions Seller's obligation to close on Buyer's delivery of items described in Section 11.4. Without reviewing Section 11.4 directly in this clause, Buyer cannot immediately assess the full scope of its delivery obligations, which could include documents or items that are difficult or time-consuming to obtain. If Buyer fails to deliver any required item, Seller could refuse to close without liability.
p_47.problematic_text: those items described in Section 11.4 hereof
p_47.user_recommendation: Review Section 11.4 deliverables; ensure all are within Buyer's control.
p_47.model_instructions: Review Section 11.4 (referenced in para p_93 through p_100) to identify all Buyer delivery obligations. Consider whether any items require third-party cooperation or could cause closing delay. If any items are outside Buyer's direct control, negotiate to add qualifiers such as 'to the extent reasonably obtainable' or specify that failure to deliver due to third-party non-cooperation shall not constitute a failure of condition.

p_48.title: Bring-Down May Block Closing
p_48.description: This provision requires that Buyer's representations and warranties be true as of Closing. While standard, this creates a bring-down condition that could allow Seller to refuse to close if any of Buyer's representations become inaccurate—even due to circumstances beyond Buyer's control. The 'material respects' qualifier provides some protection, but Buyer should ensure its representations are limited and accurate.
p_48.problematic_text: Each representation and warranty made by Buyer in this Agreement shall be true, accurate and complete in all material respects of as of the Closing Date
p_48.user_recommendation: Review Buyer's reps in Section 7B; ensure they are narrow and accurate.
p_48.model_instructions: Cross-reference Section 7B (para p_62 through p_64) to review the scope of Buyer's representations and warranties. Ensure representations are limited to matters within Buyer's knowledge and control. Consider whether any representations could become inaccurate between signing and closing. If representations are broad, negotiate to add knowledge qualifiers or limit to matters 'as of the Effective Date' rather than bringing down to Closing.

p_48.title: Typographical Error in Text
p_48.description: The phrase 'in all material respects of as of the Closing Date' contains a typographical error ('of as of' should be 'as of'). While likely a scrivener's error, ambiguous language could potentially be exploited in a dispute.
p_48.problematic_text: in all material respects of as of the Closing Date
p_48.user_recommendation: Correct to 'in all material respects as of the Closing Date'.
p_48.model_instructions: Correct the typographical error by changing 'in all material respects of as of the Closing Date' to 'in all material respects as of the Closing Date'. This is a minor scrivener's error but should be corrected to avoid any ambiguity.

p_49.title: Termination Right May Be Waived Inadvertently
p_49.description: While the clause clarifies that conditions in Sections 5.1-5.4 are for Buyer's exclusive benefit, the termination right requires 'written notice' without specifying a deadline or cure period. This could create uncertainty about when the right lapses. Additionally, a party proceeding toward closing despite knowledge of an unsatisfied condition might be deemed to have waived the condition.
p_49.problematic_text: this Agreement may be terminated by the party benefiting from such condition by written notice to the other party
p_49.user_recommendation: Add deadline for termination notice; clarify waiver standards.
p_49.model_instructions: Consider adding language that specifies: (1) a deadline by which the termination notice must be delivered (e.g., 'prior to the Closing Date'), (2) that proceeding to closing with knowledge of an unsatisfied condition shall not constitute a waiver unless explicitly waived in writing, and (3) that the terminating party shall not be required to provide any cure period to the other party. Suggested addition: 'Such termination right must be exercised prior to the Closing Date and shall not be deemed waived by any action short of an express written waiver.'

p_49.title: Section Reference Appears Incomplete
p_49.description: The clause references 'Sections 5.1 through 5.4' but the document structure shows these are Sections 5A through 5D. Additionally, there is no space between '5.4' and 'are' in the text ('5.4are'), suggesting a formatting or typographical issue. This could create ambiguity about which conditions are for Buyer's benefit.
p_49.user_recommendation: Correct section references to match document numbering convention.
p_49.model_instructions: Review the actual section numbering convention used in the Agreement. If sections are labeled 5A, 5B, 5C, 5D rather than 5.1, 5.2, 5.3, 5.4, correct the cross-references accordingly. Also add the missing space: 'Sections 5.1 through 5.4 are' or 'Sections 5A through 5D are' as appropriate. Verify that all conditions intended for Buyer's benefit are captured in the reference.

p_50.title: Deposit Treatment Unclear on Termination
p_50.description: This termination provision addresses return of documents and sharing of escrow cancellation fees, but critically does not address the return of Buyer's Deposit upon termination. The clause explicitly excludes 'Section 13' scenarios (which addresses defaults), but does not affirmatively state that Buyer's Deposit is returned in non-default termination scenarios. This omission could be exploited by Seller to argue the Deposit is not automatically returned.
p_50.problematic_text: If this Agreement is terminated for any reason other than as described in Section 13
p_50.user_recommendation: Add explicit language requiring return of Deposit upon non-default termination.
p_50.model_instructions: Add explicit language addressing Deposit disposition upon termination. Suggested revision: 'If this Agreement is terminated for any reason other than as described in Section 13: (a) all documents deposited with the Escrow Holder by Buyer shall be returned to Buyer, all documents deposited with Escrow Holder by Seller shall be returned to Seller, and all documents delivered to Buyer by Seller shall be returned to Seller; (a-1) the Deposit shall be returned to Buyer; (b) no Broker's Fee shall be payable to Broker; and (c) the parties shall equally share any cancellation fee of the Escrow Holder.' Cross-reference Section 13 (p_116) to ensure no conflict with liquidated damages provisions.

p_50.title: Buyer Must Return Due Diligence Documents
p_50.description: Upon termination, Buyer must return 'all documents delivered to Buyer by Seller.' This could include voluminous due diligence materials that Buyer may have copied, analyzed, or relied upon in making decisions about other properties. The obligation to return (rather than destroy) could be burdensome and the scope is unclear regarding copies.
p_50.problematic_text: all documents delivered to Buyer by Seller shall be returned to Seller
p_50.user_recommendation: Clarify whether destruction is permitted; address copies and digital files.
p_50.model_instructions: Consider revising to: 'all documents delivered to Buyer by Seller shall, at Seller's election, be either returned to Seller or destroyed by Buyer (with written certification of destruction provided to Seller upon request).' Also clarify treatment of copies: 'Buyer shall return or destroy all copies of such documents, whether in physical or electronic form, except that Buyer may retain one copy in its legal files solely for purposes of establishing compliance with this Agreement.'

p_50.title: Shared Cancellation Fee Even If Seller Caused Termination
p_50.description: The clause requires parties to 'equally share any cancellation fee of the Escrow Holder' regardless of which party caused the termination. This means Buyer pays half the cancellation fee even if Seller breached a representation or failed to satisfy a condition, as long as the termination is not under Section 13 (default).
p_50.problematic_text: the parties shall equally share any cancellation fee of the Escrow Holder
p_50.user_recommendation: Allocate cancellation fee to party causing termination.
p_50.model_instructions: Revise cost allocation to reflect fault: 'the cancellation fee of the Escrow Holder shall be paid by the party whose action or inaction caused the termination, or if neither party is at fault (e.g., failure of financing contingency or mutual agreement to terminate), the parties shall equally share any cancellation fee of the Escrow Holder.'

p_52.title: Representations Limited by Knowledge Qualifiers
p_52.description: This introductory clause to Seller's representations does not itself contain risk, but the substantive representations that follow (Sections 7A(i) through 7A(vi)) are heavily qualified by 'Seller's Actual Knowledge' standards. Buyer should be aware that the following representations may be significantly limited and should review the definition of 'Seller's Actual Knowledge' carefully.
p_52.problematic_text: Seller represents and warrants to Buyer as follows
p_52.user_recommendation: Review knowledge qualifiers and consider expanding scope of unqualified reps.
p_52.model_instructions: This is an introductory clause. The substantive risks are in the following subsections (p_53 through p_61). Key concerns to flag for negotiation: (1) Definition of 'Seller's Actual Knowledge' in p_59 limits knowledge to specific individuals without duty of inquiry; (2) Most representations are qualified by knowledge, reducing their protective value; (3) p_60 limits remedies for pre-closing discovered breaches; (4) p_61 eliminates liability for representations that become untrue due to permitted actions. Recommend negotiating for broader unqualified representations or expanding the knowledge definition to include constructive knowledge or a duty of reasonable inquiry.

p_53.title: Unqualified Organization Representation
p_53.description: Unlike other Seller representations that are qualified by 'Seller's Actual Knowledge,' this representation regarding Seller's organization, authorization, and non-violation of contracts/judicial orders is made without any knowledge qualifier. While organization reps are typically unqualified, the inclusion of the broad statement that documents 'do not, and at the time of Closing, will not, violate any provisions of any contract or judicial order' could expose Buyer to risk if Seller unknowingly violates an obscure contractual restriction. If this representation proves false, Buyer may have a claim, but the survival period and any caps on liability will limit Buyer's remedies.
p_53.problematic_text: do not, and at the time of Closing, will not, violate any provisions of any contract or judicial order to which Seller is a party or to which Seller is subject
p_53.user_recommendation: Consider adding 'to Seller's Actual Knowledge' to the non-violation portion.
p_53.model_instructions: Revise the representation to add a knowledge qualifier to the non-violation covenant. Suggested language: 'and, to Seller's Actual Knowledge, do not, and at the time of Closing, will not, violate any provisions of any contract or judicial order to which Seller is a party or to which Seller is subject.' Alternatively, consider whether Buyer actually wants this qualified or prefers the stronger unqualified rep with potential recourse.

p_53.title: No Good Standing Representation
p_53.description: The representation states Seller is 'duly organized and validly existing' but does not include the customary 'in good standing' language. While Seller may be validly existing, it could be administratively dissolved or not in good standing in its state of formation, which could affect its authority to convey property or result in tax liens. This is particularly important if the Property is in a different state than Seller's state of formation.
p_53.problematic_text: duly organized and validly existing under the laws of the State of
p_53.user_recommendation: Add 'and in good standing' after 'validly existing.'
p_53.model_instructions: Revise the representation to include good standing confirmation. Suggested language: 'Seller is a ___________ duly organized, validly existing and in good standing under the laws of the State of ___________.' Also consider adding a requirement that Seller be qualified to do business in the state where the Property is located if different from Seller's state of formation.

p_54.title: Rent Roll Accuracy Limited to Seller's Knowledge
p_54.description: The rent roll representation is qualified by 'Seller's Actual Knowledge' and further limited to 'material respects.' Combined with the narrow definition of 'Seller's Actual Knowledge' in Section 7A(vi) (which typically limits knowledge to specific individuals without duty of inquiry), this provides Buyer with very limited protection if the rent roll contains inaccuracies that Seller's designated representative did not personally know about. Rent roll accuracy is fundamental to the economic deal.
p_54.problematic_text: To Seller's Actual Knowledge, the rent roll identified in the Due Diligence Documents (the "Rent Roll") is true and correct in all material respects
p_54.user_recommendation: Request unqualified rent roll rep or add Seller's duty to investigate.
p_54.model_instructions: Strengthen this representation by either: (1) removing the knowledge qualifier entirely so it reads 'The Rent Roll is true and correct in all material respects as of the Effective Date'; (2) adding a duty of inquiry to the knowledge definition in Section 7A(vi); or (3) requiring Seller to certify the rent roll at Closing with an updated representation. Also consider removing 'in all material respects' to provide full accuracy protection, or at minimum define what constitutes 'material.'

p_54.title: Rent Roll Not Dated or Updated at Closing
p_54.description: The representation references 'the rent roll identified in the Due Diligence Documents' but does not specify a date for the rent roll or require an updated rent roll at Closing. Between the Effective Date and Closing, lease terms may change, tenants may default, or new leases may be signed. Without a bring-down requirement or updated rent roll certification, Buyer could acquire property with materially different rental income than represented.
p_54.problematic_text: the rent roll identified in the Due Diligence Documents (the "Rent Roll")
p_54.user_recommendation: Require updated certified rent roll at Closing.
p_54.model_instructions: Add language requiring an updated rent roll at Closing: 'To Seller's Actual Knowledge, the rent roll identified in the Due Diligence Documents (the "Rent Roll") is true and correct in all material respects as of the Effective Date, and Seller shall deliver to Buyer at Closing an updated Rent Roll certified by Seller to be true and correct in all material respects as of the Closing Date.' Cross-reference Section 11.3 for Seller's closing deliveries to ensure this is captured as a required delivery.

p_55.title: Violation Representation Limited to Effective Date
p_55.description: The representation regarding governmental notices of violations is explicitly limited to 'as of the Effective Date.' This means Seller makes no representation about violations existing or notices received between the Effective Date and Closing. While Seller agrees to forward notices received after the Effective Date, there is no representation that no violations exist at Closing, leaving Buyer exposed to acquiring property with undisclosed code violations or compliance issues that arose after contract signing.
p_55.problematic_text: as of the Effective Date, Seller has received no notice from any governmental authority
p_55.user_recommendation: Extend violation representation through Closing with bring-down.
p_55.model_instructions: Revise to extend the representation through Closing: 'To Seller's Actual Knowledge, as of the Effective Date and continuing through the Closing Date, Seller has received no notice from any governmental authority with jurisdiction over the Property of any current violation by the Property of any laws, ordinances or regulations applicable to the Property, and Seller is in compliance with any such past notices of past violations.' Ensure Section 5.4(iii) bring-down covers this representation.

p_55.title: Limited to Notices Received by Seller
p_55.description: The representation is limited to notices 'Seller has received' from governmental authorities. This does not cover: (1) violations that exist but for which no notice has been issued; (2) notices sent to the Property address rather than Seller's address; (3) notices sent to a property manager or other agent; or (4) violations discoverable through public records. Buyer could acquire property with existing violations that simply haven't resulted in formal notice to Seller.
p_55.problematic_text: Seller has received no notice from any governmental authority
p_55.user_recommendation: Broaden to include violations generally, not just noticed violations.
p_55.model_instructions: Strengthen the representation to cover actual violations: 'To Seller's Actual Knowledge, (a) the Property is in compliance with all applicable laws, ordinances, and regulations, (b) as of the Effective Date, Seller has received no notice from any governmental authority with jurisdiction over the Property of any violation by the Property of any laws, ordinances or regulations applicable to the Property, and (c) Seller is in compliance with any past notices of violations. Seller shall immediately provide Buyer with a copy of any such notices received after the Effective Date.'

p_55.title: Notice Forwarding Without Termination Right
p_55.description: While Seller agrees to 'immediately provide Buyer with a copy of any such notices received after the Effective Date,' the clause does not give Buyer any remedies if a material violation notice is received. There is no right to terminate, no price adjustment mechanism, and no obligation for Seller to cure. Buyer could be stuck acquiring property with newly-discovered material code violations with no recourse other than proceeding to Closing or potentially claiming a breach of the bring-down condition.
p_55.problematic_text: Seller shall immediately provide Buyer with a copy of any such notices received after the Effective Date
p_55.user_recommendation: Add termination right or cure obligation for material violations.
p_55.model_instructions: Add remedies for post-Effective Date violation notices: 'Seller shall immediately provide Buyer with a copy of any such notices received after the Effective Date. If any such notice discloses a violation that would cost in excess of $_____ to cure, Buyer may elect to either (a) terminate this Agreement and receive a return of the Deposit, or (b) proceed to Closing with a credit against the Purchase Price equal to the estimated cost of cure. If Buyer elects option (a), Seller shall have the right, but not the obligation, to cure such violation within ____ days, in which event the Closing Date shall be extended accordingly.'

p_56.title: Litigation Rep Covers All Seller Litigation Not Property
p_56.description: The representation states there is no litigation 'pending or threatened against Seller' rather than being limited to litigation affecting the Property. This is actually overbroad and could inadvertently cause a breach if Seller has unrelated litigation. However, from Buyer's perspective, the opposite problem exists: this representation could be interpreted narrowly to NOT cover litigation against the Property itself if Seller is not named as a defendant (e.g., suits by third parties over title, boundary disputes, etc.). A well-drafted litigation rep should cover both Seller and the Property.
p_56.problematic_text: there is no litigation pending or threatened against Seller
p_56.user_recommendation: Revise to cover litigation against both Seller and the Property.
p_56.model_instructions: Revise for appropriate scope: 'To Seller's Actual Knowledge, there is no litigation, arbitration, or administrative proceeding pending or threatened (a) against Seller that would materially adversely affect Seller's ability to perform its obligations under this Agreement or (b) against or affecting the Property or any portion thereof.' This covers Buyer's legitimate concerns while narrowing Seller's exposure for unrelated corporate litigation.

p_56.title: No Disclosure Schedule for Litigation
p_56.description: Unlike the hazardous materials representation in Section 7A(vi) which references 'Exhibit H' for exceptions, the litigation representation contains no carve-out for disclosed matters. If there is any pending or threatened litigation, Seller cannot make this representation truthfully without a disclosure schedule. Additionally, if litigation arises between signing and Closing, there is no mechanism for supplemental disclosure without breaching the bring-down condition.
p_56.problematic_text: there is no litigation pending or threatened against Seller
p_56.user_recommendation: Add 'except as disclosed on Exhibit ___' and require Seller disclosure.
p_56.model_instructions: Add disclosure mechanism: 'To Seller's Actual Knowledge, except as set forth on Exhibit ___ attached hereto, there is no litigation, arbitration, or administrative proceeding pending or threatened against Seller or affecting the Property.' Also reference Section 7A(vi) procedure for updating disclosures between signing and Closing.

p_57.title: Condemnation Rep Limited to Seller's Actual Knowledge
p_57.description: Condemnation and eminent domain proceedings are matters of public record and published notice. Qualifying this representation by 'Seller's Actual Knowledge' allows Seller to avoid liability even if condemnation proceedings are publicly pending but Seller's designated representative did not personally know about them. Condemnation can dramatically affect property value, and Buyer should have stronger protection.
p_57.problematic_text: To Seller's Actual Knowledge, no condemnation or eminent domain proceedings are pending or threatened against the Property
p_57.user_recommendation: Remove knowledge qualifier or add Seller duty to investigate public records.
p_57.model_instructions: Either remove the knowledge qualifier entirely: 'No condemnation or eminent domain proceedings are pending or threatened against the Property, and Seller has received no notice of any contemplated condemnation or eminent domain proceedings.' Alternatively, add a duty of inquiry: 'To Seller's Actual Knowledge (after reasonable inquiry of the applicable governmental authorities), no condemnation or eminent domain proceedings are pending or threatened against the Property.' Also add post-signing notice requirement similar to Section 7A(iii).

p_57.title: No Post-Signing Condemnation Notice Obligation
p_57.description: Unlike Section 7A(iii) regarding violation notices which requires Seller to 'immediately provide Buyer with a copy of any such notices received after the Effective Date,' the condemnation representation contains no similar obligation. If Seller learns of threatened condemnation between signing and Closing, there is no express duty to notify Buyer. While Section 14 addresses destruction/condemnation occurring before Closing, it is triggered by the event itself, not notice of threatened proceedings.
p_57.problematic_text: no condemnation or eminent domain proceedings are pending or threatened against the Property
p_57.user_recommendation: Add post-signing notice obligation for condemnation threats.
p_57.model_instructions: Add notice and remedy provisions: 'To Seller's Actual Knowledge, no condemnation or eminent domain proceedings are pending or threatened against the Property. Seller shall immediately notify Buyer in writing if Seller receives any notice or otherwise becomes aware of any condemnation or eminent domain proceedings that are pending, threatened, or contemplated against all or any portion of the Property after the Effective Date. Upon receipt of such notice, the provisions of Section 14 shall apply.'

p_58.title: Inconsistent Knowledge Qualifier Standard
p_58.description: This paragraph uses 'to the best of Seller's knowledge' while other sections use 'to Seller's Actual Knowledge.' The phrase 'best of knowledge' could imply a duty to investigate, but this inconsistency creates ambiguity about the applicable standard and could lead to disputes about what Seller was required to know.
p_58.problematic_text: To the best of Seller's knowledge
p_58.user_recommendation: Conform all knowledge qualifiers to use the defined term 'Seller's Actual Knowledge' consistently.
p_58.model_instructions: Replace all instances of 'To the best of Seller's knowledge' in this paragraph with 'To Seller's Actual Knowledge' to ensure consistency with the defined term in Section 7A(vi) (p_59) and avoid any argument that a different standard applies to these representations.

p_58.title: Uncapped Exhibit H Disclosure Carve-Out
p_58.description: The representation regarding tenant concessions is subject to exceptions disclosed on Exhibit H. Buyer should carefully review Exhibit H to ensure it does not contain sweeping exceptions that gut this representation. The carve-out allows Seller to disclose any tenant concessions or allowances without liability.
p_58.problematic_text: except as set forth on Exhibit H hereto
p_58.user_recommendation: Review Exhibit H carefully and negotiate to limit scope of permitted disclosures.
p_58.model_instructions: Buyer's counsel should immediately review Exhibit H to determine what concessions and allowances are being disclosed. Consider adding language that Exhibit H shall not be amended after the Effective Date without Buyer's consent, or that material additions to Exhibit H after Due Diligence shall give Buyer a termination right.

p_58.title: Representation Limited to Existing Leases Only
p_58.description: The representations are limited to 'leases in existence as of the Effective Date,' which could exclude new leases entered into between Effective Date and Closing. Buyer may be exposed to undisclosed concessions or commissions on leases executed after the Effective Date.
p_58.problematic_text: any lease in existence as of the Effective Date
p_58.user_recommendation: Expand representation to cover all leases through Closing Date.
p_58.model_instructions: Modify the representation to read 'any lease in existence as of the Effective Date or entered into prior to Closing in accordance with this Agreement' to ensure Buyer receives the same protections for any new leases Seller may execute during the contract period pursuant to Section 8.

p_58.title: Materiality Qualifier on Lease Copies
p_58.description: The representation that lease copies are 'true, correct and complete in all material respects' allows Seller to have immaterial inaccuracies in the leases provided. While standard, this could allow Seller to omit side letters or amendments that individually appear immaterial but collectively affect lease economics.
p_58.problematic_text: true, correct and complete in all material respects
p_58.user_recommendation: Consider removing 'in all material respects' for more complete lease disclosure.
p_58.model_instructions: Consider removing 'in all material respects' so the representation reads 'true, correct and complete' without qualification. Alternatively, add a representation that all amendments, side letters, and modifications to the leases have been provided to Buyer.

p_59.title: No Duty to Investigate for Knowledge
p_59.description: The definition of 'Seller's Actual Knowledge' is limited to a single named individual's actual knowledge 'without such person undertaking any investigation.' This extremely narrow standard means Seller has no obligation to make any inquiry, and the knowledge of all other Seller personnel, property managers, or agents is excluded. This could allow Seller to claim ignorance of material issues.
p_59.problematic_text: without such person undertaking any investigation
p_59.user_recommendation: Add duty of reasonable inquiry and expand knowledge parties to include property manager.
p_59.model_instructions: Revise to read: 'the actual knowledge of [named individual] and [property manager], after reasonable inquiry of such persons' direct reports and review of the Property files.' This imposes a minimal investigation duty and includes the property manager who typically has day-to-day knowledge of Property operations, tenant issues, and physical condition.

p_59.title: Representations Auto-Modified by Due Diligence Materials
p_59.description: This provision automatically deems Seller's representations modified to conform to any inconsistent information in the Due Diligence Materials. This is extremely Seller-favorable because it shifts the burden to Buyer to identify all inconsistencies, effectively negating representations if contrary information is buried anywhere in the due diligence documents.
p_59.problematic_text: such representations and warranties shall be deemed modified to the extent necessary to eliminate such inconsistency and to conform such representations and warranties to such Due Diligence Materials
p_59.user_recommendation: Delete auto-modification clause or limit to express written disclosures on a schedule.
p_59.model_instructions: Delete this sentence entirely. If Seller insists on some protection, replace with: 'In the event of any inconsistency between the representations and warranties and information expressly disclosed in a schedule attached to this Agreement, the disclosure on such schedule shall control.' This limits the modification to scheduled disclosures rather than anything buried in a document room.

p_59.title: Buyer Covenant Not to Sue Knowledge Individuals
p_59.description: Buyer covenants not to bring any action against the named knowledge individuals personally. While it is reasonable to protect employees from personal liability, this language is broad ('any action of any kind') and could be read to prevent Buyer from even deposing these individuals in litigation against Seller.
p_59.problematic_text: Buyer covenants that it will bring no action of any kind against any such individuals related to or arising out of the representations and warranties
p_59.user_recommendation: Clarify that covenant only bars claims for personal liability, not discovery.
p_59.model_instructions: Revise to read: 'Buyer covenants that it will bring no action seeking personal monetary liability against any such individuals related to or arising out of the representations and warranties set forth in Section 7.1 of this Agreement, provided that this covenant shall not limit Buyer's right to seek discovery from such individuals in any action against Seller.'

p_60.title: Broad Pre-Closing Waiver of Representation Claims
p_60.description: If Buyer closes with knowledge of a breach, Buyer waives all remedies including rescission. This is a significant risk because 'knowledge' is broadly defined to include anything in the 'Property Information' that is inconsistent with a representation—meaning Buyer could be deemed to know of issues buried in documents it may not have fully reviewed.
p_60.problematic_text: Buyer hereby expressly waives, relinquishes and releases any right or remedy available to it at law, in equity or under this Agreement to make a claim against Seller for damages that Buyer may incur, or to rescind this Agreement
p_60.user_recommendation: Delete waiver or limit to matters expressly disclosed in writing by Seller.
p_60.model_instructions: Revise this provision to read: 'In the event the Closing occurs and Buyer had actual knowledge (as opposed to constructive or deemed knowledge) that a representation or warranty was materially untrue based on express written disclosure by Seller specifically identifying the representation affected, Buyer shall be deemed to have waived its claim with respect to such specifically disclosed matter only.' This limits the waiver to matters Seller expressly brings to Buyer's attention.

p_60.title: Deemed Knowledge from Property Information
p_60.description: Buyer is 'deemed to have known' of representation breaches if any 'Property Information' contains inconsistent information. This constructive knowledge standard is extremely broad and could trap Buyer if adverse information is buried in voluminous due diligence materials that Buyer did not specifically review.
p_60.problematic_text: Buyer shall be 'deemed to have known' that a representation or warranty was untrue, inaccurate or incorrect at the time of the Closing if any Property Information furnished or made available to or otherwise obtained by Buyer contains express information which is inconsistent with such representation or warranty
p_60.user_recommendation: Delete deemed knowledge provision or limit to information in specifically identified documents.
p_60.model_instructions: Delete this sentence. Alternatively, revise to: 'Buyer shall be deemed to have known that a representation or warranty was untrue if Seller delivers to Buyer, prior to Closing, a written notice specifically identifying the representation or warranty and the inconsistent facts.' This requires Seller to affirmatively bring issues to Buyer's attention rather than relying on buried disclosures.

p_60.title: $50,000 Aggregate Deductible on Claims
p_60.description: Buyer cannot make claims for representation breaches unless aggregate damages exceed $50,000. While baskets are market, this provision operates as a true deductible (Buyer cannot recover the first $50,000) rather than a threshold (where once exceeded, Buyer recovers from dollar one). The aggregate nature means multiple smaller issues could individually fall below the threshold.
p_60.problematic_text: Buyer's damages as a result of such representations or warranties being untrue, inaccurate or incorrect are, in the aggregate, less than $50,000
p_60.user_recommendation: Negotiate for threshold (not deductible) or lower amount; clarify multiple claims aggregate.
p_60.model_instructions: Revise to read: '(2) Buyer's damages as a result of such representations or warranties being untrue, inaccurate or incorrect are, in the aggregate, less than $25,000; provided that once Buyer's aggregate damages exceed $25,000, Buyer may recover all damages from dollar one.' This converts the deductible to a threshold and reduces the amount.

p_61.title: Blank Aggregate Liability Cap
p_61.description: The aggregate liability cap is left blank ($_________). This is a critical negotiating point that must be resolved. If the cap is set too low relative to the purchase price, Buyer's remedies for material breaches could be severely limited. Typical caps range from 1-3% of purchase price for non-fundamental representations.
p_61.problematic_text: shall not exceed $___________, in the aggregate
p_61.user_recommendation: Negotiate cap at minimum 3-5% of Purchase Price; exclude fraud and intentional misconduct.
p_61.model_instructions: Fill in the blank with an appropriate percentage of the Purchase Price (suggest 3-5% minimum). Add exclusions: 'provided that this limitation shall not apply to (a) claims arising from Seller's fraud or intentional misconduct, (b) breaches of Seller's covenants under Section 8, (c) Seller's indemnification obligations under Section 5.2, or (d) claims covered by the Deed warranties.' This ensures the cap does not protect Seller from egregious conduct.

p_61.title: Liability Cap Applies to Both Parties
p_61.description: The cap applies to 'either party,' meaning Buyer's liability to Seller is also capped. While this appears balanced, Buyer's primary exposure is losing the deposit (which is already addressed in Section 13.1), so a mutual cap may give Seller more protection than Buyer. The cap should be asymmetric if Seller's potential liability exposure is greater.
p_61.problematic_text: the aggregate liability of either party arising pursuant to or in connection with the representations, warranties, covenants and other obligations
p_61.user_recommendation: Consider asymmetric caps given different risk profiles of each party.
p_61.model_instructions: Consider whether the cap should be asymmetric. Buyer's primary exposure for breach is the liquidated damages provision in Section 13.1 (deposit forfeiture). The cap may be more important for limiting Seller's exposure. If retained as mutual, ensure the cap amount is appropriate for both parties' exposure profiles.

p_61.title: Cap Covers All Obligations Including Covenants
p_61.description: The liability cap applies not just to representations and warranties but to 'covenants and other obligations (whether express or implied).' This could limit Buyer's recovery for breach of Seller's operating covenants, failure to deliver documents, or other contractual obligations beyond just rep breaches.
p_61.problematic_text: representations, warranties, covenants and other obligations (whether express or implied)
p_61.user_recommendation: Limit cap to representations and warranties only; exclude covenants.
p_61.model_instructions: Revise to read: 'the aggregate liability of Seller arising pursuant to or in connection with the representations and warranties of Seller in Section 7.1 of this Agreement shall not exceed $[X].' This limits the cap to representation claims and excludes covenant breaches, indemnification obligations, and other contractual duties.

p_62.title: Introductory Language Only - No Substantive Content
p_62.description: This paragraph is merely introductory language for Buyer's representations and warranties. The actual representations follow in subsequent paragraphs. No risks in this specific paragraph, but Buyer should ensure its representations are appropriately qualified and not broader than necessary.
p_62.problematic_text: Buyer hereby represents and warrants that:
p_62.user_recommendation: Review subsequent Buyer representations for appropriate qualifications.
p_62.model_instructions: Review paragraphs p_63 and p_64 for Buyer's substantive representations to ensure they are appropriately limited in scope and qualified where necessary. Buyer's representations should be symmetrical with Seller's where appropriate.

p_63.title: Buyer Rep Broader Than Seller's Equivalent
p_63.description: Buyer's organizational representation includes 'in good standing' and 'full right, power and authority,' which is broader than Seller's equivalent representation in Section 7A(i) (p_53). This asymmetry means Buyer bears a higher standard of warranty than Seller for equivalent organizational matters. Additionally, Buyer's representation is unqualified while many of Seller's representations are limited by 'Seller's Actual Knowledge.'
p_63.problematic_text: duly organized, validly existing and in good standing under the laws of the State of __________, with full right, power and authority
p_63.user_recommendation: Request parallel language for Seller's organizational rep or soften Buyer's language.
p_63.model_instructions: Either (a) modify Buyer's representation to match the Seller's organizational representation in p_53 by removing 'in good standing' if not included there, or (b) alternatively, propose reciprocal language requiring Seller to also represent 'good standing' and 'full right, power and authority' in p_53. The goal is symmetry between the parties' organizational warranties.

p_64.title: Unqualified No-Violation Rep Creates Risk
p_64.description: Buyer represents that execution 'do not, and at the time of Closing will not, violate any provisions of any contract or judicial order.' This is an absolute, unqualified representation with no materiality qualifier. Minor technical violations of any contract could theoretically constitute a breach. Compare this to Seller's representations which are heavily qualified by 'Seller's Actual Knowledge.'
p_64.problematic_text: do not, and at the time of Closing will not, violate any provisions of any contract or judicial order to which Buyer is a party or to which Buyer is subject
p_64.user_recommendation: Add materiality qualifier: 'do not materially violate' or knowledge qualifier.
p_64.model_instructions: Revise the representation to read: 'do not, and at the time of Closing will not, to Buyer's knowledge, violate in any material respect any provisions of any contract or judicial order to which Buyer is a party or to which Buyer is subject.' This adds both a knowledge qualifier (consistent with how Seller's reps are qualified) and a materiality threshold to prevent technical foot-faults from constituting a breach.

p_65.title: 6-Month Survival Period Too Short for Buyer
p_65.description: The six-month survival period for representations and warranties is extremely short and favors Seller. Many breaches of Seller's representations (particularly regarding the rent roll, litigation, environmental matters, or lease compliance) may not be discoverable until well after six months of ownership. Industry standard for commercial real estate is typically 12-18 months. This short period significantly limits Buyer's ability to seek recourse for Seller misrepresentations.
p_65.problematic_text: shall survive for a period of six (6) months from the Closing Date
p_65.user_recommendation: Negotiate for 12-18 month survival period, minimum 12 months.
p_65.model_instructions: Revise the survival period from 'six (6) months' to 'twelve (12) months' or 'eighteen (18) months.' Additionally, consider adding a carve-out for fraud, intentional misrepresentation, or willful misconduct which should survive indefinitely or for the applicable statute of limitations period. Proposed language: 'shall survive for a period of eighteen (18) months from the Closing Date; provided, however, that claims based on fraud, intentional misrepresentation, or willful misconduct shall survive until the expiration of the applicable statute of limitations.'

p_65.title: Auto-Termination of Claims Not in Litigation
p_65.description: The provision automatically terminates 'any cause of action resulting from a breach thereof not then in litigation' at the end of the Survival Period. This requires Buyer to actually file litigation (not merely give notice of a claim or begin negotiations) to preserve claims. This is more restrictive than provisions allowing claims to survive if written notice is given within the survival period.
p_65.problematic_text: any cause of action resulting from a breach thereof not then in litigation
p_65.user_recommendation: Change to allow survival if written notice of claim given within period.
p_65.model_instructions: Revise the termination language to read: 'at which time such representations and warranties (and any cause of action resulting from a breach thereof as to which Buyer has not given written notice to Seller specifying in reasonable detail the nature of such breach) shall terminate.' This allows Buyer to preserve claims by giving written notice rather than requiring actual litigation to be commenced within the survival period.

p_66.title: Termination as Sole Remedy for Seller's Changed Reps
p_66.description: If Seller discovers that a representation has become incorrect after the Due Diligence Period, Buyer's 'sole remedy' is termination. This means Buyer cannot pursue damages even if Seller's misrepresentation was negligent or caused Buyer to incur significant costs. This effectively allows Seller to disclose problems at the last minute and escape liability by allowing Buyer to terminate, putting all risk of wasted due diligence costs, financing costs, and opportunity costs on Buyer.
p_66.problematic_text: Buyer's termination of this Agreement shall be Buyer's sole remedy against Seller in the circumstances described in this paragraph
p_66.user_recommendation: Preserve right to damages for misrepresentation, add expense reimbursement at minimum.
p_66.model_instructions: Delete 'shall be Buyer's sole remedy against Seller in the circumstances described in this paragraph' and replace with: 'shall not preclude Buyer from seeking recovery of Buyer's actual out-of-pocket costs and expenses incurred in connection with this transaction, including but not limited to due diligence costs, legal fees, financing costs, and inspection expenses, subject to a cap of $_______. Nothing herein shall limit Buyer's remedies for fraud or intentional misrepresentation.' Alternatively, add reimbursement of Buyer's transaction expenses upon termination under this provision.

p_66.title: Compressed Decision Timeline on Changed Reps
p_66.description: If Seller notifies of a changed representation late in the process, Buyer has only 10 days (or until Closing if less than 10 days remain) to evaluate and decide whether to terminate. Seller then has 5 days to elect to cure. This compressed timeline may not allow Buyer sufficient time to assess the impact of material new information, particularly if it involves complex issues like environmental contamination, title defects, or tenant disputes.
p_66.problematic_text: Buyer may elect within ten (10) days after receipt of such notice (or, if such notice is received less than ten days prior to the Closing Date, Buyer may elect on or before the Closing Date)
p_66.user_recommendation: Require minimum 15 days for Buyer evaluation, automatic Closing extension if needed.
p_66.model_instructions: Revise to provide: 'Buyer may elect within fifteen (15) days after receipt of such notice to provide written notice to Seller of Buyer's intent to terminate this Agreement; provided that if such notice is received less than fifteen (15) days prior to the scheduled Closing Date, the Closing Date shall be automatically extended to provide Buyer the full fifteen (15) day evaluation period.' This ensures Buyer always has adequate time to assess material changes.

p_66.title: Seller Cure Right Delays Closing Without Cost
p_66.description: If Buyer elects to terminate due to a changed representation, Seller can elect to cure, making Seller's cure a 'condition precedent to Buyer's obligations.' However, there is no deadline for Seller's cure, no requirement that Seller bear the costs of delay, and no compensation to Buyer if Seller's cure attempts fail. Buyer could be held in limbo while Seller attempts to cure, incurring carrying costs and losing other opportunities.
p_66.problematic_text: Seller may within five (5) days after receipt of such termination notice (or, if such termination notice is received less than five days prior to the Closing Date, on or before the Closing Date) notify Buyer of Seller's intent to cure the condition causing such misrepresentation prior to Closing, in which event Seller's cure of such condition shall be a condition precedent to Buyer's obligations hereunder
p_66.user_recommendation: Add cure deadline, Buyer expense reimbursement if cure fails, right to terminate if cure exceeds 30 days.
p_66.model_instructions: Revise to add: 'Seller's cure period shall not exceed thirty (30) days from Seller's notice of intent to cure, and the Closing Date shall be extended accordingly. If Seller fails to cure the condition within such thirty (30) day period, Buyer may terminate this Agreement and receive a return of the Deposit together with reimbursement of Buyer's actual out-of-pocket transaction costs incurred after the original Closing Date, up to a maximum of $_______. Seller shall provide Buyer with weekly written updates on cure progress.'

p_67.title: Covenant Period Has No Post-Termination Tail
p_67.description: Seller's covenants apply 'between the Effective Date and the Closing or earlier termination of this Agreement.' If the Agreement terminates (for any reason), Seller's covenants immediately cease. This is standard, but if there are any surviving obligations or wind-down activities, Buyer would have no contractual protection for Seller's conduct during any interim period before termination is fully effectuated.
p_67.problematic_text: Between the Effective Date and the Closing or earlier termination of this Agreement
p_67.user_recommendation: Confirm survival provisions adequately cover any post-termination exposure.
p_67.model_instructions: This is informational. Review the survival provisions (p_65, p_38) to ensure any breaches of Seller's covenants that occurred prior to termination remain actionable. Consider adding: 'provided that any breach of the covenants set forth herein occurring prior to such termination shall survive termination for the Survival Period set forth in Section 7(c).'

p_68.title: Deemed Approval After 5 Days
p_68.description: Buyer's consent to new leases, lease modifications, or lease terminations is 'conclusively deemed granted' if Buyer does not object within 5 days of Seller's request. This is an extremely short window for Buyer to review potentially complex lease documents, evaluate tenant creditworthiness, and assess the impact on property value. If Buyer is traveling, distracted by other matters, or experiences any delay in receiving the notice, Buyer could inadvertently approve a lease that materially affects the Property's value or operations.
p_68.problematic_text: Buyer's consent shall conclusively be deemed granted if Buyer does not object to a proposed new lease, lease modification or lease termination within five (5) days after Seller has provided Buyer with a written request for approval
p_68.user_recommendation: Extend deemed approval period to 10-15 business days.
p_68.model_instructions: Replace 'five (5) days' with 'ten (10) business days' and add language requiring that Seller's request must include complete copies of all relevant lease documents and a summary of material terms. Consider adding: 'Failure to provide complete documentation shall toll the approval period until such documentation is provided.'

amplified_by.effect: Buyer becomes responsible for all leasing commissions and TI costs for approved leases

p_68.title: Buyer Assumes All Leasing Costs Post-Approval
p_68.description: If Buyer approves (or is deemed to approve) any new lease or lease modification, Buyer becomes 'responsible for all leasing commissions, tenant improvements and other costs payable by the Landlord thereunder' from Closing. This could represent significant unexpected costs, especially if combined with the 5-day deemed approval provision. There is no cap on these costs, no requirement that Seller disclose estimated costs when seeking approval, and no distinction between costs arising before vs. after Closing.
p_68.problematic_text: If any new lease or Lease modification is entered into with Buyer's approval as set forth above, then from and after Closing Buyer shall be responsible for all leasing commissions, tenant improvements and other costs payable by the Landlord thereunder.
p_68.user_recommendation: Require cost disclosure; cap Buyer's exposure; allocate pre-Closing costs to Seller.
p_68.model_instructions: Modify to: 'If any new lease or Lease modification is entered into with Buyer's prior written approval (which approval shall not be deemed granted), Buyer shall be responsible for leasing commissions, tenant improvements and other landlord costs thereunder that accrue or become due after Closing. Seller shall remain responsible for all such costs that accrue or become due prior to Closing. Seller's request for approval shall include a detailed estimate of all anticipated leasing commissions, tenant improvement costs, and other landlord obligations under the proposed lease or modification.'

amplified_by.effect: Deemed approval after 5 days could trigger cost assumption without informed consent

p_68.title: Vague 'Same Manner' Operating Standard
p_68.description: During the Due Diligence Period, Seller must maintain and operate the Property 'in the same manner in which Seller is currently operating.' This standard is subjective and difficult to enforce. It does not require Seller to maintain the Property in good condition, comply with all laws, or meet any objective standard—only to continue whatever practices Seller was employing, which could be substandard.
p_68.problematic_text: Seller shall continue to maintain, operate, and lease the Property in the same manner in which Seller is currently operating, maintaining and leasing the Property
p_68.user_recommendation: Add objective standards: 'in good condition' and 'in compliance with applicable laws.'
p_68.model_instructions: Revise to: 'Seller shall continue to maintain, operate, and lease the Property (i) in the same manner in which Seller is currently operating, maintaining and leasing the Property, (ii) in good condition and repair, ordinary wear and tear excepted, (iii) in compliance with all applicable laws, and (iv) in accordance with the terms of all Leases and Service Contracts.'

p_68.title: No Lease Consent Rights During Due Diligence
p_68.description: The consent requirement for new leases, modifications, or terminations only applies 'After the Due Diligence Period expires.' During the Due Diligence Period itself, Seller appears free to enter into new leases or modify/terminate existing leases without Buyer's consent, as long as it's consistent with Seller's current manner of leasing. This could allow Seller to lock in unfavorable long-term leases before Buyer has completed its review.
p_68.problematic_text: After the Due Diligence Period expires, Seller shall not modify or terminate any lease, or enter into any new lease, without the prior written consent of Buyer
p_68.user_recommendation: Require Buyer consent for material leasing activity from Effective Date.
p_68.model_instructions: Revise to: 'From and after the Effective Date, Seller shall not modify or terminate any lease, or enter into any new lease, without the prior written consent of Buyer, which consent shall not be unreasonably withheld, conditioned or delayed; provided that during the Due Diligence Period, Buyer may withhold consent in its sole and absolute discretion.'

mitigated_by.effect: Buyer can terminate during DD period if it discovers unfavorable leasing

p_69.title: Broad Exception for 'Reasonably Necessary' Contracts
p_69.description: While Seller generally needs Buyer's consent to enter into, modify, or terminate Service Contracts, there is a broad exception for contracts 'deemed reasonably necessary by Seller which are cancelable on thirty (30) days' notice without penalty.' The determination of what is 'reasonably necessary' is made by Seller, not an objective standard, and Seller could enter into unfavorable contracts under this exception that burden Buyer post-Closing.
p_69.problematic_text: except those deemed reasonably necessary by Seller which are cancelable on thirty (30) days' notice without penalty
p_69.user_recommendation: Require notice to Buyer of all new contracts; limit exception to emergency situations.
p_69.model_instructions: Revise to: 'except those that are (i) necessary to address an emergency threatening imminent harm to persons or material damage to the Property, (ii) cancelable on thirty (30) days' notice without penalty or premium, and (iii) on market terms. Seller shall provide Buyer with written notice of any such contract within two (2) business days of execution, together with a copy thereof.'

mitigated_by.effect: Contracts under this exception must be cancelable on 30 days notice

p_69.title: Seller Not Obligated to Terminate Contracts Creating Cost
p_69.description: Seller is not obligated to terminate any Service Contract that Buyer does not want to assume 'if such termination will create any additional cost or liability for Seller.' This could leave Buyer saddled with unwanted, long-term, or above-market service contracts if termination would cost Seller anything. There is no provision for Buyer to offer to pay the termination cost or for the parties to share such costs.
p_69.problematic_text: Seller shall not be obligated to terminate any Service Contract if such termination will create any additional cost or liability for Seller
p_69.user_recommendation: Allow Buyer to pay termination costs to exit unwanted contracts.
p_69.model_instructions: Add: 'Notwithstanding the foregoing, if Buyer elects not to assume any Service Contract and termination thereof would create additional cost or liability, Buyer may elect to pay such termination cost or liability (not to exceed $_____), in which case Seller shall terminate such Service Contract effective as of the Closing Date. If Buyer does not so elect and Seller does not terminate such Service Contract, Buyer shall have the right to terminate this Agreement and receive a refund of the Deposit if the aggregate annual cost of non-terminable Service Contracts that Buyer has elected not to assume exceeds $_____.'

amplified_by.effect: AS-IS provision may limit Buyer's recourse for assuming unfavorable contracts

p_70.title: Insurance Maintenance Limited to 'Currently in Force'
p_70.description: Seller's obligation is only to 'maintain all casualty and liability insurance currently in force.' There is no requirement that current insurance is adequate, that it meets any particular coverage levels, or that it complies with lender requirements. If current coverage is deficient, Seller has no obligation to cure that deficiency.
p_70.problematic_text: Seller shall maintain all casualty and liability insurance currently in force with respect to the Property
p_70.user_recommendation: Require insurance meeting specified minimums and lender requirements.
p_70.model_instructions: Revise to: 'Seller shall maintain all casualty and liability insurance currently in force with respect to the Property, but in no event less than (i) property/casualty insurance in an amount not less than the full replacement cost of the Improvements, (ii) commercial general liability insurance with limits of not less than $_____ per occurrence and $_____ aggregate, and (iii) such other insurance as may be required by any lender holding a lien on the Property or by any Lease. Seller shall provide Buyer with certificates of insurance upon request.'

amplified_by.effect: Inadequate insurance could leave Buyer exposed if casualty occurs before Closing

p_71.title: Only 'Commercially Reasonable Efforts' for Estoppels
p_71.description: Seller's obligation to obtain tenant estoppels is limited to 'commercially reasonable efforts.' This is a lower standard than 'best efforts' and provides Seller significant latitude. If Seller fails to obtain the Minimum Tenant Estoppels, Buyer's only remedy is termination—there is no right to specific performance or damages, and no obligation for Seller to use stronger efforts.
p_71.problematic_text: Seller shall use commercially reasonable efforts to obtain an estoppel statement from each tenant
p_71.user_recommendation: Require 'best efforts' or define specific actions Seller must take.
p_71.model_instructions: Revise to: 'Seller shall use best efforts to obtain an estoppel statement from each tenant, substantially in the form of Exhibit G ("Tenant Estoppels"). Such efforts shall include, without limitation, (i) delivering estoppel requests to all tenants within five (5) business days after the Effective Date, (ii) following up with tenants who have not responded within ten (10) days, and (iii) if requested by Buyer, providing rent concessions or other reasonable incentives to tenants to encourage timely response.'

mitigated_by.effect: Buyer can terminate if Minimum Tenant Estoppels not obtained

p_71.title: Seller's Certificate Substitutes for Missing Estoppels
p_71.description: If Seller obtains the Minimum Tenant Estoppels but cannot obtain estoppels from remaining tenants, Buyer must accept a 'Seller's Lease Certificate' certifying (only 'to Seller's knowledge') the matters in the estoppel form. This certificate is far less valuable than a tenant estoppel because: (1) it's qualified by Seller's knowledge, (2) Seller may have limited liability for inaccuracies (see survival and liability provisions), and (3) it doesn't bind the tenant.
p_71.problematic_text: Buyer shall accept a certificate of Seller ("Seller's Lease Certificate") certifying, to Seller's knowledge, those matters included in the attached form of Tenant Estoppel regarding the lease(s) with such tenant(s)
p_71.user_recommendation: Limit use of Seller's Certificate; require indemnity for inaccuracies; extend survival.
p_71.model_instructions: Add after the existing text: 'Seller's Lease Certificate shall not be subject to any knowledge qualification and Seller shall indemnify and hold Buyer harmless from any loss, cost, damage or expense arising from any inaccuracy in any Seller's Lease Certificate, which indemnification obligation shall survive Closing for a period of [eighteen (18) months / the Survival Period]. Notwithstanding the foregoing, Buyer shall not be required to accept a Seller's Lease Certificate with respect to any tenant occupying more than _____ rentable square feet or any tenant whose Lease has a remaining term (including renewal options) of more than _____ years.'

amplified_by.effect: Narrow knowledge definition limits utility of Seller's Certificate
Limited survival period may expire before lease issues materialize

p_71.title: Subordination Agreements Conditioned on Lease Terms
p_71.description: Seller's obligation to cooperate in obtaining subordination agreements (SNDAs) is heavily conditioned: only if the tenant's lease permits such a request. Additionally, Seller has 'no obligation to obtain and deliver' any subordination agreements—only to 'cooperate.' This may leave Buyer unable to satisfy lender requirements for subordination agreements.
p_71.problematic_text: Seller agrees to cooperate with Buyer to obtain subordination agreements from tenants on the Property and deliver same to Buyer; provided said tenants' leases permit the landlord to request a subordination agreement from the Tenant and provided, further, Seller shall have no obligation to obtain and deliver any such subordination agreements to Buyer
p_71.user_recommendation: Require Seller to use commercially reasonable efforts to obtain SNDAs.
p_71.model_instructions: Revise to: 'Seller shall use commercially reasonable efforts to obtain subordination, non-disturbance and attornment agreements ("SNDAs") from tenants in a form reasonably required by Buyer's lender. If Seller is unable to obtain an SNDA from any tenant whose lease does not permit landlord to require same, Seller shall (i) notify Buyer in writing and (ii) use commercially reasonable efforts to negotiate with such tenant for execution of an SNDA.'

p_72.title: Comprehensive AS-IS Waiver Including Environmental
p_72.description: This extremely broad AS-IS provision disclaims virtually all warranties and representations except those expressly stated in Section 7. Of particular concern, it disclaims representations regarding: (x) presence or absence of hazardous materials, (ix) compliance with environmental laws, (vii) compliance with all laws, and (xi) accuracy of due diligence materials. This shifts substantial risk to Buyer, particularly environmental risk which can result in significant remediation costs and liability.
p_72.problematic_text: (IX) COMPLIANCE WITH ANY ENVIRONMENTAL PROTECTION, POLLUTION OR LAND USE LAWS, RULES, REGULATIONS, ORDERS OR REQUIREMENTS; (X) THE PRESENCE OR ABSENCE OF HAZARDOUS MATERIALS AT, ON, UNDER, OR ADJACENT TO THE PROPERTY
p_72.user_recommendation: Carve out environmental matters from AS-IS; add environmental rep to Section 7.
p_72.model_instructions: Add to the AS-IS provision: 'Notwithstanding the foregoing, the disclaimers set forth in this Section 9 shall not apply to (i) any claims arising from Seller's fraud or intentional misrepresentation, (ii) any claims arising from Seller's breach of the representations and warranties set forth in Section 7, or (iii) [environmental conditions that existed prior to the Effective Date to the extent Seller had actual knowledge thereof and failed to disclose same to Buyer].' Additionally, consider adding an environmental representation to Section 7: 'To Seller's Actual Knowledge, except as disclosed in the environmental reports included in the Due Diligence Documents, there are no Hazardous Materials located on, under or about the Property in violation of applicable Environmental Laws.'

mitigated_by.effect: Section 7 representations are carved out from AS-IS

amplified_by.effect: Section 10 Release compounds this waiver with an affirmative release
Short survival period limits time to discover and assert claims

p_72.title: Waiver of Reliance on Due Diligence Materials
p_72.description: Buyer expressly agrees it is 'relying solely on its own investigation' and not on 'any information provided or to be provided by Seller.' This waiver extends to the accuracy and completeness of due diligence materials, meaning Buyer may have no recourse even if Seller provided materially inaccurate information (outside of Section 7 reps). This significantly undermines the value of the due diligence process.
p_72.problematic_text: BUYER IS, EXCEPT FOR SELLER'S REPRESENTATIONS AND WARRANTIES CONTAINED IN SECTION 7 HEREIN, RELYING SOLELY ON ITS OWN INVESTIGATION OF THE PROPERTY AND REVIEW OF SUCH INFORMATION AND DOCUMENTATION, AND NOT ON ANY INFORMATION PROVIDED OR TO BE PROVIDED BY SELLER
p_72.user_recommendation: Add exception for materially misleading information provided by Seller.
p_72.model_instructions: Add: 'Notwithstanding the foregoing, Buyer may rely upon information provided by Seller to the extent such information is materially false or misleading and Seller had actual knowledge that such information was materially false or misleading at the time it was provided. This provision shall not limit any claim for fraud.'

mitigated_by.effect: Representations in Section 7 are carved out

amplified_by.effect: Section 5.2 also disclaims reliance on DD Documents

p_72.title: Release of Third-Party Information Sources
p_72.description: Buyer agrees to 'fully and irrevocably release all such sources of information and preparers of information' retained by Seller from any claims. This could include environmental consultants, property condition assessors, and others whose reports may contain errors. Buyer would be precluded from pursuing claims against these parties even if their reports were negligently prepared.
p_72.problematic_text: BUYER AGREES TO FULLY AND IRREVOCABLY RELEASE ALL SUCH SOURCES OF INFORMATION AND PREPARERS OF INFORMATION AND DOCUMENTATION AFFECTING THE PROPERTY WHICH WERE RETAINED BY SELLER FROM ANY AND ALL CLAIMS
p_72.user_recommendation: Delete third-party release or limit to parties with no direct contractual relationship.
p_72.model_instructions: Revise to: 'Buyer agrees not to pursue claims against third-party sources of information retained by Seller for matters disclosed in reports provided to Buyer during the Due Diligence Period, except to the extent such third parties had a direct contractual relationship with Buyer or provided reliance letters to Buyer. This release shall not apply to claims for fraud, gross negligence, or willful misconduct.'

mitigated_by.effect: Carve-out exists for claims based on direct relationship with preparers

p_72.title: No Seller Obligation to Repair
p_72.description: The AS-IS provision expressly states that 'SELLER HAS NO OBLIGATIONS TO MAKE REPAIRS, REPLACEMENTS OR IMPROVEMENTS.' Combined with the covenant in Section 8(a) that only requires Seller to maintain the Property 'in the same manner' as currently, this creates a gap where Property condition could deteriorate without remedy to Buyer.
p_72.problematic_text: SELLER HAS NO OBLIGATIONS TO MAKE REPAIRS, REPLACEMENTS OR IMPROVEMENTS EXCEPT AS MAY OTHERWISE BE EXPRESSLY STATED HEREIN
p_72.user_recommendation: Require material repairs needed for Closing; add condition precedent for Property condition.
p_72.model_instructions: Add to Section 8 or as a condition precedent: 'Notwithstanding Section 9, Seller shall make all repairs necessary to (i) maintain the Property in substantially the same condition as of the Effective Date, ordinary wear and tear excepted, (ii) comply with all applicable laws and codes, and (iii) comply with the terms of all Leases. If at Closing the Property is not in substantially the same condition as of the Effective Date (ordinary wear and tear excepted), Buyer may elect to (a) proceed to Closing with a credit against the Purchase Price equal to the estimated cost of such repairs, or (b) terminate this Agreement and receive a refund of the Deposit.'

amplified_by.effect: Vague operating covenant doesn't require repairs

p_74.title: Sweeping release of all claims
p_74.description: This release is extraordinarily broad, requiring Buyer to release Seller from 'any and all losses, liabilities, damages, claims, demands, causes of action, costs and expenses, whether known or unknown' arising from or connected with the Property. This includes structural conditions, environmental issues, and title matters. The 'whether known or unknown' language is particularly dangerous as it waives claims Buyer may not discover until after closing, potentially including latent defects, undisclosed environmental contamination, or other significant issues that due diligence may not uncover.
p_74.problematic_text: shall forever release Seller, its members and principals, and its officers, directors, agents and employees, and its and their respective successors, of and from any and all losses, liabilities, damages, claims, demands, causes of action, costs and expenses, whether known or unknown, arising out of or in any way connected with the Property
p_74.user_recommendation: Narrow release to exclude fraud, intentional misconduct, and known but undisclosed defects.
p_74.model_instructions: Revise the release to carve out: (a) claims arising from fraud or intentional misrepresentation by Seller; (b) claims arising from Seller's willful misconduct or gross negligence; (c) matters actually known to Seller but not disclosed to Buyer; (d) third-party claims arising from Seller's acts or omissions prior to Closing; and (e) indemnification obligations under Section 7.1 representations.
