Add language stating 'This release shall not apply to any matter that Seller had actual knowledge of prior to Closing and failed to disclose to Buyer in writing.'

mitigated_by.effect: Partially preserves claims under Section 7.1 representations and post-closing obligations

amplified_by.effect: Combined with AS-IS clause, eliminates virtually all Buyer recourse
Short survival period on reps further limits window to discover and pursue excepted claims

p_74.title: Broad environmental claims release
p_74.description: Buyer releases Seller from 'any environmental claims and causes of action existing now or hereafter created or enacted.' This waives current and future environmental claims under laws that may not yet exist. While there is an exception for hazardous substances 'caused by Seller,' the burden of proving Seller caused the contamination will fall on Buyer, which is extremely difficult after closing when chain of custody is broken and Seller controls no records.
p_74.problematic_text: Buyer will thereby forever release Seller of and from any environmental claims and causes of action existing now or hereafter created or enacted, whether at common law or by federal, state, county, or municipal law or ordinance, except for any reimbursement or contribution claims which Buyer may have against Seller under any state or federal laws regarding the release of any hazardous substances on the Property caused by Seller
p_74.user_recommendation: Preserve environmental claims for pre-closing contamination and require Seller's cooperation in third-party claims.
p_74.model_instructions: Revise the environmental release to: (a) preserve Buyer's claims for contamination that existed prior to Closing, regardless of who caused it; (b) preserve claims for contamination caused by Seller, its tenants, or any party under Seller's control during Seller's ownership period; (c) require Seller to cooperate with Buyer in any third-party environmental claims at Seller's expense to the extent related to Seller's ownership period; (d) require Seller to retain environmental records for a period of [5-10] years post-Closing and make them available to Buyer; and (e) add an indemnification from Seller for pre-closing environmental violations.

mitigated_by.effect: Environmental representation (if included) may provide limited recourse subject to survival period

amplified_by.effect: AS-IS provision combined with release leaves Buyer with minimal environmental protection

p_74.title: Covenant not to sue is absolute
p_74.description: The covenant that Buyer 'agrees never to commence, aid in any way, or prosecute against Seller... any action or other proceeding' is extremely broad and could be interpreted to prevent Buyer from even participating as a witness in litigation involving Seller and the Property, or from joining necessary parties in third-party claims. The 'aid in any way' language could hamper Buyer's ability to pursue legitimate claims against third parties where Seller's testimony or cooperation is needed.
p_74.problematic_text: Buyer agrees never to commence, aid in any way, or prosecute against Seller, its officers, directors, agents and employees and its and their respective successors, any action or other proceeding based upon any losses, liabilities, damages, claims, demands, causes of action, costs and expenses, covered in this paragraph
p_74.user_recommendation: Limit covenant to direct claims, preserve rights for contribution and third-party actions.
p_74.model_instructions: Revise the covenant not to sue to: (a) apply only to direct claims by Buyer against Seller, not to claims where Seller is a necessary party or witness; (b) expressly preserve Buyer's right to seek contribution or indemnification from Seller in connection with third-party claims; (c) carve out claims excepted from the release in Section 10; and (d) add language that 'Nothing in this covenant shall prevent Buyer from defending itself in any action or proceeding, including by naming Seller as a necessary or indispensable party.'

p_76.title: Limited survival exception for reps
p_76.description: While this carve-out preserves claims under Section 7.1 representations, it is limited 'to the extent same survive Closing as provided therein.' This ties directly to Section 7.3 (p_65) which likely contains a short survival period, potentially as little as 6-12 months. Combined with the narrow 'to Seller's Actual Knowledge' qualifiers on most representations, this exception provides less protection than it appears.
p_76.problematic_text: any representations and warranties made specifically by Seller in Section 7.1 above to the extent same survive Closing as provided therein
p_76.user_recommendation: Extend representation survival period and add specific indemnification obligations.
p_76.model_instructions: Strengthen this carve-out by: (a) removing the qualifier 'to the extent same survive Closing as provided therein' and instead specifying a minimum survival period of [18-24 months] directly in this section; (b) adding language that 'The survival period for representations relating to environmental matters, title, and authority shall be [3-5 years]'; (c) adding an express indemnification obligation: 'Seller shall indemnify Buyer for any breach of the foregoing representations and warranties'; and (d) specifying that the survival period shall be tolled during any period when Buyer is prevented from discovering a breach.

amplified_by.effect: Short survival period in Section 7.3 significantly limits the practical value of this carve-out
Narrow knowledge qualifier on reps reduces likelihood of successful breach claim

p_76.title: Vague 'other obligations' carve-out
p_76.description: The carve-out for 'any other obligations of Seller identified herein which are to be performed after Closing' is vague and may be subject to dispute. It does not specify which obligations survive, potentially leading to litigation over whether specific Seller obligations (such as proration true-ups, estoppel delivery, or cooperation with 1031 exchanges) are covered.
p_76.problematic_text: any other obligations of Seller identified herein which are to be performed after Closing
p_76.user_recommendation: Enumerate specific post-closing obligations that survive the release.
p_76.model_instructions: Replace the vague reference with a specific enumeration: 'The following obligations of Seller shall survive Closing and are excepted from the foregoing release: (i) proration adjustments under Section 11.6; (ii) reconciliation obligations under Section 11.8 and 11.9; (iii) cooperation with Buyer's 1031 exchange under Section 17; (iv) any indemnification obligations under this Agreement; (v) Seller's obligation to deliver documents in Seller's possession relating to the Property; and (vi) any express survival provisions elsewhere in this Agreement.'

p_79.title: Closing date left blank
p_79.description: The Closing Date is left blank ('on or before ______________________'). An undefined closing date creates significant uncertainty and could result in disputes over when performance is due, when time-is-of-the-essence provisions trigger, and when default occurs. This is a critical term that should never be left undefined in an executed agreement.
p_79.user_recommendation: Insert specific Closing Date tied to a date certain or formula based on Effective Date.
p_79.model_instructions: Insert a specific closing date or a formula: 'on or before the date that is [forty-five (45)] days after the expiration of the Due Diligence Period, or such earlier date as Buyer and Seller may mutually agree in writing (the "Closing Date")'. Alternatively, insert a specific date if known. Ensure the closing date provides adequate time after due diligence expiration for Buyer to arrange financing, complete title review, and satisfy closing conditions.

amplified_by.effect: If time-is-of-the-essence, undefined date creates immediate default risk

p_79.title: Extension fee is non-refundable except for Seller default
p_79.description: The Extension Fee is described as 'nonrefundable, except in case of Seller's default.' This means if Buyer pays an Extension Fee but closing fails to occur for reasons other than Seller's default (e.g., title issues, failure of a condition, mutual termination, casualty), Buyer loses the Extension Fee. This is a one-sided risk allocation that could result in significant forfeiture.
p_79.problematic_text: The Extension Fee shall be nonrefundable, except in case of Seller's default.
p_79.user_recommendation: Make Extension Fee refundable if closing fails through no fault of Buyer.
p_79.model_instructions: Revise to: 'The Extension Fee shall be nonrefundable, except (i) in case of Seller's default, (ii) if Closing fails to occur due to a failure of any condition precedent to Buyer's obligation to close set forth in Section 5.4 (other than conditions within Buyer's control), (iii) if this Agreement is terminated due to a casualty or condemnation under Section 13, or (iv) if the parties mutually agree to terminate this Agreement. In any such case, Seller shall promptly return the Extension Fee to Buyer.'

p_79.title: Extension terms left blank
p_79.description: Multiple critical extension terms are left blank: the extension period length ('_____________ day extension periods'), notice period ('at least __________ business days prior'), and Extension Fee amount ('$_______________'). These blanks create uncertainty about Buyer's extension rights and costs, which are valuable protections if Buyer needs additional time to close.
p_79.problematic_text: two _____________ day extension periods, by giving written notice to Seller of its intention to extend the Closing Date, which notice shall be given at least __________ business days prior to the then-current closing date (as it may have been previously extended), in which notice shall be accompanied by payment to Seller in the amount of $_______________ (each an "Extension Fee")
p_79.user_recommendation: Fill in extension terms: suggest 15-day extensions, 5-day notice, and reasonable fee.
p_79.model_instructions: Insert reasonable terms: 'two fifteen (15) day extension periods, by giving written notice to Seller of its intention to extend the Closing Date, which notice shall be given at least five (5) business days prior to the then-current closing date (as it may have been previously extended), in which notice shall be accompanied by payment to Seller in the amount of $[insert amount representing approximately 0.1-0.25% of Purchase Price] (each an "Extension Fee")'. Ensure the extension period is sufficient to address potential delays and the fee is proportionate to the transaction size.

p_79.title: Only partial credit for second extension fee
p_79.description: While the first Extension Fee is fully credited to the Purchase Price, only 'one-half (1/2) of the Extension Fee' for the second extension is credited. This means Buyer effectively loses half of the second extension fee even if closing occurs, creating an additional cost for exercising this contractual right.
p_79.problematic_text: one-half (1/2) of the Extension Fee paid by Buyer, if any, for the second extension shall be applicable to the Purchase Price
p_79.user_recommendation: Negotiate for full credit of both extension fees toward Purchase Price.
p_79.model_instructions: Revise to: 'The Extension Fee, if any, paid by Buyer with respect to any extension period shall be applicable to the Purchase Price.' This ensures Buyer receives full credit for extension fees if closing occurs, making the extension fee function purely as consideration for additional time rather than as a penalty.

p_80.title: Strict Time-of-Essence Closing Obligation
p_80.description: The requirement that all documents be executed and delivered 'on or before the Closing Date' creates a strict time obligation without express grace periods or cure rights. If Buyer encounters any delays in funding or document preparation, even minor ones, this could be characterized as a breach triggering default remedies under Section 13A (liquidated damages/deposit forfeiture).
p_80.problematic_text: shall be paid, and all documents necessary for the consummation of the purchase and sale transaction contemplated hereby shall be executed and delivered on or before the Closing Date
p_80.user_recommendation: Add reasonable cure period for non-material closing delays.
p_80.model_instructions: Modify the clause to add a reasonable cure period for Buyer: After 'on or before the Closing Date,' insert: ', provided, however, that in the event Buyer fails to deliver all required funds or documents on the Closing Date due to circumstances beyond Buyer's reasonable control (excluding lack of funds), Buyer shall have two (2) business days to cure such failure without such failure constituting a default hereunder.'

p_80.title: Possession Subject to Tenant Rights
p_80.description: Buyer receives possession 'subject to the rights of tenants in possession under Leases' without any representation that such tenants are in compliance with their leases or that no tenants are in holdover status. This could result in Buyer taking possession with problematic tenancies, including tenants who should have vacated, tenants in default, or tenants with unexpired rights that impair Buyer's intended use.
p_80.problematic_text: subject to the rights of tenants in possession under Leases
p_80.user_recommendation: Add representation that tenants are in compliance and not in holdover.
p_80.model_instructions: Modify the clause to clarify the condition of tenant possession. After 'under Leases' add: ', it being agreed that Seller represents that as of the Closing Date (i) no tenant is in material default under its Lease, (ii) no tenant is in holdover status, and (iii) all tenants in possession are parties to written Leases delivered to Buyer during the Due Diligence Period. Seller shall indemnify Buyer against any claims by or relating to any occupant of the Property whose occupancy is not pursuant to a Lease disclosed to Buyer.'

p_81.title: Undefined Alternate Delivery Timeframes
p_81.description: The parenthetical 'or within such timeframe as may be more specifically provided below' creates ambiguity about when certain deliverables are actually due. While this provides flexibility, it could allow Seller to argue that certain documents need not be delivered at Closing, potentially leaving Buyer without critical documents needed to verify the transaction.
p_81.problematic_text: (or within such timeframe as may be more specifically provided below)
p_81.user_recommendation: Clarify which items may be delivered post-Closing and set deadlines.
p_81.model_instructions: For clarity, modify the parenthetical to read: '(or if a different timeframe is expressly specified for a particular item below, within such specified timeframe, but in no event later than five (5) business days after the Closing Date)'. This ensures all items have a backstop deadline even if the specific provisions are ambiguous.

p_82.title: No Specification of Deed Form or Warranty Type
p_82.description: The clause requires delivery of 'The Deed' without specifying the form of deed (special warranty, general warranty, quitclaim, etc.) or referencing an exhibit. While Section 4C references 'Special Warranty Deed' and there is an exhibit, this delivery provision does not cross-reference those requirements, creating potential ambiguity about what form of deed satisfies Seller's obligation.
p_82.problematic_text: The Deed conveying to Buyer the Real Property, Appurtenances and Improvements
p_82.user_recommendation: Specify deed must be Special Warranty Deed per Exhibit B.
p_82.model_instructions: Replace 'The Deed' with 'A Special Warranty Deed in the form attached hereto as Exhibit B,' to ensure consistency with Section 4C and remove any ambiguity about the type of deed and warranties Seller is providing.

p_82.title: Deed Deliverable Lacks Express Recordability Requirement
p_82.description: While a Real Estate Excise Tax Affidavit is required (suggesting recordation is contemplated), there is no express requirement that the Deed be in recordable form, properly acknowledged/notarized, and otherwise satisfy recording requirements. If the deed has technical defects preventing recording, Buyer may not discover this until after Closing.
p_82.problematic_text: The Deed conveying to Buyer the Real Property, Appurtenances and Improvements, together with a Real Estate Excise Tax Affidavit
p_82.user_recommendation: Add requirement that Deed must be in recordable form.
p_82.model_instructions: Modify the clause to read: 'A Special Warranty Deed in the form attached hereto as Exhibit B, duly executed and acknowledged by Seller in recordable form, conveying to Buyer the Real Property, Appurtenances and Improvements, together with a fully completed Real Estate Excise Tax Affidavit in form acceptable for recording in the county where the Property is located'.

p_83.title: Bill of Sale Without Warranty Language Specified
p_83.description: The Bill of Sale is referenced as being 'in the form of Exhibit C' but the actual exhibit would need to be reviewed to confirm it includes appropriate warranties of title and freedom from liens on the personal property. Buyer should confirm Exhibit C contains adequate protections.
p_83.problematic_text: The Bill of Sale duly executed by Seller, in the form of Exhibit C attached hereto
p_83.user_recommendation: Verify Exhibit C Bill of Sale includes title warranty.
p_83.model_instructions: Add clarifying language to ensure adequate warranties: 'The Bill of Sale duly executed by Seller, in the form of Exhibit C attached hereto, warranting Seller's good and marketable title to the Personal Property, free and clear of all liens, claims, and encumbrances'. Alternatively, confirm Exhibit C contains such language and add reference: 'including the warranties set forth therein'.

p_84.title: Lease Assignment Lacks Tenant Consent Requirement
p_84.description: The Assignment and Assumption of Leases is to be delivered by Seller, but there is no requirement that Seller obtain any consents from tenants that may be required under their Leases for assignment of the landlord's interest. Some commercial leases require landlord to obtain tenant consent or provide notice before assigning the lease. Failure to comply could give tenants termination rights or other claims.
p_84.problematic_text: Two (2) counterparts of the Assignment and Assumption of Leases duly executed by Seller, assigning and conveying to Buyer the Seller's interest in, to and under the Leases
p_84.user_recommendation: Add Seller covenant to obtain required tenant consents pre-Closing.
p_84.model_instructions: Add to the delivery requirement: 'together with evidence of any tenant consents required under the Leases for assignment of the landlord's interest, or a certificate from Seller that no such consents are required under any Lease.' Additionally, consider adding to Section 8 a Seller covenant to use commercially reasonable efforts to obtain any required tenant consents prior to Closing.

p_84.title: No Rent Roll or Arrears Schedule at Closing
p_84.description: While Seller must assign the Leases, there is no requirement in the Closing deliverables for an updated rent roll or schedule of tenant arrears/delinquencies as of the Closing Date. The representation in Section 7A(ii) regarding the rent roll only speaks to accuracy 'as of the Effective Date.' Buyer could close without current information on which tenants are paying and which are delinquent.
p_84.problematic_text: assigning and conveying to Buyer the Seller's interest in, to and under the Leases, in the form of Exhibit D attached hereto
p_84.user_recommendation: Require updated rent roll and delinquency schedule at Closing.
p_84.model_instructions: Add a new delivery item to Section 11.3: '(xii) A current rent roll certified by Seller as true and correct as of the Closing Date, including a schedule of all tenant delinquencies, prepaid rents, and security deposits held by Seller, together with any changes to the information reflected on the rent roll provided during the Due Diligence Period.'

p_85.title: Lease Delivery Limited to Seller's Possession
p_85.description: The delivery obligation is limited to Leases and Lease Documents 'in Seller's possession or control.' This qualifier allows Seller to avoid delivering documents it may have lost, misplaced, or that are held by third parties (property managers, prior counsel, etc.). Buyer could close without complete lease files, making it difficult to enforce lease terms, verify tenant obligations, or identify estoppel issues post-closing.
p_85.user_recommendation: Require Seller to use best efforts to obtain all lease documents before Closing.
p_85.model_instructions: Modify the delivery requirement to impose a broader obligation on Seller. Replace 'in Seller's possession or control' with 'in Seller's possession or control, and Seller shall use commercially reasonable efforts to obtain any Leases or Lease Documents not in Seller's possession or control prior to Closing.' Additionally, add a representation that the delivered lease files are complete to Seller's Actual Knowledge.

p_85.title: No Deadline for Outside-Escrow Delivery
p_85.description: The parenthetical '(to be delivered outside of Escrow)' creates ambiguity about when these documents must be delivered. Unlike items delivered into escrow which have a clear closing deadline, documents delivered outside escrow could theoretically be delivered after closing, leaving Buyer without critical lease documentation at the time of ownership transfer.
p_85.user_recommendation: Specify delivery deadline for documents delivered outside escrow.
p_85.model_instructions: Add timing clarity by replacing '(to be delivered outside of Escrow)' with '(to be delivered to Buyer outside of Escrow no later than one (1) business day prior to Closing)' to ensure Buyer has adequate time to review lease files before taking title.

p_86.title: Assignment Limited to Buyer-Continued Contracts
p_86.description: The assignment covers only 'Service Contracts to be continued by Buyer after the Closing.' This language implies Buyer has selected which contracts to continue, but the mechanism and timing for that selection is in Section 8B, which gives Seller discretion over modifications. If there is any dispute about which contracts are 'to be continued,' Buyer could be left without clear assignment of beneficial contracts or inadvertently assume unfavorable ones.
p_86.problematic_text: Service Contracts to be continued by Buyer after the Closing
p_86.user_recommendation: Cross-reference the specific schedule of assumed contracts.
p_86.model_instructions: Add clarity by modifying to read: 'the Service Contracts identified on Exhibit __ as contracts to be assumed by Buyer after the Closing (the "Assumed Contracts")' and ensure there is a corresponding exhibit that will be finalized and attached prior to expiration of the Due Diligence Period, subject to Buyer's approval. This creates a definitive list of assumed contracts.

p_87.title: Service Contract Delivery Limited to Possession
p_87.description: Similar to the lease delivery issue, delivery of Service Contracts is limited to those 'in the possession or control of Seller.' This allows Seller to avoid delivering contracts held by property managers, vendors, or other third parties. Buyer may not have complete documentation of ongoing service obligations being assumed.
p_87.problematic_text: in the possession or control of Seller
p_87.user_recommendation: Require Seller to obtain all service contracts from property managers.
p_87.model_instructions: Strengthen the delivery obligation by adding: 'Seller shall use commercially reasonable efforts to obtain from its property manager and any other third parties all Service Contracts relating to the Property and not currently in Seller's possession.' Also add a Seller representation that all material Service Contracts have been delivered to Buyer.

p_87.title: Copies Acceptable in Lieu of Originals
p_87.description: The provision allows for 'Originals or copies' of Service Contracts. While copies are often acceptable, originals are preferable for enforceability purposes and to verify authenticity. Without originals, Buyer may face challenges if contract disputes arise with vendors.
p_87.user_recommendation: Require originals where available; copies only if originals unavailable.
p_87.model_instructions: Modify to read: 'Originals of all Service Contracts (or, if originals are not in Seller's possession or control, copies thereof certified by Seller as true and complete)'. This ensures Buyer receives the best available documentation and Seller certifies copy accuracy.

p_88.title: FIRPTA Affidavit Form at Escrow Holder Discretion
p_88.description: The FIRPTA affidavit must be 'in the form reasonably required by the Escrow Holder.' While 'reasonably' provides some protection, this gives Escrow Holder discretion over the form, which could create last-minute issues if Escrow Holder requires non-standard language that Seller resists. The parties lose control over the specific content of this closing document.
p_88.problematic_text: in the form reasonably required by the Escrow Holder
p_88.user_recommendation: Attach the required FIRPTA affidavit form as an exhibit.
p_88.model_instructions: Replace 'in the form reasonably required by the Escrow Holder' with 'in the form attached hereto as Exhibit __, or such other form as may be reasonably required by the Escrow Holder or Title Company.' Then attach a standard FIRPTA affidavit as the referenced exhibit. This provides certainty while allowing flexibility for escrow requirements.

p_89.title: Unlimited Documentation Requirements
p_89.description: This provision requires Seller to deliver 'Such entity formation documents, authorizations, certificates of trust, and other documentation' as Escrow Holder or Title Company 'may require.' This is an open-ended obligation with no limitations, potentially allowing last-minute demands for extensive documentation that could delay closing or create disputes. Buyer's closing is indirectly affected if Seller balks at unreasonable requests.
p_89.problematic_text: and other documentation with respect to Seller as Escrow Holder may require
p_89.model_instructions: Modify the provision to add reasonableness standards: 'Such entity formation documents, authorizations, certificates of trust, and other documentation with respect to Seller as Escrow Holder or the Title Company may reasonably require in order to cause the Closing to occur and issue the Title Policy; provided, however, that such documentation requirements shall be consistent with customary commercial real estate closing requirements in the jurisdiction where the Property is located.'

p_89.title: Title Company Controls Documentation Scope
p_89.description: The Title Company's requirements for issuing the Title Policy drive documentation obligations. If the Title Company has unusual or onerous documentation requirements, Seller must comply, which could create closing delays. Conversely, if Seller cannot satisfy the Title Company, Buyer's condition precedent (receiving the Title Policy) may fail through no fault of either party.
p_89.problematic_text: as the Title Company may require in order issue the Title Policy
p_89.user_recommendation: Confirm Title Company requirements during due diligence.
p_89.model_instructions: Add a sentence at the end: 'Seller agrees to cooperate with Buyer to identify any such documentation requirements of the Title Company during the Due Diligence Period. If the Title Company's requirements cannot be satisfied through commercially reasonable efforts, the parties shall cooperate in good faith to identify an alternative title insurer acceptable to Buyer.'

p_90.title: Closing Statement Requires Only Seller Approval
p_90.description: The closing statement is required to be 'approved in writing by Seller' but there is no corresponding requirement for Buyer approval. This creates an asymmetry where Seller controls the final closing statement without Buyer having a contractual right to review and approve prorations, credits, and adjustments. If the closing statement contains errors or unfavorable calculations, Buyer has no explicit contractual protection to require corrections before closing.
p_90.user_recommendation: Add requirement for Buyer's written approval of closing statement.
p_90.model_instructions: Revise the clause to require mutual approval of the closing statement by adding 'and Buyer' after 'Seller'. The revised text should read: 'A closing statement prepared in writing by Escrow Holder and approved in writing by Seller and Buyer;' This ensures both parties must approve the final accounting before closing proceeds.

p_92.title: Unlimited Additional Document Obligation on Seller
p_92.description: While this clause obligates Seller to deliver additional documents 'reasonably required' to close, the phrasing is open-ended and could be interpreted narrowly by Seller. The phrase 'or otherwise to close the Escrow' is broad but may not capture all documents Buyer needs for post-closing operations (such as complete tenant files, vendor information, building systems documentation, etc.). This catch-all provision could be strengthened to ensure Buyer receives all operational documents necessary for property management.
p_92.problematic_text: reasonably required by Escrow Holder or otherwise to close the Escrow
p_92.user_recommendation: Expand to include documents reasonably required by Buyer for property operations.
p_92.model_instructions: Revise the clause to explicitly include Buyer's reasonable requests and post-closing operational needs. Replace 'reasonably required by Escrow Holder or otherwise to close the Escrow' with 'reasonably required by Escrow Holder, Buyer, or the Title Company to close the Escrow and to enable Buyer to assume ownership and operation of the Property'. This ensures Buyer can request necessary operational documents as part of closing deliveries.

p_93.title: Delivery Timing Framework Mirrors Seller Section
p_93.description: This introductory clause for Buyer deliveries appropriately mirrors the structure of Seller's delivery obligations (Section 11.3). However, Buyer should ensure that all specific timeframes referenced in sub-sections are reasonable and achievable. The parenthetical 'or within such timeframe as may be more specifically provided below' creates flexibility but Buyer should verify no compressed timelines exist in the specific delivery requirements.
p_93.problematic_text: On or before the Closing Date (or within such timeframe as may be more specifically provided below)
p_93.user_recommendation: Review all sub-section timeframes to confirm they are achievable.
p_93.model_instructions: No change required to this clause. However, during review, confirm that any specific timeframes referenced in Sections 11.4(i) through 11.4(vii) (or however many sub-sections exist) provide Buyer adequate time to prepare and deliver all required documents. If any compressed timeframes are identified, flag for negotiation.

p_96.title: Lease Assignment Execution Requirement
p_96.description: This clause requires Buyer to execute the Assignment and Assumption of Leases, which is standard. However, Buyer should review the form attached as Exhibit D carefully, as execution of this document will bind Buyer to assume all landlord obligations under the Leases from the Conveyance Date forward. The form should be reviewed in conjunction with representations about lease status (Section 7.1(ii)) and any tenant estoppel requirements (Section 5.4(iv)).
p_96.problematic_text: Assignment and Assumption of Leases duly executed by Buyer
p_96.user_recommendation: Verify Exhibit D form includes appropriate landlord liability cutoff date.
p_96.model_instructions: Review Exhibit D (Assignment and Assumption of Leases form) to confirm: (1) Buyer's assumption of obligations is limited to obligations arising or accruing from and after the Conveyance Date; (2) Seller retains liability for pre-closing landlord defaults or obligations; (3) the indemnification provisions in the Assignment form are mutual and appropriately balanced. Cross-reference with p_301 (Assignor indemnification of Assignee) and p_303 (Assignee assumption) to ensure consistency.

p_100.title: Open-Ended Closing Document Requirement
p_100.description: This clause creates an unlimited obligation for Buyer to deliver 'any other documents' that are 'reasonably required by Escrow Holder or otherwise to close the Escrow.' The phrase 'or otherwise' is dangerously vague and could be interpreted to require Buyer to execute documents beyond those contemplated in the Agreement. This open-ended language could be used by Seller or Escrow Holder to demand additional documents, guarantees, or instruments at closing that Buyer never agreed to provide, potentially as a condition to closing.
p_100.problematic_text: Any other documents, instruments, records, correspondence or agreements called for hereunder which have not previously been delivered, or which are reasonably required by Escrow Holder or otherwise to close the Escrow and consummate the purchase of the Property in accordance with the terms hereof.
p_100.user_recommendation: Add 'reasonably' qualifier and limit to documents consistent with Agreement terms.
p_100.model_instructions: Revise to read: 'Such other documents and instruments as are expressly required under this Agreement and which have not previously been delivered, or which are reasonably required by Escrow Holder to effectuate the transfer of title in accordance with this Agreement; provided, however, that Buyer shall not be required to deliver any document that would (i) materially expand Buyer's obligations beyond those set forth in this Agreement, (ii) create any new representations, warranties, or indemnities, or (iii) impose any liability on Buyer not expressly contemplated herein.'

amplified_by.effect: If Buyer refuses to provide demanded documents, Seller could claim Buyer default and retain deposit as liquidated damages

p_101.title: Uncertain 'Customary' Closing Costs Allocation
p_101.description: The clause allocates recording fees and 'all other costs' based on what is 'customary for the county' without defining what those customs are or providing a fallback if customs are disputed. This creates uncertainty about Buyer's financial obligations and could lead to disputes at closing. The phrase 'all other costs and charges of the escrow' is also vague and could include unexpected fees.
p_101.problematic_text: Recording fees and all other costs and charges of the escrow for the sale shall be paid in the manner customary for the county in which the Property is located or, if there is no custom, shall be split equally between Buyer and Seller.
p_101.user_recommendation: Specify exact closing cost allocation or cap Buyer's share of unspecified costs.
p_101.model_instructions: Replace with specific allocation: 'Recording fees for the Deed shall be paid by Buyer. Recording fees for releases of existing liens and encumbrances shall be paid by Seller. All other customary closing costs shall be split equally between Buyer and Seller, provided that in no event shall Buyer be responsible for any single closing cost item exceeding $[amount] or aggregate unspecified closing costs exceeding $[amount] without Buyer's prior written consent. The parties agree that the following costs are included in 'customary closing costs': [list specific items].'

p_101.title: Buyer Bears All Extended Coverage and Endorsement Costs
p_101.description: While standard for commercial transactions, Buyer is responsible for all incremental costs of extended title coverage and any endorsements. Depending on the complexity of title and lender requirements, these costs could be substantial. The clause provides no cap or estimate of these costs.
p_101.problematic_text: Buyer shall pay the incremental premium to obtain "extended" coverage and the cost of any endorsements to the Title Policy requested by Buyer or its lender
p_101.user_recommendation: Consider negotiating Seller contribution to endorsements required to cure title issues.
p_101.model_instructions: Add language: 'Notwithstanding the foregoing, Seller shall pay the cost of any endorsements required to insure over or cure any title exceptions that Seller is obligated to remove pursuant to Section 4 of this Agreement, including but not limited to gap coverage, any endorsements necessitated by matters first appearing on title after the Effective Date, and any endorsements required to insure over matters created by Seller's actions or omissions.'

mitigated_by.effect: Seller's obligation to convey clear title may require Seller to address issues that would otherwise require costly endorsements

p_102.title: Buyer Bears Risk of Uncollected Rents
p_102.description: The proration is based on 'rents actually collected' as of Closing, meaning if tenants are delinquent, Buyer receives no credit for unpaid rent even though Buyer will own the property going forward. Combined with the delinquent rent provisions in p_103, Buyer may have difficulty collecting arrears that Seller allowed to accumulate, while Seller has no incentive to aggressively pursue collections pre-closing.
p_102.problematic_text: Rents actually collected, property taxes and assessments for the then current year shall be prorated at the Closing effective as of the Closing Date.
p_102.user_recommendation: Request credit for accrued but uncollected rent above a threshold, or holdback.
p_102.model_instructions: Revise to add protection: 'Rents actually collected shall be prorated at the Closing effective as of the Closing Date. In addition, if any tenant is more than thirty (30) days delinquent in rent payments as of the Closing Date, Buyer shall receive a credit against the Purchase Price equal to fifty percent (50%) of such delinquent amounts (the "Delinquency Credit"). If Buyer subsequently collects any portion of such delinquent amounts, Buyer shall remit to Seller the portion of collections attributable to the pre-Closing period, up to the amount of the Delinquency Credit, after first applying such collections to current rent obligations. Alternatively, Seller may elect to retain such delinquent amounts in escrow pending collection, to be disbursed in accordance with Section 11.7.'

mitigated_by.effect: Buyer retains right to collect delinquent rents post-closing with allocation to Seller

amplified_by.effect: As-is clause may limit Buyer's recourse if delinquencies result from property condition issues

p_102.title: Indefinite Tax Adjustment Obligation
p_102.description: The clause requires tax adjustments after closing when final tax amounts become known, but provides no time limit for when such adjustments must be claimed or made. This creates an open-ended obligation that could extend well beyond closing, and lacks specificity on mechanics of payment. There is also no materiality threshold—any difference, no matter how small, triggers an adjustment.
p_102.problematic_text: If the Closing occurs before the tax rate is fixed for the then current year, the apportionment of the taxes shall be upon the basis of the tax rate for the preceding year applied to the latest assessed valuation but any difference in ad valorem taxes for the year of sale actually paid by Buyer shall be adjusted between the parties upon receipt of written evidence of the payment thereof.
p_102.user_recommendation: Add deadline for tax adjustment claims and minimum threshold for adjustments.
p_102.model_instructions: Revise to add limitations: 'If the Closing occurs before the tax rate is fixed for the then current year, the apportionment of taxes shall be based on the tax rate for the preceding year applied to the latest assessed valuation. Upon receipt of the actual tax bill for the year of Closing, the parties shall re-prorate taxes based on the actual amounts; provided, however, that (i) any claim for adjustment must be made in writing within ninety (90) days after the party seeking adjustment receives the final tax bill, (ii) no adjustment shall be required if the aggregate difference is less than $1,000, and (iii) payment of any adjustment shall be made within thirty (30) days of written demand accompanied by reasonable supporting documentation. This obligation shall survive Closing for a period of eighteen (18) months.'

p_102.title: Security Deposit Credit Based on Seller Disclosure
p_102.description: Buyer receives credit for security deposits based on what was 'paid to Seller' and 'disclosed on the Rent Roll,' but Buyer has limited ability to verify actual deposit amounts held. If Seller's records are inaccurate or deposits have been improperly applied, Buyer may not receive full credit and could face tenant claims for deposits Buyer never received.
p_102.problematic_text: Buyer shall be entitled to a credit against the Purchase Price for the total sum of all refundable security deposits paid to Seller by tenants under any Leases affecting the Property, except for deposits which have been credited or refunded to tenants as disclosed on the Rent Roll, or are expressly nonrefundable to tenants pursuant to their Leases.
p_102.user_recommendation: Require Seller representation on deposit accuracy and indemnity for undisclosed deposits.
p_102.model_instructions: Add protective language: 'Seller represents and warrants that the security deposit amounts shown on the Rent Roll attached as Exhibit [_] are true, correct, and complete in all material respects, and that no security deposits have been applied, credited, or refunded except as expressly noted thereon. Seller shall indemnify and hold Buyer harmless from any claims by tenants for security deposits in excess of the amounts credited to Buyer at Closing, which indemnity shall survive Closing for a period of [eighteen (18) months / the applicable statute of limitations]. At Buyer's request, Seller shall provide bank statements or other documentation evidencing the security deposits held as of a date within ten (10) days of Closing.'

mitigated_by.effect: Seller's representation on rent roll accuracy provides some recourse, though subject to knowledge qualifier and survival limits

amplified_by.effect: Short survival period for representations limits time to discover deposit discrepancies
As-is clause may be argued to limit Buyer's recourse for deposit issues

p_103.title: Delinquent Rent Priority Disfavors Buyer
p_103.description: The waterfall for applying delinquent rent collections prioritizes current rent owed to Buyer first, but then pays collection costs second and Seller's pre-closing delinquencies third. This means Buyer must actively pursue collections, incur costs, and only then can Seller recover its past-due amounts. However, if a tenant pays only partial amounts, Buyer's current rent is covered but Buyer bears the ongoing collection burden with no compensation for administrative efforts beyond 'reasonable outside collection costs.' More importantly, the order could be restructured to better protect Buyer by ensuring Buyer receives all post-closing rent before any application to Seller's delinquencies.
p_103.problematic_text: shall be applied in the following order of priority, with respect to the applicable lease: (i) first, to any rent then due to Buyer for the month in which the Closing occurs or any subsequent month(s) for which rent is then delinquent; (ii) second, to pay reasonable outside collection costs incurred by the party collecting such rent; and (iii) third, to Seller to the extent of any rents delinquent as of the Closing Date
p_103.user_recommendation: Add buyer compensation for collection efforts beyond outside costs
p_103.model_instructions: Revise the payment waterfall to: (1) add a provision requiring Buyer to be compensated for internal administrative costs of collection (e.g., $250 per delinquent account pursued), not just 'outside collection costs'; (2) clarify that 'reasonable outside collection costs' includes attorney fees if collection requires legal action; and (3) consider adding a time limit (e.g., 90 days post-closing) after which Buyer has no obligation to pursue delinquent rents on Seller's behalf and may retain all collections as compensation for ongoing tenant relationship management.

amplified_by.effect: If rents are prorated as of Closing, Seller gets credit for unpaid rent that may never be collected

p_103.title: Seller Retains Post-Closing Collection Rights
p_103.description: Seller reserves the right to collect delinquent rents directly from tenants after Closing. While Seller cannot terminate leases or evict tenants, Seller's collection efforts could interfere with Buyer's tenant relationships, create confusion about payment obligations, and potentially harass tenants that Buyer wishes to retain. There is no requirement for Seller to coordinate with Buyer or limit collection methods.
p_103.problematic_text: Seller reserves the right after Closing to collect delinquent rents from tenants for periods prior to the Closing Date, provided that Seller shall have no right to terminate the lease of any such tenant or to evict any such tenant from the Property after the Closing Date
p_103.user_recommendation: Require Seller to coordinate collection efforts with Buyer
p_103.model_instructions: Add the following limitations on Seller's post-closing collection rights: (1) Seller must provide Buyer with written notice at least 10 business days before initiating any collection action against a tenant; (2) Seller may not engage collection agencies, file lawsuits, or report tenants to credit bureaus without Buyer's prior written consent; (3) Seller's collection efforts must cease upon written request from Buyer if Buyer determines such efforts are adversely affecting the tenant relationship or Property operations; (4) Seller's collection rights terminate 180 days after Closing, after which all rights to delinquent rent are assigned to Buyer; and (5) Seller shall indemnify Buyer for any damages caused by Seller's post-closing collection activities.

mitigated_by.effect: Seller cannot terminate leases or evict tenants, limiting most aggressive collection tactics

p_104.title: Vague Estimation Process for Pass-Through Credits
p_104.description: When the excess Operating Expense Pass-throughs cannot be determined at Closing, Buyer receives a credit 'based upon an estimate' with no specified methodology, standards, or dispute resolution mechanism. This creates uncertainty about how the estimate will be calculated, who prepares it, and what happens if the parties disagree on the estimate amount.
p_104.problematic_text: if the excess cannot be determined at Closing, Buyer shall receive a credit based upon an estimate, and the parties shall make an adjusting payment between them when the correct amount can be determined
p_104.user_recommendation: Specify estimation methodology and who controls calculation
p_104.model_instructions: Replace the vague estimation language with: 'if the excess cannot be determined at Closing, Buyer shall receive a credit equal to the greater of (a) 105% of Seller's reasonable good-faith estimate of the excess, supported by documentation of the calculation methodology, or (b) the average monthly Operating Expense Pass-through collections for the six months preceding Closing multiplied by the number of months in the applicable reconciliation period. The estimate shall be prepared by Seller and delivered to Buyer at least five (5) business days before Closing for Buyer's review. Any adjusting payment shall be made within thirty (30) days after the correct amount is determined, with interest at the rate of [Prime + 2%] on any underpayment from Closing Date to payment date.'

mitigated_by.effect: Section 1I provides a 60-day reconciliation process that will eventually determine correct amounts

p_104.title: Buyer Bears Tenant Repayment Obligation
p_104.description: Buyer is made responsible for crediting or repaying excess Operating Expense Pass-throughs to tenants, but there is no express indemnification from Seller if the amounts credited to Buyer at Closing prove insufficient to cover actual tenant repayment obligations. If Seller's estimates are low, Buyer could be out-of-pocket.
p_104.problematic_text: In either event, Buyer shall be responsible for crediting or repaying those amounts to the appropriate tenants
p_104.user_recommendation: Add Seller indemnification for any shortfall in credits
p_104.model_instructions: After the sentence ending with 'to the appropriate tenants,' add: 'Seller shall indemnify and hold Buyer harmless from any liability to tenants for Operating Expense Pass-through overpayments attributable to Seller's period of ownership to the extent such liability exceeds the credit received by Buyer at Closing. Such indemnification obligation shall survive Closing for a period of eighteen (18) months.'

mitigated_by.effect: Post-closing reconciliation process should capture any shortfalls

p_105.title: Seller Controls Reconciliation Calculation Timing
p_105.description: Seller has 60 days post-closing to prepare the final Operating Expense Pass-through calculation. This gives Seller significant time to prepare figures in its favor while Buyer must rely on Seller's records and calculation methodology. Additionally, there is no deadline for when the final adjusting payment must be made after Buyer's review period, potentially leaving disputes unresolved indefinitely.
p_105.problematic_text: Within 60 days after closing, Seller shall prepare and present to Buyer a final calculation of Operating Expense Pass-throughs for Seller's period of ownership
p_105.user_recommendation: Shorten Seller's calculation period and add payment deadline
p_105.model_instructions: Revise the timing provisions as follows: (1) reduce Seller's calculation period from 60 days to 45 days; (2) add after Buyer's 60-day review period: 'Any disputes regarding the calculations shall be submitted to an independent certified public accountant mutually selected by the parties (or, if the parties cannot agree, selected by the American Arbitration Association) within 30 days after the expiration of Buyer's review period, whose determination shall be final and binding. The cost of such accountant shall be borne by the party whose position is further from the accountant's determination.'; (3) add: 'Any adjusting payment due from either party shall be paid within fifteen (15) days after final determination of the correct amounts, with interest at [Prime + 2%] per annum from Closing Date on any amount owed by Seller.'

mitigated_by.effect: Buyer has 60 days to review Seller's calculations

p_105.title: Buyer Bears Under-Collection Recovery Risk
p_105.description: If Seller under-collected Operating Expense Pass-throughs, the adjustment between the parties occurs only 'after year-end billing to and receipt from said tenants.' This means Buyer must first successfully collect the under-collected amounts from tenants before receiving reimbursement from Seller. If tenants dispute or refuse to pay, Buyer bears the collection risk and may never recover funds owed to Seller's period of ownership.
p_105.problematic_text: If Seller under-collected payments of Operating Expense Pass-throughs for any tenant's share of such expenses, an adjustment will be made between the parties after year-end billing to and receipt from said tenants
p_105.user_recommendation: Require Seller to bear under-collection risk for its ownership period
p_105.model_instructions: Replace the under-collection provision with: 'If Seller under-collected payments of Operating Expense Pass-throughs for any tenant's share of such expenses during Seller's period of ownership, Seller shall be entitled to reimbursement from Buyer only to the extent Buyer actually collects such amounts from the applicable tenants within twelve (12) months after year-end billing. Buyer shall use commercially reasonable efforts to collect such amounts but shall have no obligation to initiate litigation or incur legal fees to collect under-payments attributable to Seller's ownership period. Buyer shall provide Seller with monthly reports on collection status. Any amounts not collected within the twelve-month period shall be deemed uncollectible and Seller shall have no further claim thereto.'

amplified_by.effect: Similar collection risk exists for delinquent rents, compounding Buyer's exposure

p_105.title: Buyer Protected from Undisclosed Pre-Closing Expenses
p_105.description: This provision helpfully states that no expense related to ownership or operation 'shall be charged to or paid or assumed by Buyer...other than those obligations expressly assumed by Buyer.' This is actually FAVORABLE to Buyer and provides important protection. However, it should be cross-referenced with Seller's representations to ensure consistency and should survive closing.
p_105.problematic_text: No other expense related to the ownership or operation of the Property shall be charged to or paid or assumed by Buyer, whether allocable to any period before or after the Closing, other than those obligations expressly assumed by Buyer
p_105.user_recommendation: Confirm this protection survives closing and add indemnification
p_105.model_instructions: After the existing sentence, add: 'The foregoing protection shall survive Closing and Seller shall indemnify, defend, and hold Buyer harmless from any claims, costs, expenses, or liabilities arising from expenses or obligations of ownership or operation of the Property allocable to any period prior to Closing that are not expressly assumed by Buyer hereunder. This indemnification obligation shall survive Closing for a period of [eighteen (18) months/two (2) years].' Also add a cross-reference: 'This provision is in addition to, and not in limitation of, Seller's representations and warranties under Section 7 hereof.'

p_106.title: Broad Buyer Indemnification for Seller's TI Obligations
p_106.description: Buyer is required to indemnify and hold Seller harmless from 'all claims, losses, liabilities and expenses (including attorneys' fees and costs)' related to the In Process TI Work, but only 'to the extent of the funds escrowed.' This creates ambiguity—if a claim exceeds the escrowed funds, is Buyer's indemnification capped at the escrow amount or is Buyer fully exposed? The phrase 'to the extent of' is unclear. Additionally, the indemnification covers work that Seller contracted for and may have been improperly scoped or defectively begun.
p_106.problematic_text: To the extent of the funds escrowed for such purpose, Buyer shall defend, indemnify and hold Seller harmless from all claims, losses, liabilities and expenses (including attorneys' fees and costs) incurred by or asserted against Seller and related to the In Process TI Work
p_106.user_recommendation: Cap indemnification at escrowed funds and exclude Seller's negligence
p_106.model_instructions: Revise the indemnification provision to read: 'Buyer's obligation to indemnify Seller shall be strictly limited to the funds actually held in escrow for In Process TI Work and shall not exceed such amount under any circumstances. Buyer shall have no indemnification obligation for (i) claims arising from Seller's negligence, willful misconduct, or breach of contract with contractors or tenants prior to Closing, (ii) defects in the design, specifications, or work product completed prior to Closing, (iii) disputes with contractors regarding work performed or amounts invoiced prior to Closing, or (iv) any claims by tenants arising from Seller's failure to timely commence or properly perform tenant improvement obligations. Seller shall remain primarily liable for all claims arising from the foregoing and shall indemnify Buyer for the same.'

mitigated_by.effect: The 'to the extent of' language suggests some limitation on exposure

amplified_by.effect: The AS-IS provision could be argued to extend to TI work conditions

p_106.title: Vague Standard for TI Work Cost Agreement
p_106.description: The amount to be escrowed for In Process TI Work is determined by costs 'as reasonably agreed by Buyer and Seller during the Due Diligence Period.' There is no mechanism for resolving disputes if the parties cannot agree, no requirement for contractor bids or third-party estimates, and no contingency for cost overruns. If costs exceed the escrow amount, Buyer must fund the shortfall and seek reimbursement from Seller.
p_106.problematic_text: such costs as reasonably agreed by Buyer and Seller during the Due Diligence Period shall be withheld from the Purchase Price at Closing
p_106.user_recommendation: Require contractor estimates and contingency; add dispute mechanism
p_106.model_instructions: Replace the cost determination language with: 'Seller shall provide Buyer, no later than ten (10) days before the expiration of the Due Diligence Period, with (a) a detailed scope of all In Process TI Work, (b) copies of all contracts and change orders related thereto, (c) a certified statement from Seller's contractor(s) of the estimated cost to complete, and (d) evidence of all amounts paid to date. The amount to be escrowed shall equal 115% of the contractor's certified estimate of remaining costs (to provide a contingency for unforeseen costs). If the parties cannot agree on the escrow amount, the matter shall be determined by an independent construction consultant selected by the Title Company, whose determination shall be binding. If actual costs exceed the escrowed amount, Seller shall reimburse Buyer for such excess within ten (10) days of demand, and Seller's obligation shall be secured by [a holdback from proceeds/a letter of credit/personal guaranty].'

amplified_by.effect: Short due diligence period may not allow adequate time to assess TI work costs

p_106.title: Buyer Only 'Consults' on TI Work Completion
p_106.description: Buyer is required only to 'consult with Seller's contractors and project managers regarding the completion of such work.' This suggests Seller's contractors remain in control of the work despite Buyer owning the Property. Buyer should have full authority to direct the work, hire replacement contractors if necessary, and make decisions about completion.
p_106.problematic_text: Buyer shall consult with Seller's contractors and project managers regarding the completion of such work
p_106.user_recommendation: Give Buyer full control over TI work completion post-closing
p_106.model_instructions: Replace 'Buyer shall consult with Seller's contractors and project managers regarding the completion of such work' with: 'Effective upon Closing, Buyer shall have full authority and control over the completion of the In Process TI Work, including the right to (i) direct Seller's contractors in the performance of the work, (ii) approve or reject work product, (iii) negotiate and approve change orders, (iv) terminate Seller's contractors for cause and engage replacement contractors, and (v) make all decisions regarding the scope, timing, and quality of the work. Seller shall cooperate with Buyer and, upon request, shall assign to Buyer all of Seller's rights under contracts with contractors and project managers related to the In Process TI Work.'

p_106.title: Escrow Funds Released Without Verification
p_106.description: The provision states that escrow funds 'shall be released to Buyer without any requirement for the consent of Seller and shall be used by Buyer to pay the landlord's share of such tenant improvements.' While this gives Buyer flexibility, it could create disputes if Seller believes funds are being misapplied. The lack of documentation requirements could also create issues with the escrow holder.
p_106.problematic_text: Any funds held in the escrow shall be released to Buyer without any requirement for the consent of Seller and shall be used by Buyer to pay the landlord's share of such tenant improvements and allowances
p_106.user_recommendation: Add disbursement procedures while maintaining Buyer control
p_106.model_instructions: Revise to read: 'Funds held in escrow shall be released to Buyer upon Buyer's written request to Escrow Holder, which request shall include a certification that the funds will be used for In Process TI Work. Seller's consent shall not be required for any such release. Buyer agrees to maintain records of all expenditures from escrow funds and shall provide Seller with a summary accounting within thirty (30) days after completion of all In Process TI Work or full disbursement of escrowed funds, whichever occurs first. Such accounting obligation shall not limit or delay Buyer's right to receive disbursements.'

p_108.title: Escrow Closing Conditions Incomplete
p_108.description: The conditions for Escrow Holder to close include only (i) recording the Deed, and (ii) Seller receiving payment when Title Company is ready to deliver the Title Policy. This section does not expressly incorporate Buyer's conditions precedent from Section 5D, which include delivery of Seller's closing documents, truth of representations, and estoppel delivery. If Escrow Holder closes without all Buyer conditions being satisfied, Buyer may have closed without contractual protections.
p_108.problematic_text: when and only when each of the following conditions have been satisfied
p_108.user_recommendation: Add express reference to Buyer's conditions precedent in Section 5D
p_108.model_instructions: After subsection (ii), add the following conditions: '(iii) all conditions precedent to Buyer's obligation to close set forth in Section 5.4 have been satisfied or waived by Buyer in writing; (iv) Escrow Holder has received written confirmation from Buyer that Buyer is prepared to close; and (v) Seller has deposited all items required under Section 11.3 into escrow.' Also add: 'Notwithstanding anything to the contrary herein, Escrow Holder shall not close the Escrow or record any documents without the express written authorization of both Buyer and Seller (or their respective counsel), which authorization may be provided by email.'

mitigated_by.effect: Section 5D sets forth additional conditions that should prevent closing

amplified_by.effect: Conditions may be deemed waived if Buyer proceeds to close

p_108.title: Deed Recording Sequence Risk
p_108.description: The provision contemplates that Escrow Holder will close by 'causing the Deed to be recorded' and 'delivering the Closing Payment... to Seller.' Standard practice requires confirmation of collected funds before recording. The clause should clarify that recording occurs only after funds have been verified as collected/cleared.
p_108.problematic_text: close the Escrow on the Closing Date by (i) causing the Deed to be recorded in the Recorder's Office of the county in which the Property is located, and (ii) delivering the Closing Payment and the Deposit to Seller
p_108.user_recommendation: Clarify that deed records only after funds are verified collected
p_108.model_instructions: Revise the opening of Section 12.1 to read: 'Escrow Holder shall close the Escrow on the Closing Date by (i) first, confirming that the Closing Payment has been received in collected funds by Escrow Holder, (ii) then, causing the Deed to be recorded in the Recorder's Office of the county in which the Property is located, and (iii) upon confirmation of recording, delivering the Closing Payment and the Deposit to Seller and delivering the other funds and documents as provided in this Agreement...'

p_109.title: Undefined Document Delivery Standard
p_109.description: The condition that 'all funds and documents have been delivered' lacks specificity about which documents are required and what constitutes proper delivery. This vagueness could allow Seller to argue Buyer has not satisfied a condition when minor or disputed items remain outstanding, potentially delaying or preventing closing. There is no mechanism to resolve disputes about whether delivery has occurred.
p_109.problematic_text: All funds and documents have been delivered to Escrow Holder
p_109.user_recommendation: Cross-reference specific document lists from Sections 11.3 and 11.4.
p_109.model_instructions: Revise to read: 'All funds required under Section 3 and all documents required under Sections 11.3 (Seller's Deliveries) and 11.4 (Buyer's Deliveries) have been delivered to Escrow Holder in the form required by this Agreement.' This creates clear, verifiable standards tied to specific contract sections rather than a vague 'all documents' requirement.

p_110.title: Title Company Readiness Subjective Standard
p_110.description: The condition that Title Company be 'prepared to deliver' the Title Policy introduces subjectivity. There is no standard for what 'prepared' means—the Title Company could delay indefinitely by claiming it is not yet 'prepared' without breaching any obligation. This could delay closing or give Seller leverage to claim Buyer's conditions are unsatisfied if Buyer has any responsibility for title matters.
p_110.problematic_text: Title Company is prepared to deliver the Title Policy
p_110.user_recommendation: Require Title Company to irrevocably commit or issue the policy.
p_110.model_instructions: Revise to read: 'Title Company has irrevocably committed to issue, or has issued, the Title Policy in accordance with Section 4.4, subject only to the recording of the Deed and payment of the applicable premium.' This creates an objective, verifiable standard and aligns with Section 5.4(ii) which already uses 'irrevocably committed' language for Buyer's conditions precedent.

p_111.title: Interest Allocation Before Closing Favors Buyer
p_111.description: This provision allocates pre-closing interest on deposited funds to Buyer, which is favorable. However, the clause lacks specificity on what happens to interest if the transaction terminates—particularly important if Buyer terminates during due diligence and is entitled to deposit return. The provision should clarify that interest follows the deposit in all termination scenarios.
p_111.problematic_text: Interest accruing to such account prior to the Closing shall be for the account of Buyer
p_111.user_recommendation: Clarify interest follows deposit upon any termination and return.
p_111.model_instructions: Add clarifying language: 'Interest accruing to such account prior to the Closing shall be for the account of Buyer. In the event this Agreement is terminated and the Deposit is returned to Buyer pursuant to Section 6 or otherwise, all accrued interest shall be returned to Buyer along with the Deposit.' This ensures Buyer receives the full benefit of its funds during any holding period.

p_112.title: Seller May Redirect Closing Funds
p_112.description: The phrase 'or as Seller may otherwise direct' allows Seller to redirect the entire purchase price to third parties without Buyer's consent or verification. While common in commercial transactions, this creates risk that funds could be diverted to parties with adverse claims, creating title or lien issues for Buyer post-closing. Buyer has no ability to object or verify the propriety of such directions.
p_112.problematic_text: to Seller, or as Seller may otherwise direct
p_112.user_recommendation: Require Buyer approval for non-standard disbursement instructions.
p_112.model_instructions: Revise to read: 'Escrow Holder shall disburse the Closing Payment and the Deposit to Seller in accordance with wiring instructions provided by Seller pursuant to Section 12.2(b); provided, however, that if Seller directs disbursement to any party other than Seller, such direction must be provided in writing at least three (3) business days prior to Closing, and Buyer shall have the right to object to any such disbursement direction that Buyer reasonably believes may create an adverse claim against the Property.' This protects Buyer from potential fraud or improper diversions.

p_113.title: No Timeline for Deed Delivery to Buyer
p_113.description: While this provision requires the recorded Deed to be delivered to Buyer, there is no timeline specified. Buyer could close and fund without receiving evidence of title transfer for an extended period. The provision also does not address what happens if recording is rejected or delayed by the county recorder's office.
p_113.problematic_text: Escrow Holder shall cause the recorded Deed to be delivered to Buyer
p_113.user_recommendation: Add delivery timeline and procedure for recording failures.
p_113.model_instructions: Revise to read: 'Escrow Holder shall cause the Deed to be recorded in the Official Records of [County] County promptly following Closing, and shall deliver to Buyer a conformed copy of the recorded Deed within five (5) business days after recording. In the event the Deed is rejected for recording, Escrow Holder shall immediately notify both parties and the parties shall cooperate to cure any defect; provided that Seller shall be responsible for curing any defect arising from Seller's execution or the form of the Deed.' This creates accountability and a process for addressing recording issues.

p_114.title: Ambiguous Entitlement Standard for Escrow Items
p_114.description: The phrase 'entitled thereto or benefited thereby' provides no objective standard for determining which party receives disputed items from escrow. In the event of a dispute between Buyer and Seller regarding entitlement to documents, deposits, or other escrowed items, this vague language gives the Escrow Holder discretion that could harm Buyer's interests. There is no mechanism for resolving disputes or protecting Buyer's claim to items it may be entitled to receive.
p_114.problematic_text: to the party entitled thereto or benefited thereby
p_114.user_recommendation: Add dispute resolution mechanism and objective criteria for determining entitlement.
p_114.model_instructions: Revise to add clarity: 'Escrow Holder shall deliver all other items deposited into Escrow to the party entitled thereto pursuant to the express terms of this Agreement. In the event of a dispute between Buyer and Seller regarding entitlement to any escrowed item, Escrow Holder shall hold such item pending (a) joint written instructions from both parties, or (b) a final, non-appealable court order directing disbursement.'

p_116.title: Broad Carve-Outs Undermine Liquidated Damages Protection
p_116.description: While the liquidated damages provision limits Seller's remedy to retention of the Deposit, the final sentence carves out Buyer's 'indemnification or repair and restoration obligations under this Agreement' and attorney's fees under Section 15. These carve-outs could expose Buyer to significant additional liability beyond the Deposit. The indemnification obligations in Section 5B(iii) are broadly worded and could result in substantial claims. This undermines the certainty that a liquidated damages provision is meant to provide.
p_116.problematic_text: THE FOREGOING LIMITATION OF REMEDY SHALL NOT APPLY TO BUYER'S INDEMNIFICATION OR REPAIR AND RESTORATION OBLIGATIONS UNDER THIS AGREEMENT, OR BUYER'S COVENANT UNDER SECTION 15 BELOW REGARDING PAYMENT OF ATTORNEYS' FEES.
p_116.user_recommendation: Cap indemnification exposure or clarify that carve-outs only apply post-closing.
p_116.model_instructions: Revise carve-out language to limit Buyer's exposure: 'THE FOREGOING LIMITATION OF REMEDY SHALL NOT APPLY TO (I) BUYER'S INDEMNIFICATION OBLIGATIONS UNDER SECTION 5.2 OF THIS AGREEMENT, PROVIDED THAT SUCH OBLIGATIONS SHALL BE LIMITED TO ACTUAL THIRD-PARTY CLAIMS ARISING FROM BUYER'S PHYSICAL ENTRY ONTO THE PROPERTY PRIOR TO TERMINATION AND SHALL NOT EXCEED [INSERT CAP] IN THE AGGREGATE, (II) BUYER'S REPAIR AND RESTORATION OBLIGATIONS UNDER SECTION 5.2 FOR PHYSICAL DAMAGE ACTUALLY CAUSED BY BUYER'S INSPECTIONS, OR (III) BUYER'S COVENANT UNDER SECTION 15 BELOW REGARDING PAYMENT OF ATTORNEYS' FEES IN ANY ENFORCEMENT ACTION COMMENCED BY SELLER AFTER BUYER'S DEFAULT.'

p_116.title: Broad Definition of Buyer Default
p_116.description: The provision is triggered by 'a DEFAULT UNDER THIS AGREEMENT BY BUYER' without defining what constitutes a default. Minor technical breaches, delays in delivering non-material items, or other foot-faults could potentially be characterized as defaults, resulting in forfeiture of the Deposit. There is no notice requirement, no cure period, and no materiality qualifier before the Deposit is forfeited.
p_116.problematic_text: IF CLOSING FAILS TO OCCUR AS THE RESULT OF A DEFAULT UNDER THIS AGREEMENT BY BUYER
p_116.user_recommendation: Define 'default' and add notice/cure period before forfeiture.
p_116.model_instructions: Revise the trigger language: 'IF CLOSING FAILS TO OCCUR AS THE RESULT OF A MATERIAL DEFAULT BY BUYER IN THE PERFORMANCE OF BUYER'S EXPRESS OBLIGATIONS TO CLOSE UNDER THIS AGREEMENT (INCLUDING BUYER'S FAILURE TO DEPOSIT THE CLOSING PAYMENT OR DELIVER CLOSING DOCUMENTS), WHICH DEFAULT CONTINUES FOR FIVE (5) BUSINESS DAYS AFTER WRITTEN NOTICE FROM SELLER SPECIFYING SUCH DEFAULT'. This limits forfeiture to material defaults directly related to closing obligations and provides a brief cure opportunity.

p_116.title: Escrow Holder Instructed to Release Without Dispute Resolution
p_116.description: The instruction to Escrow Holder to deliver the Deposit to Seller upon Buyer's default lacks any mechanism for Buyer to contest the characterization of default. In practice, Seller could claim default where the facts are disputed, and Escrow Holder may release funds based solely on Seller's assertion. This creates risk of improper forfeiture without recourse.
p_116.problematic_text: THE ESCROW HOLDER IS HEREBY INSTRUCTED BY SELLER AND BUYER TO DELIVER THE DEPOSIT TO SELLER IN SUCH EVENT
p_116.user_recommendation: Require joint written instructions or demand letter before release.
p_116.model_instructions: Revise escrow instructions: 'IN SUCH EVENT, SELLER SHALL DELIVER TO ESCROW HOLDER AND BUYER A WRITTEN NOTICE SPECIFYING THE NATURE OF BUYER'S DEFAULT. IF BUYER FAILS TO OBJECT IN WRITING WITHIN TEN (10) BUSINESS DAYS OF RECEIPT OF SUCH NOTICE, ESCROW HOLDER IS HEREBY INSTRUCTED TO DELIVER THE DEPOSIT TO SELLER. IF BUYER TIMELY OBJECTS, ESCROW HOLDER SHALL CONTINUE TO HOLD THE DEPOSIT PENDING JOINT WRITTEN INSTRUCTIONS OR A FINAL COURT ORDER.'

p_119.title: Buyer Waives Specific Performance and All Damage Claims
p_119.description: This provision requires Buyer to waive specific performance and 'any other damage claims' against a defaulting Seller. This is highly unfavorable to Buyer because: (1) in a rising market, the Property may be worth substantially more than Buyer's out-of-pocket costs, and Buyer loses that appreciation; (2) Buyer cannot compel Seller to close even if Seller simply gets a better offer; (3) the $50,000 cap on expense reimbursement may not cover Buyer's actual costs for legal fees, due diligence, financing costs, and other expenses in complex transactions.
p_119.problematic_text: Buyer expressly waives its right to specific performance, and any other damage claims.
p_119.user_recommendation: Delete waiver of specific performance or add carve-out for willful breach.
p_119.model_instructions: Delete the sentence 'Buyer expressly waives its right to specific performance, and any other damage claims.' and replace with: 'Notwithstanding the foregoing, in the event of Seller's willful default or Seller's conveyance of the Property to a third party in breach of this Agreement, Buyer shall be entitled to pursue specific performance of Seller's obligations hereunder in addition to the remedies set forth above.' This preserves Buyer's right to the bargained-for property in cases of bad faith by Seller.

p_119.title: Expense Reimbursement Capped at $50,000
p_119.description: Buyer's recovery for Seller's default is limited to return of the Deposit plus actual out-of-pocket costs capped at $50,000. In a commercial real estate transaction, Buyer's due diligence costs alone (environmental reports, surveys, appraisals, legal fees, engineering studies, lender costs) often exceed this amount. If Seller defaults close to closing, Buyer may have incurred substantially greater expenses that cannot be recovered.
p_119.problematic_text: Buyer's actual out-of-pocket third party costs and expenses in connection with this transaction in no event to exceed Fifty Hundred Thousand Dollars ($50,000)
p_119.user_recommendation: Increase cap to at least $150,000-$250,000 or remove cap entirely.
p_119.model_instructions: Replace '$50,000' with a higher cap appropriate to the transaction size, such as '$250,000' or '1% of the Purchase Price, whichever is greater'. Alternatively, revise to: 'together with all of Buyer's actual out-of-pocket third party costs and expenses in connection with this transaction, including without limitation due diligence costs, lender fees, legal fees, and consultant fees, which shall be documented by reasonable evidence of payment.'

p_119.title: Asymmetric Default Remedies Favor Seller
p_119.description: The remedy structure is significantly asymmetric: Buyer forfeits its entire Deposit upon default (p_116), while Seller's maximum exposure for default is return of Deposit plus $50,000. This creates moral hazard where Seller has minimal downside risk from default but Buyer faces full forfeiture. This asymmetry incentivizes Seller to default if it receives a better offer or market conditions change.
p_119.problematic_text: Buyer's sole remedy shall be to terminate this Agreement and receive the Deposit [(plus accrued interest)], together with an additional sum from Seller equal to Buyer's actual out-of-pocket third party costs and expenses in connection with this transaction in no event to exceed Fifty Hundred Thousand Dollars ($50,000)
p_119.user_recommendation: Negotiate for liquidated damages from Seller equal to Deposit amount.
p_119.model_instructions: Revise to create symmetry: 'then, upon notice by Buyer to Seller and Escrow Holder to that effect, at Buyer's election, Buyer may either (a) pursue specific performance of Seller's obligations to convey the Property, or (b) terminate this Agreement and receive the Deposit (plus accrued interest), together with liquidated damages from Seller in an amount equal to the Deposit, plus reimbursement of Buyer's actual out-of-pocket third party costs and expenses in connection with this transaction.' This creates equivalent exposure for both parties.

p_119.title: Buyer's Remedy Conditioned on All Seller Conditions Being Satisfied
p_119.description: Buyer's remedies for Seller's default are only available 'if all other conditions to Seller's obligations to consummate the sale of the Property to be satisfied as of the date of such default or failure of condition have been satisfied.' This means if any Seller condition precedent (e.g., Buyer's closing conditions under Section 5E) is unsatisfied, Seller could avoid liability for its default. Seller could engineer a condition failure to escape default liability.
p_119.problematic_text: if all other conditions to Seller's obligations to consummate the sale of the Property to be satisfied as of the date of such default or failure of condition have been satisfied at the time of such default or failure
p_119.user_recommendation: Revise to exclude conditions frustrated by Seller's own breach.
