p_119.model_instructions: Revise the conditional language: 'and if all other conditions to Seller's obligations to consummate the sale of the Property required to be satisfied as of the date of such default have been satisfied at the time of such default (other than conditions the non-satisfaction of which was caused by or results from Seller's default)'. This prevents Seller from using its own breach to manufacture an excuse from liability.

p_120.title: Material Damage Threshold Left Blank
p_120.description: The materiality threshold for damage that triggers Buyer's termination right is left blank ('$_________'). Without a defined threshold, there will be disputes about whether damage is 'material' and whether Buyer has the right to terminate. This creates significant uncertainty in a casualty scenario.
p_120.problematic_text: For purposes hereof, damage is material if the reasonable estimated cost of repair exceeds $_________.
p_120.user_recommendation: Insert specific dollar threshold (e.g., $100,000 or 5% of Purchase Price).
p_120.model_instructions: Insert an appropriate materiality threshold. Suggested language: 'For purposes hereof, damage is material if the reasonable estimated cost of repair exceeds the lesser of (i) $100,000 or (ii) five percent (5%) of the Purchase Price.' The dual test protects Buyer in both high and low-value transactions.

p_120.title: Only 10 Days to Elect Termination After Casualty
p_120.description: Buyer has only 10 days from receipt of Seller's notice to elect termination after a casualty or condemnation. This may be insufficient time to: (1) assess the true extent of damage; (2) obtain contractor estimates; (3) consult with lenders about impacts on financing; (4) evaluate whether insurance proceeds will be adequate. If Buyer fails to elect within 10 days, the right is waived.
p_120.problematic_text: If Buyer does not elect to terminate this Agreement within 10 days of receipt of written notice from Seller of the damage or taking
p_120.user_recommendation: Extend election period to 20-30 days after receipt of damage assessment.
p_120.model_instructions: Revise to provide adequate time: 'If Buyer does not elect to terminate this Agreement within twenty (20) business days of receipt of written notice from Seller of the damage or taking (which notice shall include a reasonably detailed description of the damage, Seller's estimate of repair costs, and information regarding applicable insurance coverage)'. This gives Buyer adequate time with better information.

p_120.title: No Purchase Price Reduction for Non-Material Damage
p_120.description: If damage is not 'material' (below the threshold), Buyer must close at the full Purchase Price and can only receive an assignment of insurance proceeds. However, insurance proceeds may not fully cover repair costs due to deductibles, coverage gaps, or depreciation. Buyer bears the risk of any shortfall between actual repair costs and insurance recovery.
p_120.problematic_text: nor shall the Purchase Price be reduced
p_120.user_recommendation: Add Purchase Price credit for uninsured damage.
p_120.model_instructions: Revise to protect Buyer: 'nor shall the Purchase Price be reduced except that Buyer shall receive a credit against the Purchase Price equal to the amount of any applicable deductible under Seller's casualty insurance policy plus the amount by which actual repair costs (as reasonably estimated by a contractor selected by Buyer and approved by Seller, such approval not to be unreasonably withheld) exceed available insurance proceeds.'

p_120.title: Buyer's Election Period Triggered Only by Seller's Notice
p_120.description: Buyer's 10-day election period runs from 'receipt of written notice from Seller' of the damage. This gives Seller control over when the clock starts. Seller could delay notice to pressure Buyer toward closing, or provide notice at an inconvenient time. There is no requirement that Seller provide prompt notice or that Buyer have independent discovery rights.
p_120.problematic_text: within 10 days of receipt of written notice from Seller of the damage or taking
p_120.user_recommendation: Require prompt notice from Seller and allow Buyer's own discovery to trigger rights.
p_120.model_instructions: Add notice obligation and alternative trigger: 'Seller shall provide written notice to Buyer of any casualty or condemnation within two (2) business days of Seller's knowledge thereof. If Buyer does not elect to terminate this Agreement within twenty (20) business days of the earlier of (x) receipt of written notice from Seller of the damage or taking, or (y) Buyer's actual knowledge of such damage or taking'. This prevents Seller from manipulating timing.

p_121.title: No definition of 'prevailing party'
p_121.description: The clause awards attorneys' fees to the 'prevailing party' but does not define what constitutes prevailing. In mixed-outcome litigation where each party wins some claims and loses others, courts may struggle to determine the prevailing party, or may find no prevailing party exists, leaving Buyer unable to recover fees even after substantially winning. This ambiguity could result in protracted satellite litigation over fee entitlement.
p_121.problematic_text: who is the prevailing party in any legal proceeding
p_121.user_recommendation: Add definition of 'prevailing party' including partial success scenarios.
p_121.model_instructions: Insert a definition clarifying that 'prevailing party' means the party who achieves the primary relief sought or who obtains a net favorable judgment on the principal claims in controversy, and that the court shall have discretion to apportion fees in mixed-outcome cases where neither party clearly prevails.

amplified_by.effect: If Buyer must litigate to recover deposit after improper Seller termination claim, fee recovery uncertainty compounds financial exposure

p_121.title: Fee recovery limited to signatories only
p_121.description: The fee-shifting provision applies only to 'signatories' of the Agreement. If Buyer needs to bring or defend claims against Seller's principals, guarantors, affiliates, or agents who are not signatories, this provision would not apply, potentially leaving Buyer without fee recovery even if successful in related litigation.
p_121.problematic_text: Any signatory to this Agreement who is the prevailing party in any legal proceeding against any other signatory
p_121.user_recommendation: Expand to include affiliates, principals, and agents of signatories.
p_121.model_instructions: Revise to read: 'Any signatory to this Agreement, or any affiliate, principal, agent, or successor thereof, who is the prevailing party in any legal proceeding against any other signatory or its affiliates, principals, agents, or successors brought in connection with this Agreement or the transaction contemplated hereby...'

p_122.title: No deemed delivery for refused notices
p_122.description: While the provision addresses 'refusal to accept delivery,' it does not clearly specify when a refused notice is deemed effective. The clause states notice is 'deemed to have been given upon the date of actual receipt or delivery (or refusal to accept delivery)' but requires 'written or electronic confirmation of such delivery or refusal.' If Seller refuses delivery and the courier cannot obtain confirmation of refusal, Buyer may be unable to prove effective notice, potentially causing missed deadlines for due diligence objections, termination, or other critical time-sensitive matters.
p_122.problematic_text: as evidenced by the notifying party's receipt of written or electronic confirmation of such delivery or refusal
p_122.user_recommendation: Add deemed delivery provision for refusal or evasion of delivery.
p_122.model_instructions: Add the following sentence after the existing text: 'Notwithstanding the foregoing, if a party refuses delivery or evades attempts at delivery, notice shall be deemed effective on the date of such refusal or, in the case of evasion, on the third business day after the first attempted delivery, provided the notifying party can demonstrate reasonable evidence of such refusal or attempted delivery.'

amplified_by.effect: Short 10-day title review period makes notice delivery failures particularly damaging
Due diligence termination rights depend on timely notice

p_122.title: No provision for certified mail delivery
p_122.description: The notice provision permits only personal delivery, overnight courier, or electronic transmission. Certified mail with return receipt requested is a common and legally reliable method of delivery that provides clear evidence of receipt, but is not permitted here. While not critical, this limits Buyer's delivery options and backup methods.
p_122.problematic_text: (i) personally delivered, (ii) sent by Federal Express or similar nationally recognized overnight courier service, or (iii) electronically transmitted
p_122.user_recommendation: Add certified/registered mail as permitted notice method.
p_122.model_instructions: Revise the enumerated list to add: '(iv) sent by United States certified or registered mail, return receipt requested, postage prepaid, in which case notice shall be deemed given three (3) business days after deposit in the mail.'

p_122.title: Incomplete notice addresses in document
p_122.description: The provision references 'the addresses of the parties shall be as follows' but the actual addresses are not fully visible in this section. Buyer should verify that complete and accurate addresses for Seller and all required copy recipients are included in the executed agreement, including any address changes that may have occurred since drafting.
p_122.problematic_text: For the purposes of notice, the addresses of the parties shall be as follows:
p_122.user_recommendation: Verify all party addresses are complete and accurate before execution.
p_122.model_instructions: Ensure the notice section includes complete street addresses, city, state, zip code, and email addresses for both Buyer and Seller, as well as for their respective counsel and any other required copy recipients. Consider adding a provision that notice to counsel alone is insufficient to constitute notice to a party.

p_130.title: Incomplete copy recipient information
p_130.description: The copy provision only shows a law firm name without complete contact information. If this is intended as required copy to Buyer's or Seller's counsel, incomplete information could result in failed delivery and arguments that notice was ineffective.
p_130.problematic_text: Copies to:	Fikso Kretschmer Smith Dixon Ormseth P.S.
p_130.user_recommendation: Include complete address, email, and specify whether copy is required.
p_130.model_instructions: Complete the copy recipient information to include full street address, city, state, zip code, attention line, email address, and telephone/fax numbers. Also clarify whether delivery of copies to counsel is required for effective notice or merely courtesy, by adding: 'Copies to counsel are for convenience only and failure to deliver copies shall not affect the validity of notice to the party.'

p_152.title: Broad integration clause excludes all prior negotiations
p_152.description: This integration clause is absolute and provides that the Agreement 'contains the complete agreement' and 'cannot be varied except by the written agreement of the parties.' Combined with the statement that 'there are no oral agreements, understandings, representations or warranties that are not expressly set forth herein,' this effectively eliminates any claim Buyer might have based on pre-contractual representations made by Seller or its brokers during negotiations. If Seller made material representations about the Property during negotiations that induced Buyer to enter the agreement, Buyer has waived reliance on those representations.
p_152.problematic_text: The parties agree that there are no oral agreements, understandings, representations or warranties that are not expressly set forth herein.
p_152.user_recommendation: Negotiate carve-out for fraudulent or intentional misrepresentations.
p_152.model_instructions: Add the following at the end of the integration clause: 'Notwithstanding the foregoing, nothing in this Section shall be deemed to limit any claim by Buyer based on fraud, intentional misrepresentation, or the willful concealment of material information by Seller or its agents.' Alternatively, ensure all material representations made during negotiations are incorporated into Section 7A as express warranties.

mitigated_by.effect: Express representations in Section 7A provide some protection, but are narrowly drafted with knowledge qualifiers

amplified_by.effect: AS-IS clause combined with integration clause creates comprehensive waiver of reliance on any non-written statements
Release provision further limits claims Buyer can bring

p_152.title: No specification of modification requirements
p_152.description: The clause states the Agreement 'cannot be varied except by the written agreement of the parties' but does not specify whether modifications must be signed by authorized representatives, whether email constitutes sufficient 'writing,' or whether specific formalities are required. This could create disputes about whether informal written communications constitute binding modifications.
p_152.problematic_text: cannot be varied except by the written agreement of the parties
p_152.user_recommendation: Specify that modifications require signed written amendment by authorized representatives.
p_152.model_instructions: Revise to read: 'cannot be varied except by a written amendment signed by authorized representatives of both parties. No course of dealing, course of performance, or informal written communication (including email) shall be deemed to modify, amend, or waive any provision hereof unless expressly stated in a signed writing.'

p_153.title: Successors and Assigns Limited by Agreement
p_153.description: The phrase 'where permitted by this Agreement' effectively subordinates the binding effect on successors and assigns to the restrictions found elsewhere in the Agreement (specifically Section 9/p_154). This means the Agreement's benefits may not automatically flow to Buyer's assignees if Seller's consent is required and withheld. While this is standard protective language, combined with the assignment restrictions in Section 9, it limits Buyer's flexibility in structuring its acquisition through related entities or bringing in co-investors post-signing.
p_153.user_recommendation: Ensure assignment rights in Section 9 are adequate for Buyer's transaction structure.
p_153.model_instructions: Review Section 9 (p_154) assignment provisions in conjunction with this clause. Consider whether additional permitted assignees should be included in Section 9, such as (i) any entity formed for the purpose of acquiring the Property, (ii) institutional investors or co-investors, or (iii) any qualified intermediary for 1031 exchange purposes. If Buyer anticipates bringing in equity partners or restructuring the acquisition vehicle, negotiate broader assignment rights in Section 9 to ensure this binding effect clause does not inadvertently limit Buyer's flexibility.

amplified_by.effect: Assignment restrictions require Seller consent for most transfers, limiting who can benefit from this binding effect clause

p_154.title: Buyer Assignment Requires Seller Consent
p_154.description: Buyer cannot assign its interest under the Agreement without Seller's prior written consent, which is not qualified by any 'not to be unreasonably withheld' standard. This gives Seller absolute discretion to block any assignment outside of the affiliate exception, potentially trapping Buyer in the transaction even if legitimate business reasons exist for an assignment (such as bringing in an institutional co-investor, syndicating the deal, or assigning to a joint venture). This could prevent Buyer from effectuating common transaction structures.
p_154.problematic_text: Buyer may not assign its interest under this Agreement without Seller's prior written consent
p_154.user_recommendation: Add 'which consent shall not be unreasonably withheld, conditioned or delayed.'
p_154.model_instructions: Modify the assignment consent requirement to add 'which consent shall not be unreasonably withheld, conditioned, or delayed.' Additionally, consider expanding the list of permitted assignees beyond just controlled affiliates to include: (i) any entity in which Buyer or its principals hold a controlling interest, (ii) any qualified intermediary or exchange accommodation titleholder in connection with a 1031 exchange, (iii) any institutional investor or fund managed by Buyer's sponsor, and (iv) any joint venture in which Buyer or its affiliate is a managing member or general partner. Also consider adding a provision that Buyer shall not be released from liability for any assignee that is not creditworthy to Seller's reasonable satisfaction, which may make Seller more willing to accept broader assignment rights.

mitigated_by.effect: Buyer can assign to controlled affiliates without consent, which covers some restructuring scenarios

amplified_by.effect: If Buyer cannot assign and cannot close, deposit may be at risk as liquidated damages

p_154.title: Control Definition May Exclude Common Structures
p_154.description: The definition of 'control' requires 'ownership of a majority of the beneficial interest' AND 'managerial control.' This conjunctive standard may exclude legitimate acquisition structures where Buyer has managerial control but not majority economic interest (common in joint ventures with institutional capital partners), or where a sponsor controls the entity through contractual rights rather than majority ownership. Many real estate investment structures involve passive majority investors with a sponsor maintaining control through management rights.
p_154.problematic_text: "control" and similar terms mean ownership of a majority of the beneficial interest in, and managerial control over the assignee entity
p_154.user_recommendation: Broaden 'control' to include managerial control alone, regardless of economic ownership.
p_154.model_instructions: Revise the definition of 'control' to be more flexible and reflective of common real estate ownership structures. Replace the current definition with: '"control" and similar terms mean (i) ownership of a majority of the beneficial interest in the assignee entity, or (ii) managerial control over the assignee entity (including but not limited to control exercised by the managing member of a limited liability company, the general partner of a limited partnership, or pursuant to contractual management rights), regardless of the percentage of beneficial ownership held.' This revision uses 'or' instead of 'and' and recognizes that managerial control can exist without majority economic ownership.

amplified_by.effect: If Buyer's intended structure doesn't meet the narrow 'control' definition, Seller consent is required

p_154.title: Buyer Remains Liable After Permitted Assignment
p_154.description: The assignment provision is silent on whether Buyer is released from its obligations after a permitted assignment to an affiliate. While this is common in PSAs and may be acceptable, Buyer should be aware that even after assigning to a controlled entity, the original Buyer may remain liable for the assignee's performance obligations. This could expose the original signing entity to liability even after it has divested its interest.
p_154.problematic_text: Buyer may assign this Agreement to any entity which controls, is controlled by, or is under common control with Buyer, upon prior written notice to Seller
p_154.user_recommendation: Consider adding that Buyer is released upon assignment to a creditworthy assignee.
p_154.model_instructions: Consider adding the following language at the end of the assignment provision: 'Upon any permitted assignment hereunder (whether to an affiliate or otherwise with Seller's consent), the original Buyer shall be released from all obligations hereunder arising from and after the date of such assignment, provided that the assignee assumes in writing all of Buyer's obligations under this Agreement.' Alternatively, if Seller is unlikely to agree to a full release, consider adding: 'provided that the original Buyer shall remain liable for the performance of the assignee only with respect to the obligation to close and pay the Purchase Price, and shall have no liability for any post-Closing obligations assumed by such assignee.'

p_155.title: No Affirmative Obligation to Facilitate 1031 Exchange
p_155.description: While the provision states parties 'will cooperate,' it is heavily qualified by limitations that neither party shall incur additional cost, advance excess monies, or cause delays. This essentially converts the cooperation obligation into a passive, no-cost accommodation rather than an affirmative duty to facilitate. If Buyer's 1031 exchange requires any accommodation that could be characterized as causing 'delays' or involving any indirect cost, Seller could refuse to cooperate.
p_155.problematic_text: neither party shall incur additional cost or expense on the other party's behalf, and shall not be required to advance or deposit monies in excess of amounts required by this Agreement for purchase of the subject Property, and such exchange shall not cause any delays in the time periods or Closing Date specified in this Agreement
p_155.user_recommendation: Clarify that reasonable accommodations not materially delaying Closing are required.
p_155.model_instructions: Revise the 1031 exchange provision to provide more meaningful cooperation while protecting against material prejudice. Consider: 'Seller and/or Buyer may wish to effect an IRC Section 1031 tax-deferred exchange, and each party agrees to cooperate reasonably in facilitating such exchange, including executing such documents and taking such actions as may be reasonably required to effectuate such exchange; provided, however, (i) the cooperating party shall not be required to incur any material out-of-pocket cost or expense (unless reimbursed by the exchanging party), (ii) the cooperating party shall not be required to take title to any property other than as contemplated by this Agreement, (iii) the exchanging party shall indemnify and hold harmless the cooperating party from any liability arising from such exchange, and (iv) the Closing Date shall not be extended by more than five (5) business days to accommodate such exchange without the other party's consent.'

amplified_by.effect: Strict closing date requirements may make it impossible to accommodate 1031 exchange timing needs

p_155.title: No Extension of Closing for Exchange Purposes
p_155.description: The provision explicitly prohibits any delays to 'time periods or Closing Date' to accommodate a 1031 exchange. This is particularly problematic because 1031 exchanges often require precise timing coordination with qualified intermediaries, identification of replacement property, and other logistical matters. If Buyer's exchange fails due to this rigid timing, Buyer could lose significant tax deferral benefits. Even a short extension of a few days could be critical for exchange completion.
p_155.problematic_text: such exchange shall not cause any delays in the time periods or Closing Date specified in this Agreement
p_155.user_recommendation: Negotiate ability to extend Closing by 3-5 business days for exchange coordination.
p_155.model_instructions: Modify the no-delay provision to permit limited flexibility for exchange purposes: 'such exchange shall not cause any delays in the time periods or Closing Date specified in this Agreement; provided, however, that the exchanging party may, upon written notice delivered at least five (5) business days prior to the scheduled Closing Date, extend the Closing Date by up to five (5) business days solely to coordinate the logistics of such exchange, and provided further that such extension shall only be permitted once and shall not extend the Closing Date beyond [insert outside date].' This gives Buyer a narrow but meaningful accommodation for exchange timing while limiting Seller's exposure to extended uncertainty.

p_156.title: Fixed Venue May Be Inconvenient for Buyer
p_156.description: Venue is fixed in a specific Washington county (to be filled in). Depending on Buyer's location and the Property's location, this may or may not be convenient. Buyer should confirm this is an appropriate venue and that the specified county has jurisdiction over the Property and the parties. If Buyer is an out-of-state entity, litigating disputes in Washington state court may be inconvenient and costly.
p_156.problematic_text: Venue for any dispute under this Agreement shall be in _________ County, Washington
p_156.user_recommendation: Confirm venue is appropriate; consider permitting federal court as alternative.
p_156.model_instructions: Review the venue provision for appropriateness given Buyer's business location and the Property location. Consider the following modifications: (i) ensure the blank is filled with the county where the Property is located, which is typically most convenient for property-related disputes; (ii) consider adding 'or in the United States District Court for the Western/Eastern District of Washington' to provide federal court as an alternative venue for diversity jurisdiction cases; (iii) if Buyer prefers arbitration, consider adding: 'Notwithstanding the foregoing, any party may elect to submit any dispute to binding arbitration in accordance with the Commercial Arbitration Rules of the American Arbitration Association, which arbitration shall be conducted in [City], Washington.' Also confirm that Washington choice of law is appropriate for this transaction.

p_157.title: No Reformation or Modification Provision
p_157.description: The severability clause only provides for provisions to be treated 'as if' they were never contained in the Agreement. It does not include a reformation provision that would allow a court to modify an unenforceable provision to make it enforceable to the maximum extent permitted by law. Additionally, there is no savings clause addressing what happens if a severed provision was material to the parties' bargain, potentially leaving the remainder of the agreement unbalanced.
p_157.problematic_text: this Agreement shall be construed as if such invalid, illegal, or unenforceable provision had never been contained herein
p_157.user_recommendation: Add reformation language to modify rather than delete unenforceable provisions.
p_157.model_instructions: Consider enhancing the severability provision with reformation and savings language: 'In case any one or more of the provisions contained in this Agreement shall for any reason be held to be invalid, illegal, or unenforceable in any respect, such invalidity, illegality, or unenforceability shall not affect any other provision hereof, and such provision shall be reformed and construed so that it will be valid, legal, and enforceable to the maximum extent permitted by applicable law. If such provision cannot be so reformed, this Agreement shall be construed as if such invalid, illegal, or unenforceable provision had never been contained herein; provided, however, that if the removal of such provision would materially and adversely alter the economic bargain of this Agreement, the parties shall negotiate in good faith to amend this Agreement to restore the parties to their original intended positions as closely as possible.'

p_158.title: Exhibits Incorporated Without Verification
p_158.description: This clause incorporates all exhibits by reference without any provision requiring Buyer to verify that all referenced exhibits are actually attached, complete, and accurate. If an exhibit is missing, incomplete, or contains unfavorable terms, Buyer would still be bound by whatever was purportedly 'attached.' This creates risk that Seller could later claim certain terms were part of an exhibit that Buyer did not review. The clause also provides no mechanism for addressing conflicts between the main agreement and exhibits.
p_158.problematic_text: All exhibits attached hereto are incorporated herein by this reference.
p_158.user_recommendation: Add language requiring all exhibits to be listed and attached at execution.
p_158.model_instructions: Revise to read: 'All exhibits attached hereto and listed on Schedule [X] are incorporated herein by this reference. Buyer acknowledges receipt of all such exhibits prior to execution. In the event of any conflict between the terms of this Agreement and any exhibit, the terms of this Agreement shall control unless the exhibit expressly states otherwise.'

amplified_by.effect: The integration clause prevents Buyer from arguing exhibits were not properly disclosed

p_160.title: Extension Limited to Certain Deadlines
p_160.description: While this provision extends performance dates that fall on non-business days, it only applies to dates for 'performance of any act.' This may not clearly extend notice deadlines, option exercise periods, or approval periods that expire (rather than require affirmative acts). A deadline expiring on a Saturday could trap Buyer if the clause is narrowly construed. Additionally, this provision may not extend deadlines triggered by elapsed time periods (e.g., '10 days after receipt') if the calculation results in a weekend.
p_160.problematic_text: If the date for performance of any act under this Agreement falls on a Saturday, Sunday or federal holiday
p_160.user_recommendation: Clarify that all deadlines, including expiration dates, are extended.
p_160.model_instructions: Revise to read: 'If the date for performance of any act, the expiration of any period, or any deadline under this Agreement falls on a Saturday, Sunday or federal holiday, such date shall automatically be extended to the first succeeding business day. For purposes of calculating any time period measured in days, Saturdays, Sundays, and federal holidays shall be included in the calculation, but if the resulting date falls on a Saturday, Sunday, or federal holiday, performance shall be due on the next business day.'

p_161.title: Seller May Continue Marketing During Due Diligence
p_161.description: This clause expressly permits Seller to continue marketing the Property and negotiating with other potential buyers until expiration of the Due Diligence Period and satisfaction of all Buyer conditions. This is highly unusual and seller-favorable. Buyer is exposed to being used as a stalking horse while Seller shops for better offers. Buyer invests time and money in due diligence with no assurance Seller will not accept a competing offer. This undermines Buyer's exclusivity despite having a signed PSA and deposit at risk.
p_161.problematic_text: Seller shall have the right to continue to market the Property and/or to negotiate with other potential Buyers of the Property until the expiration of the Due Diligence Period and the satisfaction or waiver in writing of all conditions to the obligations of Buyer under this Agreement
p_161.user_recommendation: Delete Seller's right to market or require exclusivity upon deposit.
p_161.model_instructions: Delete the sentence beginning 'Buyer understands and agrees that Seller shall have the right to continue to market the Property...' in its entirety. Alternatively, if Seller insists on some protection, replace with: 'Upon Buyer's delivery of the Initial Deposit, Seller agrees not to market the Property, solicit offers, or negotiate with any third party for the sale of the Property during the pendency of this Agreement.'

amplified_by.effect: The longer the due diligence period, the longer Buyer is exposed to being shopped
If Buyer terminates after being shopped, Buyer loses deposit

p_161.title: Integration Clause Disclaims All Prior Representations
p_161.description: The integration clause states there are no 'oral contracts, representations, conditions, or warranties, express or implied, in addition to this Agreement.' This disclaims any representations made by Seller or Seller's broker during negotiations that are not expressly included in the Agreement. If Seller or its agents made material statements about the Property during marketing (income projections, tenant quality, condition issues, etc.), Buyer cannot rely on them unless written into the PSA. This significantly limits Buyer's fraud and misrepresentation claims.
p_161.problematic_text: there being no oral contracts, representations, conditions, or warranties, express or implied, in addition to this Agreement
p_161.user_recommendation: Add carve-out for fraud and intentional misrepresentation.
p_161.model_instructions: Add the following at the end of the first sentence: '; provided, however, that nothing in this Section shall limit Buyer's remedies for fraud or intentional misrepresentation by Seller or its agents, regardless of whether such representations are contained in this Agreement.'

amplified_by.effect: The AS-IS clause combined with integration makes it nearly impossible to pursue claims based on pre-contract statements

p_162.title: No Prejudice to Buyer's Waiver Rights
p_162.description: While this clause is facially mutual, it confirms that Buyer's failure to enforce a Seller breach does not waive future enforcement. However, the clause could be strengthened to clarify that Buyer's acceptance of partial performance or delayed performance does not waive strict compliance going forward, particularly for closing conditions and delivery obligations.
p_162.problematic_text: No waiver of any default by Buyer or Seller hereunder shall be implied from any omission by the other party to take any action on account of such default if such default persists or is repeated
p_162.user_recommendation: Add language preserving Buyer's right to insist on strict compliance.
p_162.model_instructions: Add the following sentence at the end: 'Buyer's acceptance of any partial or delayed performance by Seller, or Buyer's failure to object to any non-conforming tender, shall not waive Buyer's right to require strict compliance with all terms of this Agreement with respect to any future performance.'

p_163.title: Mutual Confidentiality May Limit Buyer's Flexibility
p_163.description: The confidentiality provision requires both parties to keep Agreement terms confidential and prohibits public announcements without consent. While this is mutual, it may hamper Buyer's ability to: (1) discuss the transaction with potential joint venture partners or equity sources not yet identified; (2) make required disclosures if Buyer is a public company or REIT; (3) discuss the transaction with potential replacement tenants or property managers during due diligence; (4) comply with legal or regulatory disclosure requirements. The exception for 'lenders, partners, consultants and professional advisors' may be too narrow.
p_163.problematic_text: Seller and Buyer agree to keep the terms of this Agreement confidential and not make any public announcements or disclosures with respect to the subject matter hereof without the prior written consent of the other party
p_163.user_recommendation: Expand permitted disclosure list and add carve-out for required disclosures.
p_163.model_instructions: Revise to read: 'Seller and Buyer agree to keep the terms of this Agreement confidential and not make any public announcements or disclosures with respect to the subject matter hereof without the prior written consent of the other party (which consent shall not be unreasonably withheld, conditioned, or delayed); provided that each party may disclose the terms of this Agreement (a) to its lenders, potential lenders, investors, potential investors, partners, potential partners, attorneys, accountants, consultants, property managers, brokers, and professional advisors as necessary or convenient for the completion of this transaction or the financing or syndication thereof; (b) as required by applicable law, regulation, court order, or securities filing requirements; and (c) in connection with any dispute arising out of this Agreement.'

p_163.title: No Remedy Specified for Confidentiality Breach
p_163.description: The confidentiality provision does not specify remedies for breach. Without specifying that injunctive relief is available and that the non-breaching party need not prove irreparable harm, Buyer may have difficulty enforcing this provision if Seller makes unauthorized disclosures that harm Buyer's negotiating position with tenants or damage the transaction.
p_163.problematic_text: Seller and Buyer agree to keep the terms of this Agreement confidential
p_163.user_recommendation: Add provision for injunctive relief without need to prove irreparable harm.
p_163.model_instructions: Add the following at the end of the section: 'Each party acknowledges that a breach of this Section 18 may cause irreparable harm to the other party for which monetary damages would be inadequate, and the non-breaching party shall be entitled to seek injunctive relief, specific performance, and other equitable remedies without the necessity of proving actual damages or posting a bond.'

p_164.title: Unlimited Further Instruments Obligation
p_164.description: This provision creates an open-ended obligation for Buyer to execute additional documents 'as often as' requested by Seller, with no limitation on the scope, timing, or number of such requests. While subject to a 'reasonable opinion' standard, this is determined by the requesting party (Seller), not objectively. This could require Buyer to execute documents post-closing that were not contemplated at closing, potentially expanding Buyer's obligations or affecting title/rights in unanticipated ways.
p_164.problematic_text: whenever and as often as it shall be requested so to do by the other, cause to be executed, acknowledged or delivered any and all such further instruments and documents as may be necessary or proper, in the reasonable opinion of the requesting party
p_164.user_recommendation: Add time limit and scope restrictions on further instruments requests.
p_164.model_instructions: Modify the provision to: (1) add a time limitation (e.g., 'for a period of six (6) months following Closing'); (2) clarify that such instruments shall not impose any additional material obligations, liabilities, or costs on the non-requesting party beyond those contemplated by this Agreement; (3) change 'reasonable opinion of the requesting party' to 'mutual reasonable agreement of the parties' or 'objectively necessary'; and (4) add that the non-requesting party shall not be required to execute any instrument that would expand its representations, warranties, or indemnification obligations.

p_164.title: No Cost Allocation for Further Instruments
p_164.description: The provision does not address which party bears the costs associated with preparing, executing, acknowledging, or delivering further instruments. Buyer could be required to incur significant legal and administrative costs to comply with Seller's post-closing requests.
p_164.problematic_text: cause to be executed, acknowledged or delivered any and all such further instruments and documents
p_164.user_recommendation: Require requesting party to bear all costs of further instruments.
p_164.model_instructions: Add the following language at the end of the provision: 'The requesting party shall bear all reasonable costs and expenses, including attorneys' fees, incurred by the non-requesting party in connection with the preparation, review, execution, acknowledgment, and delivery of any such further instruments and documents.'

p_166.title: Uncapped Broker Indemnification Survives Closing
p_166.description: Buyer provides an unlimited, uncapped indemnification to Seller for any broker claims arising through Buyer. This indemnity expressly survives Closing with no time limitation, unlike the limited survival period for Seller's representations (Section 7.3 provides only 9 months). The indemnity includes 'any and all claims, liabilities, costs and expenses' with no cap, creating potentially unlimited exposure for Buyer if a broker makes a claim, even years after closing.
p_166.problematic_text: each agrees to and does hereby indemnify and hold the other harmless against the payment of any commission to any person or entity claiming by, through or under Seller or Buyer, as applicable.  This indemnification shall extend to any and all claims, liabilities, costs and expenses (including reasonable attorneys' fees and litigation costs) arising as a result of such claims and shall survive the Closing
p_166.user_recommendation: Add cap and survival period consistent with rep survival at Section 7.3.
p_166.model_instructions: Modify the indemnification provision to: (1) add a cap on Buyer's indemnification obligation (e.g., 'not to exceed the Purchase Price' or a specific dollar amount); (2) add a survival period consistent with other representations and warranties (e.g., 'This indemnification shall survive the Closing for a period of nine (9) months'); and (3) add a notice and opportunity to defend provision requiring prompt notice of any claim and allowing the indemnifying party to control the defense.

p_166.title: Express Unlimited Survival for Broker Section
p_166.description: The final sentence states this Section 'shall expressly survive any Closing or any termination of this Agreement' with no time limitation. This creates asymmetric treatment compared to Seller's representations which survive only 9 months (Section 7.3). Buyer's broker indemnity exposure could continue indefinitely while Seller's representation exposure expires quickly.
p_166.problematic_text: This Section 31 shall expressly survive any Closing or any termination of this Agreement.
p_166.user_recommendation: Limit survival to 9 months consistent with Section 7.3.
p_166.model_instructions: Replace 'This Section 31 shall expressly survive any Closing or any termination of this Agreement.' with 'This Section shall survive the Closing or any termination of this Agreement for a period of nine (9) months, consistent with the survival period for representations and warranties set forth in Section 7.3.'

p_166.title: Incorrect Section Cross-Reference
p_166.description: The survival provision references 'Section 31' but this appears to be Section 21 based on the document structure. This drafting error could create ambiguity about which section's survival is being addressed, potentially affecting enforceability or interpretation.
p_166.model_instructions: Change 'This Section 31' to 'This Section 21' or simply 'This Section' to avoid any numbering confusion and ensure the survival provision clearly applies to the broker indemnification obligations.

p_167.title: Waiver of Statutory Disclosure Rights
p_167.description: Buyer is waiving its statutory right under Washington law (RCW Ch. 64.06) to receive the Seller Disclosure Statement. While the Environmental section is carved out, Buyer loses the right to receive disclosures about structural issues, systems, title matters, and other material conditions that could affect the Property. This waiver eliminates a statutory protection designed to ensure buyers receive material information about property conditions.
p_167.problematic_text: BUYER HEREBY WAIVES ITS RIGHT TO RECEIVE THE SELLER DISCLOSURE STATEMENT REFERRED TO THEREIN.  THIS WAIVER DOES NOT EXTEND TO THE SECTION OF THE DISCLOSURE STATEMENT ENTITLED "ENVIRONMENTAL".
p_167.user_recommendation: Consider requiring full Seller Disclosure Statement, not just Environmental section.
p_167.model_instructions: Consider deleting this waiver provision entirely and requiring Seller to provide the complete Seller Disclosure Statement pursuant to RCW Ch. 64.06. If the waiver must remain, add the following carve-out language: 'This waiver does not extend to the sections entitled "Environmental," "Structural," "Systems and Fixtures," "Title," and "Homeowners' Association/Common Interest." Additionally, nothing in this waiver shall limit Seller's liability for fraud, intentional misrepresentation, or knowing concealment of material defects.'

p_168.title: Incomplete Waiver Clause - Text Cut Off
p_168.description: This provision appears to be incomplete, with the text cutting off mid-sentence at 'Buyer waive'. This could create ambiguity about what exactly Buyer is waiving and render the provision unenforceable or subject to interpretation disputes. The incomplete language could be construed against Seller (as drafter) or could leave Buyer's rights unclear.
p_168.problematic_text: and by executing this Agreement, Buyer waive
p_168.user_recommendation: Complete the provision or delete incomplete language entirely.
p_168.model_instructions: This provision must be completed to clarify what Buyer is waiving. If this is intended to waive the right to receive the balance of the Seller Disclosure Statement, the complete language should read: 'and by executing this Agreement, Buyer waives its right to receive the balance of the completed Seller Disclosure Statement, other than the Environmental section.' However, Buyer should consider whether this waiver is advisable and may wish to delete this waiver language entirely and require the full Seller Disclosure Statement.

p_168.title: Environmental Disclosure Timing Uses Undefined Term
p_168.description: The provision requires Seller to provide the Environmental section 'during the Review Period,' but the Agreement uses 'Due Diligence Period' as the defined term (Section 5.1). 'Review Period' is not defined, creating ambiguity about when the Environmental disclosure must be delivered and when Buyer's approval period runs. This could affect Buyer's ability to terminate if environmental issues are disclosed late.
p_168.user_recommendation: Change 'Review Period' to 'Due Diligence Period' for consistency.
p_168.model_instructions: Replace 'Review Period' with 'Due Diligence Period' to match the defined term used throughout the Agreement (see Section 5.1). Additionally, consider adding specific timing language such as 'within five (5) business days following the Effective Date' to ensure Buyer has adequate time to review environmental disclosures during the Due Diligence Period.

p_169.title: Waiver of Seller Disclosure Statement
p_169.description: Buyer is waiving its right to receive the complete Seller Disclosure Statement, which under Washington law (RCW 64.06) typically provides important information about the property's condition, known defects, and environmental issues. This waiver limits Buyer's ability to obtain information that Seller may be legally required to disclose and could expose Buyer to unknown property conditions.
p_169.problematic_text: its right to receive the balance of the completed Seller Disclosure Statement
p_169.user_recommendation: Consider requiring full Seller Disclosure Statement or limiting waiver scope.
p_169.model_instructions: Revise to either: (1) delete this waiver and require Seller to provide the complete Seller Disclosure Statement, or (2) add language stating 'Notwithstanding this waiver, Buyer reserves all rights to pursue claims based on Seller's fraud, intentional misrepresentation, or knowing concealment of material defects.' Also consider adding: 'Buyer's waiver of the right to receive the Seller Disclosure Statement shall not affect Buyer's rights under Section 7 (Seller's Representations and Warranties) or any other provision of this Agreement.'

p_170.title: No Right to Updated Disclosures
p_170.description: Buyer waives any right to receive updated or revised Seller Disclosure Statements even if Seller becomes aware of new material information about the property condition after the initial disclosure. This means Seller could learn of significant defects or environmental issues before closing but have no obligation to inform Buyer, leaving Buyer exposed to undisclosed problems.
p_170.problematic_text: Buyer further agrees that any information discovered by Buyer concerning the Property shall not obligate Seller to prepare and deliver to Buyer a revised or updated Seller Disclosure Statement. Buyer hereby waives any right to receive an updated or revised Seller Disclosure Statement, regardless of the source of any new information.
p_170.user_recommendation: Require Seller to disclose newly discovered material defects before closing.
p_170.model_instructions: Revise to add: 'Notwithstanding the foregoing, Seller shall promptly notify Buyer in writing of any material defect, environmental condition, or other matter that would materially adversely affect the Property or its value that Seller becomes aware of after the Effective Date and prior to Closing. Such disclosure obligation shall not be deemed a Seller Disclosure Statement under RCW 64.06 but shall be a covenant of this Agreement, breach of which shall entitle Buyer to terminate this Agreement and receive a return of the Deposit, or to proceed to Closing and pursue claims against Seller for breach.'

p_170.title: Broad Waiver of Reliance on Seller Info
p_170.description: Buyer agrees to acquire the property solely based on its own inspections and 'not on any information provided in any Seller Disclosure Statement or... any information otherwise provided or to be provided by Seller.' This extremely broad language could be interpreted to bar claims for Seller's misrepresentations or fraudulent statements made outside of the formal representations and warranties, significantly limiting Buyer's remedies if Seller provides false information during due diligence.
p_170.problematic_text: will acquire the Property solely on the basis of and in reliance upon such examinations and not on any information provided in any Seller Disclosure Statement or, except as set forth in this Agreement or the Closing documents, any information otherwise provided or to be provided by Seller or by anyone acting or claiming to act by, through or under or on Seller's behalf
p_170.user_recommendation: Carve out fraud and intentional misrepresentation from reliance waiver.
p_170.model_instructions: Revise to read: 'will acquire the Property solely on the basis of and in reliance upon such examinations and the representations and warranties expressly set forth in this Agreement and the Closing documents; provided, however, that nothing in this Section shall limit or waive Buyer's rights or remedies arising from (a) Seller's fraud, intentional misrepresentation, or knowing concealment of material facts, (b) Seller's breach of any representation, warranty, or covenant expressly set forth in this Agreement, or (c) any indemnification obligations of Seller under this Agreement.'

p_170.title: Buyer Warrants Sophistication
p_170.description: Buyer warrants it is a 'sophisticated Buyer' familiar with real estate ownership and development. This warranty could be used by Seller to argue that Buyer should have discovered defects through its inspections or that Buyer cannot claim reliance on any Seller statements because a sophisticated party would have verified independently. This strengthens Seller's defenses against Buyer claims.
p_170.problematic_text: Buyer further warrants that it is a sophisticated Buyer who is familiar with the ownership and development of real estate projects similar to the Property
p_170.user_recommendation: Delete or limit scope of sophistication warranty.
p_170.model_instructions: Delete 'Buyer further warrants that it is a sophisticated Buyer who is familiar with the ownership and development of real estate projects similar to the Property and' OR revise to acknowledge Buyer's sophistication without creating a warranty: 'Buyer acknowledges that it has experience with commercial real estate transactions; provided, however, that such acknowledgment shall not affect Buyer's rights under this Agreement or limit Seller's obligations hereunder.'

p_171.title: Waiver of Statutory Rescission Rights
p_171.description: Buyer waives 'TO THE FULLEST EXTENT PERMISSIBLE BY LAW' its right to rescind the Agreement under RCW 64.06, Washington's seller disclosure statute. This eliminates a statutory protection that would otherwise allow Buyer to rescind if Seller fails to provide required disclosures or provides materially inaccurate disclosures. The prospective nature of this waiver (applying to future updated disclosures) is particularly concerning.
p_171.problematic_text: BUYER HEREBY WAIVES, TO THE FULLEST EXTENT PERMISSIBLE BY LAW, THE RIGHT TO RESCIND THIS AGREEMENT PURSUANT TO ANY PROVISION OF RCW 64.06, AS AMENDED BY CHAPTER 64, LAWS OF 2010
p_171.user_recommendation: Preserve rescission rights for fraud or knowing misrepresentation.
p_171.model_instructions: Revise to add carve-outs: 'BUYER HEREBY WAIVES, TO THE FULLEST EXTENT PERMISSIBLE BY LAW, THE RIGHT TO RESCIND THIS AGREEMENT PURSUANT TO ANY PROVISION OF RCW 64.06, AS AMENDED BY CHAPTER 64, LAWS OF 2010; PROVIDED, HOWEVER, THAT THIS WAIVER SHALL NOT APPLY TO (A) ANY FRAUDULENT, INTENTIONALLY FALSE, OR KNOWINGLY MISLEADING STATEMENTS OR OMISSIONS IN ANY SELLER DISCLOSURE STATEMENT, (B) SELLER'S KNOWING CONCEALMENT OF MATERIAL DEFECTS, OR (C) ENVIRONMENTAL CONDITIONS NOT DISCLOSED IN THE ENVIRONMENTAL SECTION OF THE SELLER DISCLOSURE STATEMENT REQUIRED TO BE DELIVERED PURSUANT TO SECTION 32.'

p_171.title: Disclosure Statement Provides No Rights
p_171.description: The provision states that any Seller Disclosure Statement 'SHALL GIVE BUYER NO RIGHTS WITH RESPECT TO SELLER OR UNDER THIS AGREEMENT.' This could be interpreted to mean that even intentionally false statements in the Seller Disclosure Statement cannot support a claim against Seller, which is an extremely Seller-favorable position that may not be enforceable as to fraud but creates significant litigation risk.
p_171.problematic_text: IT IS THE INTENT OF BUYER THAT ANY SELLER DISCLOSURE STATEMENT PROVIDED BY SELLER WILL NOT BE RELIED UPON BY BUYER, AND SHALL GIVE BUYER NO RIGHTS WITH RESPECT TO SELLER OR UNDER THIS AGREEMENT
p_171.user_recommendation: Add carve-out preserving claims for fraud or intentional misstatement.
p_171.model_instructions: Revise to read: 'IT IS THE INTENT OF BUYER THAT ANY SELLER DISCLOSURE STATEMENT PROVIDED BY SELLER WILL NOT BE RELIED UPON BY BUYER FOR PURPOSES OF ANY NEGLIGENT MISREPRESENTATION CLAIM, AND SHALL GIVE BUYER NO RIGHTS WITH RESPECT TO SELLER OR UNDER THIS AGREEMENT EXCEPT THAT BUYER EXPRESSLY RESERVES ALL CLAIMS AND REMEDIES ARISING FROM SELLER'S FRAUD, INTENTIONAL MISREPRESENTATION, OR KNOWING OMISSION OF MATERIAL INFORMATION IN ANY SELLER DISCLOSURE STATEMENT.'

p_171.title: Disclosure Waiver Survives Closing
p_171.description: The waiver provisions survive closing, meaning Buyer cannot assert any claims based on the Seller Disclosure Statement even after discovering post-closing defects that were required to be but were not disclosed. Combined with the AS-IS provision and other waivers, this significantly limits Buyer's post-closing remedies.
p_171.problematic_text: THE PROVISIONS OF THIS SECTION 32 SHALL SURVIVE THE CLOSING
p_171.user_recommendation: Ensure fraud and intentional misrepresentation claims survive.
p_171.model_instructions: Revise to read: 'THE PROVISIONS OF THIS SECTION 32 SHALL SURVIVE THE CLOSING; PROVIDED, HOWEVER, THAT BUYER'S CLAIMS FOR SELLER'S FRAUD, INTENTIONAL MISREPRESENTATION, OR KNOWING CONCEALMENT OF MATERIAL FACTS SHALL ALSO SURVIVE CLOSING AND SHALL NOT BE LIMITED OR WAIVED BY THIS SECTION 32.'

p_200.title: Property Description Blank
p_200.description: The legal description of the property has blank fields (County and the actual metes and bounds or lot description). While this is clearly a form to be completed, Buyer should ensure the legal description is accurate and complete before signing, and that it matches the title commitment and survey.
p_200.problematic_text: All that certain real property situated in ____________________ County, Washington, as more particularly described as follows:
p_200.user_recommendation: Verify legal description matches title commitment and survey before signing.
p_200.model_instructions: Prior to execution, complete the blank with the correct county name and ensure the complete legal description following this introductory language matches: (1) the legal description in the Title Commitment to be provided under Section 4.1(ii), (2) the survey description, and (3) any property description referenced in the Leases. Consider adding: 'The legal description shall be subject to confirmation by the Title Company and may be revised by mutual agreement of the parties to correct any errors or to conform to the legal description shown on the Survey.'

p_243.title: Special Warranty Deed Limits Title Protection
p_243.description: The deed form is a Special Warranty Deed rather than a General Warranty Deed. This means Seller only warrants title against defects arising during Seller's period of ownership ('by, through or under' Seller), not against title defects that predate Seller's acquisition. Buyer bears the risk of any title defects originating from prior owners, which could include undiscovered liens, encumbrances, adverse claims, or boundary disputes that existed before Seller took title.
p_243.user_recommendation: Negotiate for General Warranty Deed or enhanced title insurance.
p_243.model_instructions: Replace the Special Warranty Deed form with a General Warranty Deed that includes full covenants of seisin, right to convey, against encumbrances, quiet enjoyment, and general warranty. Alternatively, if Seller insists on Special Warranty Deed, negotiate for: (1) enhanced owner's title insurance with extended coverage, (2) Seller's indemnification for known title defects, and (3) representations regarding Seller's knowledge of any title matters arising prior to Seller's ownership.

mitigated_by.effect: Title insurance may cover some defects not warranted by Seller, reducing but not eliminating exposure

amplified_by.effect: AS-IS provision could be argued to limit Buyer's recourse for undisclosed title issues
Express exclusion of implied covenants further narrows Buyer's warranty protection

p_243.title: Personal Property and Intangibles Not Conveyed in Deed
p_243.description: The deed only conveys real property, buildings, improvements, and lessor's interest in leases. It does not convey personal property, service contracts, permits, licenses, warranties, or other intangible property that are part of the purchase under the PSA. Buyer must rely on separate conveyance documents (Bill of Sale, Assignment of Contracts) which could create gaps if those documents are not properly executed or delivered.
p_243.problematic_text: all of its right, title and interest in that certain real property, together with buildings and improvements now or hereafter situated thereon and the lessor's or landlord's interest in all space leases
p_243.user_recommendation: Confirm all conveyance documents are closing deliveries under PSA.
p_243.model_instructions: Verify that the PSA Section 11.3 closing deliveries include all required conveyance documents for the full scope of the Property as defined in Section 1, including: (1) the Deed for real property and improvements, (2) Bill of Sale for personal property, (3) Assignment of Leases, (4) Assignment of Contracts and Intangibles. Add a closing condition requiring delivery of all such documents as a condition to Buyer's obligation to close.

mitigated_by.effect: PSA requires separate documents for personal property and contract assignments at closing

p_244.title: Conveyance Subject to Undefined Exhibit B Exceptions
p_244.description: The deed is expressly subject to matters listed in an Exhibit B that is not provided for review. These 'Permitted Exceptions' could include significant encumbrances, easements, restrictions, or other matters that materially affect Buyer's use and enjoyment of the Property. Without reviewing Exhibit B, Buyer cannot assess what limitations will burden the Property post-closing.
p_244.problematic_text: expressly subject to the matters set forth in Exhibit B attached hereto
p_244.user_recommendation: Require Exhibit B to match only Buyer-approved Permitted Exceptions.
p_244.model_instructions: Add language to the PSA requiring that Exhibit B to the Deed shall consist only of the 'Permitted Exceptions' as defined and approved by Buyer under Section 4 (Title Review). Include a closing condition that Buyer shall have the right to review and approve the final form of Exhibit B prior to closing, and that any matter not previously approved as a Permitted Exception shall not be included. Consider adding: 'Exhibit B shall contain only those title exceptions expressly approved or deemed approved by Buyer pursuant to Section 4B of the Purchase Agreement.'

mitigated_by.effect: Buyer has approval rights over title matters during due diligence, which should define what becomes Permitted Exceptions

amplified_by.effect: AS-IS provision could limit Buyer's post-closing remedies for burdensome exceptions

p_245.title: Express Exclusion of Implied Title Covenants
p_245.description: This provision expressly excludes all covenants that would otherwise arise by statute or implication, limiting Buyer's warranty protection to only those covenants expressly stated in the deed. Under Washington law, a General Warranty Deed would typically include implied covenants of seisin, right to convey, freedom from encumbrances, quiet enjoyment, and general warranty. This language strips away those protections.
p_245.problematic_text: does by these presents expressly limit the covenants of the deed to those herein expressed, and excludes all covenants arising or to arise by statutory or other implication
p_245.user_recommendation: Delete exclusion or negotiate for express inclusion of standard covenants.
p_245.model_instructions: Delete the clause excluding implied covenants, or alternatively modify the deed to expressly include the standard covenants of title: (1) covenant of seisin (Grantor owns the Property), (2) covenant of right to convey, (3) covenant against encumbrances (except Permitted Exceptions), (4) covenant of quiet enjoyment, and (5) covenant of general warranty. If Seller refuses, ensure title insurance provides equivalent protection and consider a separate indemnification agreement for title defects.

mitigated_by.effect: Title insurance provides some protection against title defects regardless of deed covenants

amplified_by.effect: Combined with special warranty limitation, Buyer has minimal contractual title protection

p_245.title: Warranty Limited to Claims Through Grantor Only
p_245.description: The warranty defense obligation is limited to claims 'by, through or under said Grantor and not otherwise.' This means Seller has no obligation to defend Buyer against title claims arising from parties other than those claiming through Seller's chain of title during Seller's ownership. Pre-existing title defects, third-party adverse claims, or boundary disputes from adjacent owners are not covered.
p_245.problematic_text: against all persons whomsoever lawfully claiming or to claim by, through or under said Grantor and not otherwise
p_245.user_recommendation: Negotiate broader warranty or require enhanced title insurance endorsements.
p_245.model_instructions: Modify the warranty language to provide broader protection. Replace 'by, through or under said Grantor and not otherwise' with 'by, through or under said Grantor or any predecessor in title.' Alternatively, delete 'and not otherwise' to preserve some ambiguity in Buyer's favor. If Seller refuses deed modification, require extended coverage title insurance with endorsements for survey matters, access, zoning, and any other identified risks not covered by the limited warranty.

mitigated_by.effect: Title insurance may cover third-party claims not warranted by Seller

p_265.title: Bill of Sale Contains No Warranties on Personal Property
p_265.description: The Bill of Sale form transfers personal property without any express warranties regarding title, condition, or fitness for purpose. Combined with the AS-IS provisions in the PSA, Buyer receives personal property without any assurance that Seller owns it free and clear, that it is in working condition, or that it is fit for its intended use.
p_265.problematic_text: does hereby sell, transfer and convey to
p_265.user_recommendation: Add warranty of title and condition to Bill of Sale.
p_265.model_instructions: Modify the Bill of Sale to include: (1) Warranty of title - 'Seller warrants that it is the lawful owner of the Personal Property, that the Personal Property is free and clear of all liens, claims, and encumbrances, and that Seller has the right to sell and transfer the same'; (2) Consider adding a warranty that the Personal Property is in the same condition as existed during Buyer's due diligence inspection. Reference should be made to any representations in the PSA regarding personal property that survive closing.

mitigated_by.effect: Bill of Sale Exhibit F contains a representation that Seller is lawful owner

amplified_by.effect: AS-IS provision disclaims warranties on personal property condition

p_265.title: Personal Property Limited to Schedule I Items
p_265.description: The Bill of Sale references 'Schedule I' for the list of personal property items, but this schedule is not provided for review. If Schedule I is incomplete or does not match Buyer's understanding of what personal property is included in the sale, Buyer may not receive all items expected. The phrase 'including, without limitation' provides some protection but the scheduled items define the core conveyance.
p_265.problematic_text: including, without limitation, those items described in Schedule I attached hereto
p_265.user_recommendation: Verify Schedule I matches PSA inventory; add catch-all language.
p_265.model_instructions: Ensure Schedule I to the Bill of Sale is prepared and reviewed by Buyer prior to closing. Add language that Schedule I shall include all personal property identified in the Due Diligence Documents or observed during Buyer's property inspections. Consider adding: 'Schedule I shall include, but not be limited to, all furniture, fixtures, equipment, supplies, and other tangible personal property located on or in the Property as of the Effective Date of the Purchase Agreement that is owned by Seller and used in connection with the operation of the Property.'

mitigated_by.effect: The phrase 'including, without limitation' suggests Schedule I is not exhaustive

p_265.title: Bill of Sale Incorporates PSA Terms by Reference
p_265.description: The Bill of Sale incorporates terms of the Purchase Agreement by reference. While this can be protective by preserving PSA rights, it also means any limitations, disclaimers, or AS-IS provisions in the PSA apply to the personal property conveyance. Buyer should understand that the PSA's AS-IS language and survival limitations will govern post-closing claims related to personal property.
p_265.problematic_text: The terms of the Purchase Agreement with respect to this Bill of Sale and the property conveyed in this Bill of Sale are incorporated herein by reference
p_265.user_recommendation: Clarify which PSA terms survive and apply to personal property claims.
p_265.model_instructions: Review the PSA to identify which provisions apply to personal property and confirm they provide adequate protection. Consider adding clarifying language specifying that Seller's representations regarding ownership of personal property (if any) survive closing for the same period as other representations under Section 7C. Confirm that the incorporation by reference does not inadvertently waive claims for breach of personal property representations.

amplified_by.effect: AS-IS provision incorporated by reference disclaims condition warranties
Limited survival period constrains time for personal property claims

p_267.title: Unqualified Personal Property Warranty
p_267.description: Seller provides an absolute representation and warranty that personal property is 'free and clear of all liens, encumbrances, conditional sales contracts, security interests and claims' without any knowledge qualifier. This is broader than the knowledge-qualified representations in Section 7A of the main agreement, creating potential inconsistency. While this benefits Buyer, the lack of a schedule identifying the specific personal property covered makes enforcement difficult and could lead to disputes about scope.
p_267.problematic_text: Seller hereby represents and warrants to Buyer that Seller is the lawful owner of such personal property, and that such personal property is free and clear of all liens, encumbrances, conditional sales contracts, security interests and claims
p_267.user_recommendation: Ensure personal property is specifically identified on attached schedule.
p_267.model_instructions: Add a cross-reference to identify the covered personal property: 'Seller hereby represents and warrants to Buyer that Seller is the lawful owner of the personal property described in the attached Schedule [X] (the "Personal Property"), and that such Personal Property is free and clear of all liens, encumbrances, conditional sales contracts, security interests and claims.' Also consider whether this representation should survive closing consistent with Section 7C survival provisions.

mitigated_by.effect: If this representation is subject to the same survival period in Section 7C, claims must be brought within that limited window

amplified_by.effect: The AS-IS provision may create tension with this warranty if personal property issues arise post-closing

p_267.title: Personal Property Not Specifically Identified
p_267.description: The Bill of Sale references 'such personal property' without a clear definition or attached schedule identifying what personal property is actually being conveyed. This creates significant risk that Buyer may not receive all personal property expected, or disputes may arise about what was included in the sale. The reference to p_284 shows only a placeholder bracket suggesting a schedule should be attached but may not be.
p_267.user_recommendation: Require detailed schedule of all personal property to be attached before closing.
p_267.model_instructions: Replace 'such personal property' with a defined term that references an attached schedule: 'the Personal Property described in Schedule A attached hereto and incorporated herein by reference (the "Personal Property")'. Ensure that this schedule is cross-referenced with the personal property definition in Section 1D of the PSA (p_12) to ensure consistency and completeness. As a closing condition, Buyer should verify Schedule A is complete and accurate.

amplified_by.effect: If personal property is not properly identified, the AS-IS disclaimer may prevent Buyer from claiming additional items post-closing

p_284.title: Missing Personal Property Schedule
p_284.description: This appears to be a placeholder for a schedule that should list the personal property included in the sale, but contains only bracketed text indicating it needs to be completed. If this schedule is not properly filled out before closing, Buyer will have no clear record of what personal property was conveyed, making enforcement of the warranty in p_267 extremely difficult and potentially allowing Seller to remove valuable FF&E.
p_284.problematic_text: [Personal Property of Personal Property Included in the Sale]
p_284.user_recommendation: Require completed inventory schedule with values before closing.
p_284.model_instructions: This bracketed placeholder must be replaced with a comprehensive schedule listing all personal property included in the sale. Add the following as a closing condition in Section 5D or 11C: 'Seller shall deliver to Buyer at least five (5) business days prior to Closing a complete and accurate schedule of all Personal Property to be conveyed at Closing (the "Personal Property Schedule"), which shall include a description of each item and its approximate value. Buyer shall have the right to inspect and verify such Personal Property prior to Closing.' The schedule should cross-reference the personal property description in Section 1D.

amplified_by.effect: If personal property schedule is not a required Seller delivery, there is no mechanism to ensure it is provided

p_289.title: Blank Assignment Form Fields
p_289.description: The Assignment and Assumption of Leases contains blank fields for date, party names, and entity types that must be completed before execution. While this is standard for a form document, Buyer should ensure all blanks are properly completed consistent with the PSA before execution at Closing.
p_289.user_recommendation: Verify all blanks completed correctly and consistently with PSA at closing.
p_289.model_instructions: As part of closing review procedures, ensure: (1) the date matches the Closing Date; (2) Assignor name and entity type exactly matches Seller as defined in PSA; (3) Assignee name and entity type exactly matches Buyer (or permitted assignee if Buyer has assigned rights under Section 15 or 20); (4) all entity designations are accurate per formation documents. Consider adding a closing checklist item to verify consistency across all closing documents.

mitigated_by.effect: Section 11C requires proper execution of assignment documents as a Seller delivery

p_291.title: Lease Schedule Must Be Complete and Accurate
p_291.description: The assignment covers only leases 'described in Schedule I attached hereto.' If Schedule I is incomplete or inaccurate, Buyer may not receive assignment of all leases, potentially leaving some tenant relationships unassigned and creating title/ownership issues. Buyer should verify Schedule I matches the rent roll and all leases disclosed during due diligence.
p_291.problematic_text: which leases are described in Schedule I attached hereto (the "Leases")
p_291.user_recommendation: Cross-check Schedule I against rent roll and all disclosed leases before closing.
p_291.model_instructions: Add a verification requirement: As a closing condition, Buyer shall confirm that Schedule I to the Assignment and Assumption of Leases includes all leases and occupancy agreements affecting the Property as disclosed in the Due Diligence Documents, the rent roll delivered pursuant to Section 7A(ii), and any new leases entered into in accordance with Section 8B. Any discrepancy shall be resolved prior to Closing. Consider adding Seller representation that Schedule I is complete and accurate as of Closing.

mitigated_by.effect: Seller's representation regarding the rent roll provides some protection if leases are omitted

amplified_by.effect: The knowledge qualifier on Seller's representations may limit Buyer's recourse for undisclosed leases

p_293.title: PSA Terms Incorporated by Reference
p_293.description: The assignment incorporates the PSA terms by reference, which is appropriate for ensuring consistency. However, Buyer should be aware that any limitations, caps, or disclaimers in the PSA will also apply to claims arising under this assignment unless specifically stated otherwise.
p_293.problematic_text: The terms of the Agreement with respect to this Assignment are incorporated herein by reference.
p_293.user_recommendation: Confirm PSA terms (especially limitations) apply appropriately to assignment.
p_293.model_instructions: Review this incorporation clause to ensure it does not inadvertently import limitations that should not apply to the assignment. Consider clarifying which specific PSA terms are incorporated, particularly: (1) indemnification provisions from Section 10; (2) survival periods from Section 7C; (3) liability limitations from Section 13. If Buyer negotiates different or better terms in the assignment (such as the indemnification in p_301), ensure those terms are not overridden by this incorporation clause by adding: 'In the event of any conflict between this Assignment and the Agreement, the terms of this Assignment shall control with respect to the assignment and assumption of the Leases.'

amplified_by.effect: The limited survival period in the PSA may apply to claims under this assignment

p_295.title: Vague Assignment Terms Reference
p_295.description: The clause references assignment 'on the terms and conditions set forth below' without specifying those terms within this paragraph. While the subsequent paragraphs do contain terms, this introductory language creates potential ambiguity about what exactly constitutes the full scope of the assignment terms, and whether any oral or extrinsic terms could be argued to apply.
p_295.problematic_text: on the terms and conditions set forth below
p_295.user_recommendation: Ensure all material assignment terms are expressly stated in the document.
p_295.model_instructions: Consider adding a clause stating that 'Such terms and conditions are set forth exclusively in Sections [X] through [Y] below, and no other terms shall apply to this assignment.' This ensures completeness and prevents arguments about implied or unstated terms.

p_299.title: Conveyance Date Determination Ambiguity
p_299.description: The assignment is effective 'as of the date on which the Property is conveyed to Assignee pursuant to the Agreement.' If there is any dispute about when conveyance actually occurred (e.g., recording date vs. delivery of deed vs. closing), Buyer/Assignee could face a gap in coverage or unclear allocation of pre/post-closing liabilities. The definition relies on an external event without specifying the precise moment of effectiveness.
p_299.problematic_text: As of the date on which the Property is conveyed to Assignee pursuant to the Agreement (the "Conveyance Date")
p_299.user_recommendation: Define Conveyance Date as the date of recording of the Deed.
p_299.model_instructions: Replace the definition with more precise language: 'As of the date on which the Deed is recorded in the official records of [County] County (the "Conveyance Date")' or alternatively 'As of the Closing Date as defined in the Agreement (the "Conveyance Date")'. This eliminates ambiguity about when the assignment becomes effective and when liability shifts.

p_301.title: Favorable Pre-Closing Indemnity From Seller
p_301.description: This provision provides Buyer/Assignee with indemnification from Seller/Assignor for all Claims originating prior to the Conveyance Date and arising out of Assignor's obligations under the Leases. This is favorable to Buyer, but Buyer should verify this indemnity survives closing and is not limited by caps, baskets, or survival periods in the main Agreement that could undermine its value.
p_301.problematic_text: Assignor hereby agrees to indemnify Assignee against and hold Assignee harmless from any and all liabilities, losses, claims, damages, costs or expenses, including, without limitation, reasonable attorneys' fees and costs (collectively, the "Claims"), originating prior to the Conveyance Date and arising out of the Assignor's obligations under the Leases
p_301.user_recommendation: Confirm this indemnity survives closing and is not subject to caps/baskets.
p_301.model_instructions: Add explicit survival language: 'This indemnification obligation shall survive the Conveyance Date and the Closing for a period of [24/36] months.'
