Also consider adding: 'Notwithstanding any limitation on liability, survival period, basket, or cap contained in the Agreement, this indemnification obligation shall not be subject to any such limitations.' Cross-reference the main Agreement's liability provisions (Section 7C survival, any indemnity caps) to ensure this assignment-level indemnity is not inadvertently limited.

p_301.title: No Express Survival Period for Seller Indemnity
p_301.description: The indemnification from Assignor to Assignee for pre-closing Lease obligations does not include an express survival period. Without clear survival language, there may be arguments that this indemnity terminates upon closing or is subject to a short limitations period, leaving Buyer unprotected for latent claims that surface after closing.
p_301.problematic_text: Assignor hereby agrees to indemnify Assignee against and hold Assignee harmless
p_301.user_recommendation: Add explicit survival period of at least 24 months post-closing.
p_301.model_instructions: Insert the following at the end of the paragraph: 'The obligations of Assignor under this Section shall survive the Conveyance Date and Closing for a period of twenty-four (24) months, and shall not merge with any instrument delivered at Closing.' This protects Buyer's ability to pursue claims that arise from pre-closing matters but are discovered post-closing.

p_303.title: Unlimited Assumption of Seller's Lease Obligations
p_303.description: Buyer/Assignee assumes 'all of Assignor's obligations under the Leases' without limitation. This broad assumption could include: (1) unfunded tenant improvement obligations, (2) free rent obligations, (3) lease buyout provisions, (4) landlord repair/maintenance backlogs, (5) potential lease violations by Seller that Buyer inherits. The assumption is uncapped and unlimited, exposing Buyer to potentially significant unknown liabilities.
p_303.problematic_text: Assignee hereby assumes all of Assignor's obligations under the Leases
p_303.user_recommendation: Limit assumption to obligations arising post-closing only.
p_303.model_instructions: Revise to read: 'Assignee hereby assumes all of Assignor's obligations under the Leases that first arise or accrue on or after the Conveyance Date, excluding (i) any obligation of Assignor arising from Assignor's breach or default occurring prior to the Conveyance Date, (ii) any unfunded tenant improvement allowances or free rent obligations relating to periods prior to the Conveyance Date, and (iii) any obligation arising from Assignor's failure to perform landlord obligations prior to the Conveyance Date.' This carve-out ensures Buyer only assumes truly forward-looking obligations.

p_303.title: Buyer Provides Uncapped Indemnity to Seller
p_303.description: Buyer/Assignee agrees to indemnify Seller/Assignor against 'any and all Claims' arising from Assignee's obligations under the Leases post-closing. This indemnity has no cap, no basket, and no temporal limitation. Combined with the broad assumption of 'all' obligations, Buyer's exposure is unlimited and could include claims that actually originated from Seller's pre-closing conduct but are characterized as relating to Assignee's obligations.
p_303.problematic_text: agrees to indemnify Assignor against and hold Assignor harmless from any and all Claims originating on or subsequent to the Conveyance Date and arising out of the Assignee's obligations under the Leases
p_303.user_recommendation: Add a cap on Buyer's indemnity equal to the Purchase Price or insurance limits.
p_303.model_instructions: Add the following limitation: 'Notwithstanding the foregoing, Assignee's aggregate liability under this indemnification shall not exceed [the Purchase Price / $X / the limits of Assignee's commercial general liability insurance], and shall exclude any Claims to the extent arising from (i) Assignor's breach of any representation or warranty in the Agreement, (ii) Assignor's pre-Conveyance Date defaults under the Leases, or (iii) Assignor's negligence or willful misconduct.' This caps exposure and clarifies that Seller cannot shift its own misconduct to Buyer via this indemnity.

p_303.title: Origination Date Creates Gap Risk
p_303.description: The indemnity structure uses 'originating' prior to or 'on or subsequent to' the Conveyance Date as the dividing line. Claims that 'originate' before closing but 'arise' after closing (or vice versa) create allocation disputes. For example, a tenant improvement obligation that originated pre-closing but becomes due post-closing could fall into a grey area. The distinction between 'originating' and 'arising' is not clearly defined.
p_303.problematic_text: originating on or subsequent to the Conveyance Date and arising out of the Assignee's obligations
p_303.user_recommendation: Clarify that Seller indemnifies for all matters relating to pre-closing periods.
p_303.model_instructions: Revise both p_301 and p_303 to use clearer temporal language. In p_301, change to: 'Claims arising out of or relating to (i) any act, omission, or condition occurring or existing prior to the Conveyance Date, or (ii) Assignor's performance or non-performance of obligations under the Leases for periods prior to the Conveyance Date.' In p_303, change to: 'Claims arising out of or relating to Assignee's performance or non-performance of obligations under the Leases for periods on or after the Conveyance Date, but excluding any Claim to the extent attributable to Assignor's acts, omissions, or defaults prior to the Conveyance Date.'

p_305.title: Losing Party Pays Attorney Fees
p_305.description: The prevailing party fee-shifting provision creates significant litigation cost exposure for Buyer. If Buyer brings a claim under this Assignment and does not prevail, Buyer must pay Seller's attorneys' fees and costs without limitation. This could chill Buyer's willingness to enforce legitimate claims and creates asymmetric risk if Seller has greater litigation resources.
p_305.problematic_text: the losing party shall pay the prevailing party's costs and expenses of such dispute, including, without limitation, reasonable attorneys' fees and costs
p_305.user_recommendation: Consider removing or making fee-shifting mutual only above a threshold.
p_305.model_instructions: Consider revising to: 'In any dispute arising under this Assignment, each party shall bear its own attorneys' fees and costs, unless a court determines that a party's position was frivolous or taken in bad faith, in which case the court may award reasonable attorneys' fees to the other party.' Alternatively, add a materiality threshold: 'provided that this fee-shifting provision shall only apply to disputes involving claims in excess of $[50,000].' This reduces the chilling effect on legitimate smaller claims while still deterring frivolous litigation.

p_305.title: No Definition of Prevailing Party
p_305.description: The clause does not define what constitutes a 'prevailing party,' which can be ambiguous in cases where each party wins on some issues or where the plaintiff recovers less than a settlement offer. Without a clear definition, there could be additional litigation over who actually prevailed.
p_305.problematic_text: the losing party shall pay the prevailing party's costs
p_305.user_recommendation: Define 'prevailing party' to reduce post-dispute litigation.
p_305.model_instructions: Add the following definition: 'For purposes of this Section, the "prevailing party" shall mean the party who obtains a judgment or award substantially in its favor on the principal claims at issue, or if the dispute is settled, the party in whose favor the settlement is predominantly rendered. A party who recovers money damages shall be considered the prevailing party unless such recovery is less than [the opposing party's last written settlement offer / 50% of the amount claimed].'

p_307.title: Unrestricted Assignability of Lease Assignment
p_307.description: This provision allows the Assignment of Leases to be binding on 'successors and assigns' without any restriction on Seller/Assignor's ability to assign. While this benefits Buyer by allowing future transferability, it also means Seller could potentially assign its indemnification obligations under p_301 to a less creditworthy entity before closing or during the survival period, potentially leaving Buyer without recourse for pre-closing landlord obligations.
p_307.problematic_text: This Assignment shall be binding on and inure to the benefit of the parties hereto and their respective successors and assigns
p_307.user_recommendation: Add restriction on Assignor's assignment without Buyer consent
p_307.model_instructions: Modify the provision to read: 'This Assignment shall be binding on and inure to the benefit of the parties hereto and their respective successors and assigns; provided, however, that Assignor may not assign its obligations hereunder (including without limitation its indemnification obligations under Section [reference to indemnity section]) without the prior written consent of Assignee, which consent may be withheld in Assignee's sole discretion.' This ensures Buyer retains recourse against a creditworthy indemnitor.

p_337.title: Blank Date and Party Information
p_337.description: The Assignment of Contracts contains blank fields for the date and party identification. While this is standard for a form document attached as an exhibit, Buyer should ensure these blanks are properly completed at closing to match the actual closing date and correct legal entity names. Incorrect or incomplete party information could affect enforceability of the assignment and related indemnification provisions.
p_337.user_recommendation: Confirm all blanks completed correctly at closing
p_337.model_instructions: No modification to contract language required. Add a closing checklist item or instruction note: 'Buyer's counsel shall verify that all blanks in the Assignment and Assumption of Contracts and Intangibles are completed accurately at closing, including (i) the correct closing date, (ii) Seller's full legal entity name and state of formation matching the PSA, and (iii) Buyer's full legal entity name and state of formation matching the PSA.'

p_339.title: Schedule I Dependency Without Verification Right
p_339.description: The definition of 'Contracts' is entirely dependent on Schedule I, which is an exhibit prepared by the Seller/Assignor. Buyer has no independent verification mechanism in this assignment document to confirm Schedule I is complete and accurate. If Seller omits contracts from Schedule I, Buyer may unknowingly assume obligations under undisclosed contracts or fail to receive the benefit of favorable contracts.
p_339.problematic_text: which service contracts are described in Schedule I attached hereto (the "Contracts")
p_339.user_recommendation: Add warranty that Schedule I is complete and accurate.
p_339.model_instructions: Insert the following sentence after the defined term: 'Assignor represents and warrants that Schedule I contains a complete and accurate list of all service contracts affecting the Property as of the Conveyance Date.' Additionally, cross-reference this with Section 7A representations to ensure survival of this warranty beyond closing.

amplified_by.effect: Buyer will assume all obligations under undisclosed contracts that affect the Property

p_341.title: Blanket Incorporation of PSA Terms
p_341.description: The broad incorporation of PSA terms by reference ('The terms of the Agreement with respect to this Assignment are incorporated herein by reference') creates potential ambiguity about which specific PSA provisions govern this Assignment. In a dispute, Seller could argue that unfavorable PSA provisions (such as liability caps, survival limitations, or dispute resolution procedures) override more favorable provisions that might otherwise apply to this Assignment.
p_341.problematic_text: The terms of the Agreement with respect to this Assignment are incorporated herein by reference.
p_341.user_recommendation: Specify which PSA terms apply to this Assignment.
p_341.model_instructions: Replace the blanket incorporation clause with specific cross-references: 'The following provisions of the Agreement are incorporated herein by reference and shall govern this Assignment: [Section __ (Definitions), Section __ (Survival), Section __ (Dispute Resolution), Section __ (Governing Law)]. In the event of any conflict between this Assignment and the Agreement, the terms most favorable to Assignee shall control.'

p_347.title: Seller Retains Pre-Closing Claims Against Contracts
p_347.description: The carve-out 'excluding claims by Assignor, if any, arising out of matters occurring before the Conveyance Date' allows Seller to retain valuable claims (such as breach of contract claims against service providers, warranties from contractors, or rights to refunds/credits) that relate to the Property. This could leave Buyer without recourse against vendors for pre-closing defects or without the benefit of favorable contract terms.
p_347.problematic_text: excluding claims by Assignor, if any, arising out of matters occurring before the Conveyance Date
p_347.user_recommendation: Require assignment of all claims or obtain representations about pending claims.
p_347.model_instructions: Delete the carve-out language entirely OR modify to read: 'Assignor hereby assigns to Assignee all of its right, title and interest in and to the Contracts and any intangible property now owned by Assignor in connection with the Property, including without limitation all claims, causes of action, warranties, and rights to credits or refunds arising under the Contracts, whether arising before or after the Conveyance Date. To the extent any such pre-Conveyance Date claims are not assignable, Assignor shall hold such claims in trust for the benefit of Assignee and shall prosecute such claims at Assignee's direction and expense, with all proceeds payable to Assignee.'

amplified_by.effect: AS-IS clause may limit Buyer's ability to seek recourse for pre-closing defects discovered post-closing

p_347.title: Undefined 'Intangible Property' Scope
p_347.description: The phrase 'any intangible property now owned by Assignor in connection with the Property' is vague and lacks a clear definition. This could lead to disputes about whether specific items (trade names, permits, licenses, warranties, intellectual property, domain names, telephone numbers) are included in the assignment. The lack of specificity may result in Buyer not receiving items it expected or Seller retaining valuable intangibles.
p_347.problematic_text: any intangible property now owned by Assignor in connection with the Property
p_347.user_recommendation: Define intangible property with specific enumerated categories.
p_347.model_instructions: Replace 'any intangible property now owned by Assignor in connection with the Property' with: 'all intangible property owned by Assignor in connection with the Property, including without limitation: (a) all trade names, trademarks, and service marks used in connection with the Property; (b) all permits, licenses, approvals, and authorizations; (c) all warranties and guaranties from contractors, subcontractors, suppliers, and manufacturers; (d) all telephone numbers, domain names, and websites; (e) all plans, specifications, drawings, and architectural works; (f) all tenant and prospect lists, marketing materials, and promotional materials; and (g) all goodwill associated with the foregoing (collectively, the "Intangible Property")'

mitigated_by.effect: PSA Section 1E provides some definition of Intangible Property that may govern

p_349.title: Indemnity Limited to Pre-Closing Matters Only
p_349.description: The indemnity only covers claims 'originating prior to the Conveyance Date.' This creates a dangerous gap for claims that straddle the closing date or are discovered post-closing but relate to pre-closing conduct. For example, if a service provider was performing defective work before closing but the claim doesn't 'originate' until post-closing discovery, Buyer may have no indemnification coverage. The word 'originating' is also ambiguous—it's unclear whether this means when the underlying conduct occurred, when the claim accrues, or when a third party first asserts it.
p_349.problematic_text: originating prior to the Conveyance Date
p_349.user_recommendation: Change 'originating' to 'arising from acts or omissions occurring' for clarity.
p_349.model_instructions: Replace 'originating prior to the Conveyance Date and arising out of Assignor's obligations under the Contracts' with: 'arising out of or related to: (a) any breach or default by Assignor under any Contract occurring on or prior to the Conveyance Date; (b) any act or omission of Assignor under any Contract on or prior to the Conveyance Date; (c) any obligation or liability under any Contract that accrued or relates to the period on or prior to the Conveyance Date, regardless of when such Claim is asserted or discovered; or (d) any Contract not listed on Schedule I that affects the Property.'

amplified_by.effect: Buyer assumes all post-closing obligations, creating exposure if pre-closing defaults trigger post-closing consequences

p_349.title: No Survival Period for Contract Assignment Indemnity
p_349.description: Unlike Section 7C of the PSA which specifies a 270-day survival period for representations and warranties, this Assignment document contains no explicit survival period for the indemnification obligation. Without a specified survival term, the indemnity could be subject to general statute of limitations arguments or could be deemed to merge into the closing, leaving Buyer without recourse for later-discovered claims.
p_349.problematic_text: Assignor hereby agrees to indemnify Assignee against and hold Assignee harmless from any and all liabilities, losses, claims, damages, costs or expenses
p_349.user_recommendation: Add explicit survival period of at least 2-3 years for this indemnity.
p_349.model_instructions: Add the following sentence at the end of this paragraph: 'The indemnification obligations of Assignor under this Section shall survive the Closing and the Conveyance Date for a period of three (3) years, provided that any claim for indemnification asserted in writing within such period shall survive until final resolution thereof, regardless of such three (3) year period.'

mitigated_by.effect: PSA survival clause may be incorporated by reference via p_341, but this is ambiguous

p_349.title: No Liability Cap on Contract Assignment Indemnity
p_349.description: This indemnity contains no cap or basket limitation on Seller's exposure. While this is favorable to Buyer, it creates a potential inconsistency with liability limitations that may exist elsewhere in the PSA. If the PSA contains liability caps that apply 'notwithstanding anything to the contrary,' Seller may argue those caps apply to this Assignment indemnity, creating uncertainty about Buyer's actual recovery rights.
p_349.problematic_text: any and all liabilities, losses, claims, damages, costs or expenses
p_349.user_recommendation: Confirm this indemnity is excluded from any PSA liability caps.
p_349.model_instructions: Add the following clarification: 'For the avoidance of doubt, the indemnification obligations under this Assignment are not subject to any basket, deductible, cap, or other limitation on liability set forth in the Agreement, and the foregoing indemnification shall be in addition to, and not in limitation of, any other remedies available to Assignee at law or in equity.'

p_343.title: Buyer 'Desires' Rather Than Unconditionally Accepts
p_343.description: The recital uses precatory language ('Assignee desires to accept the assignment thereof') rather than operative acceptance language. While recitals are generally not operative provisions, this weak language could be used by Seller to argue that Buyer's acceptance is somehow conditional or that Buyer has not fully accepted all assigned items.
p_343.problematic_text: Assignee desires to accept the assignment thereof
p_343.user_recommendation: Ensure operative provisions contain clear acceptance language.
p_343.model_instructions: This is a recital, so the primary fix should be ensuring that the operative provisions (particularly the assumption clause at p_351) contain unconditional acceptance language. However, for consistency, consider revising this recital to: 'Pursuant to the Agreement, Assignor desires to assign, and Assignee desires to accept and assume, Assignor's interest in the Contracts and in certain intangible personal property with respect to the Property, on the terms and conditions set forth below.'

mitigated_by.effect: The operative assumption clause provides clearer acceptance language

p_351.title: Uncapped assumption of all contract obligations
p_351.description: As Buyer/Assignee, this provision requires assumption of 'all' obligations under the Contracts without limitation or qualification. The scope is unlimited and could include unknown liabilities, disputes, or breaches by Seller that occurred pre-closing but manifest post-closing. There is no carve-out for pre-existing breaches, no cap on exposure, and no limitation to obligations that were disclosed or discoverable during due diligence.
p_351.problematic_text: Assignee hereby assumes all of Assignor's obligations under the Contracts
p_351.user_recommendation: Limit assumption to disclosed contracts and post-closing performance obligations only.
p_351.model_instructions: Modify to read: 'Assignee hereby assumes Assignor's obligations under the Contracts listed on Exhibit ___ attached hereto, but only to the extent such obligations (a) arise from events occurring on or after the Conveyance Date, (b) do not result from any breach, default, or failure to perform by Assignor prior to the Conveyance Date, and (c) were disclosed in the Due Diligence Documents or otherwise known to Assignee prior to Closing.'

p_351.title: Unlimited buyer indemnity for contract claims
p_351.description: The indemnity obligation has no cap, basket, or time limitation. Buyer must indemnify Seller for 'any and all Claims' arising from assumed contract obligations, which could result in unlimited exposure. This is particularly concerning because it is not mutual—Seller's indemnity in p_349 covers pre-closing claims, but there is no cap on either party's indemnity and no survival period limiting when claims can be brought.
p_351.problematic_text: agrees to indemnify Assignor against and hold Assignor harmless from any and all Claims originating on or subsequent to the Conveyance Date
p_351.user_recommendation: Add liability cap tied to Purchase Price and survival period for indemnity claims.
p_351.model_instructions: Add the following limitation after 'under the Contracts': '; provided, however, that (i) Assignee's aggregate liability under this indemnity shall not exceed $_______ [or ___% of the Purchase Price], (ii) Assignee shall have no liability for any Claim unless Assignor provides written notice of such Claim within twelve (12) months after the Conveyance Date, and (iii) Assignee shall have no liability for any individual Claim unless the damages exceed $_______ and no aggregate liability unless total Claims exceed $_______.'

p_353.title: Attorneys' fees shifting creates litigation risk
p_353.description: The prevailing party fee-shifting provision applies to disputes under this Assignment. While facially mutual, this creates risk for Buyer if any dispute arises over contract interpretation, particularly given the broad assumption of obligations in p_351. If Seller brings a claim under the Assignment and prevails, Buyer bears not only the underlying liability but also Seller's attorneys' fees, which could substantially increase exposure.
p_353.problematic_text: the losing party shall pay the prevailing party's costs and expenses of such dispute, including, without limitation, reasonable attorneys' fees and costs
p_353.user_recommendation: Consider limiting fee-shifting to claims above a threshold amount.
p_353.model_instructions: Consider modifying to: 'the losing party shall pay the prevailing party's reasonable attorneys' fees and costs, provided that this fee-shifting provision shall only apply to disputes involving claimed damages in excess of $_______ and shall not apply to any claim that is resolved through good faith negotiation within thirty (30) days of written notice.'

p_355.title: Binding on successors expands indemnity exposure
p_355.description: This provision makes the Assignment binding on successors and assigns, which means Buyer's indemnity obligations under p_351 could follow any sale of the Property. If Buyer sells the Property, Buyer may remain liable under the indemnity even after disposition unless the successor expressly assumes these obligations and Seller releases Buyer.
p_355.problematic_text: This Assignment shall be binding on an inure to the benefit of the parties hereto and their respective successors and assigns
p_355.user_recommendation: Add release mechanism upon transfer to qualified successor.
p_355.model_instructions: Add the following sentence: 'Notwithstanding the foregoing, in the event Assignee transfers its interest in the Property to a successor who expressly assumes Assignee's obligations under this Assignment in writing, Assignor agrees to release Assignee from its obligations hereunder, provided such successor has a net worth reasonably acceptable to Assignor or provides other reasonable credit support.'

p_359.title: Execution date not specified in form
p_359.description: The Assignment references 'the day and year first written above' but this is a form document attached as an exhibit. Ensure that the execution date is properly filled in at closing and corresponds to the Conveyance Date to avoid any gap in coverage or ambiguity about when obligations transfer.
p_359.problematic_text: as of the day and year first written above
p_359.user_recommendation: Confirm execution date matches Conveyance Date at closing.
p_359.model_instructions: This is a form document issue. At closing, ensure the date in the preamble of this Assignment matches the actual Closing Date/Conveyance Date. Consider modifying to: 'as of the Closing Date (as defined in the Agreement)' to ensure automatic alignment with the PSA.

p_391.title: No Duty to Investigate Rent Roll
p_391.description: The Seller's representation regarding the Rent Roll is qualified by 'to its actual knowledge, without investigating.' This 'without investigating' language explicitly relieves Seller of any duty to verify the accuracy of the Rent Roll information before making the representation. This means Seller could provide materially inaccurate rent roll information and claim they had no duty to check it, leaving Buyer without recourse for reliance on incorrect information that could significantly impact property valuation and investment returns.
p_391.problematic_text: to its actual knowledge, without investigating
p_391.user_recommendation: Remove 'without investigating' or require Seller to make reasonable inquiry.
p_391.model_instructions: Delete the phrase 'without investigating' from the representation. Alternatively, replace the knowledge qualifier with 'to Seller's actual knowledge after reasonable inquiry' or 'to Seller's knowledge' with a definition in the Agreement that includes a duty of reasonable investigation. At minimum, require that Seller has reviewed the Rent Roll with the property manager before certifying its accuracy.

p_391.title: Rent Roll Date Not Tied to Closing
p_391.description: The Rent Roll representation is made 'as of' a blank date that appears to be filled in at signing, not at Closing. This creates a gap where the Rent Roll could become materially inaccurate between the date of the representation and the actual Closing Date, yet Seller would have no obligation to update or re-certify the information. Tenant defaults, lease terminations, or rent modifications occurring after the representation date but before Closing would not be covered.
p_391.user_recommendation: Require Seller to re-certify Rent Roll accuracy as of Closing Date.
p_391.model_instructions: Modify the representation to require accuracy both as of the Effective Date and as of the Closing Date. Add language such as: 'The undersigned hereby represents and warrants that to its actual knowledge, the information in the attached Rent Roll is true and correct in all material respects as of the Effective Date and shall be re-certified by Seller as true and correct in all material respects as of the Closing Date.' Also add an obligation for Seller to promptly notify Buyer of any changes to the Rent Roll between signing and Closing.

p_391.title: Materiality Qualifier on Rent Roll Accuracy
p_391.description: The representation that the Rent Roll is accurate 'in all material respects' introduces subjectivity and allows for potentially significant inaccuracies that may not rise to the level of 'material.' There is no definition of what constitutes a material inaccuracy in the Rent Roll context. This could excuse errors in rent amounts, lease expiration dates, security deposit balances, or tenant concessions that individually might not be deemed 'material' but collectively could significantly impact the property's value or cash flow.
p_391.problematic_text: true and correct in all material respects
p_391.user_recommendation: Define 'material' with specific dollar thresholds for Rent Roll representations.
p_391.model_instructions: Either (1) remove the 'in all material respects' qualifier so the representation is unqualified, or (2) add a specific definition of materiality for Rent Roll purposes, such as: 'For purposes of this representation, any inaccuracy shall be deemed material if (a) monthly rent amounts are misstated by more than $500 per lease, (b) lease expiration dates are misstated by more than 30 days, (c) security deposit amounts are misstated by more than $250, or (d) the aggregate impact of all inaccuracies exceeds $5,000.' Consider negotiating a schedule of acceptable variance thresholds.

p_391.title: No Survival Period Specified for Rent Roll Rep
p_391.description: This Rent Roll representation appears in a separate exhibit/certificate form and does not specify its own survival period. While the main Agreement may have a survival provision in Section 7.3, it is unclear whether this separate certification is covered by that survival period or whether it survives Closing at all. If the representation terminates at Closing, Buyer would have no post-Closing recourse for discovering Rent Roll inaccuracies.
p_391.problematic_text: The undersigned hereby represents and warrants
p_391.user_recommendation: Add explicit survival period or cross-reference to Agreement's survival terms.
p_391.model_instructions: Add a survival provision to this certificate: 'This representation and warranty shall survive the Closing for a period consistent with the survival of Seller's representations and warranties under Section 7.3 of the Purchase and Sale Agreement, or for a period of [twelve (12) months] following the Closing Date, whichever is longer.' Alternatively, add language expressly incorporating this certificate into the Agreement's survival framework: 'This representation and warranty is made pursuant to and subject to the terms and conditions of the Agreement, including the survival provisions of Section 7.3 thereof.'

p_393.title: Reliance Statement May Limit Third-Party Claims
p_393.description: The representation explicitly states it is made 'for your benefit and protection' with the understanding that 'you intend to rely upon this statement in connection with your intended purchase.' While this establishes reliance for the Buyer, it may inadvertently limit who can rely on the representation—potentially excluding Buyer's lenders, assignees, or successors who may also need to rely on the Rent Roll accuracy for financing or subsequent transactions.
p_393.problematic_text: for your benefit and protection with the understanding that you intend to rely upon this statement
p_393.user_recommendation: Expand reliance to include Buyer's lenders, successors, and assigns.
p_393.model_instructions: Modify the reliance language to expressly permit reliance by additional parties: 'The undersigned makes this representation and warranty for the benefit and protection of [Buyer], its lenders, successors, and assigns, with the understanding that such parties intend to rely upon this statement in connection with the purchase of the Property and any financing related thereto.' This ensures that Buyer's lender can rely on the representation for underwriting purposes and that the representation survives any assignment of Buyer's interest.

p_377.title: Heading Only - No Substantive Terms
p_377.description: This paragraph contains only a heading 'Assignment and Assumption of Contracts and Intangible Property' without any substantive terms. This appears to be either a section header or an incomplete exhibit. The actual assignment form appears earlier in the document (see p_335-p_359). Buyer should confirm this is not a duplicate or missing exhibit and that all necessary assignment documentation is complete.
p_377.problematic_text: Assignment and Assumption of Contracts and Intangible Property
p_377.user_recommendation: Confirm this is intentional section break or complete with substantive terms.
p_377.model_instructions: Review the document structure to determine if this heading is: (1) a duplicate of the exhibit at p_335 that should be deleted, (2) a placeholder for additional content that needs to be completed, or (3) an intentional section break that should include a cross-reference to the actual Assignment form. If this is meant to reference the Assignment form, add: 'See Exhibit E attached hereto and incorporated herein by reference.' Ensure the exhibit numbering and cross-references throughout the Agreement are consistent.

title_objection_termination.trigger: Seller failure to cure title objections

casualty_condemnation.type: elective by Buyer for material events
casualty_condemnation.consequence: Return of Deposit or proceed with credit

seller_default.consequence: Return of Deposit plus up to $50K expenses

notice_provisions.value: Written notice via personal delivery, overnight courier, or electronic transmission
notice_provisions.limitations: Deemed delivery upon confirmation; refusal provisions unclear

assignment_termination.notes: Assignment appears unconditional upon Conveyance Date

assignment_specific.value: None - Assignment takes effect at Conveyance Date

notes.value: Initial clauses do not address default remedies. See Section 13 for buyer default (liquidated damages) and seller default provisions.

seller_default.remedy: Specific performance OR return of Deposit plus actual damages up to cap

title_review_deemed_approval.value: Silence = approval of all title exceptions
title_review_deemed_approval.limitations: Automatic upon failure to object within Title Review Period

inspection_damage.value: Buyer must promptly repair and restore

buyer_extension_right.limitations: Requires Extension Fee; terms left blank

automatic_consequences.value: Indemnification available for pre-closing breaches per p_349

Effective_Date.value: Date Agreement executed and delivered by last signing party
Effective_Date.limitations: No verification mechanism; potential for dispute

Real_Property.value: Property at specified address per Exhibit A
Real_Property.limitations: Dependent on accuracy of Exhibit A

Appurtenances.limitations: Limited to appurtenant rights only; may not include easements in gross

Property.value: p_8-p_15 - Includes Real Property, Appurtenances, Improvements, Personal Property, Intangible Property, Leases

Improvements.definition: All improvements and fixtures on Real Property, excluding tenant-owned and Seller-leased fixtures

Personal_Property.definition: Personal property owned by Seller located on or used in connection with the Property, subject to exclusions

Intangible_Property.definition: Undefined in assignment - 'intangible property now owned by Assignor in connection with Property'
Intangible_Property.risk_note: Vague scope creates assignment gaps - cross-ref p_13

Service_Contracts.definition: Equipment leases, utility contracts, maintenance contracts, and similar agreements

Leases.definition: All leases and other occupancy agreements

Initial_Deposit.definition: Amount specified in Section 3A, delivered within specified business days after Effective Date

Additional_Deposit.definition: Amount specified in Section 3B, delivered within 1 business day after approval/DD expiration

Deposit.definition: Initial Deposit + Additional Deposit + all interest thereon

Closing_Payment.definition: Purchase Price minus Deposit (plus interest) as adjusted by prorations and credits

existing_survey.value: Most recent survey in Seller's possession, if any

title_documents.value: Commitment plus all instruments constituting exceptions

title_objections.value: Written objections to Title Documents delivered by Buyer

permitted_exceptions.definition: Items approved or deemed approved under title review process

due_diligence_period.definition: Period ending on date specified in blank

due_diligence_documents.notes: List of materials Seller provides; Buyer takes 'as-is'

title_policy.definition: Extended coverage owner's policy (2006 ALTA) with agreed endorsements
title_policy.risk_note: Endorsements must be agreed during DD Period

Sellers_Actual_Knowledge.value: p_59 - Actual knowledge of designated persons without inquiry duty

Rent_Roll.impact: References Due Diligence Documents; no date specified

Due_Diligence_Documents.value: p_31 - Documents provided for Buyer's review

property_information.definition: Due diligence materials furnished or made available to Buyer
property_information.significance: Used to deem Buyer's constructive knowledge

minimum_tenant_estoppels.value: Estoppels from tenants representing not less than __% of NRA, including all tenants over ___ RSF

service_contracts.value: Referenced but definition not in analyzed sections
service_contracts.notes: Should review definition to understand scope

extension_fee.value: Blank amount; nonrefundable except Seller default

property.definition: Real Property, Appurtenances, Improvements, Personal Property, Intangible Property, Leases

rent_roll.notes: Basis for security deposit credits and rent prorations

In_Process_TI_Work.definition: Tenant improvement obligations under the leases that Seller has begun but not yet completed and paid in full by Closing

Operating_Expense_Pass_throughs.definition: Additional rent collected from tenants to cover taxes, insurance, utilities, maintenance and other operating costs and expenses

material_damage.definition: Reasonable estimated cost of repair exceeds $___

integration_clause.value: Complete agreement; no oral agreements or representations outside written contract
integration_clause.limitations: Absolute waiver of pre-contractual representations with no fraud carve-out

notice_addresses.limitations: Addresses appear incomplete in provided text; must verify in full document

control.definition: Ownership of majority beneficial interest AND managerial control
control.risk_note: Conjunctive standard may be too narrow

effective_date.value: Date of mutual execution per p_4

Permitted_Exceptions.value: p_28 - Title matters approved or deemed approved by Buyer

leases.value: Defined by reference to main Agreement and Recitals
leases.issues: Should verify all leases are scheduled

personal_property.definition: Right, title and interest in tangible personal property, equipment, supplies located on Property

conveyance_date.value: Date Property is conveyed to Assignee pursuant to Agreement
conveyance_date.issues: Not precisely defined (recording date vs. delivery)

claims.value: Liabilities, losses, claims, damages, costs, expenses including attorneys' fees

Contracts.notes: Should cross-reference to disclosed contracts list

Conveyance_Date.value: Date Property is conveyed pursuant to Agreement

buyer_assignment.exceptions: Affiliates (entities controlling, controlled by, or under common control with Buyer)
buyer_assignment.notice_requirement: Prior written notice for affiliate assignments
buyer_assignment.release_on_assignment: Not addressed - Buyer may remain liable

1031_exchange.limitations: No additional cost, no excess deposits, no delays

R1.title: Uncertain Effective Date Determination
R1.description: The Effective Date is defined as when the Agreement is 'executed and delivered by the last of Buyer and Seller,' but there is no mechanism to verify or document when this occurs. This creates uncertainty about when contractual deadlines (due diligence period, deposit deadlines, closing date) begin to run. Disputes could arise about whether delivery occurred, particularly if signatures are exchanged electronically or through intermediaries.

amplified_by.effect: Uncertain Effective Date makes deposit deadline uncertain, risking default
Due diligence period start date becomes uncertain

R2.title: Purchase Price Forward Reference
R2.description: The Purchase Price is referenced but defined elsewhere. While this is standard drafting practice, Buyer should verify that the Purchase Price definition in Section 2 is complete and includes all adjustments, prorations, and credits to which Buyer is entitled.

R3.title: Exhibit A Legal Description Missing
R3.description: The Real Property is identified only by a blank street address and reference to Exhibit A. Buyer must verify that Exhibit A contains a complete and accurate metes-and-bounds or platted legal description that matches the title commitment. An incorrect or incomplete legal description could result in Buyer not acquiring all intended property or acquiring unintended parcels.

mitigated_by.effect: Title commitment review should reveal description discrepancies
Buyer has opportunity to identify issues during title review

R4.title: Undefined Appurtenant Rights Scope
R4.description: The conveyance of 'all rights, easements and rights-of-way appurtenant to the beneficial use and enjoyment of the Real Property' is limited to appurtenant rights only. This may not capture easements in gross, license agreements, or other access/utility rights that benefit the Property but are not technically 'appurtenant.' Seller could retain valuable rights that Buyer expects to receive.

mitigated_by.effect: Some rights may be captured under Intangible Property

amplified_by.effect: As-is provision may limit Buyer's recourse if important rights not conveyed

R5.title: Undefined Tenant/Leased Fixtures Exclusion
R5.description: The clause excludes 'fixtures owned by tenants or leased by Seller from third parties' from the conveyance, but there is no schedule or exhibit identifying these excluded items. Without a definitive list, Buyer cannot verify what is actually being purchased versus what will be removed or retained. Post-closing disputes could arise if Seller claims valuable fixtures were excluded when Buyer believed they were included.

amplified_by.effect: AS-IS clause may limit Buyer's ability to recover for missing fixtures Buyer believed were included

R6.title: Personal Property Exclusions Not Specified
R6.description: The bracketed language indicates that specific exclusions should be listed but the blank is unfilled. This creates uncertainty about what personal property is actually being conveyed. Seller could later claim valuable items were excluded, or Buyer may not receive property it expected.

amplified_by.effect: AS-IS language may preclude Buyer from claiming reliance on inclusion of unlisted items

R7.title: No Personal Property Inventory Required
R7.description: The clause conveys personal property 'owned by Seller and located on, in, or used in connection with' the Property, but there is no requirement for Seller to provide an inventory or schedule of such items. Buyer cannot verify what personal property exists or will be conveyed at Closing.

mitigated_by.effect: Bill of Sale at closing will document what personal property is actually conveyed

R8.title: Intangibles Limited to 'Extent Transferable'
R8.description: The conveyance of intangible property is qualified by 'to the extent transferable by Seller.' This places the risk of non-transferability on Buyer without requiring Seller to make efforts to obtain necessary consents or to warrant transferability. Key permits, licenses, or contracts may not transfer, leaving Buyer without critical operational rights.

amplified_by.effect: AS-IS clause may limit recourse if key permits do not transfer

R9.title: Seller Retains All Pre-Closing Third Party Claims
R9.description: Seller excludes from the conveyance 'any present or future claims of Seller against any third parties that relate to any period of time prior to the Closing.' This means if there are construction defects, warranty claims, or causes of action arising from pre-closing events (e.g., contractor negligence, environmental contamination caused by third parties), Buyer has no right to pursue those claims even though Buyer inherits the physical consequences. This is a significant allocation of risk to Buyer.

amplified_by.effect: Combined with AS-IS language, Buyer absorbs property defects with no recourse against responsible third parties
Release further limits Buyer's ability to recover for pre-closing issues

R10.title: Service Contracts Undefined and Unscheduled
R10.description: The clause includes 'equipment leases, utility contracts, maintenance contracts, and all other similar agreements' as Service Contracts being conveyed, but there is no schedule identifying these contracts. Buyer cannot evaluate the terms, obligations, or termination rights of these agreements during due diligence. Buyer may inherit unfavorable long-term contracts.

mitigated_by.effect: Seller cannot enter into new material Service Contracts without Buyer consent

R11.title: Lease Definition Includes 'Other Agreements to Occupy'
R11.description: The definition of 'Leases' includes not only formal leases but also 'other agreements to occupy the Real Property.' This broad language could include license agreements, month-to-month arrangements, or informal occupancy rights that may not be documented. Buyer should confirm all occupancy arrangements are disclosed.

mitigated_by.effect: Rent roll representation provides some protection if accurate

R12.title: Seller Retains Non-Exclusive Claim Rights Post-Closing
R12.description: Seller reserves 'on a non-exclusive basis with Buyer' the right to assert claims under warranties, guaranties, and agreements related to design, construction, or performance of the Property. This creates potential conflicts: Seller may pursue claims that Buyer would prefer to settle, or Seller may settle claims Buyer needs to pursue. The 'non-exclusive' nature creates coordination issues and potential claim-splitting problems.

amplified_by.effect: Combined with exclusion in 1E, this creates uncertainty about which party can pursue which claims

R13.title: Initial Deposit Non-Refundable Upon Receipt
R13.description: The clause states the Initial Deposit 'will become non-refundable upon Escrow Holder's receipt except in case of Seller's default.' This means Buyer loses the deposit immediately upon delivery, even before conducting any due diligence. If Buyer discovers material issues during the due diligence period (see p_31), Buyer would lose the entire Initial Deposit upon termination. This is highly unusual and buyer-unfavorable; standard practice is for deposits to become non-refundable only AFTER the due diligence period expires without termination.

amplified_by.effect: Liquidated damages provision allows Seller to retain entire Deposit as sole remedy, compounding the early non-refundability risk
Only applies to termination for reasons 'other than Buyer's default,' potentially excluding due diligence termination

R14.title: Immediate Payment of Deposit to Seller
R14.description: The bracketed alternative provision states 'Upon receipt, Escrow Holder shall promptly pay the Initial Deposit to Seller.' If this alternative is selected, Buyer loses escrow protection entirely. The deposit would be in Seller's hands rather than held by a neutral Escrow Holder, making recovery difficult even in cases of Seller default. This creates significant counterparty credit risk and eliminates the protective function of escrow.

amplified_by.effect: If deposit is paid to Seller and Seller defaults, Buyer's remedy to recover deposit depends on Seller's willingness/ability to return funds

R15.title: Narrow Exception for Deposit Refund
R15.description: The deposit is non-refundable 'except in case of Seller's default hereunder.' This language is too narrow. It does not expressly preserve Buyer's right to recover the deposit upon (i) failure of Buyer's conditions precedent under Section 5.4, (ii) casualty or condemnation under Section 14, (iii) title defects Seller cannot cure, or (iv) other express termination rights in the Agreement. Buyer should not lose its deposit when termination is permitted under the Agreement for reasons other than Seller's default.

mitigated_by.effect: Section 6 provides some protection for deposit return upon termination, but scope is unclear

R16.title: One Business Day Deadline for Additional Deposit
R16.description: Buyer has only one (1) business day to deliver the Additional Deposit after approval or expiration of due diligence. This extremely short window creates significant operational risk. Wire transfer delays, banking holidays, or administrative errors could result in missed deadline. If the Additional Deposit is not timely delivered, Buyer could be in default, potentially forfeiting the Initial Deposit.

amplified_by.effect: Late deposit could trigger default and forfeiture of Initial Deposit as liquidated damages

R17.title: Additional Deposit Immediately Non-Refundable
R17.description: The Additional Deposit is stated to be 'nonrefundable, except in case of Seller's default hereunder, and as otherwise expressly provided in this Agreement.' While this includes the qualifier 'as otherwise expressly provided,' the baseline non-refundability creates risk if conditions precedent fail or other termination events occur that are not clearly covered by express Agreement provisions. This compounds with the Initial Deposit issue to put the entire Deposit at risk.

mitigated_by.effect: Section 6 provides some framework for deposit return, adding marginal protection

amplified_by.effect: Entire Deposit including Additional Deposit serves as liquidated damages

R18.title: Immediate Payment of Additional Deposit to Seller
R18.description: Similar to the Initial Deposit, a bracketed alternative states 'Upon receipt, Escrow Holder shall promptly pay the Additional Deposit to Seller.' If this alternative is selected along with the similar provision for the Initial Deposit, the entire Deposit would be in Seller's hands, eliminating all escrow protection for Buyer. Recovery would require legal action against Seller.

amplified_by.effect: Buyer's ability to recover deposit upon Seller default would be impaired if funds are already with Seller

R19.title: Deemed Approval Through Inaction on Due Diligence
R19.description: The Additional Deposit becomes due upon 'expiration of the Due Diligence Period without Buyer's delivery of a Termination Notice.' This creates a deemed approval mechanism where Buyer's failure to act (deliver Termination Notice) triggers non-refundable deposit obligations. If Buyer's team misses the deadline or miscommunicates, Buyer is locked into the transaction without affirmative approval.

amplified_by.effect: Deemed approval locks in non-refundability of Initial Deposit already at risk

R20.title: Bracketed Interest Credit Language
R20.description: The bracketed language '[plus accrued interest thereon]' suggests uncertainty about whether interest on the Deposit will be credited to Buyer at Closing. The first bracketed alternative in p_18 states interest is 'held for the account of Buyer,' but this p_20 bracket creates ambiguity. If interest is substantial and the deal closes, Buyer should ensure interest credits against Purchase Price.

mitigated_by.effect: First bracketed alternative in p_18 provides that interest is held for Buyer's account

R21.title: Blank Purchase Price Allocation
R21.description: The allocation amount for Personal Property is left blank ($____________). This creates ambiguity that could result in disputes over the allocation, which has significant tax implications. If Seller fills in an unfavorable allocation or disputes arise later, Buyer may face unexpected tax consequences. Personal property is typically depreciated over shorter periods than real property, so Buyer generally benefits from a higher personal property allocation.

R22.title: No Tax Reporting Consistency Requirement
R22.description: The allocation provision lacks any requirement that both parties report the allocation consistently for tax purposes. Without such language, Seller could report a different allocation to the IRS, potentially triggering an audit or dispute with tax authorities.

R23.title: Seven-Day Delivery Window May Be Insufficient
R23.description: Seller has seven days after mutual execution to deliver survey and title documents. However, there is no remedy specified if Seller fails to deliver within this timeframe. Buyer's Title Review Period runs from the Effective Date (per Section 4B), not from receipt of documents, meaning Buyer could lose review time if Seller delays delivery. This creates a timing mismatch that disadvantages Buyer.

R24.title: No Consequence for Late Delivery
R24.description: The clause obligates Seller to deliver documents within seven days but provides no consequence or remedy if Seller fails to comply. Buyer has no explicit right to extend review periods, terminate, or seek other relief for late delivery.

R25.title: Survey Delivery Conditioned on Seller's Possession
R25.description: Seller's obligation to deliver a survey is qualified by 'if any' and 'in the possession of Seller.' This allows Seller to claim no survey exists or that it is not in their possession, leaving Buyer without baseline survey information. Buyer bears the full cost and time burden of obtaining a new survey.

R26.title: Buyer Bears Full Survey Cost
R26.description: Buyer is required to pay for any updated or new ALTA survey at Buyer's expense. While this is market-standard, in a Buyer-favorable negotiation, Seller could be required to share this cost or provide a credit.

R27.title: Title Company Name Left Blank
R27.description: The title company name is left blank, which could lead to disputes over which title company will be used. Buyer should ensure a reputable title company acceptable to Buyer is specified.

R28.title: Silence Constitutes Approval of Title Defects
R28.description: If Buyer fails to deliver Title Objections within the ten-day Title Review Period, all exceptions and title conditions are deemed approved. This is a significant trap for Buyer—missing the deadline results in waiver of all title objections, even material defects. The period runs from the Effective Date, not from receipt of Title Documents, compounding the risk if Seller delays delivery.

R29.title: Title Review Period Runs from Effective Date, Not Receipt
R29.description: The Title Review Period is ten days from the Effective Date, but Seller has seven days after mutual execution to deliver Title Documents (Section 4A). This means Buyer could have as few as three days to review Title Documents if Seller delivers on the last day. This is grossly inadequate for proper title review.

R30.title: Seller Has Absolute Discretion to Refuse Title Cure
R30.description: Seller may elect not to cure any Title Objection in its sole discretion. Even for material defects that render title unmarketable, Seller can simply refuse to cure, leaving Buyer with only the option to waive or terminate. This gives Seller significant leverage and allows Seller to refuse to address even readily curable defects.

R31.title: Buyer's Only Remedy is Termination or Waiver
R31.description: If Seller refuses to cure Title Objections, Buyer's only options are to waive the objection or terminate the Agreement. Buyer has no right to a purchase price reduction, credit at closing, or other remedy for uncured title defects.

R32.title: Termination Right Limited to Due Diligence Period
R32.description: If Seller refuses to cure Title Objections, Buyer's termination right is limited to 'any time prior to the end of the Due Diligence Period.' If the Due Diligence Period ends before Seller responds to Title Objections, or shortly thereafter, Buyer may lose its termination right. This creates a timing trap.

R33.title: Five-Day Review Too Short for Supplements
R33.description: Buyer has only five (5) days to review and disapprove title exceptions in supplemental reports. Given that supplements may arrive close to closing and could contain significant new encumbrances (mechanics' liens, judgment liens, new easements), this compressed timeframe may be insufficient for proper legal review, especially if Buyer's counsel is unavailable or if the exception requires investigation. Missing this deadline results in automatic deemed approval of potentially harmful exceptions.

amplified_by.effect: Title review cannot extend closing, compressing available time even further

R34.title: Automatic Deemed Approval of Exceptions
R34.description: If Buyer fails to timely communicate disapproval of a supplemental exception, it automatically becomes a Permitted Exception. This 'silence equals consent' provision shifts risk to Buyer and could result in Buyer taking title subject to objectionable encumbrances (such as easements, liens, or restrictions) simply due to an administrative oversight or delayed mail delivery.

amplified_by.effect: AS-IS provision may limit Buyer's post-closing remedies for title defects

R35.title: Title Review Cannot Extend Closing
R35.description: The express prohibition that 'in no event shall title review extend the Closing Date' creates significant risk for Buyer. If a critical title defect appears in a supplemental report received close to closing, Buyer may be forced to either (a) accept a defective title, (b) waive material objections, or (c) potentially be in default for refusing to close. This is particularly dangerous if Seller causes new exceptions to appear (through liens, new agreements, etc.) near closing.

amplified_by.effect: Buyer could lose deposit if deemed in default for refusing to close over title issues

R36.title: Special Warranty Deed Limits Title Protection
R36.description: Seller is conveying title by special warranty deed rather than general warranty deed. A special warranty deed only warrants against defects arising during Seller's ownership period, not against defects from prior owners. This leaves Buyer exposed to claims arising from title defects that originated before Seller acquired the property, with recourse only against the title insurance policy rather than Seller directly.

mitigated_by.effect: Title insurance provides alternative protection against covered defects

R37.title: Permitted Exceptions Definition Circular
R37.description: The definition of 'Permitted Exceptions' is somewhat circular and relies heavily on deemed approvals from the title review process. Combined with the automatic deemed approval provisions in Section 4B, this could result in Buyer taking title subject to exceptions that were never actually reviewed or consciously approved, merely not timely objected to.

amplified_by.effect: Automatic deemed approval expands what becomes a Permitted Exception

R38.title: Endorsements Must Be Agreed During DD Period
R38.description: The requirement that endorsements be 'requested by Buyer and agreed to by Title Company during the Due Diligence Period' could prevent Buyer from obtaining necessary endorsements discovered after due diligence expires. If title issues are revealed post-due diligence (e.g., through a supplemental report), Buyer may not be able to require additional endorsements to address newly discovered risks.

amplified_by.effect: Combined with no closing extension, limits Buyer's ability to address late-discovered title issues

R39.title: Title Insurance Limited to Purchase Price
R39.description: Title insurance coverage is limited to the Purchase Price amount. If Buyer is making significant improvements or the property appreciates substantially, this coverage may become inadequate. Additionally, Purchase Price may not reflect true market value if Buyer negotiated a favorable deal.

R40.title: Due Diligence Deadline Left Blank
R40.description: The due diligence period end date is left blank ('on or before 5 p.m. Pacific time on ____________________'). This is a critical term that, if not properly completed, creates ambiguity about when Buyer's inspection rights terminate and when the deposit may become non-refundable. This could lead to disputes about whether Buyer timely exercised termination rights.

amplified_by.effect: Missing deadline could affect when Additional Deposit becomes due/at risk
Ambiguity affects deposit refund rights

R41.title: Three Business Days for Document Delivery May Be Insufficient
R41.description: Seller has only three (3) business days to deliver Due Diligence Documents. While this short timeframe benefits Buyer by getting materials quickly, if Seller fails to timely deliver, there is no automatic extension of the Due Diligence Period. Buyer could be forced to conduct inspections with incomplete information, yet still face the same deadline.

mitigated_by.effect: Buyer's sole discretion approval right provides termination flexibility

R42.title: Broad Sole Discretion Termination Right
R42.description: This is a FAVORABLE provision for Buyer. Buyer has 'sole and absolute discretion' to approve or disapprove all matters pertaining to the property's condition. This provides Buyer maximum flexibility to terminate during due diligence for any reason or no reason, making the deposit refundable during this period. Ensure this right is preserved.

R43.title: Waiver of Reliance on Due Diligence Materials
R43.description: This provision disclaims any representation or warranty by Seller regarding the accuracy or completeness of due diligence documents. Buyer is essentially agreeing to conduct its entire investigation based on materials that may be incomplete, inaccurate, or misleading, with no recourse against Seller for deficiencies in those materials. This significantly increases Buyer's risk of making an uninformed purchase decision and eliminates any claim Buyer might have if the materials provided are materially inaccurate.

R44.title: Narrow Carve-Out for Section 7 Representations Only
R44.description: The exception 'except as expressly provided in Section 7 hereof' limits Buyer's recourse to only those specific representations made in Section 7. If Seller provides materially misleading due diligence materials that are not covered by Section 7 representations, Buyer has no claim. This creates a gap between the information relied upon and the representations protecting that reliance.

R45.title: Nonintrusive Inspection Limitation May Impair Due Diligence
R45.description: The restriction to 'nonintrusive inspections, tests and studies' may prevent Buyer from conducting Phase II environmental testing, soil borings, or other invasive testing necessary to fully assess the Property's condition. This limitation could leave Buyer unable to discover material defects or environmental contamination before closing.

R46.title: Seller Accompaniment May Chill Thorough Inspection
R46.description: Seller's unilateral right to accompany Buyer during all inspections may inhibit frank discussions between Buyer and its consultants, particularly regarding environmental or structural concerns. While facially neutral, this could chill thorough inspection and documentation of Property defects.

R47.title: Blank Advance Notice Period Creates Uncertainty
R47.description: The advance notice requirement contains a blank ('____________ (___) business days') that must be negotiated and filled in. An overly long notice period could impair Buyer's ability to efficiently conduct due diligence within the Due Diligence Period, particularly for follow-up inspections.

R48.title: Buyer Bears All Inspection Costs
R48.description: While standard in commercial transactions, this provision places the entire financial burden of due diligence on Buyer. There is no provision for Seller to bear costs of re-inspection if Seller fails to provide access or if Property conditions change between inspections.

R49.title: Undefined 'Reasonable Advance Notice' Standard
R49.description: The requirement for 'reasonable advance notice' is undefined and subjective, potentially allowing Seller to claim insufficient notice and deny access. This conflicts with the specific notice period mentioned in Section 5B and creates ambiguity as to which standard governs.

R50.title: Minimize Interference Standard is Subjective
R50.description: The requirement to 'minimize interference with Seller's business on, and Seller's tenants' occupancy of, the Property' is inherently subjective and could be used by Seller to obstruct legitimate inspection activities. What constitutes 'minimized' interference is not defined and could be disputed.

R51.title: Broad Uncapped Indemnity for Entry and Testing
R51.description: Buyer provides an unlimited indemnity for 'all costs, expenses, damages, liabilities, liens or claims' arising from entry onto the Property. This indemnity is uncapped, survives closing or termination, and could expose Buyer to substantial liability even for minor inspection-related incidents. The breadth of 'directly related to any entry' is potentially very wide.

R52.title: Indemnity Survives Indefinitely
R52.description: The indemnity obligation survives closing or termination without any time limitation. This creates perpetual exposure for Buyer related to pre-closing inspection activities, potentially for years after the transaction closes or terminates.

R53.title: Broad Restoration Obligation Without Standard
R53.description: Buyer must 'promptly repair any damage' and 'restore the Property to its prior condition.' The standard of 'prior condition' is vague and could be disputed. Additionally, there is no qualification for ordinary wear and tear from inspections or reasonable tolerance for minor cosmetic impacts inherent in property testing.

R54.title: Pre-Existing Conditions Carve-Out May Be Narrowly Construed
R54.description: While the carve-out for pre-existing conditions is favorable to Buyer, the parenthetical excludes only 'non-negligent aggravation' of pre-existing conditions. If Buyer's testing is deemed to have negligently aggravated a pre-existing condition (even if the condition was unknown and would have required testing to discover), Buyer could be liable. The distinction between discovery and aggravation may be difficult to prove.

R55.title: Seller Discretion Over Insurance Requirements
R55.description: While the clause establishes a minimum $2,000,000 CGL requirement, additional insurance requirements are subject to Seller's 'reasonably satisfactory' approval. This subjective standard could allow Seller to demand excessive or unusual coverage, potentially delaying or complicating Buyer's due diligence access. There is no cap on what Seller can request beyond the stated minimum, and no mechanism for resolving disputes over reasonableness.

R56.title: Insurance Requirement May Delay Property Access
R56.description: Buyer must provide insurance certificates before entry, which is standard but could create timing issues if Buyer needs to quickly arrange inspections during a limited due diligence period. Combined with the subjective 'reasonably satisfactory' standard, this could effectively shorten the Due Diligence Period.

R57.title: Unlimited Survival of Inspection Obligations
R57.description: This provision causes Buyer's indemnification obligations and other onerous terms from Section 5.2 (including repair obligations, indemnification for liens and claims, insurance requirements) to survive termination without any time limitation. This creates perpetual exposure for Buyer even if the deal terminates during due diligence. Buyer could face claims years after walking away from the transaction for alleged damage during inspections.

R58.title: Silence Deemed Approval with Deposit at Risk
R58.description: If Buyer fails to deliver a Termination Notice by the end of the Due Diligence Period, Buyer is automatically deemed to have provided an Approval Notice, which causes the Deposit to become nonrefundable. This creates significant risk: if Buyer's team misses the deadline (even due to circumstances beyond control like illness, emergency, or communication failures), Buyer loses the ability to terminate and places the Deposit at risk. This is a 'trap' provision that could result in substantial financial exposure.

R59.title: Mandatory Turnover of Due Diligence Reports
R59.description: Upon termination for any reason other than Seller's default, Buyer must deliver copies of all third-party reports to Seller upon request. This gives Seller free access to potentially valuable studies, reports, and test results that Buyer paid for. These materials may identify defects Seller can remedy before remarketing the property, or may be used against Buyer in any disputes. There is no reciprocal obligation for Seller to compensate Buyer for these materials.

R60.title: Vague Timing for Notice Delivery
R60.description: The clause requires Buyer to 'promptly' notify Seller of both termination and approval decisions, but does not define what 'promptly' means. While the hard deadline is the end of the Due Diligence Period, the 'promptly' language could be used by Seller to argue Buyer breached by not delivering notice earlier, potentially affecting Buyer's rights or creating disputes about whether proper notice was given.

R61.title: Conditions Subject to Waiver Framework
R61.description: This provision establishes that Buyer's closing conditions are subject to 'satisfaction or waiver by Buyer.' While this preserves Buyer's flexibility to waive conditions, it also means Buyer cannot refuse to close by claiming a condition failed if Buyer could have waived it. This framework should be reviewed in conjunction with Section 5.6 (waiver provisions) to understand the full scope of Buyer's discretion and any limitations.

R62.title: Closing Condition Tied to Section 11.3 Deliveries
R62.description: This condition requires Seller to deliver items listed in Section 11.3, but the language 'as provided in this Agreement' could be interpreted to mean that if Section 11.3 provides any flexibility on timing or manner of delivery, Seller has satisfied this condition even with delayed or incomplete delivery. The condition should be absolute rather than qualified by 'as provided in this Agreement.'

R63.title: Irrevocable Commitment Standard Undefined
R63.description: The condition requires the Title Company to be 'irrevocably committed' to issue the Title Policy, but this standard is ambiguous. Title companies typically issue commitments with standard exceptions and requirements. It's unclear what constitutes an 'irrevocable' commitment versus a standard commitment, and whether any conditions or requirements in the commitment would defeat this standard. This ambiguity could lead to disputes about whether this condition has been satisfied or give Seller an argument that the condition is not met even when a standard commitment is available.

R64.title: Condition Depends on Section 4 Requirements
R64.description: This condition precedent incorporates the requirements of Section 4 by reference. Buyer should ensure that Section 4 adequately addresses the form of Title Policy required, including extended coverage, deletion of standard exceptions (survey, mechanics' liens, parties in possession), and any required endorsements. If Section 4 requirements are insufficient, this condition precedent may be satisfied with a Title Policy that doesn't fully protect Buyer.

R65.title: Material Qualifier Weakens Rep Bring-Down
R65.description: The condition requires representations to be true only 'in all material respects,' which significantly weakens Buyer's protection. This means Seller's representations could be inaccurate in ways that don't meet the 'material' threshold, yet Buyer would still be required to close. Combined with the existing 'Seller's Actual Knowledge' qualifiers on many representations in Section 7A, this creates a double-layered shield for Seller. Immaterial misrepresentations could still cause Buyer financial harm post-closing without triggering the condition precedent.

R66.title: No Mechanism to Verify Reps at Closing
R66.description: While this condition requires representations to be true at Closing, the Agreement does not appear to require Seller to deliver a bring-down certificate confirming the continued accuracy of representations as of Closing. Without a closing deliverable confirming representation accuracy, Buyer has limited ability to verify compliance with this condition precedent and may have difficulty establishing a breach if issues arise post-closing.

R67.title: Minimum Tenant Estoppels Not Defined
R67.description: The condition references 'Minimum Tenant Estoppels' but this term does not appear to be defined in the document map. Without a clear definition specifying which tenants must provide estoppels (e.g., by square footage threshold, rent amount, or specific named tenants), Buyer has uncertain protection. Seller could argue that estoppels from minor tenants satisfy this condition even if major tenants refuse or provide adverse estoppels. This is a critical gap for multi-tenant properties where estoppels from anchor or major tenants are essential.

R68.title: Substantially In Form Standard May Allow Deviations
R68.description: The 'substantially in the form' language allows estoppels to deviate from Exhibit H. Tenants frequently modify requested estoppel forms, sometimes inserting claims, qualifications, or adverse information. If deviations are permitted as long as estoppels are 'substantially' in the required form, Buyer may be required to accept estoppels containing adverse information or lacking key confirmations. There is no standard for what deviations are acceptable.

R69.title: Estoppel Condition is Bracketed/Optional
R69.description: The entire estoppel condition precedent is in brackets, indicating it is optional or subject to negotiation. Buyer should ensure this provision is included in the final Agreement, particularly for multi-tenant properties where estoppel verification is critical to confirming lease terms, rental obligations, security deposits, and the absence of landlord defaults.

R70.title: Seller Conditions May Create Closing Uncertainty
R70.description: This provision establishes Seller's conditions precedent to closing. While some conditions favoring Seller are standard, Buyer should carefully review Sections 5E(i) through 5E(iii) to ensure they don't create opportunities for Seller to avoid closing on pretextual grounds. The 'all other conditions to Seller's obligations' reference also incorporates unstated conditions that may be scattered throughout the Agreement, creating uncertainty about what Seller can use to refuse closing.

R71.title: Seller May Waive Its Own Conditions
R71.description: The provision allows Seller to waive its conditions precedent at Seller's discretion. While this is standard, Buyer should confirm that Seller cannot use the failure of its own waivable conditions as a basis for termination or to claim Buyer default. The interplay between this provision and Section 5F (p_49) regarding waiver of conditions should be reviewed.

R72.title: No Deadline Specified for Closing Payment Deposit
R72.description: While this condition requires Buyer to deposit the Closing Payment into escrow, it does not specify a deadline other than before Closing. Section 3C (p_20) should specify the timing, but if it merely says 'at Closing,' there could be a gap where Seller claims the condition is not satisfied because funds weren't deposited sufficiently in advance. This creates potential for Seller to claim Buyer default on timing grounds.

R73.title: Delivery Obligations Undefined Here
R73.description: This clause conditions Seller's obligation to close on Buyer's delivery of items described in Section 11.4. Without reviewing Section 11.4 directly in this clause, Buyer cannot immediately assess the full scope of its delivery obligations, which could include documents or items that are difficult or time-consuming to obtain. If Buyer fails to deliver any required item, Seller could refuse to close without liability.

R74.title: Bring-Down May Block Closing
R74.description: This provision requires that Buyer's representations and warranties be true as of Closing. While standard, this creates a bring-down condition that could allow Seller to refuse to close if any of Buyer's representations become inaccurate—even due to circumstances beyond Buyer's control. The 'material respects' qualifier provides some protection, but Buyer should ensure its representations are limited and accurate.

R75.title: Typographical Error in Text
R75.description: The phrase 'in all material respects of as of the Closing Date' contains a typographical error ('of as of' should be 'as of'). While likely a scrivener's error, ambiguous language could potentially be exploited in a dispute.

R76.title: Termination Right May Be Waived Inadvertently
R76.description: While the clause clarifies that conditions in Sections 5.1-5.4 are for Buyer's exclusive benefit, the termination right requires 'written notice' without specifying a deadline or cure period. This could create uncertainty about when the right lapses. Additionally, a party proceeding toward closing despite knowledge of an unsatisfied condition might be deemed to have waived the condition.

R77.title: Section Reference Appears Incomplete
R77.description: The clause references 'Sections 5.1 through 5.4' but the document structure shows these are Sections 5A through 5D. Additionally, there is no space between '5.4' and 'are' in the text ('5.4are'), suggesting a formatting or typographical issue. This could create ambiguity about which conditions are for Buyer's benefit.

R78.title: Deposit Treatment Unclear on Termination
R78.description: This termination provision addresses return of documents and sharing of escrow cancellation fees, but critically does not address the return of Buyer's Deposit upon termination. The clause explicitly excludes 'Section 13' scenarios (which addresses defaults), but does not affirmatively state that Buyer's Deposit is returned in non-default termination scenarios. This omission could be exploited by Seller to argue the Deposit is not automatically returned.

R79.title: Buyer Must Return Due Diligence Documents
R79.description: Upon termination, Buyer must return 'all documents delivered to Buyer by Seller.'
