This could include voluminous due diligence materials that Buyer may have copied, analyzed, or relied upon in making decisions about other properties. The obligation to return (rather than destroy) could be burdensome and the scope is unclear regarding copies.

R80.title: Shared Cancellation Fee Even If Seller Caused Termination
R80.description: The clause requires parties to 'equally share any cancellation fee of the Escrow Holder' regardless of which party caused the termination. This means Buyer pays half the cancellation fee even if Seller breached a representation or failed to satisfy a condition, as long as the termination is not under Section 13 (default).

R81.title: Representations Limited by Knowledge Qualifiers
R81.description: This introductory clause to Seller's representations does not itself contain risk, but the substantive representations that follow (Sections 7A(i) through 7A(vi)) are heavily qualified by 'Seller's Actual Knowledge' standards. Buyer should be aware that the following representations may be significantly limited and should review the definition of 'Seller's Actual Knowledge' carefully.

R82.title: Unqualified Organization Representation
R82.description: Unlike other Seller representations that are qualified by 'Seller's Actual Knowledge,' this representation regarding Seller's organization, authorization, and non-violation of contracts/judicial orders is made without any knowledge qualifier. While organization reps are typically unqualified, the inclusion of the broad statement that documents 'do not, and at the time of Closing, will not, violate any provisions of any contract or judicial order' could expose Buyer to risk if Seller unknowingly violates an obscure contractual restriction. If this representation proves false, Buyer may have a claim, but the survival period and any caps on liability will limit Buyer's remedies.

R83.title: No Good Standing Representation
R83.description: The representation states Seller is 'duly organized and validly existing' but does not include the customary 'in good standing' language. While Seller may be validly existing, it could be administratively dissolved or not in good standing in its state of formation, which could affect its authority to convey property or result in tax liens. This is particularly important if the Property is in a different state than Seller's state of formation.

R84.title: Rent Roll Accuracy Limited to Seller's Knowledge
R84.description: The rent roll representation is qualified by 'Seller's Actual Knowledge' and further limited to 'material respects.' Combined with the narrow definition of 'Seller's Actual Knowledge' in Section 7A(vi) (which typically limits knowledge to specific individuals without duty of inquiry), this provides Buyer with very limited protection if the rent roll contains inaccuracies that Seller's designated representative did not personally know about. Rent roll accuracy is fundamental to the economic deal.

R85.title: Rent Roll Not Dated or Updated at Closing
R85.description: The representation references 'the rent roll identified in the Due Diligence Documents' but does not specify a date for the rent roll or require an updated rent roll at Closing. Between the Effective Date and Closing, lease terms may change, tenants may default, or new leases may be signed. Without a bring-down requirement or updated rent roll certification, Buyer could acquire property with materially different rental income than represented.

R86.title: Violation Representation Limited to Effective Date
R86.description: The representation regarding governmental notices of violations is explicitly limited to 'as of the Effective Date.' This means Seller makes no representation about violations existing or notices received between the Effective Date and Closing. While Seller agrees to forward notices received after the Effective Date, there is no representation that no violations exist at Closing, leaving Buyer exposed to acquiring property with undisclosed code violations or compliance issues that arose after contract signing.

R87.title: Limited to Notices Received by Seller
R87.description: The representation is limited to notices 'Seller has received' from governmental authorities. This does not cover: (1) violations that exist but for which no notice has been issued; (2) notices sent to the Property address rather than Seller's address; (3) notices sent to a property manager or other agent; or (4) violations discoverable through public records. Buyer could acquire property with existing violations that simply haven't resulted in formal notice to Seller.

R88.title: Notice Forwarding Without Termination Right
R88.description: While Seller agrees to 'immediately provide Buyer with a copy of any such notices received after the Effective Date,' the clause does not give Buyer any remedies if a material violation notice is received. There is no right to terminate, no price adjustment mechanism, and no obligation for Seller to cure. Buyer could be stuck acquiring property with newly-discovered material code violations with no recourse other than proceeding to Closing or potentially claiming a breach of the bring-down condition.

R89.title: Litigation Rep Covers All Seller Litigation Not Property
R89.description: The representation states there is no litigation 'pending or threatened against Seller' rather than being limited to litigation affecting the Property. This is actually overbroad and could inadvertently cause a breach if Seller has unrelated litigation. However, from Buyer's perspective, the opposite problem exists: this representation could be interpreted narrowly to NOT cover litigation against the Property itself if Seller is not named as a defendant (e.g., suits by third parties over title, boundary disputes, etc.). A well-drafted litigation rep should cover both Seller and the Property.

R90.title: No Disclosure Schedule for Litigation
R90.description: Unlike the hazardous materials representation in Section 7A(vi) which references 'Exhibit H' for exceptions, the litigation representation contains no carve-out for disclosed matters. If there is any pending or threatened litigation, Seller cannot make this representation truthfully without a disclosure schedule. Additionally, if litigation arises between signing and Closing, there is no mechanism for supplemental disclosure without breaching the bring-down condition.

R91.title: Condemnation Rep Limited to Seller's Actual Knowledge
R91.description: Condemnation and eminent domain proceedings are matters of public record and published notice. Qualifying this representation by 'Seller's Actual Knowledge' allows Seller to avoid liability even if condemnation proceedings are publicly pending but Seller's designated representative did not personally know about them. Condemnation can dramatically affect property value, and Buyer should have stronger protection.

R92.title: No Post-Signing Condemnation Notice Obligation
R92.description: Unlike Section 7A(iii) regarding violation notices which requires Seller to 'immediately provide Buyer with a copy of any such notices received after the Effective Date,' the condemnation representation contains no similar obligation. If Seller learns of threatened condemnation between signing and Closing, there is no express duty to notify Buyer. While Section 14 addresses destruction/condemnation occurring before Closing, it is triggered by the event itself, not notice of threatened proceedings.

R93.title: Inconsistent Knowledge Qualifier Standard
R93.description: This paragraph uses 'to the best of Seller's knowledge' while other sections use 'to Seller's Actual Knowledge.' The phrase 'best of knowledge' could imply a duty to investigate, but this inconsistency creates ambiguity about the applicable standard and could lead to disputes about what Seller was required to know.

R94.title: Uncapped Exhibit H Disclosure Carve-Out
R94.description: The representation regarding tenant concessions is subject to exceptions disclosed on Exhibit H. Buyer should carefully review Exhibit H to ensure it does not contain sweeping exceptions that gut this representation. The carve-out allows Seller to disclose any tenant concessions or allowances without liability.

R95.title: Representation Limited to Existing Leases Only
R95.description: The representations are limited to 'leases in existence as of the Effective Date,' which could exclude new leases entered into between Effective Date and Closing. Buyer may be exposed to undisclosed concessions or commissions on leases executed after the Effective Date.

R96.title: Materiality Qualifier on Lease Copies
R96.description: The representation that lease copies are 'true, correct and complete in all material respects' allows Seller to have immaterial inaccuracies in the leases provided. While standard, this could allow Seller to omit side letters or amendments that individually appear immaterial but collectively affect lease economics.

R97.title: No Duty to Investigate for Knowledge
R97.description: The definition of 'Seller's Actual Knowledge' is limited to a single named individual's actual knowledge 'without such person undertaking any investigation.' This extremely narrow standard means Seller has no obligation to make any inquiry, and the knowledge of all other Seller personnel, property managers, or agents is excluded. This could allow Seller to claim ignorance of material issues.

R98.title: Representations Auto-Modified by Due Diligence Materials
R98.description: This provision automatically deems Seller's representations modified to conform to any inconsistent information in the Due Diligence Materials. This is extremely Seller-favorable because it shifts the burden to Buyer to identify all inconsistencies, effectively negating representations if contrary information is buried anywhere in the due diligence documents.

R99.title: Buyer Covenant Not to Sue Knowledge Individuals
R99.description: Buyer covenants not to bring any action against the named knowledge individuals personally. While it is reasonable to protect employees from personal liability, this language is broad ('any action of any kind') and could be read to prevent Buyer from even deposing these individuals in litigation against Seller.

R100.title: Broad Pre-Closing Waiver of Representation Claims
R100.description: If Buyer closes with knowledge of a breach, Buyer waives all remedies including rescission. This is a significant risk because 'knowledge' is broadly defined to include anything in the 'Property Information' that is inconsistent with a representation—meaning Buyer could be deemed to know of issues buried in documents it may not have fully reviewed.

R101.title: Deemed Knowledge from Property Information
R101.description: Buyer is 'deemed to have known' of representation breaches if any 'Property Information' contains inconsistent information. This constructive knowledge standard is extremely broad and could trap Buyer if adverse information is buried in voluminous due diligence materials that Buyer did not specifically review.

R102.title: $50,000 Aggregate Deductible on Claims
R102.description: Buyer cannot make claims for representation breaches unless aggregate damages exceed $50,000. While baskets are market, this provision operates as a true deductible (Buyer cannot recover the first $50,000) rather than a threshold (where once exceeded, Buyer recovers from dollar one). The aggregate nature means multiple smaller issues could individually fall below the threshold.

R103.title: Blank Aggregate Liability Cap
R103.description: The aggregate liability cap is left blank ($_________). This is a critical negotiating point that must be resolved. If the cap is set too low relative to the purchase price, Buyer's remedies for material breaches could be severely limited. Typical caps range from 1-3% of purchase price for non-fundamental representations.

R104.title: Liability Cap Applies to Both Parties
R104.description: The cap applies to 'either party,' meaning Buyer's liability to Seller is also capped. While this appears balanced, Buyer's primary exposure is losing the deposit (which is already addressed in Section 13.1), so a mutual cap may give Seller more protection than Buyer. The cap should be asymmetric if Seller's potential liability exposure is greater.

R105.title: Cap Covers All Obligations Including Covenants
R105.description: The liability cap applies not just to representations and warranties but to 'covenants and other obligations (whether express or implied).' This could limit Buyer's recovery for breach of Seller's operating covenants, failure to deliver documents, or other contractual obligations beyond just rep breaches.

R106.title: Introductory Language Only - No Substantive Content
R106.description: This paragraph is merely introductory language for Buyer's representations and warranties. The actual representations follow in subsequent paragraphs. No risks in this specific paragraph, but Buyer should ensure its representations are appropriately qualified and not broader than necessary.

R107.title: Buyer Rep Broader Than Seller's Equivalent
R107.description: Buyer's organizational representation includes 'in good standing' and 'full right, power and authority,' which is broader than Seller's equivalent representation in Section 7A(i) (p_53). This asymmetry means Buyer bears a higher standard of warranty than Seller for equivalent organizational matters. Additionally, Buyer's representation is unqualified while many of Seller's representations are limited by 'Seller's Actual Knowledge.'

R108.title: Unqualified No-Violation Rep Creates Risk
R108.description: Buyer represents that execution 'do not, and at the time of Closing will not, violate any provisions of any contract or judicial order.' This is an absolute, unqualified representation with no materiality qualifier. Minor technical violations of any contract could theoretically constitute a breach. Compare this to Seller's representations which are heavily qualified by 'Seller's Actual Knowledge.'

R109.title: 6-Month Survival Period Too Short for Buyer
R109.description: The six-month survival period for representations and warranties is extremely short and favors Seller. Many breaches of Seller's representations (particularly regarding the rent roll, litigation, environmental matters, or lease compliance) may not be discoverable until well after six months of ownership. Industry standard for commercial real estate is typically 12-18 months. This short period significantly limits Buyer's ability to seek recourse for Seller misrepresentations.

R110.title: Auto-Termination of Claims Not in Litigation
R110.description: The provision automatically terminates 'any cause of action resulting from a breach thereof not then in litigation' at the end of the Survival Period. This requires Buyer to actually file litigation (not merely give notice of a claim or begin negotiations) to preserve claims. This is more restrictive than provisions allowing claims to survive if written notice is given within the survival period.

R111.title: Termination as Sole Remedy for Seller's Changed Reps
R111.description: If Seller discovers that a representation has become incorrect after the Due Diligence Period, Buyer's 'sole remedy' is termination. This means Buyer cannot pursue damages even if Seller's misrepresentation was negligent or caused Buyer to incur significant costs. This effectively allows Seller to disclose problems at the last minute and escape liability by allowing Buyer to terminate, putting all risk of wasted due diligence costs, financing costs, and opportunity costs on Buyer.

R112.title: Compressed Decision Timeline on Changed Reps
R112.description: If Seller notifies of a changed representation late in the process, Buyer has only 10 days (or until Closing if less than 10 days remain) to evaluate and decide whether to terminate. Seller then has 5 days to elect to cure. This compressed timeline may not allow Buyer sufficient time to assess the impact of material new information, particularly if it involves complex issues like environmental contamination, title defects, or tenant disputes.

R113.title: Seller Cure Right Delays Closing Without Cost
R113.description: If Buyer elects to terminate due to a changed representation, Seller can elect to cure, making Seller's cure a 'condition precedent to Buyer's obligations.' However, there is no deadline for Seller's cure, no requirement that Seller bear the costs of delay, and no compensation to Buyer if Seller's cure attempts fail. Buyer could be held in limbo while Seller attempts to cure, incurring carrying costs and losing other opportunities.

R114.title: Covenant Period Has No Post-Termination Tail
R114.description: Seller's covenants apply 'between the Effective Date and the Closing or earlier termination of this Agreement.' If the Agreement terminates (for any reason), Seller's covenants immediately cease. This is standard, but if there are any surviving obligations or wind-down activities, Buyer would have no contractual protection for Seller's conduct during any interim period before termination is fully effectuated.

R115.title: Deemed Approval After 5 Days
R115.description: Buyer's consent to new leases, lease modifications, or lease terminations is 'conclusively deemed granted' if Buyer does not object within 5 days of Seller's request. This is an extremely short window for Buyer to review potentially complex lease documents, evaluate tenant creditworthiness, and assess the impact on property value. If Buyer is traveling, distracted by other matters, or experiences any delay in receiving the notice, Buyer could inadvertently approve a lease that materially affects the Property's value or operations.

amplified_by.effect: Buyer becomes responsible for all leasing commissions and TI costs for approved leases

R116.title: Buyer Assumes All Leasing Costs Post-Approval
R116.description: If Buyer approves (or is deemed to approve) any new lease or lease modification, Buyer becomes 'responsible for all leasing commissions, tenant improvements and other costs payable by the Landlord thereunder' from Closing. This could represent significant unexpected costs, especially if combined with the 5-day deemed approval provision. There is no cap on these costs, no requirement that Seller disclose estimated costs when seeking approval, and no distinction between costs arising before vs. after Closing.

amplified_by.effect: Deemed approval after 5 days could trigger cost assumption without informed consent

R117.title: Vague 'Same Manner' Operating Standard
R117.description: During the Due Diligence Period, Seller must maintain and operate the Property 'in the same manner in which Seller is currently operating.' This standard is subjective and difficult to enforce. It does not require Seller to maintain the Property in good condition, comply with all laws, or meet any objective standard—only to continue whatever practices Seller was employing, which could be substandard.

R118.title: No Lease Consent Rights During Due Diligence
R118.description: The consent requirement for new leases, modifications, or terminations only applies 'After the Due Diligence Period expires.' During the Due Diligence Period itself, Seller appears free to enter into new leases or modify/terminate existing leases without Buyer's consent, as long as it's consistent with Seller's current manner of leasing. This could allow Seller to lock in unfavorable long-term leases before Buyer has completed its review.

mitigated_by.effect: Buyer can terminate during DD period if it discovers unfavorable leasing

R119.title: Broad Exception for 'Reasonably Necessary' Contracts
R119.description: While Seller generally needs Buyer's consent to enter into, modify, or terminate Service Contracts, there is a broad exception for contracts 'deemed reasonably necessary by Seller which are cancelable on thirty (30) days' notice without penalty.' The determination of what is 'reasonably necessary' is made by Seller, not an objective standard, and Seller could enter into unfavorable contracts under this exception that burden Buyer post-Closing.

mitigated_by.effect: Contracts under this exception must be cancelable on 30 days notice

R120.title: Seller Not Obligated to Terminate Contracts Creating Cost
R120.description: Seller is not obligated to terminate any Service Contract that Buyer does not want to assume 'if such termination will create any additional cost or liability for Seller.' This could leave Buyer saddled with unwanted, long-term, or above-market service contracts if termination would cost Seller anything. There is no provision for Buyer to offer to pay the termination cost or for the parties to share such costs.

amplified_by.effect: AS-IS provision may limit Buyer's recourse for assuming unfavorable contracts

R121.title: Insurance Maintenance Limited to 'Currently in Force'
R121.description: Seller's obligation is only to 'maintain all casualty and liability insurance currently in force.' There is no requirement that current insurance is adequate, that it meets any particular coverage levels, or that it complies with lender requirements. If current coverage is deficient, Seller has no obligation to cure that deficiency.

amplified_by.effect: Inadequate insurance could leave Buyer exposed if casualty occurs before Closing

R122.title: Only 'Commercially Reasonable Efforts' for Estoppels
R122.description: Seller's obligation to obtain tenant estoppels is limited to 'commercially reasonable efforts.' This is a lower standard than 'best efforts' and provides Seller significant latitude. If Seller fails to obtain the Minimum Tenant Estoppels, Buyer's only remedy is termination—there is no right to specific performance or damages, and no obligation for Seller to use stronger efforts.

mitigated_by.effect: Buyer can terminate if Minimum Tenant Estoppels not obtained

R123.title: Seller's Certificate Substitutes for Missing Estoppels
R123.description: If Seller obtains the Minimum Tenant Estoppels but cannot obtain estoppels from remaining tenants, Buyer must accept a 'Seller's Lease Certificate' certifying (only 'to Seller's knowledge') the matters in the estoppel form. This certificate is far less valuable than a tenant estoppel because: (1) it's qualified by Seller's knowledge, (2) Seller may have limited liability for inaccuracies (see survival and liability provisions), and (3) it doesn't bind the tenant.

amplified_by.effect: Narrow knowledge definition limits utility of Seller's Certificate
Limited survival period may expire before lease issues materialize

R124.title: Subordination Agreements Conditioned on Lease Terms
R124.description: Seller's obligation to cooperate in obtaining subordination agreements (SNDAs) is heavily conditioned: only if the tenant's lease permits such a request. Additionally, Seller has 'no obligation to obtain and deliver' any subordination agreements—only to 'cooperate.' This may leave Buyer unable to satisfy lender requirements for subordination agreements.

R125.title: Comprehensive AS-IS Waiver Including Environmental
R125.description: This extremely broad AS-IS provision disclaims virtually all warranties and representations except those expressly stated in Section 7. Of particular concern, it disclaims representations regarding: (x) presence or absence of hazardous materials, (ix) compliance with environmental laws, (vii) compliance with all laws, and (xi) accuracy of due diligence materials. This shifts substantial risk to Buyer, particularly environmental risk which can result in significant remediation costs and liability.

mitigated_by.effect: Section 7 representations are carved out from AS-IS

amplified_by.effect: Section 10 Release compounds this waiver with an affirmative release
Short survival period limits time to discover and assert claims

R126.title: Waiver of Reliance on Due Diligence Materials
R126.description: Buyer expressly agrees it is 'relying solely on its own investigation' and not on 'any information provided or to be provided by Seller.' This waiver extends to the accuracy and completeness of due diligence materials, meaning Buyer may have no recourse even if Seller provided materially inaccurate information (outside of Section 7 reps). This significantly undermines the value of the due diligence process.

mitigated_by.effect: Representations in Section 7 are carved out

amplified_by.effect: Section 5.2 also disclaims reliance on DD Documents

R127.title: Release of Third-Party Information Sources
R127.description: Buyer agrees to 'fully and irrevocably release all such sources of information and preparers of information' retained by Seller from any claims. This could include environmental consultants, property condition assessors, and others whose reports may contain errors. Buyer would be precluded from pursuing claims against these parties even if their reports were negligently prepared.

mitigated_by.effect: Carve-out exists for claims based on direct relationship with preparers

R128.title: No Seller Obligation to Repair
R128.description: The AS-IS provision expressly states that 'SELLER HAS NO OBLIGATIONS TO MAKE REPAIRS, REPLACEMENTS OR IMPROVEMENTS.' Combined with the covenant in Section 8(a) that only requires Seller to maintain the Property 'in the same manner' as currently, this creates a gap where Property condition could deteriorate without remedy to Buyer.

amplified_by.effect: Vague operating covenant doesn't require repairs

R129.title: Sweeping release of all claims
R129.description: This release is extraordinarily broad, requiring Buyer to release Seller from 'any and all losses, liabilities, damages, claims, demands, causes of action, costs and expenses, whether known or unknown' arising from or connected with the Property. This includes structural conditions, environmental issues, and title matters. The 'whether known or unknown' language is particularly dangerous as it waives claims Buyer may not discover until after closing, potentially including latent defects, undisclosed environmental contamination, or other significant issues that due diligence may not uncover.

mitigated_by.effect: Partially preserves claims under Section 7.1 representations and post-closing obligations

amplified_by.effect: Combined with AS-IS clause, eliminates virtually all Buyer recourse
Short survival period on reps further limits window to discover and pursue excepted claims

R130.title: Broad environmental claims release
R130.description: Buyer releases Seller from 'any environmental claims and causes of action existing now or hereafter created or enacted.' This waives current and future environmental claims under laws that may not yet exist. While there is an exception for hazardous substances 'caused by Seller,' the burden of proving Seller caused the contamination will fall on Buyer, which is extremely difficult after closing when chain of custody is broken and Seller controls no records.

mitigated_by.effect: Environmental representation (if included) may provide limited recourse subject to survival period

amplified_by.effect: AS-IS provision combined with release leaves Buyer with minimal environmental protection

R131.title: Covenant not to sue is absolute
R131.description: The covenant that Buyer 'agrees never to commence, aid in any way, or prosecute against Seller... any action or other proceeding' is extremely broad and could be interpreted to prevent Buyer from even participating as a witness in litigation involving Seller and the Property, or from joining necessary parties in third-party claims. The 'aid in any way' language could hamper Buyer's ability to pursue legitimate claims against third parties where Seller's testimony or cooperation is needed.

R132.title: Limited survival exception for reps
R132.description: While this carve-out preserves claims under Section 7.1 representations, it is limited 'to the extent same survive Closing as provided therein.' This ties directly to Section 7.3 (p_65) which likely contains a short survival period, potentially as little as 6-12 months. Combined with the narrow 'to Seller's Actual Knowledge' qualifiers on most representations, this exception provides less protection than it appears.

amplified_by.effect: Short survival period in Section 7.3 significantly limits the practical value of this carve-out
Narrow knowledge qualifier on reps reduces likelihood of successful breach claim

R133.title: Vague 'other obligations' carve-out
R133.description: The carve-out for 'any other obligations of Seller identified herein which are to be performed after Closing' is vague and may be subject to dispute. It does not specify which obligations survive, potentially leading to litigation over whether specific Seller obligations (such as proration true-ups, estoppel delivery, or cooperation with 1031 exchanges) are covered.

R134.title: Closing date left blank
R134.description: The Closing Date is left blank ('on or before ______________________'). An undefined closing date creates significant uncertainty and could result in disputes over when performance is due, when time-is-of-the-essence provisions trigger, and when default occurs. This is a critical term that should never be left undefined in an executed agreement.

amplified_by.effect: If time-is-of-the-essence, undefined date creates immediate default risk

R135.title: Extension fee is non-refundable except for Seller default
R135.description: The Extension Fee is described as 'nonrefundable, except in case of Seller's default.' This means if Buyer pays an Extension Fee but closing fails to occur for reasons other than Seller's default (e.g., title issues, failure of a condition, mutual termination, casualty), Buyer loses the Extension Fee. This is a one-sided risk allocation that could result in significant forfeiture.

R136.title: Extension terms left blank
R136.description: Multiple critical extension terms are left blank: the extension period length ('_____________ day extension periods'), notice period ('at least __________ business days prior'), and Extension Fee amount ('$_______________'). These blanks create uncertainty about Buyer's extension rights and costs, which are valuable protections if Buyer needs additional time to close.

R137.title: Only partial credit for second extension fee
R137.description: While the first Extension Fee is fully credited to the Purchase Price, only 'one-half (1/2) of the Extension Fee' for the second extension is credited. This means Buyer effectively loses half of the second extension fee even if closing occurs, creating an additional cost for exercising this contractual right.

R138.title: Strict Time-of-Essence Closing Obligation
R138.description: The requirement that all documents be executed and delivered 'on or before the Closing Date' creates a strict time obligation without express grace periods or cure rights. If Buyer encounters any delays in funding or document preparation, even minor ones, this could be characterized as a breach triggering default remedies under Section 13A (liquidated damages/deposit forfeiture).

R139.title: Possession Subject to Tenant Rights
R139.description: Buyer receives possession 'subject to the rights of tenants in possession under Leases' without any representation that such tenants are in compliance with their leases or that no tenants are in holdover status. This could result in Buyer taking possession with problematic tenancies, including tenants who should have vacated, tenants in default, or tenants with unexpired rights that impair Buyer's intended use.

R140.title: Undefined Alternate Delivery Timeframes
R140.description: The parenthetical 'or within such timeframe as may be more specifically provided below' creates ambiguity about when certain deliverables are actually due. While this provides flexibility, it could allow Seller to argue that certain documents need not be delivered at Closing, potentially leaving Buyer without critical documents needed to verify the transaction.

R141.title: No Specification of Deed Form or Warranty Type
R141.description: The clause requires delivery of 'The Deed' without specifying the form of deed (special warranty, general warranty, quitclaim, etc.) or referencing an exhibit. While Section 4C references 'Special Warranty Deed' and there is an exhibit, this delivery provision does not cross-reference those requirements, creating potential ambiguity about what form of deed satisfies Seller's obligation.

R142.title: Deed Deliverable Lacks Express Recordability Requirement
R142.description: While a Real Estate Excise Tax Affidavit is required (suggesting recordation is contemplated), there is no express requirement that the Deed be in recordable form, properly acknowledged/notarized, and otherwise satisfy recording requirements. If the deed has technical defects preventing recording, Buyer may not discover this until after Closing.

R143.title: Bill of Sale Without Warranty Language Specified
R143.description: The Bill of Sale is referenced as being 'in the form of Exhibit C' but the actual exhibit would need to be reviewed to confirm it includes appropriate warranties of title and freedom from liens on the personal property. Buyer should confirm Exhibit C contains adequate protections.

R144.title: Lease Assignment Lacks Tenant Consent Requirement
R144.description: The Assignment and Assumption of Leases is to be delivered by Seller, but there is no requirement that Seller obtain any consents from tenants that may be required under their Leases for assignment of the landlord's interest. Some commercial leases require landlord to obtain tenant consent or provide notice before assigning the lease. Failure to comply could give tenants termination rights or other claims.

R145.title: No Rent Roll or Arrears Schedule at Closing
R145.description: While Seller must assign the Leases, there is no requirement in the Closing deliverables for an updated rent roll or schedule of tenant arrears/delinquencies as of the Closing Date. The representation in Section 7A(ii) regarding the rent roll only speaks to accuracy 'as of the Effective Date.' Buyer could close without current information on which tenants are paying and which are delinquent.

R146.title: Lease Delivery Limited to Seller's Possession
R146.description: The delivery obligation is limited to Leases and Lease Documents 'in Seller's possession or control.' This qualifier allows Seller to avoid delivering documents it may have lost, misplaced, or that are held by third parties (property managers, prior counsel, etc.). Buyer could close without complete lease files, making it difficult to enforce lease terms, verify tenant obligations, or identify estoppel issues post-closing.

R147.title: No Deadline for Outside-Escrow Delivery
R147.description: The parenthetical '(to be delivered outside of Escrow)' creates ambiguity about when these documents must be delivered. Unlike items delivered into escrow which have a clear closing deadline, documents delivered outside escrow could theoretically be delivered after closing, leaving Buyer without critical lease documentation at the time of ownership transfer.

R148.title: Assignment Limited to Buyer-Continued Contracts
R148.description: The assignment covers only 'Service Contracts to be continued by Buyer after the Closing.' This language implies Buyer has selected which contracts to continue, but the mechanism and timing for that selection is in Section 8B, which gives Seller discretion over modifications. If there is any dispute about which contracts are 'to be continued,' Buyer could be left without clear assignment of beneficial contracts or inadvertently assume unfavorable ones.

R149.title: Service Contract Delivery Limited to Possession
R149.description: Similar to the lease delivery issue, delivery of Service Contracts is limited to those 'in the possession or control of Seller.' This allows Seller to avoid delivering contracts held by property managers, vendors, or other third parties. Buyer may not have complete documentation of ongoing service obligations being assumed.

R150.title: Copies Acceptable in Lieu of Originals
R150.description: The provision allows for 'Originals or copies' of Service Contracts. While copies are often acceptable, originals are preferable for enforceability purposes and to verify authenticity. Without originals, Buyer may face challenges if contract disputes arise with vendors.

R151.title: FIRPTA Affidavit Form at Escrow Holder Discretion
R151.description: The FIRPTA affidavit must be 'in the form reasonably required by the Escrow Holder.' While 'reasonably' provides some protection, this gives Escrow Holder discretion over the form, which could create last-minute issues if Escrow Holder requires non-standard language that Seller resists. The parties lose control over the specific content of this closing document.

R152.title: Unlimited Documentation Requirements
R152.description: This provision requires Seller to deliver 'Such entity formation documents, authorizations, certificates of trust, and other documentation' as Escrow Holder or Title Company 'may require.' This is an open-ended obligation with no limitations, potentially allowing last-minute demands for extensive documentation that could delay closing or create disputes. Buyer's closing is indirectly affected if Seller balks at unreasonable requests.

R153.title: Title Company Controls Documentation Scope
R153.description: The Title Company's requirements for issuing the Title Policy drive documentation obligations. If the Title Company has unusual or onerous documentation requirements, Seller must comply, which could create closing delays. Conversely, if Seller cannot satisfy the Title Company, Buyer's condition precedent (receiving the Title Policy) may fail through no fault of either party.

R154.title: Closing Statement Requires Only Seller Approval
R154.description: The closing statement is required to be 'approved in writing by Seller' but there is no corresponding requirement for Buyer approval. This creates an asymmetry where Seller controls the final closing statement without Buyer having a contractual right to review and approve prorations, credits, and adjustments. If the closing statement contains errors or unfavorable calculations, Buyer has no explicit contractual protection to require corrections before closing.

R155.title: Unlimited Additional Document Obligation on Seller
R155.description: While this clause obligates Seller to deliver additional documents 'reasonably required' to close, the phrasing is open-ended and could be interpreted narrowly by Seller. The phrase 'or otherwise to close the Escrow' is broad but may not capture all documents Buyer needs for post-closing operations (such as complete tenant files, vendor information, building systems documentation, etc.). This catch-all provision could be strengthened to ensure Buyer receives all operational documents necessary for property management.

R156.title: Delivery Timing Framework Mirrors Seller Section
R156.description: This introductory clause for Buyer deliveries appropriately mirrors the structure of Seller's delivery obligations (Section 11.3). However, Buyer should ensure that all specific timeframes referenced in sub-sections are reasonable and achievable. The parenthetical 'or within such timeframe as may be more specifically provided below' creates flexibility but Buyer should verify no compressed timelines exist in the specific delivery requirements.

R157.title: Lease Assignment Execution Requirement
R157.description: This clause requires Buyer to execute the Assignment and Assumption of Leases, which is standard. However, Buyer should review the form attached as Exhibit D carefully, as execution of this document will bind Buyer to assume all landlord obligations under the Leases from the Conveyance Date forward. The form should be reviewed in conjunction with representations about lease status (Section 7.1(ii)) and any tenant estoppel requirements (Section 5.4(iv)).

R158.title: Open-Ended Closing Document Requirement
R158.description: This clause creates an unlimited obligation for Buyer to deliver 'any other documents' that are 'reasonably required by Escrow Holder or otherwise to close the Escrow.' The phrase 'or otherwise' is dangerously vague and could be interpreted to require Buyer to execute documents beyond those contemplated in the Agreement. This open-ended language could be used by Seller or Escrow Holder to demand additional documents, guarantees, or instruments at closing that Buyer never agreed to provide, potentially as a condition to closing.

amplified_by.effect: If Buyer refuses to provide demanded documents, Seller could claim Buyer default and retain deposit as liquidated damages

R159.title: Uncertain 'Customary' Closing Costs Allocation
R159.description: The clause allocates recording fees and 'all other costs' based on what is 'customary for the county' without defining what those customs are or providing a fallback if customs are disputed. This creates uncertainty about Buyer's financial obligations and could lead to disputes at closing. The phrase 'all other costs and charges of the escrow' is also vague and could include unexpected fees.

R160.title: Buyer Bears All Extended Coverage and Endorsement Costs
R160.description: While standard for commercial transactions, Buyer is responsible for all incremental costs of extended title coverage and any endorsements. Depending on the complexity of title and lender requirements, these costs could be substantial. The clause provides no cap or estimate of these costs.

mitigated_by.effect: Seller's obligation to convey clear title may require Seller to address issues that would otherwise require costly endorsements

R161.title: Buyer Bears Risk of Uncollected Rents
R161.description: The proration is based on 'rents actually collected' as of Closing, meaning if tenants are delinquent, Buyer receives no credit for unpaid rent even though Buyer will own the property going forward. Combined with the delinquent rent provisions in p_103, Buyer may have difficulty collecting arrears that Seller allowed to accumulate, while Seller has no incentive to aggressively pursue collections pre-closing.

mitigated_by.effect: Buyer retains right to collect delinquent rents post-closing with allocation to Seller

amplified_by.effect: As-is clause may limit Buyer's recourse if delinquencies result from property condition issues

R162.title: Indefinite Tax Adjustment Obligation
R162.description: The clause requires tax adjustments after closing when final tax amounts become known, but provides no time limit for when such adjustments must be claimed or made. This creates an open-ended obligation that could extend well beyond closing, and lacks specificity on mechanics of payment. There is also no materiality threshold—any difference, no matter how small, triggers an adjustment.

R163.title: Security Deposit Credit Based on Seller Disclosure
R163.description: Buyer receives credit for security deposits based on what was 'paid to Seller' and 'disclosed on the Rent Roll,' but Buyer has limited ability to verify actual deposit amounts held. If Seller's records are inaccurate or deposits have been improperly applied, Buyer may not receive full credit and could face tenant claims for deposits Buyer never received.

mitigated_by.effect: Seller's representation on rent roll accuracy provides some recourse, though subject to knowledge qualifier and survival limits

amplified_by.effect: Short survival period for representations limits time to discover deposit discrepancies
As-is clause may be argued to limit Buyer's recourse for deposit issues

R164.title: Delinquent Rent Priority Disfavors Buyer
R164.description: The waterfall for applying delinquent rent collections prioritizes current rent owed to Buyer first, but then pays collection costs second and Seller's pre-closing delinquencies third. This means Buyer must actively pursue collections, incur costs, and only then can Seller recover its past-due amounts. However, if a tenant pays only partial amounts, Buyer's current rent is covered but Buyer bears the ongoing collection burden with no compensation for administrative efforts beyond 'reasonable outside collection costs.' More importantly, the order could be restructured to better protect Buyer by ensuring Buyer receives all post-closing rent before any application to Seller's delinquencies.

amplified_by.effect: If rents are prorated as of Closing, Seller gets credit for unpaid rent that may never be collected

R165.title: Seller Retains Post-Closing Collection Rights
R165.description: Seller reserves the right to collect delinquent rents directly from tenants after Closing. While Seller cannot terminate leases or evict tenants, Seller's collection efforts could interfere with Buyer's tenant relationships, create confusion about payment obligations, and potentially harass tenants that Buyer wishes to retain. There is no requirement for Seller to coordinate with Buyer or limit collection methods.

mitigated_by.effect: Seller cannot terminate leases or evict tenants, limiting most aggressive collection tactics

R166.title: Vague Estimation Process for Pass-Through Credits
R166.description: When the excess Operating Expense Pass-throughs cannot be determined at Closing, Buyer receives a credit 'based upon an estimate' with no specified methodology, standards, or dispute resolution mechanism. This creates uncertainty about how the estimate will be calculated, who prepares it, and what happens if the parties disagree on the estimate amount.

mitigated_by.effect: Section 1I provides a 60-day reconciliation process that will eventually determine correct amounts

R167.title: Buyer Bears Tenant Repayment Obligation
R167.description: Buyer is made responsible for crediting or repaying excess Operating Expense Pass-throughs to tenants, but there is no express indemnification from Seller if the amounts credited to Buyer at Closing prove insufficient to cover actual tenant repayment obligations. If Seller's estimates are low, Buyer could be out-of-pocket.

mitigated_by.effect: Post-closing reconciliation process should capture any shortfalls

R168.title: Seller Controls Reconciliation Calculation Timing
R168.description: Seller has 60 days post-closing to prepare the final Operating Expense Pass-through calculation. This gives Seller significant time to prepare figures in its favor while Buyer must rely on Seller's records and calculation methodology. Additionally, there is no deadline for when the final adjusting payment must be made after Buyer's review period, potentially leaving disputes unresolved indefinitely.

mitigated_by.effect: Buyer has 60 days to review Seller's calculations

R169.title: Buyer Bears Under-Collection Recovery Risk
R169.description: If Seller under-collected Operating Expense Pass-throughs, the adjustment between the parties occurs only 'after year-end billing to and receipt from said tenants.' This means Buyer must first successfully collect the under-collected amounts from tenants before receiving reimbursement from Seller. If tenants dispute or refuse to pay, Buyer bears the collection risk and may never recover funds owed to Seller's period of ownership.

amplified_by.effect: Similar collection risk exists for delinquent rents, compounding Buyer's exposure

R170.title: Buyer Protected from Undisclosed Pre-Closing Expenses
R170.description: This provision helpfully states that no expense related to ownership or operation 'shall be charged to or paid or assumed by Buyer...other than those obligations expressly assumed by Buyer.' This is actually FAVORABLE to Buyer and provides important protection. However, it should be cross-referenced with Seller's representations to ensure consistency and should survive closing.

R171.title: Broad Buyer Indemnification for Seller's TI Obligations
R171.description: Buyer is required to indemnify and hold Seller harmless from 'all claims, losses, liabilities and expenses (including attorneys' fees and costs)' related to the In Process TI Work, but only 'to the extent of the funds escrowed.' This creates ambiguity—if a claim exceeds the escrowed funds, is Buyer's indemnification capped at the escrow amount or is Buyer fully exposed? The phrase 'to the extent of' is unclear. Additionally, the indemnification covers work that Seller contracted for and may have been improperly scoped or defectively begun.

mitigated_by.effect: The 'to the extent of' language suggests some limitation on exposure

amplified_by.effect: The AS-IS provision could be argued to extend to TI work conditions

R172.title: Vague Standard for TI Work Cost Agreement
R172.description: The amount to be escrowed for In Process TI Work is determined by costs 'as reasonably agreed by Buyer and Seller during the Due Diligence Period.' There is no mechanism for resolving disputes if the parties cannot agree, no requirement for contractor bids or third-party estimates, and no contingency for cost overruns. If costs exceed the escrow amount, Buyer must fund the shortfall and seek reimbursement from Seller.

amplified_by.effect: Short due diligence period may not allow adequate time to assess TI work costs

R173.title: Buyer Only 'Consults' on TI Work Completion
R173.description: Buyer is required only to 'consult with Seller's contractors and project managers regarding the completion of such work.' This suggests Seller's contractors remain in control of the work despite Buyer owning the Property. Buyer should have full authority to direct the work, hire replacement contractors if necessary, and make decisions about completion.

R174.title: Escrow Funds Released Without Verification
R174.description: The provision states that escrow funds 'shall be released to Buyer without any requirement for the consent of Seller and shall be used by Buyer to pay the landlord's share of such tenant improvements.' While this gives Buyer flexibility, it could create disputes if Seller believes funds are being misapplied. The lack of documentation requirements could also create issues with the escrow holder.

R175.title: Escrow Closing Conditions Incomplete
R175.description: The conditions for Escrow Holder to close include only (i) recording the Deed, and (ii) Seller receiving payment when Title Company is ready to deliver the Title Policy. This section does not expressly incorporate Buyer's conditions precedent from Section 5D, which include delivery of Seller's closing documents, truth of representations, and estoppel delivery. If Escrow Holder closes without all Buyer conditions being satisfied, Buyer may have closed without contractual protections.

mitigated_by.effect: Section 5D sets forth additional conditions that should prevent closing

amplified_by.effect: Conditions may be deemed waived if Buyer proceeds to close

R176.title: Deed Recording Sequence Risk
R176.description: The provision contemplates that Escrow Holder will close by 'causing the Deed to be recorded' and 'delivering the Closing Payment... to Seller.' Standard practice requires confirmation of collected funds before recording. The clause should clarify that recording occurs only after funds have been verified as collected/cleared.

R177.title: Undefined Document Delivery Standard
R177.description: The condition that 'all funds and documents have been delivered' lacks specificity about which documents are required and what constitutes proper delivery. This vagueness could allow Seller to argue Buyer has not satisfied a condition when minor or disputed items remain outstanding, potentially delaying or preventing closing. There is no mechanism to resolve disputes about whether delivery has occurred.

R178.title: Title Company Readiness Subjective Standard
R178.description: The condition that Title Company be 'prepared to deliver' the Title Policy introduces subjectivity. There is no standard for what 'prepared' means—the Title Company could delay indefinitely by claiming it is not yet 'prepared' without breaching any obligation. This could delay closing or give Seller leverage to claim Buyer's conditions are unsatisfied if Buyer has any responsibility for title matters.

R179.title: Interest Allocation Before Closing Favors Buyer
R179.description: This provision allocates pre-closing interest on deposited funds to Buyer, which is favorable. However, the clause lacks specificity on what happens to interest if the transaction terminates—particularly important if Buyer terminates during due diligence and is entitled to deposit return. The provision should clarify that interest follows the deposit in all termination scenarios.

R180.title: Seller May Redirect Closing Funds
R180.description: The phrase 'or as Seller may otherwise direct' allows Seller to redirect the entire purchase price to third parties without Buyer's consent or verification. While common in commercial transactions, this creates risk that funds could be diverted to parties with adverse claims, creating title or lien issues for Buyer post-closing. Buyer has no ability to object or verify the propriety of such directions.

R181.title: No Timeline for Deed Delivery to Buyer
R181.description: While this provision requires the recorded Deed to be delivered to Buyer, there is no timeline specified. Buyer could close and fund without receiving evidence of title transfer for an extended period. The provision also does not address what happens if recording is rejected or delayed by the county recorder's office.

R182.title: Ambiguous Entitlement Standard for Escrow Items
R182.description: The phrase 'entitled thereto or benefited thereby' provides no objective standard for determining which party receives disputed items from escrow. In the event of a dispute between Buyer and Seller regarding entitlement to documents, deposits, or other escrowed items, this vague language gives the Escrow Holder discretion that could harm Buyer's interests. There is no mechanism for resolving disputes or protecting Buyer's claim to items it may be entitled to receive.

R183.title: Broad Carve-Outs Undermine Liquidated Damages Protection
R183.description: While the liquidated damages provision limits Seller's remedy to retention of the Deposit, the final sentence carves out Buyer's 'indemnification or repair and restoration obligations under this Agreement' and attorney's fees under Section 15. These carve-outs could expose Buyer to significant additional liability beyond the Deposit. The indemnification obligations in Section 5B(iii) are broadly worded and could result in substantial claims. This undermines the certainty that a liquidated damages provision is meant to provide.

R184.title: Broad Definition of Buyer Default
R184.description: The provision is triggered by 'a DEFAULT UNDER THIS AGREEMENT BY BUYER' without defining what constitutes a default. Minor technical breaches, delays in delivering non-material items, or other foot-faults could potentially be characterized as defaults, resulting in forfeiture of the Deposit. There is no notice requirement, no cure period, and no materiality qualifier before the Deposit is forfeited.

R185.title: Escrow Holder Instructed to Release Without Dispute Resolution
R185.description: The instruction to Escrow Holder to deliver the Deposit to Seller upon Buyer's default lacks any mechanism for Buyer to contest the characterization of default. In practice, Seller could claim default where the facts are disputed, and Escrow Holder may release funds based solely on Seller's assertion. This creates risk of improper forfeiture without recourse.

R186.title: Buyer Waives Specific Performance and All Damage Claims
R186.description: This provision requires Buyer to waive specific performance and 'any other damage claims' against a defaulting Seller. This is highly unfavorable to Buyer because: (1) in a rising market, the Property may be worth substantially more than Buyer's out-of-pocket costs, and Buyer loses that appreciation; (2) Buyer cannot compel Seller to close even if Seller simply gets a better offer; (3) the $50,000 cap on expense reimbursement may not cover Buyer's actual costs for legal fees, due diligence, financing costs, and other expenses in complex transactions.

R187.title: Expense Reimbursement Capped at $50,000
R187.description: Buyer's recovery for Seller's default is limited to return of the Deposit plus actual out-of-pocket costs capped at $50,000. In a commercial real estate transaction, Buyer's due diligence costs alone (environmental reports, surveys, appraisals, legal fees, engineering studies, lender costs) often exceed this amount. If Seller defaults close to closing, Buyer may have incurred substantially greater expenses that cannot be recovered.

R188.title: Asymmetric Default Remedies Favor Seller
R188.description: The remedy structure is significantly asymmetric: Buyer forfeits its entire Deposit upon default (p_116), while Seller's maximum exposure for default is return of Deposit plus $50,000. This creates moral hazard where Seller has minimal downside risk from default but Buyer faces full forfeiture. This asymmetry incentivizes Seller to default if it receives a better offer or market conditions change.

R189.title: Buyer's Remedy Conditioned on All Seller Conditions Being Satisfied
R189.description: Buyer's remedies for Seller's default are only available 'if all other conditions to Seller's obligations to consummate the sale of the Property to be satisfied as of the date of such default or failure of condition have been satisfied.' This means if any Seller condition precedent (e.g., Buyer's closing conditions under Section 5E) is unsatisfied, Seller could avoid liability for its default. Seller could engineer a condition failure to escape default liability.

R190.title: Material Damage Threshold Left Blank
R190.description: The materiality threshold for damage that triggers Buyer's termination right is left blank ('$_________'). Without a defined threshold, there will be disputes about whether damage is 'material' and whether Buyer has the right to terminate. This creates significant uncertainty in a casualty scenario.

R191.title: Only 10 Days to Elect Termination After Casualty
R191.description: Buyer has only 10 days from receipt of Seller's notice to elect termination after a casualty or condemnation. This may be insufficient time to: (1) assess the true extent of damage; (2) obtain contractor estimates; (3) consult with lenders about impacts on financing; (4) evaluate whether insurance proceeds will be adequate. If Buyer fails to elect within 10 days, the right is waived.

R192.title: No Purchase Price Reduction for Non-Material Damage
R192.description: If damage is not 'material' (below the threshold), Buyer must close at the full Purchase Price and can only receive an assignment of insurance proceeds. However, insurance proceeds may not fully cover repair costs due to deductibles, coverage gaps, or depreciation. Buyer bears the risk of any shortfall between actual repair costs and insurance recovery.

R193.title: Buyer's Election Period Triggered Only by Seller's Notice
R193.description: Buyer's 10-day election period runs from 'receipt of written notice from Seller' of the damage. This gives Seller control over when the clock starts. Seller could delay notice to pressure Buyer toward closing, or provide notice at an inconvenient time. There is no requirement that Seller provide prompt notice or that Buyer have independent discovery rights.

R194.title: No definition of 'prevailing party'
R194.description: The clause awards attorneys' fees to the 'prevailing party' but does not define what constitutes prevailing. In mixed-outcome litigation where each party wins some claims and loses others, courts may struggle to determine the prevailing party, or may find no prevailing party exists, leaving Buyer unable to recover fees even after substantially winning. This ambiguity could result in protracted satellite litigation over fee entitlement.

amplified_by.effect: If Buyer must litigate to recover deposit after improper Seller termination claim, fee recovery uncertainty compounds financial exposure

R195.title: Fee recovery limited to signatories only
R195.description: The fee-shifting provision applies only to 'signatories' of the Agreement. If Buyer needs to bring or defend claims against Seller's principals, guarantors, affiliates, or agents who are not signatories, this provision would not apply, potentially leaving Buyer without fee recovery even if successful in related litigation.

R196.title: No deemed delivery for refused notices
R196.description: While the provision addresses 'refusal to accept delivery,' it does not clearly specify when a refused notice is deemed effective. The clause states notice is 'deemed to have been given upon the date of actual receipt or delivery (or refusal to accept delivery)' but requires 'written or electronic confirmation of such delivery or refusal.' If Seller refuses delivery and the courier cannot obtain confirmation of refusal, Buyer may be unable to prove effective notice, potentially causing missed deadlines for due diligence objections, termination, or other critical time-sensitive matters.

amplified_by.effect: Short 10-day title review period makes notice delivery failures particularly damaging
Due diligence termination rights depend on timely notice

R197.title: No provision for certified mail delivery
R197.description: The notice provision permits only personal delivery, overnight courier, or electronic transmission. Certified mail with return receipt requested is a common and legally reliable method of delivery that provides clear evidence of receipt, but is not permitted here. While not critical, this limits Buyer's delivery options and backup methods.

R198.title: Incomplete notice addresses in document
R198.description: The provision references 'the addresses of the parties shall be as follows' but the actual addresses are not fully visible in this section. Buyer should verify that complete and accurate addresses for Seller and all required copy recipients are included in the executed agreement, including any address changes that may have occurred since drafting.

R199.title: Incomplete copy recipient information
R199.description: The copy provision only shows a law firm name without complete contact information. If this is intended as required copy to Buyer's or Seller's counsel, incomplete information could result in failed delivery and arguments that notice was ineffective.

R200.title: Broad integration clause excludes all prior negotiations
R200.description: This integration clause is absolute and provides that the Agreement 'contains the complete agreement' and 'cannot be varied except by the written agreement of the parties.' Combined with the statement that 'there are no oral agreements, understandings, representations or warranties that are not expressly set forth herein,' this effectively eliminates any claim Buyer might have based on pre-contractual representations made by Seller or its brokers during negotiations. If Seller made material representations about the Property during negotiations that induced Buyer to enter the agreement, Buyer has waived reliance on those representations.

mitigated_by.effect: Express representations in Section 7A provide some protection, but are narrowly drafted with knowledge qualifiers

amplified_by.effect: AS-IS clause combined with integration clause creates comprehensive waiver of reliance on any non-written statements
Release provision further limits claims Buyer can bring

R201.title: No specification of modification requirements
R201.description: The clause states the Agreement 'cannot be varied except by the written agreement of the parties' but does not specify whether modifications must be signed by authorized representatives, whether email constitutes sufficient 'writing,' or whether specific formalities are required. This could create disputes about whether informal written communications constitute binding modifications.

R202.title: Successors and Assigns Limited by Agreement
R202.description: The phrase 'where permitted by this Agreement' effectively subordinates the binding effect on successors and assigns to the restrictions found elsewhere in the Agreement (specifically Section 9/p_154). This means the Agreement's benefits may not automatically flow to Buyer's assignees if Seller's consent is required and withheld. While this is standard protective language, combined with the assignment restrictions in Section 9, it limits Buyer's flexibility in structuring its acquisition through related entities or bringing in co-investors post-signing.

amplified_by.effect: Assignment restrictions require Seller consent for most transfers, limiting who can benefit from this binding effect clause

R203.title: Buyer Assignment Requires Seller Consent
R203.description: Buyer cannot assign its interest under the Agreement without Seller's prior written consent, which is not qualified by any 'not to be unreasonably withheld' standard. This gives Seller absolute discretion to block any assignment outside of the affiliate exception, potentially trapping Buyer in the transaction even if legitimate business reasons exist for an assignment (such as bringing in an institutional co-investor, syndicating the deal, or assigning to a joint venture). This could prevent Buyer from effectuating common transaction structures.

mitigated_by.effect: Buyer can assign to controlled affiliates without consent, which covers some restructuring scenarios

amplified_by.effect: If Buyer cannot assign and cannot close, deposit may be at risk as liquidated damages

R204.title: Control Definition May Exclude Common Structures
R204.description: The definition of 'control' requires 'ownership of a majority of the beneficial interest' AND 'managerial control.' This conjunctive standard may exclude legitimate acquisition structures where Buyer has managerial control but not majority economic interest (common in joint ventures with institutional capital partners), or where a sponsor controls the entity through contractual rights rather than majority ownership. Many real estate investment structures involve passive majority investors with a sponsor maintaining control through management rights.

amplified_by.effect: If Buyer's intended structure doesn't meet the narrow 'control' definition, Seller consent is required

R205.title: Buyer Remains Liable After Permitted Assignment
R205.description: The assignment provision is silent on whether Buyer is released from its obligations after a permitted assignment to an affiliate. While this is common in PSAs and may be acceptable, Buyer should be aware that even after assigning to a controlled entity, the original Buyer may remain liable for the assignee's performance obligations. This could expose the original signing entity to liability even after it has divested its interest.

R206.title: No Affirmative Obligation to Facilitate 1031 Exchange
R206.description: While the provision states parties 'will cooperate,' it is heavily qualified by limitations that neither party shall incur additional cost, advance excess monies, or cause delays. This essentially converts the cooperation obligation into a passive, no-cost accommodation rather than an affirmative duty to facilitate. If Buyer's 1031 exchange requires any accommodation that could be characterized as causing 'delays' or involving any indirect cost, Seller could refuse to cooperate.

amplified_by.effect: Strict closing date requirements may make it impossible to accommodate 1031 exchange timing needs

R207.title: No Extension of Closing for Exchange Purposes
R207.description: The provision explicitly prohibits any delays to 'time periods or Closing Date' to accommodate a 1031 exchange. This is particularly problematic because 1031 exchanges often require precise timing coordination with qualified intermediaries, identification of replacement property, and other logistical matters. If Buyer's exchange fails due to this rigid timing, Buyer could lose significant tax deferral benefits. Even a short extension of a few days could be critical for exchange completion.

R208.title: Fixed Venue May Be Inconvenient for Buyer
R208.description: Venue is fixed in a specific Washington county (to be filled in). Depending on Buyer's location and the Property's location, this may or may not be convenient. Buyer should confirm this is an appropriate venue and that the specified county has jurisdiction over the Property and the parties. If Buyer is an out-of-state entity, litigating disputes in Washington state court may be inconvenient and costly.

R209.title: No Reformation or Modification Provision
R209.description: The severability clause only provides for provisions to be treated 'as if' they were never contained in the Agreement. It does not include a reformation provision that would allow a court to modify an unenforceable provision to make it enforceable to the maximum extent permitted by law. Additionally, there is no savings clause addressing what happens if a severed provision was material to the parties' bargain, potentially leaving the remainder of the agreement unbalanced.

R210.title: Exhibits Incorporated Without Verification
R210.description: This clause incorporates all exhibits by reference without any provision requiring Buyer to verify that all referenced exhibits are actually attached, complete, and accurate. If an exhibit is missing, incomplete, or contains unfavorable terms, Buyer would still be bound by whatever was purportedly 'attached.' This creates risk that Seller could later claim certain terms were part of an exhibit that Buyer did not review. The clause also provides no mechanism for addressing conflicts between the main agreement and exhibits.

amplified_by.effect: The integration clause prevents Buyer from arguing exhibits were not properly disclosed

R211.title: Extension Limited to Certain Deadlines
R211.description: While this provision extends performance dates that fall on non-business days, it only applies to dates for 'performance of any act.' This may not clearly extend notice deadlines, option exercise periods, or approval periods that expire (rather than require affirmative acts). A deadline expiring on a Saturday could trap Buyer if the clause is narrowly construed. Additionally, this provision may not extend deadlines triggered by elapsed time periods (e.g., '10 days after receipt') if the calculation results in a weekend.

R212.title: Seller May Continue Marketing During Due Diligence
R212.description: This clause expressly permits Seller to continue marketing the Property and negotiating with other potential buyers until expiration of the Due Diligence Period and satisfaction of all Buyer conditions. This is highly unusual and seller-favorable. Buyer is exposed to being used as a stalking horse while Seller shops for better offers. Buyer invests time and money in due diligence with no assurance Seller will not accept a competing offer. This undermines Buyer's exclusivity despite having a signed PSA and deposit at risk.

amplified_by.effect: The longer the due diligence period, the longer Buyer is exposed to being shopped
If Buyer terminates after being shopped, Buyer loses deposit

R213.title: Integration Clause Disclaims All Prior Representations
R213.description: The integration clause states there are no 'oral contracts, representations, conditions, or warranties, express or implied, in addition to this Agreement.' This disclaims any representations made by Seller or Seller's broker during negotiations that are not expressly included in the Agreement. If Seller or its agents made material statements about the Property during marketing (income projections, tenant quality, condition issues, etc.), Buyer cannot rely on them unless written into the PSA. This significantly limits Buyer's fraud and misrepresentation claims.

amplified_by.effect: The AS-IS clause combined with integration makes it nearly impossible to pursue claims based on pre-contract statements

R214.title: No Prejudice to Buyer's Waiver Rights
R214.description: While this clause is facially mutual, it confirms that Buyer's failure to enforce a Seller breach does not waive future enforcement. However, the clause could be strengthened to clarify that Buyer's acceptance of partial performance or delayed performance does not waive strict compliance going forward, particularly for closing conditions and delivery obligations.

R215.title: Mutual Confidentiality May Limit Buyer's Flexibility
R215.description: The confidentiality provision requires both parties to keep Agreement terms confidential and prohibits public announcements without consent. While this is mutual, it may hamper Buyer's ability to: (1) discuss the transaction with potential joint venture partners or equity sources not yet identified; (2) make required disclosures if Buyer is a public company or REIT; (3) discuss the transaction with potential replacement tenants or property managers during due diligence; (4) comply with legal or regulatory disclosure requirements. The exception for 'lenders, partners, consultants and professional advisors' may be too narrow.

R216.title: No Remedy Specified for Confidentiality Breach
R216.description: The confidentiality provision does not specify remedies for breach. Without specifying that injunctive relief is available and that the non-breaching party need not prove irreparable harm, Buyer may have difficulty enforcing this provision if Seller makes unauthorized disclosures that harm Buyer's negotiating position with tenants or damage the transaction.

R217.title: Unlimited Further Instruments Obligation
R217.description: This provision creates an open-ended obligation for Buyer to execute additional documents 'as often as' requested by Seller, with no limitation on the scope, timing, or number of such requests. While subject to a 'reasonable opinion' standard, this is determined by the requesting party (Seller), not objectively. This could require Buyer to execute documents post-closing that were not contemplated at closing, potentially expanding Buyer's obligations or affecting title/rights in unanticipated ways.

R218.title: No Cost Allocation for Further Instruments
R218.description: The provision does not address which party bears the costs associated with preparing, executing, acknowledging, or delivering further instruments. Buyer could be required to incur significant legal and administrative costs to comply with Seller's post-closing requests.

R219.title: Uncapped Broker Indemnification Survives Closing
R219.description: Buyer provides an unlimited, uncapped indemnification to Seller for any broker claims arising through Buyer. This indemnity expressly survives Closing with no time limitation, unlike the limited survival period for Seller's representations (Section 7.3 provides only 9 months). The indemnity includes 'any and all claims, liabilities, costs and expenses' with no cap, creating potentially unlimited exposure for Buyer if a broker makes a claim, even years after closing.

R220.title: Express Unlimited Survival for Broker Section
R220.description: The final sentence states this Section 'shall expressly survive any Closing or any termination of this Agreement' with no time limitation. This creates asymmetric treatment compared to Seller's representations which survive only 9 months (Section 7.3). Buyer's broker indemnity exposure could continue indefinitely while Seller's representation exposure expires quickly.

R221.title: Incorrect Section Cross-Reference
R221.description: The survival provision references 'Section 31' but this appears to be Section 21 based on the document structure. This drafting error could create ambiguity about which section's survival is being addressed, potentially affecting enforceability or interpretation.

R222.title: Waiver of Statutory Disclosure Rights
R222.description: Buyer is waiving its statutory right under Washington law (RCW Ch. 64.06) to receive the Seller Disclosure Statement. While the Environmental section is carved out, Buyer loses the right to receive disclosures about structural issues, systems, title matters, and other material conditions that could affect the Property. This waiver eliminates a statutory protection designed to ensure buyers receive material information about property conditions.

R223.title: Incomplete Waiver Clause - Text Cut Off
R223.description: This provision appears to be incomplete, with the text cutting off mid-sentence at 'Buyer waive'. This could create ambiguity about what exactly Buyer is waiving and render the provision unenforceable or subject to interpretation disputes. The incomplete language could be construed against Seller (as drafter) or could leave Buyer's rights unclear.

R224.title: Environmental Disclosure Timing Uses Undefined Term
R224.description: The provision requires Seller to provide the Environmental section 'during the Review Period,' but the Agreement uses 'Due Diligence Period' as the defined term (Section 5.1). 'Review Period' is not defined, creating ambiguity about when the Environmental disclosure must be delivered and when Buyer's approval period runs. This could affect Buyer's ability to terminate if environmental issues are disclosed late.

R225.title: Waiver of Seller Disclosure Statement
R225.description: Buyer is waiving its right to receive the complete Seller Disclosure Statement, which under Washington law (RCW 64.06) typically provides important information about the property's condition, known defects, and environmental issues. This waiver limits Buyer's ability to obtain information that Seller may be legally required to disclose and could expose Buyer to unknown property conditions.

R226.title: No Right to Updated Disclosures
R226.description: Buyer waives any right to receive updated or revised Seller Disclosure Statements even if Seller becomes aware of new material information about the property condition after the initial disclosure. This means Seller could learn of significant defects or environmental issues before closing but have no obligation to inform Buyer, leaving Buyer exposed to undisclosed problems.

R227.title: Broad Waiver of Reliance on Seller Info
R227.description: Buyer agrees to acquire the property solely based on its own inspections and 'not on any information provided in any Seller Disclosure Statement or... any information otherwise provided or to be provided by Seller.' This extremely broad language could be interpreted to bar claims for Seller's misrepresentations or fraudulent statements made outside of the formal representations and warranties, significantly limiting Buyer's remedies if Seller provides false information during due diligence.

R228.title: Buyer Warrants Sophistication
R228.description: Buyer warrants it is a 'sophisticated Buyer' familiar with real estate ownership and development. This warranty could be used by Seller to argue that Buyer should have discovered defects through its inspections or that Buyer cannot claim reliance on any Seller statements because a sophisticated party would have verified independently. This strengthens Seller's defenses against Buyer claims.

R229.title: Waiver of Statutory Rescission Rights
R229.description: Buyer waives 'TO THE FULLEST EXTENT PERMISSIBLE BY LAW' its right to rescind the Agreement under RCW 64.06, Washington's seller disclosure statute.
