This eliminates a statutory protection that would otherwise allow Buyer to rescind if Seller fails to provide required disclosures or provides materially inaccurate disclosures. The prospective nature of this waiver (applying to future updated disclosures) is particularly concerning.

R230.title: Disclosure Statement Provides No Rights
R230.description: The provision states that any Seller Disclosure Statement 'SHALL GIVE BUYER NO RIGHTS WITH RESPECT TO SELLER OR UNDER THIS AGREEMENT.' This could be interpreted to mean that even intentionally false statements in the Seller Disclosure Statement cannot support a claim against Seller, which is an extremely Seller-favorable position that may not be enforceable as to fraud but creates significant litigation risk.

R231.title: Disclosure Waiver Survives Closing
R231.description: The waiver provisions survive closing, meaning Buyer cannot assert any claims based on the Seller Disclosure Statement even after discovering post-closing defects that were required to be but were not disclosed. Combined with the AS-IS provision and other waivers, this significantly limits Buyer's post-closing remedies.

R232.title: Property Description Blank
R232.description: The legal description of the property has blank fields (County and the actual metes and bounds or lot description). While this is clearly a form to be completed, Buyer should ensure the legal description is accurate and complete before signing, and that it matches the title commitment and survey.

R233.title: Special Warranty Deed Limits Title Protection
R233.description: The deed form is a Special Warranty Deed rather than a General Warranty Deed. This means Seller only warrants title against defects arising during Seller's period of ownership ('by, through or under' Seller), not against title defects that predate Seller's acquisition. Buyer bears the risk of any title defects originating from prior owners, which could include undiscovered liens, encumbrances, adverse claims, or boundary disputes that existed before Seller took title.

mitigated_by.effect: Title insurance may cover some defects not warranted by Seller, reducing but not eliminating exposure

amplified_by.effect: AS-IS provision could be argued to limit Buyer's recourse for undisclosed title issues
Express exclusion of implied covenants further narrows Buyer's warranty protection

R234.title: Personal Property and Intangibles Not Conveyed in Deed
R234.description: The deed only conveys real property, buildings, improvements, and lessor's interest in leases. It does not convey personal property, service contracts, permits, licenses, warranties, or other intangible property that are part of the purchase under the PSA. Buyer must rely on separate conveyance documents (Bill of Sale, Assignment of Contracts) which could create gaps if those documents are not properly executed or delivered.

mitigated_by.effect: PSA requires separate documents for personal property and contract assignments at closing

R235.title: Conveyance Subject to Undefined Exhibit B Exceptions
R235.description: The deed is expressly subject to matters listed in an Exhibit B that is not provided for review. These 'Permitted Exceptions' could include significant encumbrances, easements, restrictions, or other matters that materially affect Buyer's use and enjoyment of the Property. Without reviewing Exhibit B, Buyer cannot assess what limitations will burden the Property post-closing.

mitigated_by.effect: Buyer has approval rights over title matters during due diligence, which should define what becomes Permitted Exceptions

amplified_by.effect: AS-IS provision could limit Buyer's post-closing remedies for burdensome exceptions

R236.title: Express Exclusion of Implied Title Covenants
R236.description: This provision expressly excludes all covenants that would otherwise arise by statute or implication, limiting Buyer's warranty protection to only those covenants expressly stated in the deed. Under Washington law, a General Warranty Deed would typically include implied covenants of seisin, right to convey, freedom from encumbrances, quiet enjoyment, and general warranty. This language strips away those protections.

mitigated_by.effect: Title insurance provides some protection against title defects regardless of deed covenants

amplified_by.effect: Combined with special warranty limitation, Buyer has minimal contractual title protection

R237.title: Warranty Limited to Claims Through Grantor Only
R237.description: The warranty defense obligation is limited to claims 'by, through or under said Grantor and not otherwise.' This means Seller has no obligation to defend Buyer against title claims arising from parties other than those claiming through Seller's chain of title during Seller's ownership. Pre-existing title defects, third-party adverse claims, or boundary disputes from adjacent owners are not covered.

mitigated_by.effect: Title insurance may cover third-party claims not warranted by Seller

R238.title: Bill of Sale Contains No Warranties on Personal Property
R238.description: The Bill of Sale form transfers personal property without any express warranties regarding title, condition, or fitness for purpose. Combined with the AS-IS provisions in the PSA, Buyer receives personal property without any assurance that Seller owns it free and clear, that it is in working condition, or that it is fit for its intended use.

mitigated_by.effect: Bill of Sale Exhibit F contains a representation that Seller is lawful owner

amplified_by.effect: AS-IS provision disclaims warranties on personal property condition

R239.title: Personal Property Limited to Schedule I Items
R239.description: The Bill of Sale references 'Schedule I' for the list of personal property items, but this schedule is not provided for review. If Schedule I is incomplete or does not match Buyer's understanding of what personal property is included in the sale, Buyer may not receive all items expected. The phrase 'including, without limitation' provides some protection but the scheduled items define the core conveyance.

mitigated_by.effect: The phrase 'including, without limitation' suggests Schedule I is not exhaustive

R240.title: Bill of Sale Incorporates PSA Terms by Reference
R240.description: The Bill of Sale incorporates terms of the Purchase Agreement by reference. While this can be protective by preserving PSA rights, it also means any limitations, disclaimers, or AS-IS provisions in the PSA apply to the personal property conveyance. Buyer should understand that the PSA's AS-IS language and survival limitations will govern post-closing claims related to personal property.

amplified_by.effect: AS-IS provision incorporated by reference disclaims condition warranties
Limited survival period constrains time for personal property claims

R241.title: Unqualified Personal Property Warranty
R241.description: Seller provides an absolute representation and warranty that personal property is 'free and clear of all liens, encumbrances, conditional sales contracts, security interests and claims' without any knowledge qualifier. This is broader than the knowledge-qualified representations in Section 7A of the main agreement, creating potential inconsistency. While this benefits Buyer, the lack of a schedule identifying the specific personal property covered makes enforcement difficult and could lead to disputes about scope.

mitigated_by.effect: If this representation is subject to the same survival period in Section 7C, claims must be brought within that limited window

amplified_by.effect: The AS-IS provision may create tension with this warranty if personal property issues arise post-closing

R242.title: Personal Property Not Specifically Identified
R242.description: The Bill of Sale references 'such personal property' without a clear definition or attached schedule identifying what personal property is actually being conveyed. This creates significant risk that Buyer may not receive all personal property expected, or disputes may arise about what was included in the sale. The reference to p_284 shows only a placeholder bracket suggesting a schedule should be attached but may not be.

amplified_by.effect: If personal property is not properly identified, the AS-IS disclaimer may prevent Buyer from claiming additional items post-closing

R243.title: Missing Personal Property Schedule
R243.description: This appears to be a placeholder for a schedule that should list the personal property included in the sale, but contains only bracketed text indicating it needs to be completed. If this schedule is not properly filled out before closing, Buyer will have no clear record of what personal property was conveyed, making enforcement of the warranty in p_267 extremely difficult and potentially allowing Seller to remove valuable FF&E.

amplified_by.effect: If personal property schedule is not a required Seller delivery, there is no mechanism to ensure it is provided

R244.title: Blank Assignment Form Fields
R244.description: The Assignment and Assumption of Leases contains blank fields for date, party names, and entity types that must be completed before execution. While this is standard for a form document, Buyer should ensure all blanks are properly completed consistent with the PSA before execution at Closing.

mitigated_by.effect: Section 11C requires proper execution of assignment documents as a Seller delivery

R245.title: Lease Schedule Must Be Complete and Accurate
R245.description: The assignment covers only leases 'described in Schedule I attached hereto.' If Schedule I is incomplete or inaccurate, Buyer may not receive assignment of all leases, potentially leaving some tenant relationships unassigned and creating title/ownership issues. Buyer should verify Schedule I matches the rent roll and all leases disclosed during due diligence.

mitigated_by.effect: Seller's representation regarding the rent roll provides some protection if leases are omitted

amplified_by.effect: The knowledge qualifier on Seller's representations may limit Buyer's recourse for undisclosed leases

R246.title: PSA Terms Incorporated by Reference
R246.description: The assignment incorporates the PSA terms by reference, which is appropriate for ensuring consistency. However, Buyer should be aware that any limitations, caps, or disclaimers in the PSA will also apply to claims arising under this assignment unless specifically stated otherwise.

amplified_by.effect: The limited survival period in the PSA may apply to claims under this assignment

R247.title: Vague Assignment Terms Reference
R247.description: The clause references assignment 'on the terms and conditions set forth below' without specifying those terms within this paragraph. While the subsequent paragraphs do contain terms, this introductory language creates potential ambiguity about what exactly constitutes the full scope of the assignment terms, and whether any oral or extrinsic terms could be argued to apply.

R248.title: Conveyance Date Determination Ambiguity
R248.description: The assignment is effective 'as of the date on which the Property is conveyed to Assignee pursuant to the Agreement.' If there is any dispute about when conveyance actually occurred (e.g., recording date vs. delivery of deed vs. closing), Buyer/Assignee could face a gap in coverage or unclear allocation of pre/post-closing liabilities. The definition relies on an external event without specifying the precise moment of effectiveness.

R249.title: Favorable Pre-Closing Indemnity From Seller
R249.description: This provision provides Buyer/Assignee with indemnification from Seller/Assignor for all Claims originating prior to the Conveyance Date and arising out of Assignor's obligations under the Leases. This is favorable to Buyer, but Buyer should verify this indemnity survives closing and is not limited by caps, baskets, or survival periods in the main Agreement that could undermine its value.

R250.title: No Express Survival Period for Seller Indemnity
R250.description: The indemnification from Assignor to Assignee for pre-closing Lease obligations does not include an express survival period. Without clear survival language, there may be arguments that this indemnity terminates upon closing or is subject to a short limitations period, leaving Buyer unprotected for latent claims that surface after closing.

R251.title: Unlimited Assumption of Seller's Lease Obligations
R251.description: Buyer/Assignee assumes 'all of Assignor's obligations under the Leases' without limitation. This broad assumption could include: (1) unfunded tenant improvement obligations, (2) free rent obligations, (3) lease buyout provisions, (4) landlord repair/maintenance backlogs, (5) potential lease violations by Seller that Buyer inherits. The assumption is uncapped and unlimited, exposing Buyer to potentially significant unknown liabilities.

R252.title: Buyer Provides Uncapped Indemnity to Seller
R252.description: Buyer/Assignee agrees to indemnify Seller/Assignor against 'any and all Claims' arising from Assignee's obligations under the Leases post-closing. This indemnity has no cap, no basket, and no temporal limitation. Combined with the broad assumption of 'all' obligations, Buyer's exposure is unlimited and could include claims that actually originated from Seller's pre-closing conduct but are characterized as relating to Assignee's obligations.

R253.title: Origination Date Creates Gap Risk
R253.description: The indemnity structure uses 'originating' prior to or 'on or subsequent to' the Conveyance Date as the dividing line. Claims that 'originate' before closing but 'arise' after closing (or vice versa) create allocation disputes. For example, a tenant improvement obligation that originated pre-closing but becomes due post-closing could fall into a grey area. The distinction between 'originating' and 'arising' is not clearly defined.

R254.title: Losing Party Pays Attorney Fees
R254.description: The prevailing party fee-shifting provision creates significant litigation cost exposure for Buyer. If Buyer brings a claim under this Assignment and does not prevail, Buyer must pay Seller's attorneys' fees and costs without limitation. This could chill Buyer's willingness to enforce legitimate claims and creates asymmetric risk if Seller has greater litigation resources.

R255.title: No Definition of Prevailing Party
R255.description: The clause does not define what constitutes a 'prevailing party,' which can be ambiguous in cases where each party wins on some issues or where the plaintiff recovers less than a settlement offer. Without a clear definition, there could be additional litigation over who actually prevailed.

R256.title: Unrestricted Assignability of Lease Assignment
R256.description: This provision allows the Assignment of Leases to be binding on 'successors and assigns' without any restriction on Seller/Assignor's ability to assign. While this benefits Buyer by allowing future transferability, it also means Seller could potentially assign its indemnification obligations under p_301 to a less creditworthy entity before closing or during the survival period, potentially leaving Buyer without recourse for pre-closing landlord obligations.

R257.title: Blank Date and Party Information
R257.description: The Assignment of Contracts contains blank fields for the date and party identification. While this is standard for a form document attached as an exhibit, Buyer should ensure these blanks are properly completed at closing to match the actual closing date and correct legal entity names. Incorrect or incomplete party information could affect enforceability of the assignment and related indemnification provisions.

R258.title: Schedule I Dependency Without Verification Right
R258.description: The definition of 'Contracts' is entirely dependent on Schedule I, which is an exhibit prepared by the Seller/Assignor. Buyer has no independent verification mechanism in this assignment document to confirm Schedule I is complete and accurate. If Seller omits contracts from Schedule I, Buyer may unknowingly assume obligations under undisclosed contracts or fail to receive the benefit of favorable contracts.

amplified_by.effect: Buyer will assume all obligations under undisclosed contracts that affect the Property

R259.title: Blanket Incorporation of PSA Terms
R259.description: The broad incorporation of PSA terms by reference ('The terms of the Agreement with respect to this Assignment are incorporated herein by reference') creates potential ambiguity about which specific PSA provisions govern this Assignment. In a dispute, Seller could argue that unfavorable PSA provisions (such as liability caps, survival limitations, or dispute resolution procedures) override more favorable provisions that might otherwise apply to this Assignment.

R260.title: Seller Retains Pre-Closing Claims Against Contracts
R260.description: The carve-out 'excluding claims by Assignor, if any, arising out of matters occurring before the Conveyance Date' allows Seller to retain valuable claims (such as breach of contract claims against service providers, warranties from contractors, or rights to refunds/credits) that relate to the Property. This could leave Buyer without recourse against vendors for pre-closing defects or without the benefit of favorable contract terms.

amplified_by.effect: AS-IS clause may limit Buyer's ability to seek recourse for pre-closing defects discovered post-closing

R261.title: Undefined 'Intangible Property' Scope
R261.description: The phrase 'any intangible property now owned by Assignor in connection with the Property' is vague and lacks a clear definition. This could lead to disputes about whether specific items (trade names, permits, licenses, warranties, intellectual property, domain names, telephone numbers) are included in the assignment. The lack of specificity may result in Buyer not receiving items it expected or Seller retaining valuable intangibles.

mitigated_by.effect: PSA Section 1E provides some definition of Intangible Property that may govern

R262.title: Indemnity Limited to Pre-Closing Matters Only
R262.description: The indemnity only covers claims 'originating prior to the Conveyance Date.' This creates a dangerous gap for claims that straddle the closing date or are discovered post-closing but relate to pre-closing conduct. For example, if a service provider was performing defective work before closing but the claim doesn't 'originate' until post-closing discovery, Buyer may have no indemnification coverage. The word 'originating' is also ambiguous—it's unclear whether this means when the underlying conduct occurred, when the claim accrues, or when a third party first asserts it.

amplified_by.effect: Buyer assumes all post-closing obligations, creating exposure if pre-closing defaults trigger post-closing consequences

R263.title: No Survival Period for Contract Assignment Indemnity
R263.description: Unlike Section 7C of the PSA which specifies a 270-day survival period for representations and warranties, this Assignment document contains no explicit survival period for the indemnification obligation. Without a specified survival term, the indemnity could be subject to general statute of limitations arguments or could be deemed to merge into the closing, leaving Buyer without recourse for later-discovered claims.

mitigated_by.effect: PSA survival clause may be incorporated by reference via p_341, but this is ambiguous

R264.title: No Liability Cap on Contract Assignment Indemnity
R264.description: This indemnity contains no cap or basket limitation on Seller's exposure. While this is favorable to Buyer, it creates a potential inconsistency with liability limitations that may exist elsewhere in the PSA. If the PSA contains liability caps that apply 'notwithstanding anything to the contrary,' Seller may argue those caps apply to this Assignment indemnity, creating uncertainty about Buyer's actual recovery rights.

R265.title: Buyer 'Desires' Rather Than Unconditionally Accepts
R265.description: The recital uses precatory language ('Assignee desires to accept the assignment thereof') rather than operative acceptance language. While recitals are generally not operative provisions, this weak language could be used by Seller to argue that Buyer's acceptance is somehow conditional or that Buyer has not fully accepted all assigned items.

mitigated_by.effect: The operative assumption clause provides clearer acceptance language

R266.title: Uncapped assumption of all contract obligations
R266.description: As Buyer/Assignee, this provision requires assumption of 'all' obligations under the Contracts without limitation or qualification. The scope is unlimited and could include unknown liabilities, disputes, or breaches by Seller that occurred pre-closing but manifest post-closing. There is no carve-out for pre-existing breaches, no cap on exposure, and no limitation to obligations that were disclosed or discoverable during due diligence.

R267.title: Unlimited buyer indemnity for contract claims
R267.description: The indemnity obligation has no cap, basket, or time limitation. Buyer must indemnify Seller for 'any and all Claims' arising from assumed contract obligations, which could result in unlimited exposure. This is particularly concerning because it is not mutual—Seller's indemnity in p_349 covers pre-closing claims, but there is no cap on either party's indemnity and no survival period limiting when claims can be brought.

R268.title: Attorneys' fees shifting creates litigation risk
R268.description: The prevailing party fee-shifting provision applies to disputes under this Assignment. While facially mutual, this creates risk for Buyer if any dispute arises over contract interpretation, particularly given the broad assumption of obligations in p_351. If Seller brings a claim under the Assignment and prevails, Buyer bears not only the underlying liability but also Seller's attorneys' fees, which could substantially increase exposure.

R269.title: Binding on successors expands indemnity exposure
R269.description: This provision makes the Assignment binding on successors and assigns, which means Buyer's indemnity obligations under p_351 could follow any sale of the Property. If Buyer sells the Property, Buyer may remain liable under the indemnity even after disposition unless the successor expressly assumes these obligations and Seller releases Buyer.

R270.title: Execution date not specified in form
R270.description: The Assignment references 'the day and year first written above' but this is a form document attached as an exhibit. Ensure that the execution date is properly filled in at closing and corresponds to the Conveyance Date to avoid any gap in coverage or ambiguity about when obligations transfer.

R271.title: No Duty to Investigate Rent Roll
R271.description: The Seller's representation regarding the Rent Roll is qualified by 'to its actual knowledge, without investigating.' This 'without investigating' language explicitly relieves Seller of any duty to verify the accuracy of the Rent Roll information before making the representation. This means Seller could provide materially inaccurate rent roll information and claim they had no duty to check it, leaving Buyer without recourse for reliance on incorrect information that could significantly impact property valuation and investment returns.

R272.title: Rent Roll Date Not Tied to Closing
R272.description: The Rent Roll representation is made 'as of' a blank date that appears to be filled in at signing, not at Closing. This creates a gap where the Rent Roll could become materially inaccurate between the date of the representation and the actual Closing Date, yet Seller would have no obligation to update or re-certify the information. Tenant defaults, lease terminations, or rent modifications occurring after the representation date but before Closing would not be covered.

R273.title: Materiality Qualifier on Rent Roll Accuracy
R273.description: The representation that the Rent Roll is accurate 'in all material respects' introduces subjectivity and allows for potentially significant inaccuracies that may not rise to the level of 'material.' There is no definition of what constitutes a material inaccuracy in the Rent Roll context. This could excuse errors in rent amounts, lease expiration dates, security deposit balances, or tenant concessions that individually might not be deemed 'material' but collectively could significantly impact the property's value or cash flow.

R274.title: Reliance Statement May Limit Third-Party Claims
R274.description: The representation explicitly states it is made 'for your benefit and protection' with the understanding that 'you intend to rely upon this statement in connection with your intended purchase.' While this establishes reliance for the Buyer, it may inadvertently limit who can rely on the representation—potentially excluding Buyer's lenders, assignees, or successors who may also need to rely on the Rent Roll accuracy for financing or subsequent transactions.

R275.title: No Survival Period Specified for Rent Roll Rep
R275.description: This Rent Roll representation appears in a separate exhibit/certificate form and does not specify its own survival period. While the main Agreement may have a survival provision in Section 7.3, it is unclear whether this separate certification is covered by that survival period or whether it survives Closing at all. If the representation terminates at Closing, Buyer would have no post-Closing recourse for discovering Rent Roll inaccuracies.

R276.title: Heading Only - No Substantive Terms
R276.description: This paragraph contains only a heading 'Assignment and Assumption of Contracts and Intangible Property' without any substantive terms. This appears to be either a section header or an incomplete exhibit. The actual assignment form appears earlier in the document (see p_335-p_359). Buyer should confirm this is not a duplicate or missing exhibit and that all necessary assignment documentation is complete.
